The region's advantages include a growing middle class, educated workforce, and expanding consumer base, as well as reasonable asset valuations. 85% of respondents believe South-east Asia will wield more economic influence in the Asia-Pacific in five years. The region is also benefiting from supply chain disruption in the US-China trade war.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Chasing Cars: Best Cars of 2019 Pt 1
summary: The Money FM podcast "Chasing Cars" discussed the best cars of 2019 in its first part. Hosts Julian Kho and Claressa Monteiro reviewed various models, including the MG ZS Hybrid+, BMW's next big thing, and the 2025 Kia Carnival and Sorento. However, no clear winners were identified, and the conversation highlighted the challenges of transitioning to electric vehicles. The discussion covered multiple car models and themes, setting the stage for the next part of the series.

site_title: Fraser & Neave doubles Q2 profit to S$35.9m
summary: Fraser & Neave (F&N) reported a 100% increase in Q2 profit to S$35.9 million, driven by stronger sales from its dairy businesses, including Vinamilk. Revenue rose 3.4% to S$467.4 million, with dairies revenue increasing 5% and beverages revenue gaining 6.1%. However, printing and publishing revenue declined 8.6% due to lower printing volumes. The company's associated company Vinamilk contributed significantly to the increase in earnings.

site_title: CSE Global announces constitution of investment committee; changes to existing board committees
summary: CSE Global, a systems integrator, has established an investment committee to assist its board in reviewing and evaluating major investments and strategic initiatives, effective May 1. The committee will consist of Lim Ming Seong as chairman and Lim Boon Kheng and Syed Nazim Bin Syed Faisal as members. This brings the total number of board committees to four, including audit and risk, nominating, and compensation committees. The change aims to enhance the company's strategic decision-making capabilities.

site_title: EU court advisor sides with Airbnb in row in France
summary: The EU's top court advisor sided with Airbnb in a row with France, finding that the country's attempt to restrict the home-sharing service violates EU law. The advisor, Maciej Szpunar, ruled that France failed to notify the EU Commission and did not follow procedures, making the measure against Airbnb unenforceable. This decision is not binding, but Airbnb's services are likely to remain unaffected, at least for now.

images.alt_text: The legal advisor to the EU's top court sided with Airbnb on Tuesday as the home-sharing giant faces legal action in France aimed at restricting its services.

site_title: Singapore shares recede 0.2% on Tuesday as China data disappoints
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index declined 0.2% on Tuesday, following disappointing Chinese manufacturing PMI readings, which raised concerns about the world's second-largest economy's recovery. The index closed at 3,400.20, down 6.82 points. Banking stocks, including DBS, OCBC, and UOB, fell due to weaker-than-expected earnings, while ThaiBev and Oxley Holdings rose. The decline was attributed to the fragile economic recovery in China, despite Beijing's efforts to spur growth.

site_title: EU court rules in favour of bloc's trade deal with Canada
summary: The European Court of Justice has ruled in favor of the EU's trade deal with Canada, stating that the provisions to protect investors do not breach EU law. The Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (Ceta) with Canada, which entered force in 2017, was criticized for favoring multinationals. The court's decision brings relief to proponents of the deal, including Belgian businesses, which have seen success in the first year of Ceta. Full implementation of the agreement requires approval by all 28 EU member countries and Belgium's regional parliaments.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Oxley Holdings signed a deal to sell Chevron House for up to S$1.025 billion, 16 months after acquiring it for S$660 million. Temasek Holdings plans to increase its US holdings, while Singapore banks saw a 0.6% increase in lending in March. CDL acquired a 50% stake in trust manager IREIT Global Group for S$18.36 million. The Straits Times Index fell 0.2% on Tuesday due to disappointing China data.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks fall on disappointing China manufacturing data
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index fell 12.84 points, or 0.58%, to 2,203.59 points, amid disappointing China April factory growth. Foreigners were net buyers of 42.5 billion won worth of shares. The won weakened to 1,168.2 per dollar, while the benchmark bond yield fell. Despite this, the Kospi rose 2.94% for the month.

site_title: Australia shares fall on weak China factory data; NZ flat
summary: Australian shares fell 0.5% on Tuesday, ending at a one-week low, after disappointing factory data from China highlighted weakness in the world's second-largest economy. The S&P/ASX 200 index dropped 34 points to 6,325.50. Mining stocks, including BHP Group and Rio Tinto, fell 1.1% and 2.4%, respectively, due to the China data. Gold stocks also declined, with Newcrest Mining losing 2.4% after reporting a fall in quarterly gold production.

site_title: Hong Kong's March home prices rise at fastest pace since September 2016
summary: Hong Kong's private home prices rose 2.9% in March, the fastest pace since September 2016, driven by strong demand and improved sentiment. The third consecutive rise follows a rebound since the beginning of the year, after prices fell due to US-China trade tensions and higher interest rates. The market is expected to see another uptrend in the short term, with developers selling new launches at higher prices. The city's housing market has seen a 200% increase over the past decade, making it the least affordable market for the eighth year.

site_title: Singapore manufacturers, services firms less upbeat about next 6 months
summary: Singapore manufacturers and services firms have become less optimistic about business prospects in the next six months, with a slight overall positive sentiment. Manufacturing firms expect business conditions to stay similar, with a net weighted balance of 1% anticipating an improved situation, down from 13% last year. The services sector also expects business activity to remain the same, with a net weighted balance of 4% optimistic, down from 8% last year. Overall, both sectors are less upbeat than in previous surveys, with the manufacturing sector expecting a worsening of sentiment.

site_title: StanChart plans US$1b buyback, first in more than 20 years
summary: Standard Chartered Plc plans to buy back up to US$1 billion of shares, its first in over 20 years, as CEO Bill Winters closes in on a long-term profitability target. The move comes weeks after the bank reached a settlement with US authorities over sanctions breaches. The bank's shares rallied 7.2% in afternoon trading, and its first-quarter return on tangible equity was 9.6%. Standard Chartered aims to deliver a 10% return by 2021 and double its dividend per share by the same year.

site_title: Australian police detain man, neutralise explosive materials
summary: Australian police detained a 43-year-old man in a suburban Adelaide home after discovering explosive materials. The Bomb Response Unit was deployed to neutralize the materials, and the man appeared in court facing charges of possession of explosives. Authorities stated there is no danger or threat to the public, and investigations are ongoing.

site_title: Samsung denies new Galaxy phone burnt from malfunctioning
summary: Samsung denies a Galaxy S10 5G phone was burnt due to a malfunction, attributing the damage to an "external impact". A South Korean user claimed the phone caught fire without reason, but Samsung says it was dropped on a hot surface. The incident comes after Samsung posted a 56.9% drop in net profits amid a weakening chip market and rising competition. Samsung's Galaxy S10 5G model was released with built-in 5G communications, and the company has touted its new phones as a key technology for South Korea's economic growth.

site_title: A US$4.4b accounting error burns investors in China
summary: China's largest listed drugmaker, Kangmei Pharmaceutical Co, disclosed a US$4.4 billion accounting error, overstating cash holdings, and its shares and bonds plummeted. The error, discovered four months after regulators investigated suspected violations, raises concerns about China's disclosure practices. If classified as a major legal violation, Kangmei may face forced delisting. The incident highlights the issue of companies defaulting on debt and questionable accounting in China, prompting global investors to question borrowers.

site_title: Cheese fans raise a stink over plans for pasteurised camembert
summary: France is set to update its rules governing the production of camembert cheese, allowing pasteurized milk for the first time. The move aims to boost dairy farming in Normandy and end decades of declining production. However, traditional cheese makers and purists oppose the change, fearing it will lead to a loss of quality and authenticity. The proposal, which could benefit the entire dairy industry, is set to be voted on in November, but EU regulators may still need to approve it.

images.alt_text: A road sign reading "Camembert" at the entrance of the French northwestern village of Camembert in Normandy, where the camembert cheese is originated.

site_title: Trump sues Deutsche Bank and Capital One to block House subpoenas
summary: US President Donald Trump has filed a federal lawsuit against Deutsche Bank and Capital One Financial Corp to block subpoenas from House committees investigating his financial dealings. The lawsuit claims the subpoenas have "no legitimate or lawful purpose" and were issued to harass Trump. Trump's children and one of his companies are also named in the suit. The House committees, led by Democrats, had issued subpoenas for records related to Trump's finances and potential dealings with Russia. Trump has stated he intends to defy any efforts to dig into his affairs.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump, three of his children and one of his companies filed a federal lawsuit on Monday against Deutsche Bank and Capital One Financial Corp to block the banks from complying with federal subpoenas investigating his financial dealings.

site_title: Airbus keeps outlook as Q1 core earnings rise
summary: Airbus maintained its annual outlook despite a 24% increase in Q1 revenues to 12.55 billion euros, driven by a 549 million euro jump in adjusted EBIT. This surpasses Reuters' forecast of 12.99 billion euros and 520 million euros. In contrast, Boeing abandoned its 2019 financial outlook and lowered production due to the 737 Max grounding, which has cost it at least US$1 billion. Airbus' core earnings rise is seen as a positive sign for the company's annual results.

site_title: Singapore bank lending up 0.6% in March: MAS preliminary data
summary: Singapore bank lending increased 0.6% in March, driven by a 2.2% year-on-year rise, despite a contraction in consumer loans. Total lending stood at S$676 billion, up from S$672 billion the previous month. This follows weaker year-on-year gains in February, at 3.3%.

site_title: Courts Asia to delist on May 3 after Nojima takeover
summary: Courts Asia, a Singapore-based retailer, will delist from the Singapore Exchange on May 3 after losing its free float status following a compulsory acquisition by Nojima Asia Pacific. Nojima acquired the remaining shares at S$0.205 per share. The delisting is part of a strategic review to realise synergies and growth potential, with Nojima exercising its right of compulsory acquisition on April 23. The delisting is expected to take effect at 9am on May 3, with SGX approval received.

site_title: China manufacturing gauge slips in April as recovery moderates
summary: China's manufacturing gauge fell to 50.1 in April, down from 50.5 in March, indicating a moderation in economic recovery. The non-manufacturing PMI stood at 54.3, down from 54.8. The data suggests the strong March activity may not continue, but still shows some traction. Economists are mixed in their reactions, with some expressing concern about weak domestic demand and falling imports, while others see the data as a positive sign that the economy is stabilizing.

site_title: Virgin Australia delays Boeing 737 Max order
summary: Virgin Australia has delayed the delivery of its 48 Boeing 737 Max aircraft from November 2019 to July 2021 due to safety concerns following two deadly crashes. The airline prioritizes safety and will not introduce new aircraft unless it's completely satisfied with its safety. Virgin is shifting some orders to Max 10s while working with Boeing to address the crisis. The Boeing 737 Max has been grounded worldwide since mid-March, and the Federal Aviation Administration is set to conduct a test flight of a software fix for the anti-stall system soon.

site_title: Asia: Tech firms big losers as most markets sink
summary: Asian tech firms, including Google's Alphabet and Samsung Electronics, suffered significant losses after disappointing earnings reports. The tech sector was among the worst-hit, with shares plummeting over 7% and 1% respectively. The losses were compounded by a weak US inflation print and a below-forecast Chinese factory activity reading, which added to the downbeat mood in regional markets. The release of Apple's results later in the day will be closely watched, with some analysts predicting a weak reading could spark further selling.

site_title: Smart Entertainment's S$5.9m partial offer for Sevak fails to get shareholders' nod, closing date extended
summary: Smart Entertainment's S$5.9 million partial offer for Sevak's shares has failed to gain shareholder approval, with only 40.95% of valid votes in favor. The closing date for the offer has been extended to May 23. If successful, Smart Entertainment would increase its stake in Sevak from 38.49% to 51%. The offer was made for 1.48 million shares at S$4 apiece, representing a 25% premium to Sevak's closing price on March 20.

site_title: Hard-right Aussie politician resigns over strip club lechery
summary: Australian politician Steve Dickson, a close ally of hard-right leader Pauline Hanson, resigned from politics after being filmed groping and abusing exotic dancers in the US. The footage, shot by Al Jazeera, shows Dickson making lewd comments and physically abusing dancers. Hanson accepted his resignation, describing the comments as "unacceptable" and saying they didn't meet her expectations. Dickson had previously solicited millions of dollars from the National Rifle Association gun lobby in exchange for changing Australia's tight weapons laws. His resignation comes just weeks before the May election.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Tuesday, down 2.09 points to 1,635.31 at 9am. The market saw a trading volume of 29.22 million lots worth RM8.46 million, with gainers beating losers 88 to 69.

site_title: Do 'mechanical trees' offer the cure for climate change?
summary: A Dublin-based company, Silicon Kingdom Holdings (SKH), plans to erect 1,200 "mechanical trees" in the US to capture carbon dioxide (CO2) from the air, potentially reducing emissions by 8,000 cars' worth per year. The pilot project, set to start within a year, aims to capture 36,500 metric tons of CO2 annually, equivalent to nearly 7,750 vehicles driven for a year. The technology, dubbed "mechanical trees," is cheaper than other methods, with costs estimated at under $100 per metric ton.

site_title: Historical threads: Morocco's last brocade master
summary: Abdelkader Ouazzani, Morocco's last brocade master weaver, has been working for 63 years in his dilapidated workshop in Fes, creating intricate silk fabrics with gold or silver thread. His profession is vanishing as he struggles to find a young apprentice. Ouazzani's work requires calculation and ancestral know-how, taking an entire day to weave just one meter of brocade. With his rare fabrics costing up to 5,000 dirhams per meter, he caters to a clientele of "the elite of the elite." The future of this refined craft is now threatened, with industrial-scale competition and globalization contributing to its decline.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall as China data weighs on miners, energy firms; New Zealand up
summary: Australian shares fell 0.7% to 6,316.90, weighed down by miners and energy stocks amid China's slower-than-expected factory activity growth. The Aussie metals and mining index hit its lowest level since February 15, with copper prices and gold miner Newcrest Mining contributing to the decline. Energy stocks extended their losing streak, while New Zealand's benchmark rose 0.2% to 10,031.3. The decline follows upbeat March data and is partly attributed to investor concerns over a possible Labor government in Australia.

site_title: Manulife US Reit raises US$94m in oversubscribed issue of new units at US$0.824 apiece
summary: Manulife US Reit raised US$94 million from an oversubscribed issue of 114.1 million new units at US$0.824 apiece. The Reit plans to use the funds to pay for part of its US$122 million acquisition of two US office towers. The new units will increase the Reit's free float market capitalization to US$1.1 billion, aiming to reach a US$1.2 billion market cap for inclusion in global property indices.

site_title: Marriott to launch luxury home-sharing platform
summary: Marriott International announced the launch of its luxury home-sharing platform, Homes & Villas, offering around 2,000 high-end homes in select US, European, Caribbean, and Latin American locations. The platform is set to debut next week, reflecting the company's commitment to innovation as consumer travel needs evolve. The move joins the existing home-sharing giant Airbnb, further expanding Marriott's offerings in the hospitality industry.

site_title: US lags, China expands in race for electric vehicle dominance
summary: The US lags behind China in the production and sale of electric vehicles, with China controlling about two-thirds of the global lithium cell production capacity. The US struggles to secure a secure supply of raw materials, particularly lithium, with most needed for battery production sourced from other countries. A meeting in Washington aims to streamline the US permit process for new lithium projects and stockpile purchases, but experts warn that it will take time to build out a rechargeable battery industry in the US, and demand is expected to boom to 1 million tons by 2025.

site_title: Temasek gears up for more US deals
summary: Temasek Holdings, a Singaporean state investor, is planning to increase its US holdings to over 20% from 15% currently. The firm's head of Americas, John Vaske, says the US offers opportunities for investments driven by technology and disruptive change. Despite increased scrutiny of foreign investments in the US, Vaske believes Singapore and Temasek will be welcomed constructively. The move follows Temasek's existing US holdings in companies like Dell Technologies and Gilead Sciences, and comes as the US stock market reaches record highs, albeit in a late-cycle economic expansion.

site_title: China Everbright Water prices Hong Kong public offer at HK$2.99 apiece
summary: China Everbright Water priced its Hong Kong public offering at HK$2.99 apiece, excluding fees, for a total of around HK$311 million (S$54 million) and approximately 104 million shares. The offer is part of the company's dual listing, with 90% of shares going to international investors and 10% to Hong Kong investors. The listing is expected to take place on May 8, 2019, following agreements with joint representatives and underwriters.

site_title: CapitaLand sets up S$5b euro medium term note programme
summary: CapitaLand has established a S$5 billion euro medium term note programme, allowing the subsidiary CapitaLand Treasury to issue euro medium term notes and perpetual notes as needed. The notes may be issued in various currencies and amounts, with interest rates determined by the parties involved. The net proceeds from note issuances will primarily be used to refinance existing borrowings, finance investments, and cover general corporate purposes. DBS, HSBC Singapore, Morgan Stanley Asia, OCBC, and UOB have been appointed as arrangers and dealers of the programme.

site_title: Oil climbs, shaking off Trump calls for Opec to offset Iran sanctions
summary: Oil prices rose on Monday, rebounding from a 3% decline on Friday, as investors weighed market outlook and US sanctions against Iran. US President Donald Trump had demanded that Opec raise output to offset the impact of sanctions, but the cartel did not respond. Brent crude futures rose 0.2% to $72.04, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures climbed 0.3% to $63.50. The rally follows a week of volatility, with oil prices initially declining on Friday before rebounding on Monday.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Tuesday's open; STI up 0.15% to 3,412.23
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.15% to 3,412.23 at Tuesday's open, following a positive US market day. The Straits Times Index gained as US stocks edged up to fresh closing records amid major earnings reports and trade talks. Among the most traded stocks, Singtel and Genting Singapore increased, while City Developments Limited and DBS moved in opposite directions.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel, Ascendas Reit, Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust, Ascott Reit, CDLHT
summary: Key developments in Singapore's stock market include: Keppel Corporation issuing new bonds, Ascendas Reit and Ascott Residence Trust increasing distribution per unit, Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust rising in DPU, and CDL Hospitality Trusts declining in total distribution per stapled security. Citic Envirotech's net profit plummeted 92.2% due to delays in major projects, while China Sunsine Chemical Holdings fell 26% in net profit due to decreased revenue and raw material prices.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open with losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell slightly on Tuesday, following a 1% gain the previous day and disappointing Chinese factory data. The Hang Seng Index dropped 0.22%, the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.32%, and the Shenzhen Composite Index lost 0.49%. These losses come as investors focus on US-EU trade tensions and global economic concerns.

site_title: Broker's take: OCBC lowers DBS to 'hold' after post-earnings rally
summary: OCBC Investment Research downgraded its call on DBS Group Holdings to "hold" with a fair value of $29.18 after the bank's 3.6% gain on Monday following better-than-expected first quarter earnings. DBS shares are now trading close to the research house's fair value. The bank's shares have appreciated 11.6% from March 26 to April 29, beating the FTSE ST Financial Index's 7% gain. DBS will pay dividends on a quarterly basis starting May 2.

images.alt_text: OCBC Investment Research has downgraded its call on DBS Group Holdings to "hold" with a fair value of $29.18 after the bank's shares gained 3.6 per cent on Monday following better-than-expected first quarter earnings.

site_title: Chinese developers push land prices up as credit, purchase rules ease
summary: Chinese land prices surged in the first quarter of 2019, with premiums reaching 19.1% on average, up from 9.4% in 2018. This rebound is attributed to eased credit conditions and purchase requirements, prompting caution from some developers. Second-tier cities, such as Hefei and Chongqing, saw the largest gains, with premiums reaching 86% and 25%, respectively. Despite the surge, some developers remain cautious, citing high asking prices and thin profit margins.

site_title: New Zealand business confidence little changed in April: ANZ survey
summary: New Zealand business confidence remained little changed in April, according to an ANZ Bank survey. The headline measure showed a net 37.5% of respondents expecting the economy to deteriorate over the year ahead, similar to the previous poll. However, 7.1% of respondents expected their businesses to grow in the next 12 months, up from 6.3% last month. This suggests a slight improvement in business sentiment.

site_title: China's big banks post modest Q1 profit growth
summary: China's five largest state-owned banks, led by ICBC, posted a 4% increase in Q1 profits, slightly below expectations. The modest growth comes after disappointing 2018 results, with lenders increasing provisions for bad loans. Policymakers' push to make more loans supports the slowing economy. The Big Five banks' net profits were the strongest in over two years, but still below expectations. The growth is a sign that China's lenders are slowly recovering from the economic slowdown.

images.alt_text: Net profits at the country's so-called Big Five banks, led by Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC), grew by more than 4 per cent in the January-March quarter from a year earlier.

site_title: Keppel Corp to raise S$500m via two note issues
summary: Keppel Corp plans to raise S$500 million through two note issues, priced at S$150 million 3% notes due 2024 and S$350 million 3.66% notes due 2029. The notes will be listed on the Singapore Exchange on or about May 7, 2019, and used for general corporate or working capital purposes. The company has increased its US$5 billion multi-currency medium-term note programme to US$5 billion.

site_title: EU fine on Google weighs on parent Alphabet profits
summary: Google parent Alphabet reported a 29% decline in first-quarter profits to $6.7 billion, due in part to a $1.7 billion EU antitrust fine. Revenue grew 17% to $36.3 billion, but missed forecasts. Despite excluding the fine, profits were better than expected. Alphabet's "other bets" division, including Waymo and Verily, showed widening losses. The company remains focused on growth opportunities in mobile search, ad revenue, and cloud computing, but faces pressure from regulators over its dominance in internet search and advertising.

site_title: Japan's new imperial couple face heavy burden of tradition
summary: Japan's new imperial couple, Crown Prince Naruhito and his wife Masako, face a heavy burden of balancing tradition and modern values. Naruhito, 59, has criticized the palace's rigid rules and sought to modernize royal duties, while Masako has struggled to adapt to imperial life, particularly the pressure to bear a son. The couple has also followed their father's lead in warning against downplaying Japan's role in World War II. As they prepare to take on new roles, they will need to navigate the challenges of modernizing the monarchy while respecting tradition, with Masako's health and the couple's ability to perform duties limited by her health.

images.alt_text: Japan's incoming emperor Crown Prince Naruhito faces the delicate task of balancing tradition within the world's oldest monarchy and his own modern values, including protecting his family from the palace's rigid rules.

site_title: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding Q1 earnings up 38% to 824.1m yuan
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding reported a 38% increase in Q1 net profit to 824.1 million yuan, driven by higher vessel deliveries and trading activities. Revenue rose 27% to 6.29 billion yuan, with core shipbuilding revenue and trading business growing 17% and 32% respectively. The company secured US$116 million in contract value for three vessels and has a US$3.5 billion order book for 101 vessels, maintaining a healthy utilisation rate until 2021. However, the company cited a decline in global new shipbuilding orders due to uncertain economic and trade growth.

site_title: CDL pays S$77.7m for 12.4% of IREIT Global and 50% of trust's manager
summary: CDL has paid S$77.7 million to acquire a 12.4% stake in IREIT Global, a European property trust, and 50% of its manager IREIT Global Group (IGG). CDL bought the stake from Tikehau Capital and IGG's minority shareholder, Shanghai Summit. The deal increases Tikehau's stake in IREIT Global to 16.4%. Frank Khoo, CDL's group chief investment officer, has been appointed as IGG's non-executive director, citing the investment as part of CDL's aim to achieve assets under management of US$5 billion by 2023.

site_title: Jungle hits US$175m first close for third fund on strong institutional demand
summary: Jungle Ventures has raised US$175 million for its third fund, exceeding its original target of US$200 million, with 90% of the capital coming from institutional investors in North America, Europe, and Asia. The fund, launched in December, is expected to be oversubscribed at US$220 million and will focus on consumer and software sectors in South-east Asia. Notable limited partners include Temasek Holdings and the International Financial Corp. Jungle has already made five investments and plans to invest in 10-15 companies a year in Series A and Series B stages.

site_title: Oxley inks deal to sell Chevron House for S$1.03b
summary: Oxley Holdings has signed a deal to sell Chevron House in Raffles Place for up to S$1.025 billion, a 55% increase from its original purchase price of S$660 million in 2017. The sale is expected to have a positive impact on Oxley's net tangible assets per share and earnings per share for the current financial year. The deal, which is subject to certain conditions, will see Golden Compass (BVI) acquire Oxley Beryl, the owner of Chevron House, and take over its existing bank loans.

site_title: US March consumer spending picks up
summary: US consumer spending rose 0.9% in March, exceeding estimates, while the Federal Reserve's preferred inflation gauge eased to a one-year low. Personal income rose 0.1% and core prices were little changed from the previous month. The data supports the Fed's patient stance on interest rates despite a strong economy, with the central bank expected to hold rates steady on Wednesday.

site_title: CDL Hospitality Trusts posts 3.7% lower Q1 DPS at 2.09 Singapore cents
summary: CDL Hospitality Trusts reported a 3.7% decline in quarterly distribution per stapled security (DPS) to 2.09 Singapore cents for the first quarter. Revenue and net property income (NPI) also fell 10.6% and 10.7% respectively, primarily due to downtime at two of its properties. Interest expense rose by S$1.3 million, mainly due to additional loans for the acquisition of Hotel Cerretani Florence in Italy. The counter closed up one Singapore cent to S$1.60 on Monday.

site_title: US: Stocks edge to records ahead of Federal Reserve meeting, big earnings
summary: US stocks reached records for a second straight session ahead of a Federal Reserve meeting and major earnings announcements. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq closed at fresh records despite caution, with investors awaiting the central bank's decision on interest rates. Earnings reports have been solid, with companies such as Apple and General Motors set to report this week. The US-China trade talks are also expected to be a major focus, with top negotiators set to meet in Beijing.

site_title: Samsung Electronics Q1 net profit slumps 56.9%
summary: Samsung Electronics reported a 56.9% decline in Q1 net profits to 5.04 trillion won, the lowest since 2016. The firm attributed the slump to a weakening chip market, falling chip prices, and intensifying competition in the smartphone market from Chinese rivals like Huawei. The company also faced challenges with its foldable smartphone, delaying its US$2,000 release due to screen problems. This decline follows a similar drop in operating profits by SK Hynix, the world's second-largest memory chip maker.

site_title: US deputy attorney general who oversaw Mueller probe resigns
summary: US Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein, who oversaw the Mueller probe, announced his resignation effective May 11, 2019. He chose Special Counsel Robert Mueller in 2017 after President Trump fired FBI Director James Comey, serving as a buffer between Mueller and the White House. In his final report, Mueller found no campaign collusion with Russians but left obstruction conclusions to Congress. Rosenstein cited the Justice Department's progress in reducing crime and enforcing immigration laws during his tenure.

site_title: Japan's emperor to step down in 200-year first
summary: Japan's Emperor Akihito is set to abdicate on Tuesday, marking a historic 200-year first, and handing over to his 59-year-old son, Crown Prince Naruhito, who will become the new emperor. The abdication, dubbed the "Reiwa" era, will usher in a new era for Japan's oldest monarchy, coinciding with a 10-day holiday for the Japanese people. The historic event comes as Japan faces a declining population, stagnant economy, and a changing role on the world stage, with concerns about a potential succession crisis.

site_title: Toyota to assemble Lexus in Canada: Trudeau
summary: Toyota will assemble two Lexus models, the NX and NX hybrid, in a Canadian plant starting in 2022. Located in Cambridge, Ontario, the plant will supply the Canadian and US markets, producing over 500,000 vehicles annually. This move marks Toyota's first production outside of Japan and solidifies its presence in Canada, making it the largest automotive manufacturer in the country. The investment of C$1.4 billion and additional funding from the Ottawa government will support the production of hybrid vehicles, primarily for the North American market.

site_title: US Army veteran arrested for plotting LA mass attack
summary: A US Army veteran, Mark Steven Domingo, 26, has been arrested for plotting a terror attack near Los Angeles in response to mass shootings in New Zealand. Domingo, who had combat experience in Afghanistan, allegedly planned to detonate an improvised explosive device at a white nationalist rally in Long Beach, causing mass casualties. He was arrested after receiving a live bomb, which turned out to be inert, and was charged with providing and attempting to provide material support to terrorists, facing up to 15 years in prison.

site_title: Boeing wins confidence of shareholders, prepares for key 737 Max test flight
summary: Boeing successfully defended its authority at a shareholder meeting, with investors backing a vote of confidence despite concerns over the 737 Max's design and safety. The company expects the FAA to conduct a test flight of the updated software fix by the end of next week, a crucial step in certifying the aircraft as flight-worthy. Despite a proposal to make the chairman an independent director and disclose lobbying activities, the motions fell short of the 50% threshold needed for approval. Boeing's CEO, Dennis Muilenburg, defended the 737 Max's design and said the company remains focused on safety and quality.

images.alt_text: Boeing executives successfully beat back shareholder challenges to their authority on Monday as the company signaled it expects regulators to take a key step next week in the effort to get the 737 Max back in the air following two deadly crashes.

site_title: Americas targeted by Petronas to increase reserves
summary: Malaysia's state-owned oil company, Petronas, is shifting its focus to the Americas to boost reserves and maintain production rates as Southeast Asian wells decline. The company plans to allocate a larger share of its capital expenditure to projects in Canada, Brazil, Mexico, and Argentina, with a focus on offshore fields and shale reserves. Petronas has agreed to buy stakes in several projects, including the C$40 billion LNG Canada project and the Vaca Muerta shale oil fields in Argentina, and plans to invest $2.3 billion in Mexico's Vaca Muerta shale oil fields over four years.

site_title: Fiat Chrysler CEO certain that the company can survive tech disruption
summary: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles CEO Mike Manley is confident the company can survive the disruption in the car industry due to electric and self-driving cars. Manley attributes Fiat Chrysler's advantage to its "house of brands" strategy, citing brands like Jeep, Alfa Romeo, and Maserati. He believes these brands will hold their value, while mass-volume producers may struggle. Manley also sees potential for Fiat's 500 subcompact and the Centoventi electric car prototype to thrive in the future.

site_title: Daimler will pull Smart mini-cars out of United States, Canada
summary: Daimler AG announced the discontinuation of Smart mini-cars in the US and Canada at the end of the current model year. Despite initial popularity, sales declined rapidly, with just 90 cars sold in the US in March, down 18% from the previous year. The decline is attributed to a shift in consumer preference towards larger trucks and SUVs, driven by cheap petrol and a strong economy.

images.alt_text: The tiny, two-person Smart cars once pitched as the next big thing in urban mobility will be discontinued in the United States and Canada at the end of the current model year, German automaker Daimler AG said on Monday.

site_title: Overcoming the SME talent crunch
summary: Singaporean SMEs face a talent crunch due to a global shortage of skilled workers and rising retirement rates. To address this, the government has introduced grants to support upskilling and reskilling of employees. SMEs can overcome the talent crunch by building a strong company culture, hiring smart, and committing to employee growth. This includes offering flexible work hours, training programs, and opportunities for mentorship. By investing in their employees' future, SMEs can tackle the talent crunch and remain competitive in the market.

site_title: Ascott Reit DPU rises 7% to 1.45 Singapore cents for Q1
summary: Ascott Residence Trust (Ascott Reit) reported a 7% rise in its distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.45 Singapore cents for Q1, driven by better operating performance, lower financing costs, and higher one-off realised exchange gain. Net income before changes in fair value rose 4% to S$34.8 million, while distribution to unitholders grew 8% to S$31.5 million. The trust's debt headroom of close to S$900 million provides financial flexibility for accretive acquisitions.

site_title: WeWork, at US$47b valuation, files for public share listing
summary: WeWork, a US$47 billion-valued office-sharing startup, has filed confidential documents with the Securities & Exchange Commission to initiate a stock market listing. The New York-based firm operates in 600 cities worldwide and offers flexible office space to entrepreneurs, Fortune 500 companies, and independent workers. WeWork has received a $2 billion investment from Japanese tech giant SoftBank and is part of a wave of Silicon Valley "unicorns" going public. The company plans to raise funds for further expansion, but details on valuation and timing remain undisclosed.

site_title: Sim Lim Square up for en bloc sale with S$1.25b reserve price
summary: Sim Lim Square, a 99-year leasehold site in Singapore, has been put up for collective sale via public tender at a reserve price of S$1.25 billion. The mall, known for its electronics and IT goods, has 492 commercial units and sits on a 78,152 sq ft site with a remaining lease of 63 years. Interested developers can explore converting the property for other uses under the Strategic Development Incentive scheme, which allows for a change in land use, plot ratio, and/or building height.

site_title: Indofood Agri Resources sinks into red with Q1 net loss of 57.79b rupiah
summary: Indofood Agri Resources reported a Q1 net loss of 57.79 billion rupiah, primarily due to lower results from operations and higher financial expenses. Revenue rose 5.3% to 3.36 trillion rupiah, driven by strong sales from the edible oils and fats division. The company's plantation division revenue was flat, affected by lower commodity prices. A 33% increase in financial expenses was mainly due to higher working capital facilities and blended interest rates. The group expects ongoing economic uncertainties to impact agricultural commodities.

site_title: Fortress Minerals swings to US$4.9m profit for FY2019 on higher ore prices, demand
summary: Fortress Minerals, a Singapore-listed iron ore producer, reported a net profit of US$4.9 million for FY2019, reversing a loss of US$411,393 in the prior year. The company's restructuring exercise led to no dividend declaration for FY2019, but a one-tier first interim dividend of 0.16 Singapore cents per share was declared for FY2020. Revenue rose to US$20.6 million, driven by higher ore prices and demand, particularly in China, following disruptions to major producing countries.

site_title: Keppel Capital's fund buys 3 Grade A commercial buildings
summary: Keppel Capital's Alpha Asia Macro Trends Fund III (AAMTF III) has acquired three Grade A commercial buildings in Seoul's business districts for KRW 430 billion (S$504.7 million). The buildings, Yeouido Finance Tower, Nonhyun Building, and Naeja Building, offer a total of approximately 61,000 sq m of office and retail space. The acquisition is in line with AAMTF III's strategy of creating value and driving returns for investors, with the properties benefiting from favorable fundamentals and strong leasing demand.

site_title: Nets, Myanmar's national payment network to co-develop QR code system
summary: Nets, Myanmar's national payment network, has signed a memorandum of understanding to co-develop a QR code system with the Singapore Quick Response (SGQR) Central Repository platform. The collaboration aims to implement a similar platform in Myanmar, allowing merchants to display a single QR label and enabling quicker payments processing. The project is the first under the new payment technology exchange and development programme established by Nets and the Myanmar Payment Union. The goal is to expand digital payment services in Myanmar, driven by the country's growing mobile and internet penetration.

site_title: Peru bans electric scooters from sidewalks, pedestrian zones
summary: Peru has banned motorized scooters from sidewalks and pedestrian areas in response to a recent collision that left a 63-year-old woman with a head injury and fractures in both arms. The ban aims to reduce accidents and alleviate traffic congestion in the capital city of Lima, which struggles with huge traffic problems. The move comes as scooters have become increasingly popular in Peru over the last year.

site_title: Privacy concerns made Apple pull parental control apps
summary: Apple removed 11 parental control apps from its store due to security and privacy concerns, citing a violation of App Store policies. The move followed a report by The New York Times that Apple was eliminating competition with its own Screen Time feature. Apple claimed the removed apps put users' privacy and security at risk by relying on Mobile Device Management (MDM) technology, which gives a third party control over devices. Apple gave developers 30 days to modify their apps before removal.

site_title: Europe: Shares end higher as Spanish stocks recover poise
summary: European shares closed marginally higher on Monday, driven by gains for Banco Santander and other major lenders following the win of Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez's ruling socialists in Spain's third election in four years. The Stoxx 600 index rose 0.08% as losses for utilities were outweighed by the rally in lender shares. Investors are optimistic about Sanchez's pro-European stance, which is expected to support market reform and policy.

site_title: The trust fund kids' revolution
summary: A growing number of young people from affluent families are questioning the morality of their advantages and the social arrangements that produce them. These "class traitors" reject the "lie of meritocracy" and instead challenge the idea that wealth is solely the result of individual effort. Many have inherited or stand to inherit millions, but instead of hiding their privilege, they openly discuss their feelings of guilt and shame. They study the history of racial capitalism and discuss ways to redistribute wealth, and some have started to give away their inheritance or pursue socially responsible investments. They aim to create a more equitable future where everyone has access to the basics and is fulfilled and joyful.

site_title: DBS Q1 profit up 9% to record S$1.65b
summary: DBS Group Holdings reported a 9% rise in Q1 earnings to a record S$1.65 billion, driven by higher margins, strong trading income, and a S$100 million write-back due to improved credit quality. CEO Piyush Gupta expressed confidence in the bank's business momentum, citing robust growth across Southeast Asia, particularly in Thailand, Malaysia, and Vietnam. DBS's loan book is expected to grow mid-single digit, with a focus on mortgage loans. The bank's net interest income rose 9% to S$2.31 billion, while net fee income declined 2%.

site_title: Raffles Education unit to sell stake in China university operator for 420m yuan
summary: RAFFLES Education Corp is selling its 51% stake in China university operator Langfang Development Zone Oriental University City Sino-Singapore Education Investment Co for 420 million yuan (S$84.6 million) to individual Liu Yanwen. The sale will be made through a subsidiary, Langfang Tonghui Education Consultancy Co, which holds the beneficial interest in the equity interest. The deal marks Raffles Education's exit from the university operator.

site_title: No Signboard shares dive on news of share buyback probe
summary: No Signboard Holdings shares plummeted 9.5% on Monday after the company revealed authorities were investigating a share buyback made during a trading restriction period on January 31. The company is cooperating with the Singapore Police Force's Commercial Affairs Department, providing documents and statements from CEO Lim Yong Sim and CFO Voon Sze Yin. The incident occurred when Lim inadvertently instructed the broker to buy back shares at a price exceeding the regulatory limit, resulting in a 45% drop in shares this year.

site_title: DBS Q1 mortgage book shrinks for first time in years
summary: DBS Group Holdings, Singapore's largest home loan provider, saw its mortgage book shrink for the first time in years in Q1 2019, falling to S$74.4 billion. The contraction was attributed to the government's property cooling measures, which reduced new home loan bookings by half. Despite this, DBS expects the 2019 mortgage book to grow, albeit at a lower rate of S$1 billion-S$1.5 billion, due to completed projects.

site_title: China's biggest banks post higher Q1 profits amid fresh loan push
summary: China's largest banks reported a 4.9% increase in Q1 profits, exceeding the predicted 5.7% average. The banks' net income rose due to higher interest income as authorities encouraged fresh lending to support the economy. Industrial & Commercial Bank of China, Agricultural Bank of China, Bank of Communications, and Bank of China are among those to report the increases. This move is seen as a positive sign for the country's economy, which has been facing challenges.

site_title: FAA considered grounding some Boeing 737 Max planes last year: source
summary: The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) considered grounding some Boeing 737 Max planes last year after discovering a problem with the Maneuvering Characteristics Augmentation System (MCAS), which is suspected in two deadly crashes. Inspectors found that Boeing had deactivated a signal designed to alert cockpit crew members of a malfunctioning MCAS system, which was intended to be an optional extra costing more money. The FAA ultimately decided not to recommend grounding the planes, but instead recommended additional pilot training.

site_title: Jokowi widens lead against rival in official tally of votes mid-way
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo has widened his lead over challenger Prabowo Subianto in the official tally of votes, securing 56.2% of the votes compared to 43.8% for Prabowo. The lead is about 12 percentage points, based on data from 52% of polling stations. The General Elections Commission must still verify the data, but the results support unofficial quick counts that showed Jokowi with a comfortable win. Prabowo's campaign team claims "massive fraud," but authorities say this is unfounded.

site_title: Challenger chief, management defend offer price, dividend payout
summary: Challenger Technologies' CEO and management defended their offer price and dividend payout at the company's annual general meeting, despite pressure from Pangolin Investment Management, which argued the offer price was too low and the dividend payout insufficient. Challenger plans to use its cash for capital expenditure, including store openings and renovations, and CEO Loo Leong Thye emphasized the need for prudence in a difficult retail environment. The company's management rejected suggestions to retain S$20 million for capex and distribute the rest to shareholders, citing various expenses and potential acquisition opportunities.

site_title: Citic Envirotech's Q1 profit dives 92.2%
summary: Citic Envirotech's Q1 profit plummeted 92.2% to S$3.08 million due to delays in major projects in China caused by adverse winter conditions. Engineering revenue fell 94.3% and membrane system sales dropped 84.9%. Recurring treatment revenue rose 11%, but total revenue declined 72.2%. The company remains optimistic about its prospects in China, citing the country's commitment to environmental protection and its own proprietary technology and expertise.

site_title: Asia's oldest and longest-serving directors can be found in the Philippines
summary: The Philippines has the oldest and longest-serving directors in Asia, with an average board tenure of 10.6 years and an average age of 65.4 years, exceeding regional averages. Family-led enterprises dominate the country's banking, property, and retail sectors, with owners and their trusted advisers maintaining tight control. Regulators aim to increase board diversity, but companies prefer to hire industry experts, often in their 60s, who bring wealth of experience. Despite concerns about lack of fresh perspectives and oversight, some companies are starting to recognize the need for change and are exploring ways to bring in younger, digitally savvy directors.

site_title: China's rocket startups go small in age of 'shoebox' satellites
summary: China's rocket startups are developing inexpensive launch vehicles for "shoebox" satellites, driven by growing demand for nanosatellites. Companies like LinkSpace and LandSpace are working on reusable rockets, with LinkSpace aiming to charge $6 million per launch. The industry is expected to explode in the next few years, with China's private rocket manufacturers seeking to capitalize on the trend. Despite challenges, Chinese entrepreneurs are pushing forward, with the country's state defence contractors also entering the low-cost market, and numerous private companies planning to launch satellites this year.

images.alt_text: NewLine Baby has successfully taken off and landed without a tether, hovering 40 m above the ground before descending back to its concrete launch pad after 30 seconds.

site_title: John Soh touted Blumont as the next Rio Tinto, says remisier
summary: John Soh, a remisier, was testifying in the trial of John Soh Chee Wen and Quah Su-Ling, accused of market manipulation. Soh said he had invited former remisier Lee Chee Wee Andy to a presentation about Blumont Group, touting it as the next Rio Tinto with a potential stock price of S$5. Soh claimed Blumont had "bright prospects" and was the "next mining giant." The testimony is part of the ongoing trial.

site_title: Manulife US Reit's US$122m office play
summary: Manulife US Reit is acquiring two office towers in Virginia for US$122 million, funded mostly in equity with a US$33 million loan facility. The acquisition aims to improve the Reit's portfolio occupancy rate to 97.6% and weighted average lease expiry (WALE) from 6 to 6.1 years. The deal is expected to raise pro forma distribution per unit for 2018 by 3.3% and improve trading liquidity. The Reit's gearing will decrease from 37.6% to 36.8%, and new units will be placed to raise US$94 million in gross proceeds.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Starhill Global Reit reported a 0.9% year-over-year increase in distribution per unit to 1.10 Singapore cents, marking the first positive growth since Q2 2016. The REIT's results met analyst expectations.

site_title: Taiwan firms caught in trade war use opportunity to lure companies away from China
summary: Taiwan is attracting Taiwanese companies with operations in China, as the trade war between the US and China affects the island's economy. The government's Invest Taiwan campaign has seen 40 companies commit to investing $6.7 billion and creating 21,200 jobs, with some pledging to return to Taiwan. The campaign aims to address shortages of land, labor, and talent, and has been successful in luring companies back from China, with the largest pledge coming from Delta Electronics Inc. Analysts predict that the trend will continue, driven by rising labor costs and government regulation in China, with some predicting a 10-year repatriation trend.

site_title: Scoot to scrap flights to 4 cities, braces for slower growth
summary: Scoot, Singapore Airlines' low-cost arm, has scrapped flights to four cities due to weak demand and an aircraft shortage. The affected cities are Lucknow, Kalibo, Quanzhou, and Male. No plans have been made to reinstate these routes. Despite the changes, Scoot expects slower projected growth in capacity this financial year. The airline has contacted affected customers and offered rebooking and refund options. Analysts believe the move may lead to price and yield improvements, as well as capacity reallocation to more lucrative routes.

site_title: honestbee may face tough search for buyer
summary: Honestbee, a Singapore-based grocery and food delivery startup, may struggle to find a buyer due to concerns about its cash burn and high-level departures. Potential suitors, including tech unicorns Grab and Gojek, are reportedly hesitant due to honestbee's reported woes, including a cash crunch and layoffs. Experts note that honestbee's cash burn and intense competition in the market may make it difficult to attract buyers, particularly with its pool of freelance shoppers and delivery people.

images.alt_text: Honestbee could struggle to find a buyer amid reports that it is facing a cash crunch and looking for suitors, industry observers said.

site_title: Gulf Air, Etihad in talks to deepen partnership
summary: Gulf Air and Etihad Airways are in talks to deepen their existing codeshare agreement, aiming to expand the airline's network and become the region's boutique airline. The partnership, which began on March 20, may include domains such as maintenance and cargo handling. Gulf Air plans to continue flying Boeing 787 jets and receive 10 more by 2020, as well as 29 Airbus 320 and 321 variants by 2020. The airline's chief commercial officer, Vincent Coste, expressed optimism about the partnership, which could bring strengths to both carriers.

site_title: Asean initiative to prepare workers for future of work
summary: Singapore has proposed a regional initiative to prepare Asean member states for the future of work, addressing the impact of technology, aging populations, and a greening economy on the labor landscape. The initiative, backed by the International Labour Organisation (ILO), aims to build capacity and share best practices among the 10 Asean states through workshops, seminars, and courses. Key areas of focus include tripartism, workplace safety, and embracing technology for inclusive growth, with the goal of creating a human-centered agenda for the future of work.

site_title: OCBC not outsourcing bancassurance; it's core part of business: CEO
summary: OCBC Bank, Singapore's second-largest lender, stated that bancassurance remains a core part of its business and will not be outsourced to another partner. CEO Samuel Tsien emphasized the bank's use of data analytics to anticipate insurance needs, resulting in higher productivity and market penetration compared to competitors. OCBC's bancassurance also integrates with other businesses, such as wealth management and corporate banking. The bank reported an 11% decline in net profit in its fourth quarter of 2018 due to a fall in earnings contribution from Great Eastern.

site_title: Workers' immediate concerns as important as longer-term issues
summary: Singapore's Manpower Minister Josephine Teo emphasized the importance of addressing present-day concerns alongside longer-term moves, including raising retirement and re-employment ages. The government will support workers in accessing good jobs and better wages through initiatives like the Adapt and Grow program, which helped 30,000 workers last year. The ministry also plans to introduce measures to tighten foreign workforce controls and enhance job quality. Teo's May Day message aimed to motivate workers and employers to invest in skills upgrading and job redesign.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Coffee with Claressa: K Shanmugam on record on POFMA
summary: Minister K Shanmugam appeared on the Money FM podcast "Coffee with Claressa" to discuss his stance on the Protection from Online Falsehoods and Manipulation Act (POFMA). The discussion centered on his views on the act, but no specific details or conclusions were mentioned in the article.

site_title: Downturn could pare appetite of corporate venture capitalists
summary: Corporate venture capitalists may face a downturn in appetite for investments if global economic conditions worsen, industry watchers warn. A dual mandate of financial returns and strategic gains can mask underperformance, and companies without clear strategic objectives may struggle to stomach losses. Experts caution that venture capital is high-risk, and investors must prioritize long-term strategic goals over short-term financial gains.

site_title: Ed Sheeran puts on admirable one-man show
summary: English singer-songwriter Ed Sheeran performed to a 51,000-strong crowd at the National Stadium in Singapore, showcasing his skillful use of a loop station to pre-record sections for layering. Despite initially acknowledging the 2% of the audience who attended out of obligation, Sheeran's charm and self-deprecating humor won over the majority. The setlist, which included a surprise cover of Justin Bieber's "Love Yourself," featured a mix of his popular hits and electronic dance elements, with Sheeran entertaining the crowd with his energetic performance.

images.alt_text: On tracks like Eraser and Dive, using a loop station at his feet, it sounded like Sheeran was playing with a full band rather than by himself; while on Photograph and Perfect, he became both Simon as well as Garfunkel as he harmonised with himself.

site_title: Dollar rally stalls, underlining slowdown fears
summary: The dollar's rally stalled on Monday, despite strong US data, as investors remain cautious about a slowdown in activity. The dollar traded in a narrow range, with a Federal Reserve policy meeting, Brexit negotiations, and global data releases set to influence currency swings this week. The euro remains the largest held net short, and the dollar fell back last week due to a slowdown in core inflation. The lack of liquidity has raised concerns about a potential re-run of the dollar's flash crash from January.

site_title: Call for ideas to revamp Marina Bay floating platform into NS Square
summary: The Defence Science and Technology Agency (DSTA) and the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) will launch a call for an Expression of Interest (EOI) for the re-development of the Marina Bay floating platform into a permanent vibrant events and entertainment space called NS Square. The plan aims to transform the temporary structure built in 2007 into a permanent venue. The EOI is expected to be launched in the second quarter of 2019.

site_title: Singapore, China forge closer ties on trade, Belt and Road projects
summary: Singapore and China signed five agreements to strengthen their collaboration on trade, law enforcement, and Belt and Road projects. The agreements were inked after meetings between Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and Chinese Premier Li Keqiang, and include partnerships on financial services, technology, and urban governance. The deals aim to boost trade between the two countries, with Singapore being the largest foreign investment destination for China along the Belt and Road last year, accounting for 23% of total investment outflow.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Olam International has submitted a binding offer to acquire Nigerian flour and pasta manufacturer Dangote Flour Mills for 130 billion naira (S$491.09 million). The board of Dangote Flour Mills will consider the offer and recommend it to shareholders, subject to regulatory approvals. The proposed acquisition includes Dangote's manufacturing facilities and logistics capabilities.

site_title: Avengers: Endgame smashes box office records with US$1.2b global debut
summary: Avengers: Endgame shattered box office records with a global debut of US$1.2 billion, becoming the first film to top US$1 billion in its opening and the highest-grossing movie of the year. It surpassed expectations by 20% and broke multiple records, including the widest North American release and the biggest foreign debut. With a combined global take of US$2.3 billion from Endgame and Captain Marvel, the Marvel Cinematic Universe is nearly a US$20 billion franchise, cementing its place as a cultural phenomenon.

images.alt_text: The three-hour Endgame also set records for the biggest foreign debut (US$859 million), the biggest "single day" opening (US$156.7 million domestically, including Thursday previews) and the biggest Imax opening (US$91.5 million).

site_title: Philips sees growing demand for electric toothbrushes, apnea care
summary: Royal Philips NV reported double-digit growth in orders for electric toothbrushes and image-guided therapy, meeting analysts' estimates for first-quarter earnings. Demand for Sonicare toothbrushes led to increased sales, while the company expanded its offerings to accommodate various budgets. Philips is shifting production to within Asia due to the US-China trade war and focusing on emerging markets. The company reiterated a target for 4-6% sales growth per year through 2020, aiming to improve margins from scanners and x-ray machines.

site_title: Strange knife threat to Japanese prince underscores royal line's succession crisis
summary: A 12-year-old Japanese prince, Prince Hisahito, was threatened with two kitchen knives at his school, highlighting the vulnerability of the royal family due to a lack of male heirs. The incident occurred just days before his uncle, Crown Prince Naruhito, becomes Japan's new emperor. A 50-year-old man in a blue workman's uniform was arrested in connection with the incident, but the motive behind it remains unclear. The royal family's succession crisis has sparked concerns about the future of Japan's monarchy, with some experts calling for a change in the law to allow women to inherit the throne.

site_title: This year's market rally reveals investor divide: Bernstein analysts
summary: This year's market rally has exposed a divide among investors, with neutral confidence in equities despite record-breaking global markets. Investors have abandoned asset classes that protect portfolios in turbulent markets, such as gold and US Treasuries, favoring stocks and bonds instead. This shift has led to a significant short position on the Cboe Volatility Index, suggesting investors expect market calm to continue. However, some analysts believe the market's resilience is limited, and a potential "melt-up" scenario could be put in check by the shorting of tail hedges.

site_title: Catalist-listed Allied Tech reviewing proposed S$130m RTO of dormitory operator
summary: Catalist-listed Allied Tech is reviewing a proposed S$130 million reverse takeover (RTO) of dormitory operator Aik Chuan Construction Pte Ltd. The acquisition, if successful, will be subject to Singapore Exchange approval and shareholder vote. Allied Tech's board is reviewing the terms, including a S$30 million and S$50 million cash payment and new share issuance. The deal follows the company's warning of a net loss in 2018 due to impairment losses on assets. The acquisition would be the company's first major deal since its listing.

site_title: Banks lift STI to close above 3,400
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) closed above 3,400 for the first time this year, rising 50.07 points or 1.5% to 3,407.02, driven by strong earnings from DBS Group Holdings and its banking peers. DBS's profit increased 9% to S$1.65 billion, while its dividend payout frequency was changed to quarterly, boosting investor confidence. The banking sector's performance was also influenced by strong US economic growth and data showing Chinese industrial firms' profits grew for the first time in four months.

site_title: China wants friendship with Singapore to continue after successor takes over: PM
summary: Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong stated that China wants to maintain its friendship with Singapore, regardless of the leadership change. He noted that younger Singaporean leaders have been actively engaging with China, and the country welcomes Heng Swee Keat's promotion to Deputy Prime Minister. Lee expressed confidence that the transition will be smooth and that bilateral ties will continue, as it is in the interest of both countries. The two countries have signed five deals and have a strong partnership, particularly in the Belt and Road Initiative.

site_title: China's Belt and Road: A Japanese role
summary: China's Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) has faced criticism for "debt traps" with debtor nations unable to repay loans. In response, China pledged to operate the BRI in a "transparent way" with "zero tolerance for corruption" at the recent BRI forum. Japan, a major source of development aid for Sri Lanka, was not involved in the Hambantota Port project, but has expressed concerns over "lopsided deals" and will cooperate with China on joint investments where there is a profit. China aims to expand the BRI, with President Xi Jinping inviting Japan to join, but Japan's strategic community views the initiative as a threat to its relationships with the US and its ally Australia.

site_title: Lab meat, not just plants, is protein's future: food startup
summary: A food startup, Just Inc, is planning to diversify its business into lab-grown meat, alongside its existing plant-based products. The company aims to grow chicken, beef, and pork in a lab and is raising funds ahead of an initial public offering. This move reflects the company's belief that lab meat, not just plant-based alternatives, is the future of protein. Just Inc joins other companies in the lab-grown meat industry, which is gaining traction as a sustainable and environmentally-friendly alternative to traditional meat production.

site_title: SingPost mustn't let US debacle douse its e-commerce ambition
summary: SingPost, a Singaporean postal service provider, is selling its loss-making US subsidiaries, TradeGlobal and Jagged Peak, amid the company's efforts to focus on its e-commerce ambitions in the region. Despite the challenges faced by the US units, SingPost sees growth prospects in the Asia-Pacific market, particularly in Singapore, where e-commerce is a growing sector. The planned sale will free up resources for SingPost's Asia-Pacific operations, which have a natural competitive advantage over its US business. The company's core post and parcel business remains profitable, and SingPost aims to rebuild itself for a new era of doorstep deliveries.

site_title: KBS Prime US Reit plans up to US$705 million IPO in June
summary: KBS Prime US Reit, a US-based real estate private equity firm, plans to list its IPO in June, aiming to raise up to US$705 million. The Reit's portfolio comprises 11 Class A office buildings valued at US$1.2 billion, with a distribution yield of 7.25-7.4% for 2019. The listing will have a market capitalization of around US$840 million. Pre-deal roadshows will be held in May, with the prospectus expected to be lodged in mid-May and the IPO taking place in early June.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% as investors weighed market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions. Global stocks declined, with banks and healthcare sectors dragging down Europe, while US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10b upgrade. Indonesia detained an employee in a graft case related to 285 trillion rupiah.

site_title: Brexit pushes UK holidaymakers further afield for summer break
summary: UK holidaymakers are shifting their summer breaks further afield due to Brexit uncertainty and the pound's weakness, with 49% of Thomas Cook Group's bookings now outside the Eurozone, up from 38% last year. Turkey has become the second most popular destination, while Tunisia saw a 159% year-on-year increase in family bookings. Spain remains the UK's top summer holiday destination, despite concerns over summer disruptions easing after the Brexit deadline was pushed back.

site_title: Singaporeans' share of local home purchases surges in Q1
summary: In Q1, 79% of private apartments in Singapore were bought by locals, the highest share since 2009, according to property consultants OrangeTee & Tie. This surge in local purchases was driven by affluent locals buying luxury units, with 69% of such purchases made by locals. The demand for executive condominiums has also grown, with younger people moving out of their parents' homes earlier. The surge in local ownership contrasts with the impact of cooling measures on foreign buyers, who remain resilient but face punitive levies.

site_title: Keppel Capital fund buys 3 Grade A Seoul commercial properties
summary: Keppel Capital's Alpha Asia Macro Trends Fund III has acquired three Grade A commercial properties in Seoul's business districts for 430 billion won (S$510 million). The properties include Yeouido Finance Tower, Nonhyun Building, and Naeja Building, offering a total of 59,900 sq m of office and retail space. The acquisition aims to create value and drive returns for investors, with the properties' favorable location and accessibility to public transportation expected to generate good returns. Keppel Investment Management will manage the properties locally.

site_title: SMJ International rebrands as HealthBank Holdings
summary: SMJ International Holdings has rebranded as HealthBank Holdings after receiving shareholders' approval. The name change, effective April 29, 2019, aims to avoid confusion with the carpet furnishing business SMJ Furnishings and reflect the company's new focus on hospitality facilities management in China. The company's trading counter name will change to "HealthBank" on May 3. The name change does not affect shareholders' rights or the company's financial position.

site_title: Jaguar testing 'smart wallet' tech to reward helpful drivers with cryptocurrency
summary: Jaguar Land Rover is testing "smart wallet" technology that rewards drivers with IOTA cryptocurrency for sharing data, such as traffic congestion or potholes, with navigation providers or local authorities. The technology will be installed in Jaguar cars and allows drivers to earn IOTA coins for participating in data sharing. This initiative aims to incentivize drivers to contribute valuable data to improve road infrastructure and services.

site_title: Siemens wins US$15b Iraq power plan over GE
summary: Iraq approved a US$15 billion power plan with Siemens AG, beating General Electric Co. The deal, which will develop electricity projects, is crucial for both companies' power-generation businesses. Iraq's Cabinet picked Siemens as a partner, despite initial plans for GE, amid concerns of US political pressure. Siemens CEO Joe Kaeser criticized the apparent influence, citing skewed competition. The deal aims to boost Iraq's power output, addressing the country's long-standing electricity issues since the 2003 US-led invasion.

site_title: Raffles Medical Q1 profit falls 13.7% on Chongqing hospital startup costs
summary: Raffles Medical Group reported a 13.7% drop in Q1 net profit to S$13.6 million due to startup costs for Raffles Hospital Chongqing. Revenue increased 6.7% year-over-year to S$128.3 million. Earnings per share fell 14.4% to 0.76 Singapore cents. Despite a gestation loss, the group expects to grow revenue and remain profitable in 2019. Net debt increased to S$14.2 million, but operating cashflows remained strong.

site_title: US has recorded 704 cases of measles this year, a 25-year-high-health officials
summary: US health officials reported 704 measles cases, a 25-year high, with 78 new cases last week. This brings the total to 22 states, where the disease has been recorded. The US Centres for Disease Control and Prevention noted a 1.3% increase in cases since the previous week.

images.alt_text: People walk past a sign outside of health clinic with warnings about measles in the Orthodox Jewish area of the Williamsburg neighborhood in Brooklyn, New York. The US recorded 78 new measles cases last week for a total of 704 cases so far this year, the greatest number in a quarter century, federal health officials said on Monday.

site_title: Visa, MasterCard finalise EU card probe with fee cut pledge
summary: Visa and MasterCard have finalized a pact with the European Union to reduce fees for foreigners shopping in the region. The companies agreed to cut debit card fees to 0.2% and credit card fees to 0.3% for European cards, with online transactions having higher fees. The move aims to benefit European retailers and consumers, with the reductions lasting 5.5 years. The agreement marks the end of nearly two decades of EU antitrust scrutiny, following a previous fine of 570.6 million euros on MasterCard.

site_title: Spotify reaches 100 million paying subscribers
summary: Spotify has reached 100 million paying subscribers, a 32% year-over-year growth, driven by promotions in the US and Canada, as well as family plans. Revenue from premium accounts increased to $2.1 billion for the quarter. However, the company reported a wider operating loss of $47 million for the first quarter of 2019, despite a surprise operating profit of $94 million in February. This milestone marks an important milestone for Spotify's business model, which relies heavily on premium subscribers for revenue.

images.alt_text: Swedish music streaming giant Spotify said Monday it had amassed 100 million paying subscribers, but the company also fell back into the red and reported a first quarter operating loss.

site_title: Cambodian PM says China ready to help if EU imposes sanctions
summary: Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Sen announced a 600 million yuan Chinese aid package to his military, following a meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping. China will help Cambodia if the EU withdraws special market access due to its human rights record. China is Cambodia's biggest aid donor and investor, and has pledged to support the country's national defense sector. The EU's "Everything But Arms" trade scheme, which allows Cambodia to export most goods to the EU duty-free, is at risk of being suspended if the EU imposes sanctions.

site_title: Alibaba pays US$250m to settle lawsuit over pre-IPO counterfeiting warning
summary: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd agreed to pay $250 million to settle a US lawsuit alleging securities fraud over concealing a regulatory warning about counterfeiting before its 2014 IPO. The warning, issued by China's State Administration for Industry and Commerce, stated many products sold on Alibaba websites were fake or infringed trademarks. The settlement requires court approval and does not admit wrongdoing by Alibaba. The lawsuit was one of seven proposed class-action lawsuits filed on behalf of investors over the share price decline following the warning's release.

site_title: A-Reit's DPU rises 6.1% in Q4; it plans to rejuvenate some assets
summary: Ascendas Reit reported a 6.1% rise in distribution per unit (DPU) to 4.148 Singapore cents for Q4, driven by contributions from newly acquired properties in the UK and Australia. The Reit plans to rejuvenate some assets, such as transforming light industrial buildings into high-specifications properties, to strengthen its portfolio. With 2.8 million sq m of new industrial space coming onstream in Singapore, the Reit will look at overseas acquisitions, particularly in Europe.

site_title: A split Democratic party echoes the 1968 race
summary: The article echoes the 1968 Democratic presidential election, where Hubert Humphrey lost to Richard Nixon due to party infighting. The split within the Democratic Party, driven by ideological divisions and young activists, led to a perceived tilt towards the "loony left." This echoes the same divisions within the party that ultimately contributed to Biden's loss in the 2024 presidential election, highlighting the importance of party unity in winning the "Big Prize."

site_title: Sunpower Group wins 242m yuan manufacturing, services contract
summary: Sunpower Group has secured a 242 million yuan manufacturing and services contract from Shenhua Yulin Energy Chemical Co, a subsidiary of China Energy Investment Co. This is the third such contract for the Yulin Recycling Economy Coal Comprehensive Utilisation Project, one of the world's largest coal and chemical projects. The contract is expected to positively impact Sunpower's performance for FY19 and FY20, and its green investments business is seen as a key growth driver.

site_title: US: S&P 500 hits record high on upbeat consumer spending, earnings optimism
summary: The S&P 500 reached an all-time high for the first time since September 2019, driven by upbeat consumer spending data and positive earnings. The benchmark index closed at 2,941.24, surpassing its previous record of 2,940.91. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and Nasdaq Composite also saw gains, with the Dow up 4.92 points and the Nasdaq up 7.17 points. Investors' faith in the decade-long bull run was restored, following a series of positive earnings reports.

site_title: China says criticisms on IP protection lack evidence amid trade spat
summary: China's National Intellectual Property Administration head, Shen Changyu, has denied criticisms of the country's IP protection, stating they lack evidence. IP infringement is a global problem, and China has made significant progress in IP protection. In response to US trade concerns, China plans to strengthen its IP protections this year, including amending laws and improving approval efficiency. The move aims to increase costs for infringements and provide lower-cost protection channels. China's progress in IP protection has been ignored by critics, with the US labeling China as "inadequately protecting" US intellectual property rights.

site_title: Swee Hong supplier withdraws winding-up application against firm
