summary: Swee Hong Limited's supplier, Hock Hin Leong Timber Trading, has withdrawn its winding-up application against the company on the day it was set to be heard in court. The application was filed due to Swee Hong owing HHLT money for supplies. The withdrawal was announced on April 26, and the company will not face the risk of being wound up.

site_title: US consumer spending posts biggest gain since 2009
summary: US consumer spending increased by 0.9% in March, the largest gain since 2009, driven by higher purchases of motor vehicles and healthcare. Despite muted price pressures, real consumer spending rose 0.7% and core inflation remained at 1.6%, within the Federal Reserve's 2% target. This surge in spending suggests an acceleration in consumption in the second quarter, potentially supporting economic growth, which rose 3.2% in the first quarter.

site_title: Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust Q4 DPU up 2.7%
summary: Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust (MNACT) reported a 2.7% rise in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.956 Singapore cents for Q4, driven by contributions from new Japan properties and higher rental income. Gross revenue and net property income (NPI) also increased 16.2% and 15.3%, respectively. For the full year, DPU rose 2.8% to 7.69 Singapore cents. The trust's manager attributed the growth to proactive asset and capital management, despite potential uncertainties in the year ahead.

site_title: Biofourmis's software to detect irregular heartbeat gets US FDA clearance
summary: Biofourmis, a Singapore-based health-tech startup, has received US FDA clearance for its cloud-based software RhythmAnalytics, which aids in detecting cardiac arrhythmia. The software uses deep learning to analyze ECG data and can detect over 15 types of arrhythmias. It will be integrated into Biofourmis's Digital Therapeutics platform, providing more accurate analyses and increased scalability. The software is expected to improve accuracy and efficiency in cardiac monitoring centers, and Biofourmis plans to offer it as a Software-as-a-Service to cardiac monitoring organizations.

site_title: PODCAST: Tips on preparing to sell or buy your HDB flat (Money Hacks, Ep 41)
summary: Sisters Rhonda and Race Wong from Ohmyhome discuss tips on preparing to sell or buy an HDB flat, emphasizing the importance of setting a mindset and timeline, understanding finance calculations, and considering factors such as budget and location. They also advise on using HDB's app and exploring DIY options or working with a property agent. The podcast aims to simplify and streamline housing transactions in Singapore, making them faster and more affordable.

site_title: Amazon workers from around world join forces in Berlin
summary: Amazon workers from 15 countries met in Berlin to coordinate their strategy against the US online retail giant's employment practices. Over 50 employees gathered to compare notes on working conditions in Amazon's logistics centers worldwide, sharing information on rules and regulations to negotiate better treatment. They aim to address issues such as machine-like demands, low salaries, and surveillance, seeking calmer dialogue with management. European unions have struggled to secure recognition from Amazon since 2013, with recent industrial action reaching a new height in 2018.

site_title: Mnuchin says enforcement part of US-China deal `close to done'
summary: US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin said the enforcement part of the US-China trade deal is "close to done" and will be finalized with "a little bit of fine tuning." The next round of trade talks will begin in Beijing this week, with significant issues still unresolved. The US and China are working to finalize an agreement covering trade issues such as intellectual property, forced technology transfer, and agriculture. A completed agreement would include real enforcement provisions, and President Donald Trump has expressed a desire to move forward with the deal.

site_title: Allied Tech gets LOI for S$130m RTO of dormitory operator
summary: Allied Technologies, a precision engineering company, has received a letter of intent (LOI) for a proposed acquisition of Aik Chuan Construction Pte Ltd, a Singapore-based dormitory operator, for S$130 million. The acquisition is expected to result in a reverse takeover (RTO). The LOI is non-binding and does not constitute a legally binding obligation. Allied Tech's shares have been on a trading halt since Friday. The proposed deal includes a cash payment of between S$30 million and S$50 million and the issuance of new shares at a price not exceeding one Singapore cent per share.

site_title: China Sunsine posts 26% drop in Q1 net profit to 110.2m yuan
summary: China Sunsine Chemical Holdings reported a 26% drop in Q1 net profit to 110.2 million yuan due to a 20% decline in revenue and a 24% decrease in average selling price. Earnings per share decreased 26% to 22.42 RMB cents. The decline was mainly attributed to a decrease in raw material prices.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.98 points to 1,637.40. The market saw 2.5 billion lots traded worth RM1.6 billion, with losers beating gainers 622 to 256.

site_title: Asia's longest-serving directors can be found in the Philippines
summary: The Philippines has the longest-serving directors in Asia, with an average tenure of 10.6 years and the highest average age of 65.4 years on boards. Family-led enterprises dominate the country's corporate landscape, with some founders and relatives staying on boards for decades. This has implications for the region's push for greater board diversity, with regulators seeking to balance family control with independent directors. Companies are starting to recognize the risk of long tenures and older directors missing major industry shifts, leading to a push for younger, digitally savvy directors.

site_title: Fiat Chrysler CEO 100 per cent sure carmaker can survive tech disruption
summary: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles (FCA) CEO Mike Manley believes the company can survive the disruption in the car industry due to its "house of brands" strategy, which features distinctive brands like Jeep, Alfa Romeo, and Maserati. Manley, who took over after Sergio Marchionne's death, is confident that Fiat's brands will hold onto their cachet, unlike mass volume producers. The company is investing in electric and self-driving cars, and has begun talks with Peugeot for joint investments, signaling its ability to adapt to the changing industry landscape.

site_title: From Heisei to Reiwa: how Japan changed under Emperor Akihito
summary: Japan marks the end of an era with the abdication of Emperor Akihito, who leaves behind a country that has undergone significant changes during his 30-year reign. The country has transitioned from an economic bubble to a thriving tech industry, with advancements in fields like robotics and artificial intelligence. Emperor Naruhito will inherit a Japan with a more globalized economy, a stronger focus on international relations, and a growing emphasis on sustainability and environmental protection. The country is now poised for a new era, or Reiwa, under the leadership of the new emperor.

site_title: Sri Lanka bans face veils after attacks by Islamist militants
summary: Sri Lanka has banned women from wearing face veils under an emergency law following deadly Easter Sunday attacks by Islamist militants. The ban aims to aid security forces in identifying potential attackers and their supporters. The move has sparked concerns within the Muslim community, with some scholars opposing the ban as a violation of their religious rights. Human Rights Watch condemned the restriction, citing the potential impact on Muslim women who cover their faces for religious reasons.

site_title: Ascendas Reit posts 6.1% rise in Q4 DPU
summary: Ascendas Reit reported a 6.1% rise in distribution per unit (DPU) to 4.148 Singapore cents for Q4, driven by contributions from newly acquired properties in the UK, Australia, and Singapore. Gross revenue and net property income (NPI) also increased, with Q4 revenue up 4.3% and NPI up 3.5%. The Reit's full-year DPU rose 0.3%, while gross revenue and NPI improved 2.8% and 3.2%, respectively. The Reit plans to transform properties and continue overseas growth strategies to strengthen its portfolio.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks kick off week with a rally
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 0.97% on Monday, tracking a record-breaking lead from Wall Street, with investors awaiting China-US trade talks resumption. The Hang Seng Index closed at 29,892.81, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.77%. The resumption of China-US trade talks this week is seen as a key driver for market sentiment.

site_title: Bancassurance remains core part of OCBC's business, says bank's CEO
summary: OCBC Bank's CEO, Samuel Tsien, stated that bancassurance remains a core part of the bank's business, not just an insurance operation. The insurance arm, Great Eastern, is integral to the bank's offerings in various markets. Tsien declined to consider outsourcing the insurance business to another partner, unlike some of the bank's local peers. This decision emphasizes OCBC's commitment to bancassurance as a key aspect of its business strategy.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks jump most since Jan buoyed by US GDP growth
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index rose 1.7% on Monday, its largest gain since January 9, due to US first-quarter economic growth data. The main KOSPI index rose 37.12 points to 2,216.43, with foreigners buying 4.0 billion won worth of shares. The KOSPI has gained 8.59% this year, its largest gain since 2018. The strong performance is attributed to the US economic growth data, which offset concerns of a recession.

site_title: Manulife US Reit launches private placement to pay for US office deal
summary: Manulife US Reit has announced a private placement to raise US$94 million to fund the purchase of two office towers, Centerpointe I & II, in Virginia for US$122 million. The deal is expected to be distribution per unit (DPU)-accretive, with a 3.3% increase in DPU and improved gearing. The acquisition is seen as a strategic move to increase the Reit's portfolio exposure to the technology and government sectors, with tenants including Accenture and Edelman Financial Services.

site_title: APAC gaming growth threatens Philippine casinos
summary: The Philippines' casino industry faces a threat from growing competition in the Asia-Pacific region. Despite reaching $2.5 billion in revenue in 2018, the sector's growth is expected to slow due to competition from Macau and other countries. Fitch Ratings analysts predict near-term growth in the high single digits, but long-term expansion will be limited. The Philippine regulatory framework is less established than other countries, and the country's reliance on the VIP segment makes it vulnerable to competition. The sector is also affected by the Chinese slowdown and the impact of tariffs.

site_title: Singapore shares soar 1.5% on Monday on strong macroeconomic data
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 1.5% to 3,407.02, driven by strong US first-quarter economic growth and Chinese industrial firms' profits growth for the first time in four months. Trading volume was 1.05 billion securities, 20% higher than the January-to-March daily average. The benchmark index closed above 3,400 for the first time this year, with local banks contributing to the gains.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore shares rose 1.5% on Monday as the Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,407.02, driven by strong macroeconomic data. No Signboard shares plummeted 9.5% after being probed for share buyback. Singapore and China signed four agreements on trade, law enforcement, and Belt and Road projects. DBS's mortgage book shrank for the first time in years due to cooling measures, while Keppel Corp increased its medium-term note programme to US$5 billion.

images.alt_text: THE counter also resumed trading on Monday following a trading halt on April 24, when it last traded at 8.4 Singapore cents.

site_title: Indonesian president plans to move capital city - planning minister
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo plans to relocate the capital city from Jakarta, the country's current capital, to a new location outside of Java. This decision, made after a Cabinet meeting, could take up to 10 years to complete, citing examples of similar relocations in Brazil, Malaysia, and Kazakhstan. The administration has yet to select a new site, but the move aims to alleviate congestion and improve infrastructure on the densely populated island of Java.

site_title: Citic Envirotech Q1 net profit slumps 92.2% to S$3.08m
summary: CITIC Envirotech reported a 92.2% drop in Q1 net profit to S$3.08m, primarily due to delays in two major projects in China. Engineering revenue fell 94.3% and membrane system sales decreased 84.9% year-over-year. Recurring treatment revenue rose 11% to S$51.5m, but total revenue declined 72.2% to S$72.13m. The company attributed the decline to adverse wintry conditions in China.

site_title: The rich and famous vote in India's election
summary: Billionaires and Bollywood stars cast their votes in India's marathon election, with Prime Minister Narendra Modi stepping up his nationalist campaign. At least 40,000 police and security personnel were deployed in Mumbai, and 72 constituencies across the nation voted in the fourth round. The election is crucial for Modi's chances of securing a second term, with over 3 dozen seats at stake in key states. The Congress party has criticized Modi's handling of the economy and security issues, while Modi has relied on his tough security stance and nationalist credentials to win support.

site_title: ONE Championship launches TV and film production division
summary: ONE Championship has launched ONE Studios, its TV and film production division, to produce content starring its athletes. The division will distribute content globally via digital partners and over 140 TV broadcast partners. ONE Championship chairman and CEO Chatri Sityodtong expressed excitement about telling inspiring stories and making world-class blockbuster movies and TV shows. The organization has been working on its first movie project, with a major announcement expected soon.

site_title: Indonesia's Pertamina says jet fuel inventory rises, has stopped imports
summary: Indonesia's state energy company PT Pertamina reported a rise in jet fuel inventory to 42 days, up from 30 days last year. The company stopped importing jet fuel from January 2019 amid lower demand from airlines, which saw a 24% drop in passenger capacity in the first quarter. This decline was attributed to reduced air travel frequency in Indonesia. Pertamina sets fair prices considering high logistics costs and forecasts 14,500 kilolitres of jet fuel consumption per day during Ramadan and Eid Al-Fitr.

site_title: Jokowi leads official Indonesia vote count in blow to rival
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo (Jokowi) leads his challenger Prabowo Subianto by about 12 percentage points midway through the official vote count in the April 17 election. Jokowi secured 56.2% of the votes, compared to 43.8% for Subianto, with ballots from 52% of polling stations tallied. The official result is expected to confirm Jokowi's win, despite Prabowo's claims of "massive fraud" and potential legal challenges.

site_title: Scoot to suspend flights to 4 cities on weak demand and aircraft shortage
summary: Scoot, a low-cost arm of Singapore Airlines, is suspending flights to four cities: Lucknow in India, Kalibo in the Philippines, Quanzhou in China, and the Maldives' capital Male, due to weak demand and an aircraft shortage. The shortage was caused by the grounding of SilkAir's Boeing 737 MAX 8 fleet and the non-transfer of SilkAir's Boeing 737-800NG aircraft to Scoot. Affected customers have been contacted with options for rebooking and refunds.

site_title: Europe: Stocks steady at open
summary: European stock markets remained steady in opening trade on Monday, with London's FTSE 100 index almost unchanged. The Paris CAC 40 index was flat, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 declined 0.1%. The focus shifted to US-EU trade talks, with investors brushing off new Trump threats.

site_title: Will selfies save New York's flower district?
summary: New York's flower district, a historic hub along Sixth Avenue, is seeing a resurgence in popularity thanks to trendy hotels and businesses. The Moxy Chelsea hotel, with its floral decorations and Fleur Room lounge, is attracting tourists and locals alike, with many visiting to take photos and enjoy the unique atmosphere. This influx of interest is forcing flower shops to adapt and capitalize on the trend, with some even offering Instagram-worthy displays. While the growth is a boon for some, it also raises concerns about rising rents and parking challenges, threatening the long-term viability of the flower district.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Monday afternoon at 3,385.33, up 0.85% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Monday, advancing 0.85% to 3,385.33, driven by gains from DBS Group Holdings (2.59%) and OCBC Bank (2.12%). Genting Singapore and Annica were also among the top movers, with 536 million securities worth S$573.8 million changing hands. The Straits Times Index had a 1.33 ratio of gainers to losers, with 182 gainers out of 137 losers.

site_title: Sim Lim Square up for en bloc sale with S$1.25b reserve price
summary: Sim Lim Square, a 99-year leasehold site in Singapore, has been put up for en bloc sale via public tender with a reserve price of S$1.25 billion. The retail strata mall, one of the country's largest IT shopping centers, comprises 492 commercial units on a 78,152 sq ft site with a remaining lease of 63 years. The sale aims to refresh the mall, which has been under-utilized due to its strata system limitations. The tender closes on June 24.

site_title: Nets, Myanmar's national payment network to co-develop QR code system
summary: Nets, Myanmar's national payment network, will co-develop a QR code system with the Singaporean payment network, following a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) signed between the two parties. The system, similar to Singapore's SGQR, aims to consolidate multiple QR codes into a single code, making payments easier and faster for merchants. Myanmar's national payment system will be deployed with a single QR label under the guidance of the Central Bank of Myanmar, with the goal of increasing digital payment adoption in the country.

site_title: Apple says it pulled parental control apps over privacy concerns
summary: Apple removed 11 parental control apps from its store due to security and privacy concerns. The move was sparked by Apple's own Screen Time feature, which raised anti-competitive concerns. Apple stated that the removed apps put users' privacy and security at risk, as they relied on Mobile Device Management (MDM) technology meant for enterprises. The company gave developers 30 days to modify their apps, then removed those that weren't adjusted. Apple's move was seen as a rare public response to a media report, with some critics calling for Apple to offer tools to developers to build monitoring apps that don't violate policies.

site_title: As rain grows patchier, Andaman and Nicobar island farmers adapt
summary: The Andaman and Nicobar Islands, off India's coast, are struggling with patchy rainfall due to climate change, affecting 380,000 people. Farmers are adapting by growing drought-resistant crops, such as chilis and tomatoes, and using ponds to trap rainwater. The islands' thin soil and coral soil make it difficult to absorb and hold water, leading to crop decline and reduced earnings. Scientists are encouraging farmers to use water efficiently and grow tree crops with deeper roots, while also implementing weather forecasting systems to help manage the challenges posed by changing climate patterns.

site_title: Hot stock: No Signboard shares down by as much as 9.5% after CAD probes share buyback
summary: No Signboard Holdings shares dropped 9.5% after the Singapore Police Force's Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) launched an investigation into a recent share buyback. The shares resumed trading after a halt on April 24, when they last traded at 8.4 Singapore cents. The company's CEO, Lim Yong Sim, instructed the broker to buy back shares during a trading restriction period, exceeding a 5% cap. No Signboard is cooperating with the authorities, providing documents and access to the investigation.

site_title: Jaguar Land Rover planning to allow helpful car drivers to earn cryptocurrency
summary: Jaguar Land Rover is testing software that rewards drivers with IOTA cryptocurrency for sharing data, such as traffic congestion or potholes, to achieve zero emissions, accidents, and congestion. The "smart wallet" technology, installed in vehicles, allows drivers to earn tokens for participating in ride-sharing programs and using their cars to report useful data. The goal is to create a universal token for a machine economy, enabling interoperability with different players. The technology is being tested at a Jaguar Land Rover base in Ireland and has not yet been commercially available.

images.alt_text: Jaguar Land Rover, Britain's largest auto manufacturer, said on Monday it is testing software that will allow drivers of its cars to earn the IOTA cryptocurrency as a reward for sharing data.

site_title: The moment when Nureyev became Nureyev
summary: Rudolf Nureyev, a renowned dancer, defected from Russia to the West in 1961, changing the history of ballet. Born in 1938 in Ufa, Russia, Nureyev was raised in poverty and began dancing at a young age. He attended the Vaganova Ballet Academy and became a star, known for his passion, raw energy, and naturalness. Nureyev's defection made headlines worldwide, bringing him fame and opprobrium. He went on to form a legendary partnership with Margot Fonteyn and became director of the Paris Opera Ballet, influencing male ballet technique and style.

images.alt_text: Directed by Ralph Fiennes, the newly released "The White Crow," tells the story of the early life of Rudolf Nureyev, the man who would become one of the world's most influential dancers.

site_title: DBS mortgage book shrinks for first time in years on cooling measures
summary: DBS Group Holdings, Singapore's largest home loan provider, reported a decline in its mortgage book for the first time in years, dropping to S$74.4 billion in Q1 2019, down from S$75 billion at end-2018. The contraction was attributed to the government's property cooling measures last year, with booking of new home loans being about half of what was booked the previous year. DBS still expects the 2019 mortgage book to grow, but at a slower pace, between S$1 billion and S$1.5 billion.

site_title: Philippine rate cut a matter of timing as oil rises, Diokno says
summary: Philippine central bank Governor Benjamin Diokno said a rate cut at the May 9 policy meeting depends on key data and El Nino weather, with oil prices being a crucial factor. If oil prices remain elevated, the rate may remain unchanged. Diokno also hinted at a possible reduction in the reserve ratio ratio, aiming to bring it below 10% by 2023, but emphasized the need for data-driven decisions.

site_title: Vietnam's April annual inflation rate at 2.93%: stats office
summary: Vietnam's April annual inflation rate reached 2.93%, driven by a 6.11% increase in education services and a 4.28% rise in food costs. The consumer price index rose 0.31% from the previous month and 1.00% from the end of last year.

site_title: Australia: Shares ease off 11-year peak as financials drag
summary: Australian shares ended lower on Monday, easing off an 11-year peak, due to losses in financial stocks. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed down 0.4% at 6,359.50, snapping four straight gains. Investors await US Federal Reserve's meeting and Chinese factory data for policy direction and economic health clues. Financials, the benchmark's biggest sector, saw its worst day in two weeks, with the "Big Four" banks losing 0.9% or more.

images.alt_text: Australian shares ended lower on Monday after losses in financial stocks pulled the benchmark down from a more than 11-year high as investors remained cautious ahead of bank earnings.

site_title: Japanese: Markets closed for holiday
summary: Japan's financial markets are closed on Monday for a public holiday. No key events or conclusions are reported from other markets, as the provided articles focus on market trends and news from Europe and the US.

site_title: Singapore, China ink deals on trade, Belt and Road projects
summary: Singapore and China signed five agreements, strengthening their collaboration on trade, law enforcement, and Belt and Road Initiative projects. The agreements were inked after a meeting between Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and Chinese Premier Li Keqiang. The deals include setting up a ministerial-level Singapore-Shanghai Comprehensive Cooperation Council and partnerships in law enforcement and trade. The agreements aim to deepen bilateral cooperation and promote economic growth.

site_title: Australia holds first election debate as race tightens
summary: Australia's election campaign is tightening, with a recent poll showing the center-left opposition Labor party maintaining a narrow lead of two percentage points ahead of Prime Minister Scott Morrison's conservative coalition. The poll's results pressure Labor leader Bill Shorten ahead of their first televised debate on Monday. The campaign has been marked by shrill attacks and accusations, with Morrison's team portraying Shorten as an untrustworthy politician. Labor has focused on policies appealing to working families, while the Liberal party has tried to make the election a referendum on Shorten.

site_title: Boeing CEO faces shareholders for first time since 737 MAX crashes
summary: Boeing CEO Dennis Muilenburg faces shareholders for the first time since the 737 MAX crashes, which killed 346 people. The crashes, including an Ethiopian Airlines and a Lion Air, led to the plane's grounding and triggered investigations, lawsuits, and a sharp loss in share value. Muilenburg will try to bolster investor confidence as Boeing seeks to deliver a software fix and new pilot training package to address safety concerns. The US Federal Aviation Administration is expected to clear the plane to fly again in late May or early June.

site_title: Promotion boosts sales at Australia's Coles
summary: Coles Group Ltd, Australia's second-largest grocer, reported a quarterly sales growth boost driven by a promotion for children. However, traders are questioning the promotion's sustainability. The company's sales growth was mostly driven by this promotion, raising concerns about its long-term viability.

site_title: Philips sees growing demand for e-toothbrushes, apnea care
summary: Royal Philips NV reported a 5.8% increase in first-quarter adjusted earnings to 364 million euros, beating analyst estimates. The company is seeing growing demand for e-toothbrushes and apnea care products, with sales growth in emerging markets reaching double-digit percentages. Philips is expanding its offerings to accommodate all budgets and tapping demand in fast-growing markets for breathing masks and equipment. The company is also shifting production to within Asia to mitigate the impact of the US-China trade war, which could shave 60 million euros from sales.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed as attention returns to China-US talks
summary: Asian markets are mixed on Monday, with Hong Kong, Singapore, and Seoul rising, while Shanghai and Sydney fell. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq reached record highs due to strong earnings and a 3.2% US GDP growth rate in January-March. China-US trade talks are back in focus, with top negotiators set to meet in Beijing. Despite concerns about Chinese monetary easing measures, higher-yielding currencies made gains against the dollar, while oil prices extended losses.

site_title: Britain's Hunt urges caution over Huawei role in 5G network
summary: British Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt has urged caution over China's Huawei role in the UK's 5G network, citing concerns about the Chinese state's control over the company. Despite Prime Minister Theresa May's conditional approval of Huawei's involvement, Hunt believes the UK should carefully weigh the risks. The US has opposed Huawei's involvement due to its obligation to gather intelligence for China. The final decision on Huawei's role will be announced in June, with Hunt warning that risks should not be allowed to incite fear.

site_title: Lab meat, not plants, is protein's future, startup Just says
summary: Just Inc, a food startup, is shifting its focus from plant-based alternatives to lab-grown meat, with CEO Josh Tetrick stating that "the best way to do meat is not to do plant-based, but a meat-based approach." The company plans to grow chicken, beef, and pork in labs and is raising funds ahead of an initial public offering to support this new business strategy.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Monday, down 0.89 points to 1,637.49, following a global trend of lower stock prices. The index saw 83.71 million lots traded worth RM20.38 million. Gainers outpaced losers 124 to 68. The decline was attributed to global market volatility, with US-EU trade tensions and bank and healthcare sector issues contributing to the downturn.

site_title: Office furniture maker Versalink widens fiscal 2019 loss to RM7m
summary: Versalink, a Malaysia-based office furniture maker, reported a net loss of RM7.0 million (S$2.3 million) for fiscal 2019, widening from a RM2.5 million loss the previous year. Revenue declined 19% to RM50.7 million, driven by lower exports and domestic segments. The company's shares traded flat, and its net asset value decreased to 40.2 sen per share. The group expects its operating performance to be affected by global and Malaysian economic challenges for the next 12 months.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rise at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.33% at the open on Monday, following a record-breaking close on Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index reached 29,702.45, while the Shanghai Composite Index added 0.14%. Investors are monitoring China-US trade talks resuming this week.

site_title: DBS offers digital token with increased security for corporates, SMEs
summary: DBS Bank introduced a new digital token for corporate and small and medium-sized enterprise (SME) customers on its DBS IDEAL online banking platform, enhancing online security and user experience. The new token uses biometric fingerprint or facial recognition technology for authentication, eliminating the need for physical tokens or one-time passwords. Available in Asia from May 2019, the new digital token aims to mitigate transaction risks and provide a more secure login process, with customers receiving notifications and confirmation messages via secure networks.

images.alt_text: Fiona Lam

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Monday; STI up 0.39% to 3,369.97
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.39% to 3,369.97 on Monday, driven by gains in Genting Singapore, Thai Beverage, and Singtel. DBS Group Holdings and OCBC Bank also saw significant increases, with DBS up 1.64% and OCBC up 0.85%. The Straits Times Index gained 13.02 points, surpassing the previous week's stagnation.

site_title: HR platform Swingvy raises US$7m in Series A round led by Samsung Ventures
summary: Singapore-headquartered HR platform startup Swingvy has raised US$7 million in a Series A round led by Samsung Ventures, with participation from Aviva Ventures and Bass Investment. Existing investors also joined in, bringing total funding to US$8.6 million. Swingvy plans to use the funds to accelerate growth, expand into Asia-Pacific, and develop its product. Co-founder and CEO Jin Choeh stated that HR tech is a growing sector in the US but underdeveloped in the Asia-Pacific region, particularly for small companies. Swingvy aims to address this gap with its platform.

site_title: Coal producer Golden Energy and Resources unveils its first digital-tech innovation centre in Singapore
summary: Golden Energy and Resources (Gear) has launched its first digital-tech innovation centre in Singapore, supported by the Singapore Economic Development Board. The Gear Innovation Network will focus on digital technologies to transform capital-intensive business activities, including mining and logistics. The centre aims to co-create technology-driven solutions to reduce financial and operational risks. Located at Gear's corporate headquarters, it will test new concepts to drive innovation and growth.

site_title: China's rocket start-ups go small in age of 'shoebox' satellites
summary: China's private rocket start-ups are shifting towards a "shoebox" satellite model, sending tiny, inexpensive satellites into orbit at affordable prices. Companies like LinkSpace, led by 26-year-old Hu Zhenyu, are developing reusable rockets to launch these nanosatellites, aiming to charge as little as 30 million yuan (S$6.1 million) per launch. China's rocket entrepreneurs see this as a key to developing a new business model and capitalizing on the expected boom in demand for nanosatellites, which could lead to massive constellations of commercial satellites offering services such as high-speed internet and remote-sensing.

site_title: Australia: Shares dip, weighed by energy, financial firms; New Zealand up
summary: Australian shares dropped 0.3% on Monday, weighed by a slump in oil prices, to reach a 4-session low. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell to 6,364.2, despite a rise in gold prices and strong earnings from Coles Group. Investors remain cautious ahead of bank earnings later this week, with shares of Australia and New Zealand Banking Group and National Australia Bank Ltd dipping 0.7% and 0.8%, respectively. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index rose 0.5% to 10,046.70, driven by gains in consumer and telecom stocks.

site_title: Debao unit to sell stake in loss-making Malaysia business for 4m yuan
summary: Debao Property Development is selling a 43% stake in its loss-making Malaysian business, Profit Consortium (PC), to Chinese management firm Guangzhou Xu Zhuo Enterprise Management for 4 million yuan. The sale is intended to provide working capital for Debao's other projects, reduce liabilities, and strengthen its financial position. PC has incurred significant losses since 2016 due to high finance costs for its Plaza Rakyat project. After the sale, Pavillion Treasures Land and Development will hold a 19% interest in PC.

site_title: Memories Group to issue US$3m convertible bonds to buy stake in 3 Yangon hotels, boat cruise
summary: Memories Group, a Catalist-listed tourism company, plans to acquire a 15.28% stake in Strand Hotel International, which owns three Yangon hotels and a boat cruise, by issuing US$3.19 million in convertible bonds. The acquisition is part of Memories' expansion plans to own, develop, and operate more hotels and lodges. The deal is expected to be settled by the issuance of convertible bonds at a 177.8% premium over Memories' shares.

site_title: Keppel Corp ups limit of medium-term note programme to US$5b from US$3b
summary: Keppel Corp has increased the investable limit of its multi-currency medium-term note programme to US$5 billion from US$3 billion. The net proceeds from the issue will be used for general corporate or working capital purposes. The company has applied to the Singapore Exchange for permission to deal in and quote the new notes. This move aims to raise additional funds without impacting the company's financial obligations.

site_title: US military spending up for first time in 7 years: Sipri
summary: US military spending has risen for the first time in 7 years, according to a Stockholm International Peace Research Institute report. The global figure rose 2.6% to $1.8 trillion in 2018, with the US spending $649 billion, the highest among 9 countries. China's military spending has also increased, rising 83% since 2009, and is now second only to the US. Russia's military budget has declined due to Western economic sanctions. The US spending increase is attributed to the Trump administration's arms procurement programs implemented in 2017.

site_title: US firms trim growth forecasts amid tariffs, worker shortage: survey
summary: US businesses have revised their growth forecasts for this year, citing the impact of US trade wars and labor shortages. According to a survey, only 33% of economists now expect the GDP to expand by more than 2%, down from 67% in January. Companies are struggling with retaliatory tariffs and higher material costs, leading to negative impacts on sales and investments. Labor shortages are also a concern, with nearly half of firms raising wages to attract workers. The US economy expanded 3.2% in the first quarter, but economists say this pace cannot be sustained.

images.alt_text: As they continue to feel the impact of US trade wars and struggle to find workers, American companies have rolled back their growth estimates for this year, according to a survey released Monday.

site_title: CAD investigates No Signboard over share buyback; CEO's passport seized
summary: Singapore investigators are probing No Signboard Holdings' recent share buyback, which exceeded the regulatory limit and occurred during a black-out period. CEO Sam Lim Yong Sim's passport has been retained by the Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) for investigations. The company has cooperated with the probe, and its shares have resumed trading after a halt. No Signboard described Lim's instructions to the broker as an "honest mistake," and the company has agreed to mitigate the error. No arrests or charges have been made, and business operations continue as usual.

site_title: Nigeria flour maker to recommend Olam's 130b naira acquisition offer to shareholders
summary: Olam International, an agri and food giant, has submitted a binding offer to acquire Nigerian flour and pasta manufacturer Dangote Flour Mills (DFM) for 130 billion naira (S$491.09 million). DFM's board will recommend the offer to shareholders for consideration, subject to regulatory approvals. The acquisition would include DFM's manufacturing facilities and logistics capabilities. Olam operates in Nigeria and Sub-Saharan Africa, and the deal aims to expand its presence in the region.

site_title: Oil falls after Trump urges greater Opec output to replace Iranian oil
summary: Oil prices fell on Monday, extending a slump from Friday, after US President Donald Trump urged Opec to increase output to replace Iranian oil. Brent crude futures dropped 35 cents to $71.80 per barrel, and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures fell 39 cents to $62.91 per barrel. Trump's demand came after he called Opec and told the cartel to lower oil prices. Analysts say the market is shifting focus to voluntary supply cuts led by Opec, which may not last beyond June.

site_title: Dike breached, thousands evacuated near Montreal as floods worsen
summary: Over 6,500 people were evacuated from their homes near Montreal, Quebec, after a dike breached, causing widespread flooding. The flooding, which also affected Ontario and New Brunswick, highlights the need to adapt to climate change, according to Prime Minister Justin Trudeau. Nearly 8,000 people have been forced from their homes in Quebec, with hundreds of policemen, firefighters, and soldiers involved in the evacuation efforts. No injuries or missing persons have been reported, but the flooding has caused significant damage and disruption.

site_title: No clear majority in Spain's election with 80% of votes counted
summary: Spain's national election results show neither the rightist nor leftist bloc holds a clear majority, with 80% of votes counted. The Socialists of Spain lead with 123 seats, followed by Ciudadanos with 57 seats. The right-wing PP party has 65 seats, while the far-left Unidas Podemos and far-right Vox parties trail behind. A potential coalition between the Socialists and Ciudadanos cannot be ruled out, despite both leaders denying it. The results leave the country's future uncertain.

site_title: Extra abdication holidays pose dilemma for hardworking Japanese
summary: Japanese workers are enjoying an unprecedented 10-day holiday following Emperor Akihito's abdication, but many are finding it difficult to make the most of the time off due to crowds and high tour costs. A survey showed 45% of Japanese felt unhappy about the long vacation, while 35% felt happy. The imperial family remains popular, with a poll finding almost no one had a negative sentiment towards the emperor. Critics argue that the ceremonies surrounding the abdication and enthronement should not be funded by taxpayer money due to their religious nature.

site_title: China's quest for clean, limitless energy heats up
summary: China has made significant advancements in fusion energy with its Experimental Advanced Superconducting Tokamak (EAST) reactor, achieving a record-breaking temperature of 100 million degrees Celsius. The facility, part of the International Thermonuclear Experimental Reactor (ITER) project, aims to develop a fully functioning plant by 2050. China's investment of six billion yuan (S$1.21 billion) and international cooperation are seen as crucial steps towards achieving limitless clean energy. The project's success could pave the way for commercially viable fusion power, a goal considered the "Holy Grail" of energy.

images.alt_text: The Experimental Advanced Superconducting Tokamak (EAST) device (above), also known as the "artificial sun", is a ground-breaking fusion reactor built by Chinese scientists at a laboratory in Hefei, east of China's Anhui province.

site_title: UK pushes Google, Facebook to tackle harmful online content
summary: The UK government is urging Google, Facebook, and Snapchat to commit to removing online content surrounding self-harm and suicide. Health Secretary Matt Hancock aims to make the UK the safest place to be online, working with social media companies to address the issue. He also plans to legislate against harmful content and anti-vaccination messages.

site_title: US warns China over civil forces in South China Sea: FT
summary: The US Navy has warned China that its coast guard and maritime militia in the South China Sea will be treated as the nation's navy, citing a reported interview with Admiral John Richardson. China considers 80% of the South China Sea as its sovereign territory, sparking US concerns. Richardson emphasized the US Navy's commitment to conducting routine operations despite China's increasing assertiveness.

site_title: International cooperation critical in move towards future of work: Heng
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the importance of international cooperation in addressing the challenges of the future of work. He called for countries and organizations to work together to create a more sustainable and peaceful world, tackling issues like terrorism, climate change, and food security. Heng also highlighted the need for lifelong learning, investing in people's skills, and preparing workers for new growth areas.

images.alt_text: Amid geopolitical and economic uncertainties, it is critical for countries and international organisations to continue to work closely together towards long-term, sustainable development, said Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat on Sunday.

site_title: iFast Q1 profit down 41.8% amid weak revenue growth, higher expenses
summary: iFast Corporation reported a 41.8% decline in Q1 net profit to S$1.6 million, due to weak revenue growth and higher expenses. Total net revenue grew 4.4% year-over-year, while recurring net revenue rose 8.8%. The company's assets under administration reached a record high of S$8.75 billion. Despite this, DBS Equity Research maintained its "hold" call on iFast, citing potential for growth in the second quarter and long-term expansion in China.

site_title: Stocks to watch: DBS, Best World, iFast, Raffles Medical, Thakral, No Signboard, Ayondo
summary: DBS Group reported a 9% increase in net profit to S$1.65 billion for its first quarter, with a 30 Singapore cents per share dividend. Best World received a two-month extension for its annual general meeting and annual report. iFast Corp posted a 41.8% decline in net profit to S$1.6 million. Raffles Medical Group reported a 13.7% decrease in net profit to S$13.6 million. Thakral Corp shares rose 19.57% after its founding family gained control. No Signboard Holdings was launched under investigation by the Commercial Affairs Department for its share buyback. Ayondo was served a writ of summons by its former CEO over a disputed payment.

site_title: Canadian and Japanese leaders tout benefits of Pacific trade deal that Trump abandoned
summary: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau and Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe touted the benefits of the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP), a 11-country trade deal that the US pulled out of in 2017. Trudeau highlighted a threefold increase in Canadian beef exports to Japan under the deal, while Abe described it as a model for future agreements with its 21st-century rules-based trade approach. The two leaders also agreed to work together to expand the pact, which has already come into force in December last year.

site_title: Raffles Medical Q1 profit falls 13.7% on Chongqing hospital start-up costs
summary: Raffles Medical Group reported a 13.7% drop in Q1 net profit to S$13.6 million due to start-up costs for Raffles Hospital Chongqing. Revenue increased 6.7% to S$128.3 million, driven by growth in healthcare services and premium from existing and new clients. The group's net debt increased to S$14.2 million, but operating cashflows contributed to a cash position of S$111.8 million. Despite the gestation loss, Raffles Medical's board expects the group to grow its revenue and remain profitable in 2019.

site_title: UK govt urged to move on Brexit red lines in talks with opposition
summary: The UK government and Labour Party are in talks to find a consensus on Brexit, with Labour urging the government to move on its red lines. Labour's business spokesman, Rebecca Long-Bailey, said the discussions have been productive but no progress has been made. The key sticking point is a customs union, with Labour calling for one but the government opposing it. The EU's chief negotiator, Michel Barnier, expects the outcome of talks to be known in the coming week, and warned that if no agreement is reached, voters will participate in the EU-wide parliamentary elections at the end of May.

site_title: Raffles Education unit to sell stake in China university operator for 420m yuan
summary: Raffles Education Corp is selling its 51% stake in China university operator Langfang Development Zone Oriental University City Sino-Singapore Education Investment Co for 420 million yuan (S$84.6 million) to Liu Yanwen. The sale is due to the university operator's lack of positive cash inflow since its inception and is expected to result in a net gain of around S$41.6 million. The sale proceeds will be used for Raffles Education's working capital, loan repayment, or opportunistic investments.

site_title: Federal Reserve may end up seeing 1995-96 rate cuts as template for today
summary: Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell and his colleagues may consider cutting interest rates in the near future, drawing parallels with the 1995-96 period when the Fed eased monetary policy. The Fed has raised rates four times in 2018 and is expected to hold rates steady at its upcoming meeting. However, some officials and investors believe that the Fed may need to ease its stance due to low inflation and slowing US and global growth. If the Fed does cut rates, it would be a reversal of its recent tightening policy and could be influenced by the upcoming 2024 presidential election.

site_title: FAA considered grounding some Boeing 737 MAX planes last year: source
summary: US regulators considered grounding some Boeing 737 MAX planes in 2019 after discovering a problem with the Maneuvering Characteristics Augmentation System (MCAS), a system linked to two deadly crashes. Investigators found Boeing had deactivated a signal designed to alert pilots of a malfunctioning MCAS system, and the FAA considered recommending grounding the planes. However, they decided against it and kept the information confidential. The grounding has cost Boeing $1 billion and is expected to increase further due to canceled flights and additional staff costs.

images.alt_text: US regulators considered grounding some Boeing 737 Max planes last year after learning of a problem with a system that is now the main suspect in two deadly crashes, a source close to the matter said.

site_title: Enterprise Singapore, MAS to match startups with global investors
summary: Enterprise Singapore and the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) are working together to match startups with global investors, part of a wider strategy to strengthen the local startup ecosystem. The collaboration comes after 353 venture capital deals were closed in Singapore last year, with a total deal value of US$10.5 billion. The agencies will also provide more mentorship and startup capital to first-time entrepreneurs through the Startup SG Founder programme, and add new cities to the Global Innovation Alliance network.

site_title: Hyphens flies Asian flag in pharma industry
summary: Lim See Wah, a veteran in the healthcare industry, co-founded Hyphens Pharma in 1998 after investing in a family-owned business and acquiring his former employer. The company transformed into a healthcare business serving the needs of Asean, with a focus on innovation. Hyphens Pharma now has three main business segments, including specialty pharma principals, proprietary brands, and medical hypermart & digital. The company aims to deepen its footprint in Asean and build an international presence, with plans to roll out more products and enhance its digital health platform. Lim's focus on innovation differentiates the company from competitors, and he believes the region's growing population and increasing demand for healthcare services create opportunities for growth.

site_title: DBS Q1 profit up 9% to S$1.65b on 'healthy business momentum', higher net interest margin
summary: DBS Group Holdings' first-quarter net profit rose 9% to S$1.65 billion, driven by higher interest rates and growth in non-trade loans. Total income increased 6% to S$3.55 billion, with net interest income growing 9% to S$2.31 billion. The bank declared a dividend of 30 Singapore cents per share and plans to pay dividends quarterly instead of semi-annually. Return on equity increased 14%, the highest in over a decade, as the bank's business momentum and net interest margin offset declines in fee income.

images.alt_text: DBS Group Holdings' first-quarter profit unexpectedly rose as interest income made up for declines in wealth, investment banking and brokerage fees.

site_title: A vote for pro-business continuity
summary: Indonesia's 2019 presidential election outcome, where Joko Widodo won, is expected to provide stability for businesses and investors. The re-election validates his economic accomplishments, including infrastructure spending and social programs. A continued focus on infrastructure development, domestic connectivity, and industrial productivity will be crucial for unlocking Indonesia's true economic potential. The new administration is likely to pursue long-term objectives, such as public sector reform and sustainable finance. Businesses can expect a predictable outcome, with a pro-business stance expected to attract investors, particularly in the digital economy and startup sector.

site_title: Going in circles
summary: Singapore's Environment Minister Masagos Zulkifli has called for a "circular economy approach" to reuse and recycle resources and cut waste. Companies like Tria, which sells disposable containers and cutlery made from wheat-based material, are embracing this idea. Tria plans to collect its products for processing into compost, while a local waste management company will work to close the loop. However, experts note that not all waste can be turned into resources, with some waste being a "money-losing business."

site_title: Institutional investors see hedge funds as panacea for market uncertainty
summary: Institutional investors are increasingly turning to hedge funds as a means to mitigate market uncertainty, with 32% of respondents in a JPMorgan survey planning to increase their hedge fund allocations in 2019. Despite their reputation for uncorrelated performance, hedge funds have had unimpressive results, with many managers struggling to justify high fees. According to Hedge Fund Research, hedge funds have been positive this year but underperformed the overall stock market over the past 12 months and five years. The industry experienced its biggest annual loss since 2011, with some successful managers navigating market turbulence but many others suffering significant losses.

site_title: Avengers: Endgame blows up Hollywood records with huge weekend take
summary: Avengers: Endgame shattered box office records with a US$350 million haul in North America and US$1.2 billion worldwide. It surpassed Captain Marvel's US$8.1 million in the US and outperformed other films, including The Curse of La Llorona and Breakthrough. With a 96% critic rating, Avengers: Endgame is poised to generate the biggest revenue in box office history, according to Comscore. The film's success cements its place as a monumental achievement in Hollywood.

site_title: Wipeout in Argentina draws risk-takers and bargain hunters
summary: Argentina's assets have plummeted, drawing risk-takers and bargain hunters. Dollar bonds maturing in three years offer 16.2% yields, while those due in two years offer 17.8%, significantly higher than US Treasuries and emerging market peers. Despite concerns over Argentina's history of default, a narrowing fiscal deficit, and a trade surplus, investors see value in the country. Local investors are also seeking bargains, with the state pension fund buying local law bonds. The peso is on track to close at a record low, and the government faces a potential loss in the October election.

site_title: Ford workers' questions led to criminal emissions probe
summary: The US Justice Department has launched a criminal investigation into Ford Motor Co over its emissions certification process, following internal employee questions raised last September. The probe, which is in its early stage, does not involve "defeat devices" but may have led to inaccurate mileage ratings. Ford has disclosed the investigation and is cooperating with government agencies. The company has restated fuel economy ratings in the past and is examining models, including the 2019 Ranger pickup, as part of its internal probe.

site_title: Renault-Nissan set to enter carmaker elite, if they can reach a deal
summary: Renault and Nissan, along with Mitsubishi, are in talks to form a merger, potentially creating a global automotive pecking order dominated by three mega-players. The alliance, which churns out 10.8 million cars annually, would be second only to Germany's Volkswagen AG and third to Toyota Motor Corp. A holding-company structure would provide equal ownership and board representation for Renault and Nissan, addressing the imbalanced relationship between the two companies. However, Nissan's CEO has rejected the proposal, and a deal would put pressure on other mass-market carmakers to bulk up or risk being left behind.

site_title: Warren Buffett bets on Dubai property as market slump drags on
summary: Warren Buffett's real estate brokerage, Berkshire Hathaway HomeServices, is expanding into Dubai with a new office, led by chairman Ihsan Husein Al Marzouqi and CEO Phil Sheridan. The office aims to grow quickly, tripling its adviser count and opening a second office in Abu Dhabi within a year. Despite Dubai's property market slump, Berkshire Hathaway is investing in the emirate, with the company already operating in Dubai and planning to add Milan, Vienna, and other locations to its network.

site_title: Mall operator Arabian Centres could raise up to US$836m in IPO
summary: Arabian Centres Co, a Saudi Arabian mall operator, plans to raise up to $836 million in its initial public offering (IPO), the country's largest since 2014. The company, owned by Fawaz Alhokair Group, will sell 95 million shares at a price range of 26-33 riyals per share, implying a market capitalization of $4.5-5.7 billion. The IPO aims to deepen Saudi capital markets and boost local entertainment, amid efforts to reduce reliance on oil revenue.

site_title: To fight waste, think out of the (plastic) box
summary: Singapore's food and beverage industry is shifting towards more sustainable packaging, with businesses investing in new-age materials. However, there is no single solution to replace traditional plastics, and infrastructure for recycling remains a challenge. Experts warn that biodegradable plastics may not be a magic answer, and consumers must also change their habits to reduce waste. The industry is exploring innovative business models and technologies, such as reusable containers and seaweed-based packaging, to achieve a more circular economy.

site_title: SAS grounds more than 1,200 flights as pilot strike continues
summary: SAS grounded over 1,200 flights as a pilot strike entered its third day, affecting 280,000 passengers. The strike, which began on Friday, has disrupted 70% of the airline's flights and is estimated to cost SAS 60-80 million Swedish kronor per day. Analysts predict the strike could wipe out the airline's annual profit. Both the airline and unions have agreed to resume negotiations, but no immediate plans for talks have been announced.

site_title: UK markets vulnerable to any BOE hawkish surprise this week
summary: UK markets are vulnerable to a potential hawkish surprise from the Bank of England this week, with investors underpricing the prospect of interest rate hikes. Despite low unemployment and a Brexit extension, money markets do not expect a hike until 2021, making any move by the BOE a potential boost to the pound and benchmark gilts. Analysts predict a possibility of an interest rate hike in August, with six out of 24 economists expecting at least one MPC member to call for tightening.

site_title: Apple kicking out apps that fight iPhone addiction
summary: Apple has removed or restricted over 11 of the 17 most downloaded screen-time and parental-control apps from its App Store, citing that the apps' features were not in line with Apple's own screen-time tracking tools. The move has forced some app makers to shut down, while others are at risk of being taken off the market. Executives from the affected apps claim they were targeted because their features could limit iPhone use and hurt Apple's business. The company's actions have sparked accusations of abusing its dominant position in the market.

site_title: Silver linings in economy amid weak sentiment
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to see a recovery in the second half of 2019, with economists pointing to strong growth in the construction and services sectors. Despite weak manufacturing-related figures, including a 4.8% decline in manufacturing output in March, the economy is expected to turn towards domestic drivers for growth. The Monetary Authority of Singapore's macroeconomic review notes that the decline in exports and manufacturing activities is partially offset by stronger domestic-oriented growth drivers. Economists expect a "half-full" version of the economy, with the worst being behind it, and predict a significantly stronger second half for Singapore.

site_title: Google staff share stories of 'systemic' retaliation
summary: Google employees claim the company has a "systemic" culture of retaliation against critics, with hundreds sharing stories of mistreatment after recent protests over AI for military use, executive misconduct, and contract worker rights. Two organizers, Meredith Whittaker and Claire Stapleton, said they faced punishment after speaking out, including demotions and threats. Google denies the allegations, stating it prohibits retaliation and provides multiple channels for employees to report concerns, but some employees and former employees express frustration with the company's handling of the situation.

site_title: Combing through Hyflux's 'no haircut' plan
summary: Hyflux, a Singapore-based water treatment company, has proposed a new plan to woo investors with a new investor for its Hydrochem engineering, procurement and construction (EPC) business. However, none of the hoped-for S$400m cash injection will go to its perpetual and preference shareholders, who will remain on its books as minority investors. The plan relies on Hyflux's track record of clinching big municipal liquid treatment projects, but observers question its attractiveness and the potential for a white knight to honour its debts.

site_title: US mutual fund adds to Parkway Life Reit stake
summary: US-based mutual fund Cohen & Steers Inc increased its stake in Parkway Life Reit to 7.07% after purchasing 1,356,600 units for S$3,934,140. The company's interest in Parkway Life Reit exceeds the 5% substantial unit holder threshold. This move comes as institutional investors shift towards liquid funds over private equity real estate and infrastructure investments.

site_title: Thousands take to Hong Kong streets to protest new extradition laws
summary: Thousands of people in Hong Kong protested against proposed extradition laws that would allow individuals to be sent to mainland China for trial, citing concerns over erosion of rights and freedoms. The march, which drew several thousand participants, comes as the government defends the move as necessary to address loopholes and promote stability. Critics, including international business elites and rights groups, have voiced opposition, with some warning of further erosion of freedoms under the proposed changes.

site_title: SUTL Enterprise bulks up marina portfolio
summary: SUTL Enterprise, a mainboard-listed company, is expanding its marina portfolio across Asia and the US. The company currently owns ONE°15 Marina Sentosa Cove in Singapore and is developing a 440-berth marina in Johor, Malaysia, with a joint venture partner UEM Sunrise. SUTL's sales team will promote 6,000 club memberships once the sales gallery opens in June. The company aims to bring in "strategic money partners" to share the project's financial load. With a market capitalization of S$50 million and no debt, SUTL plans to acquire more marina assets to grow the ONE°15 Marina brand, aiming for around 20 assets under its belt.

site_title: Ayondo served writ of summons from ex-CEO over S$165,800 claim
summary: Ayondo, a fintech company, has been served a writ of summons and a statement of claim by its former CEO, Robert Lempka, alleging a repudiatory breach of their termination agreement. Lempka claims S$165,800 in unpaid payments, which Ayondo had previously acknowledged in a statutory demand. The company is seeking professional advice on the matter.

site_title: US shooting renews debate on hate crimes and political response
summary: A gunman, identified as 19-year-old John Earnest, opened fire at a synagogue in Poway, California, killing 60-year-old Lori Kaye and wounding three others, including a rabbi who was shot and seriously injured. The attack, which occurred on the final day of Passover, raised concerns about a nationwide rise in anti-Semitism and hate crimes, and President Donald Trump's response to them. Authorities have identified Earnest as having posted anti-Jewish remarks online and claiming responsibility for an earlier arson attack on a mosque. The incident has sparked renewed calls for greater protection of places of worship and a more robust response to hate crimes.

images.alt_text: A rabbi who carried on preaching despite being wounded in the latest deadly shooting at a US synagogue said Sunday that Jews would not be intimidated by the "senseless hate" of anti-semitism.

site_title: Major tech firms oppose police using AI to jail people
summary: A consortium of major tech firms, including Facebook, Google, and Amazon, opposes the use of artificial intelligence algorithms by law enforcement to make decisions about jailing people, citing concerns over bias, opacity, and efficacy. The Partnership on AI report found that current algorithms are often flawed and may lead to incorrect judgments, citing examples such as the COMPAS algorithm, which was found to be twice as likely to incorrectly label black defendants. The group recommends that AI systems be properly regulated before being used in the justice system.

site_title: Singapore closer to becoming Asia's debt restructuring hub
summary: Singapore is closer to becoming an international debt restructuring hub after a landmark ruling by an English court to recognize the city-state's new moratorium law for insolvency and corporate restructuring. The ruling comes after the High Court of England and Wales recognized a reprieve granted by the Singapore High Court to a troubled iron ore trader, H&C S Holdings, as it works on its restructuring plan. This step brings Singapore closer to rivaling London and New York as a major debt restructuring hub.

site_title: Bond traders betting on a Fed rate cut won't be easily dissuaded
summary: Bond traders have strengthened bets on a US Federal Reserve interest rate cut this year, despite reassurances on growth from the FOMC and a stronger-than-expected economic growth reading. Market pricing suggests a rate cut is likely, with traders betting the central bank's benchmark will fall to 2.18% by the end of 2019. The 10-year Treasury yield has fallen to just below 2.50%, driven by weak inflation and a softening US economy.

site_title: New malls set to sprout in 'highly competitive' Bangkok in 2019: report
summary: A report from Edmund Tie & Co Research indicates that new malls are set to sprout in Bangkok in 2019, boosting downtown and mid-town retail occupancy. The new developments, including I Am Chinatown, Sindhorn Village, and Samyan Mitrtown, will add over 50,000 square meters of net lettable area and contribute to a gradual lift in footfall. Average rents are expected to hold steady or dip, with downtown retail occupancy at 94.8% and mid-town occupancy at 90.4%. The report notes, however, that e-commerce poses a challenge in Bangkok's highly competitive retail environment.

site_title: Italian bonds set for relief rally as S&P refrains from downgrade
summary: Italian bonds are expected to experience a relief rally after S&P Global Ratings maintained the country's debt rating, citing "credit features that underpin the BBB rating". The rating agency kept a negative outlook, but this is likely to bring respite to Italy's bond market, where yields have climbed due to concerns over the country's economy and finances. The 10-year bond yield closed at 2.58% on Friday, and investors are awaiting a crucial GDP reading on Tuesday, which could confirm Italy's recession.

site_title: Countries in Opec+ deal sticking to agreement: Putin
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin stated that OPEC+ countries, including Saudi Arabia, are adhering to their agreement to limit oil output. He noted that it's challenging to predict the oil market's future in May when waivers for Iranian crude expire, and Russia is willing to meet China's demands for oil. It's unlikely that Saudi Arabia will abandon the OPEC+ pact, and Russia aims to restore normal oil flows through a major pipeline to eastern Europe within two weeks.

site_title: USD/SGD extreme low volatility could lead to explosive price action
summary: The US dollar against the Singapore dollar has experienced extreme low volatility, with a trading range of 236 pips since the start of 2019, the smallest since July 2014. According to UOB strategist Quek Ser Leang, this rare and untenable situation could lead to a multi-year explosive price action.

images.alt_text: THE extreme low volatility of the US dollar against the Singapore dollar is rare and untenable and could portend a multi-year explosive price action, said a United Overseas Bank strategist.

site_title: Deutsche Bank prepares to stand alone after Commerzbank deal fails
summary: Deutsche Bank's merger talks with Commerzbank have collapsed, leaving the German bank's future uncertain. CEO Christian Sewing acknowledged the risks and restructuring costs associated with the deal, and the bank's credit ratings agency downgraded its outlook. Without a deal, Deutsche Bank faces the mercy of equity and debt markets, with potential for a "debt-driven capital increase." Sewing believes the bank can go it alone in the short term but requires a turnaround in market conditions to achieve its long-term goals.

site_title: Proud Bottas wins as Mercedes sweep home one-two again
summary: Valtteri Bottas won the Azerbaijan Grand Prix, taking the lead in the 2019 drivers' title race with a 1.5-second victory over teammate Lewis Hamilton. This marked Mercedes' fourth consecutive season-opening one-two finish, last achieved by Ferrari in 1952. Bottas' second win of the year came after a dramatic, closely-fought race, and provided redemption after a puncture last year.

site_title: China's vast investment in Africa hits a snag in Congo
summary: China's investment in the Republic of Congo has hit a snag as the country seeks an IMF bailout. Despite China's significant investment in the country, the Congolese government's finances remain unstable, and it has asked the IMF for help. The IMF has placed conditions on its loan, including a restructuring of government debt, which China is not comfortable with. This situation is a cautionary tale for China's Belt and Road Initiative, as the country's massive investments in developing countries may not yield the expected returns.

site_title: Sentosa Cove: Is a rebound in prices on the horizon?
summary: Sentosa Cove private homes may see a rebound in prices due to the announcement of the Draft Master Plan 2019 and the development of the Integrated Resorts. Foreign buyers, who were previously deterred by cooling measures, may return to the market. The area's proximity to the Greater Southern Waterfront and upcoming developments could boost demand. However, buyers are expected to remain discerning, and sales are likely to slow, giving way to opportunities for home acquisition with a longer investment horizon.

site_title: Two Koreas mark Moon-Kim summit anniversary with different tones
summary: North and South Korea marked the one-year anniversary of their leaders' historic summit with different tones, with the North accusing Seoul of failing to take "more active measures" to improve ties. Despite the progress sparked by the summit, little progress has been made on North Korea's nuclear weapons, and Pyongyang has remained largely unresponsive to Seoul's efforts. The North's Committee for the Peaceful Reunification of the Country urged Seoul to re-engage in joint projects and attend the anniversary ceremony, which Seoul held without the North's participation.

site_title: China's iron and steel body warns of over-capacity and shrinking profits
summary: China's Iron and Steel Association warned of over-capacity and shrinking profits due to excess production, sluggish demand, and increased raw material costs. The industry, which reduced 150 million tonnes of steel production over three years, is "far from achieving its tasks" amid Beijing's supply-side reforms. The association urged companies to avoid increasing new capacity, reduce leverage, and restructure "zombie firms" to maintain market stability. It forecast weaker demand for iron and steel, citing structural changes in China's economy and rising raw material costs.

site_title: UOB, SGX ride on China's expansion into Asean
summary: UOB and the Singapore Exchange (SGX) have formed a partnership with the China Chamber of International Commerce (CCOIC) to facilitate Chinese enterprises' expansion into the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean). The partnership aims to tap into Singapore's debt and equity capital markets, as well as its role as a regional treasury hub and global financing centre. UOB and SGX will work with CCOIC to provide assistance and advisory services to over 180,000 Chinese enterprises, supporting their market entry and corporate actions in Asean.

site_title: Money FM podcast: The Hot Seat: Is open source secure enough?
summary: The Money FM podcast "The Hot Seat" discusses the security of open source software, with Dirk-Peter van Leeuwen, senior vice-president of Red Hat in Asia Pacific. Open source has been widely adopted in various applications, but its security is a concern. Van Leeuwen emphasizes that while open source software can be secure, it's not a guarantee. He suggests that businesses should carefully evaluate the security of open source software before implementing it. The conversation highlights the importance of understanding the security implications of open source software in business operations.

site_title: Air India server systems restored after affecting flights worldwide
summary: Air India's server systems were restored after being down for over five hours, affecting flights worldwide. The disruption caused delays for travelers, including Bollywood actress Gul Panag, who complained on Twitter about the airline's systems crashing. The incident occurred just days after India's Jet Airways halted all flight operations due to bank rejections. The restoration of Air India's systems was confirmed by the airline's chairman and managing director, Ashwani Lohani.

images.alt_text: Air India on Saturday said its server system was restored after being down for more than five hours and affecting some flights across the world.

site_title: Best World gets SGX RegCo nod to hold AGM by June 30
summary: Best World International has received approval from the Singapore Exchange's (SGX) regulatory arm to extend its annual general meeting (AGM) by two months to June 30, 2019. The extension is necessary to complete an independent review on the company's franchise model in China, which was ordered by SGX RegCo following a shortseller report that questioned Best World's accounting practices and sales practices in China. The review is expected to be completed by June 2019, and the company will also issue its annual report to shareholders by June 16, 2019.

site_title: Enterprise Singapore, MAS to match start-ups with global investors
summary: Enterprise Singapore and the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) are collaborating to match start-ups with global investors through curated deal-making sessions. Over 100 start-ups networked with 50 investors, corporate funds, and venture capitalists. This partnership aims to strengthen the local start-up ecosystem by adopting a market-led approach, fostering solutions that address market needs in Singapore and the region. The collaboration also includes initiatives to grow talent, provide mentorship, and increase funding opportunities for start-ups.

site_title: USDSGD to fall back within the range near term
summary: The USDSGD currency pair broke its range in October 2018 but appears to be a false break due to a pattern of "support turned resistance" and bullish rejections at the 38.2% Fibonacci level. The Daily Slow Stochastics Oscillator and Average Directional Index (ADX) indicators also suggest an impending reversal. As a result, prices are expected to fall back within the range in the near term, potentially retesting the 23.6% Fibonacci level at 1.3554, before potentially reaching the bottom of the range at 1.3456.

site_title: Canadian dollar rises as US growth composition weighs on greenback
summary: The Canadian dollar strengthened against the US dollar, rising 0.2% to 1.3458 to the greenback, following data showing US economic growth is likely to slow due to temporary factors. The US dollar fell against a basket of currencies and oil prices retreated after US President Trump pressured OPEC to raise crude production. Speculators cut their bearish bets on the Canadian dollar, and Bank of Canada governor Stephen Poloz hinted at potential future interest rate hikes, contributing to the loonie's gains.

site_title: Bayer shareholders vote against board after Monsanto merger
summary: Bayer shareholders overwhelmingly voted against the management board at the company's annual general meeting, rejecting the decision to buy US seeds and pesticides maker Monsanto. The vote resulted in 55.5% of shareholders opposing the board, a significant drop from 97% support last year. This move comes amid tension over the Monsanto acquisition, which has been a major point of contention for shareholders and investors.

site_title: HSBC braces for cost and job cuts as CEO blasts top managers
summary: HSBC Holdings plc has begun a cost review that may lead to job cuts, following a public rebuke of top executives by CEO John Flint for missing revenue and cost targets. Flint criticized leadership for "incompetence" and discussed their inability to control expenses during a global conference in Hong Kong. The move is part of a broader effort to address the bank's financial performance.

images.alt_text: Mr Flint (above) has pledged to keep a keener eye on expenses after a disappointing Q4 capped his first year in charge of HSBC.

site_title: Thakral sees equal investment in Australia, Japan real estate over time
summary: Thakral Corp expects to invest equally in Australian and Japan real estate over the long term, shifting focus from China. The firm plans to sell its Chinese real estate investments when prices are reached, with proceeds invested in Japan. Thakral's board prioritizes investments in GemLife retirement resorts in Australia and Japan, which are expected to provide strong recurring income. The Australian market appears sluggish, prompting the firm to concentrate on completing its retirement resort projects.

site_title: Spotlight on slew of economic data releases, earnings
summary: The Singapore market is set for a shortened week of trading, with the Labour Day holiday on Wednesday. Despite this, several key economic data releases and earnings reports are expected to influence market sentiment. The US first-quarter growth estimate of 3.2% and better-than-expected corporate earnings are seen as positive for regional markets. In Asia, China's April manufacturing PMI figures, Hong Kong and Malaysia's trade data, and South Korea's consumer price index data will be released, with investors watching for signs of stability in the world's second-largest economy amidst US-China trade tensions.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary:
The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for the week ending April 28, 2019, provides an overview of the tanker and dry bulk market. Key highlights include:
