site_title: US adds another Chinese e-commerce site to 'notorious' list for IP protection
summary: The US Trade Representative has added Pinduoduo.com, China's third-largest e-commerce platform, to its "notorious markets" list for intellectual property rights concerns. The move comes as the US and China engage in trade negotiations. Pinduoduo.com joins Alibaba Group's taobao.com on the list, despite the parent company taking steps to curb copyright infringement. The US also bumped Saudi Arabia up to priority due to an illicit service for pirated content. The report highlights the need for bilateral engagement to address intellectual property rights concerns in these countries.

site_title: US: Nasdaq hits record high at open on strong tech earnings
summary: The Nasdaq index reached a record high at the open on Thursday, driven by strong earnings from Facebook and Microsoft. The Nasdaq gained 48.84 points, or 0.60%, to 8,150.85, while the Dow Jones fell 170.68 points, or 0.64%, and the S&P 500 opened higher by 1.74 points. The strong tech earnings outweighed a slump in 3M, limiting gains on the S&P.

site_title: Union Gas names Teo Hark Piang as new CEO
summary: Union Gas Holdings has named Teo Hark Piang as its new CEO, following his appointment as executive director and director of sales last November. Mr. Teo, 41, is the son of Union Gas' non-executive chairman and controlling shareholder, Teo Kiang Ang. Despite previous investigations and penalties for omitting income items and not declaring car benefits, Mr. Teo holds a 12.55% shareholding interest in Union Energy Corporation, a gas manufacturer that serves different customers than Union Gas.

site_title: Capitol Theatre Comes Alive With Cuban Music Legend
summary: Omara Portuondo, a 88-year-old Cuban music legend, is set to perform at the Capitol Theatre in Singapore on May 22 as part of her final international tour, "Omara Es Cuba - The Last Kiss". The intimate show will feature a stripped-down setup with a small combo of musicians, showcasing Portuondo's renditions of boleros and other styles. Tickets are available, with prices starting at S$78 for "super early birds", and VIP packages are also available. The show is presented by Singjazz & Vamp Productions and will be followed by a complimentary after-party hosted by the Havana Social Club.

site_title: Black Gold
summary: Royal Belgian Caviar (RBC) challenges the notion that expensive caviar is of the highest quality. The company produces high-quality caviar from farmed sturgeon, adhering to traditional methods and without pasteurization. RBC's caviar is available in various grades, including Gold Label Siberian and Beluga, with distinctive pearlescent gleam and rounder eggs. The company's small production scale allows for focus on quality, with caviar packed directly into tins according to specifications. A blind taste test reveals RBC's caviar has a longer finish and satisfying burst compared to other brands.

site_title: Kronor dips as Sweden joins global wave of monetary dovishness
summary: Sweden's central bank, the Riksbank, extended its bond-purchase program and signaled interest rates will stay below zero for longer, causing the kronor to plunge over 1% against the euro. This move echoes global peers' dovish policy pullbacks amid heightened economic pessimism. The International Monetary Fund cut its world growth outlook, driving down currencies, including the Australian and Canadian dollars. The kronor was the worst performer among Group-of-10 currencies, with policymakers now expecting a potential hike towards the end of the year or early next year.

site_title: US core capital goods orders post biggest gain in eight months
summary: US core capital goods orders surged 1.3% in March, the largest gain in eight months, driven by a jump in demand for computers and electronic products. Shipments, however, slipped 0.2% due to delayed impacts from oil price drops and tax bill depreciation. This suggests a pickup in business spending in the months ahead and some stabilization in manufacturing activity.

site_title: Another US hospitality trust looks to list on SGX
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust, a US hospitality stapled group, has lodged a preliminary prospectus to list its 18 full-service hotel properties, valued at about US$1.27 billion, on the Singapore Exchange. The offering price range is between US$0.80 and US$0.81 per stapled security, with projected yield of 8.1-8.2% for 2020. The trust is backed by Urban Commons, a privately-held real estate investment and development firm, and has a significant pipeline of US hospitality assets.

site_title: Joe Biden announces 2020 presidential run
summary: Former US Vice President Joe Biden announced his candidacy for the 2020 Democratic presidential nomination, framing the race as a battle for the nation's soul. He plans to focus on rebuilding and expanding the middle class and bridging the country's partisan divide. Biden, 76, is positioning himself as the only candidate who can defeat President Donald Trump.

site_title: Japanese court approves Ghosn's release on bail, rejects prosecutors' appeal
summary: A Tokyo District Court has rejected a prosecutors' appeal against the release on bail of former Nissan Motor Chairman Carlos Ghosn, allowing him to leave a Japanese jail. Ghosn was initially approved for a 500 million yen ($6.09 million) bail, which he posted and was awaiting the appeal decision. The court's decision upholds Ghosn's release, with no further details on the appeal's outcome provided.

site_title: Venture's Q1 earnings up 8.6% despite pricing pressures
summary: VENTURE Corporation reported a 8.6% increase in Q1 net profit to S$90.9 million, despite pricing pressures and intense competition. Revenue rose 8.5% to S$928.8 million, driven by broad-based growth across its technology domains. The company attributed its sustained profitability to its engineering capabilities, lean initiatives, and cost management. It remains cautious about macro-economic factors and expects near-term volatility, but expects growth from new customers and product launches in the second half of 2019.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% as investors weighed market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions. US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats, while European stocks declined due to bank and healthcare sector drag. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss in the second half. London's Heathrow Airport considered increasing fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case involving 285 trillion rupiah.

site_title: Another US hospitality trust, Eagle Hospitality Trust, eyes SGX listing
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust, a US hospitality trust, has lodged a preliminary prospectus to list its portfolio of 18 US hotel assets on the Singapore Exchange, with an offering price range of US$0.80 to US$0.81 per stapled security. The trust, backed by Urban Commons, has a total valuation of US$1.27 billion and projects a yield of 8.1-8.2% for 2020. If successful, it will be the second US hospitality trust to list on the mainboard, following ARA US Hospitality Trust.

site_title: First Sponsor's Q1 profit up 39% to S$23.8m
summary: First Sponsor Group, a Singapore-based property developer, reported a 39% increase in first-quarter net profit to S$23.8 million, driven by a strong showing in its property financing business segment. Revenue fell 5.2% to S$45.3 million, mainly due to a drop in property sales and rental income, but was partially offset by increases in property financing and hotel operations. The company aims to acquire a 100% equity interest in a 76,570 square meter mixed-use development site in Chang'an, Dongguan, and is undertaking a rights and bonus issue to raise up to S$399.3 million.

site_title: Britain's Hunt says next Conservative leader must believe in Brexit
summary: British Foreign Minister Jeremy Hunt said the next leader of the governing Conservative Party should believe in Brexit, as the party struggles to rally behind Prime Minister Theresa May's deal. Despite her deal being rejected in parliament three times, Hunt, a Remain backer, stated that the next leader needs to support Brexit. Hunt also declined to confirm whether he would run for the leadership, saying "wait and see." The party's efforts to pass May's deal have been unsuccessful, and her departure from office is being pushed forward.

site_title: US jobless claims rise most since 2017, topping estimates
summary: US jobless claims rose 37,000 to 230,000 in the week ended April 20, the most since late 2017, surpassing the highest estimate. This marks a reversal of a five-week decline streak, indicating a still robust labor market. The four-week average increased to 206,000, while continuing claims rose slightly to 1.655 million. Despite this increase, the unemployment rate among eligible workers remained at 1.2%.

site_title: UBS Q1 results beat expectations following CEO's dire outlook
summary: UBS Group reported a net income of US$1.14 billion in its first quarter, beating analysts' estimates, after a market environment improvement at the end of March and into April. Wealth management attracted over US$22 billion in new money, with the largest Swiss bank exceeding expectations following a dire outlook from CEO Sergio Ermotti last month.

images.alt_text: Mr Ermotti has been hit by a slew of bad news that has left the stock trailing its main rivals.

site_title: RBS starts hunt for new chief executive as McEwan steps down
summary: Royal Bank of Scotland Group Plc is searching for a new CEO as Ross McEwan steps down within a year. McEwan, 61, joined RBS in 2013 and has overseen a major UK corporate turnaround. The bank has retained search firm Spencer Stuart to find a replacement, with speculation focusing on Alison Rose, a lifer at RBS and its predecessor firms. A new CEO will continue the bank's strategy of slashing costs and finding growth in the UK market, which McEwan has described as very competitive.

site_title: UBS seeks more deals among billionaires through new US venture
summary: UBS is launching a new US venture that merges its wealth-management unit and investment bank to capture more deals and trading activity among ultra-rich clients. The move aims to spur growth, particularly in ultra-high net worth, middle market institutions, and public finance businesses. Revenue at the investment bank fell 27% in the latest quarter, while global wealth management was down 9%. Despite disappointing results, the unit attracted $22.3 billion of net new money from wealthy clients in the Asia Pacific region. The new venture will be led by Mark Sanborn, Dylan Roy, and Reinhardt Olsen.

site_title: John Cheng
summary: Cheng Yew Heng, Singapore's oldest and only sugar manufacturer, has been producing rock sugar, red and black jaggery sugar since the 1950s. The company, run by third-generation owners John Cheng and his brother Liang Kheng, has an annual revenue of over S$100 million. Cheng Yew Heng has modernized its operations, achieving HACCP and ISO22000 certifications for food safety, and introduced automation to improve efficiency. The company also launched a food innovation ecosystem, Innovate 360, to help startups commercialize their ideas. Despite the challenges of the sugar industry, including the "war against sugar," the company remains committed to educating consumers and promoting moderation.

site_title: Scared Muslim refugees flee Sri Lankan homes over attack fears
summary: Hundreds of Muslim refugees in Sri Lanka, primarily from Pakistan, Afghanistan, Yemen, and Iran, have fled their homes in western Sri Lanka after facing intimidation following the Easter bombings. At least 359 people died in the attacks, with many more displaced and seeking shelter in mosques and police stations. The community, which has long faced tension and harassment, fears a backlash and is calling for unity and calm. Sri Lankan authorities have condemned the bombings, which were carried out by local Islamist group National Thowheeth Jama'ath with foreign militant support.

site_title: High Court grants Hyflux 1-month extension of debt moratorium to May 24
summary: The High Court has granted Hyflux a one-month extension of its debt moratorium to May 24, despite High Court Justice Aedit Abdullah's warning to keep the company on a "short leash". Hyflux has been in restructuring limbo for almost a year and has signed a non-binding letter of intent with a Middle Eastern investor for a possible S$400 million injection to support equity and working capital. The company will use the extra time to find a rescue investor.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 2.33 points to 1,635.68. The market saw 3.6 billion lots worth RM2.5 billion in volume, with losers beating gainers 464 to 407.

site_title: SGX, NSE agree on way forward for Nifty dispute
summary: SGX and India's National Stock Exchange (NSE) have agreed on a way forward for the Nifty dispute, allowing both exchanges to continue serving the market. The contract, which involves NSE providing data to SGX for offshore investors, was at the center of the dispute. NSE had ended agreements to provide market data to overseas exchanges, affecting the trading of offshore derivatives, including SGX's Nifty 50 Index Futures. The proposal is now with regulators, with SGX CEO Loh Boon Chye stating that both exchanges are in a good position.

site_title: Hong Leong Finance Q1 net profit up 1.5% to S$26.2m
summary: Hong Leong Finance reported a 1.5% increase in Q1 net profit to S$26.2 million, driven by loan growth and higher average loan yields. Revenue rose 18.4% to S$95.2 million, while interest expense increased 42.3% due to higher funding costs. Allowances for loans were net recoveries of S$349,000, and the company maintained adequate loss allowances. The group will continue to practice prudence in lending activities amid slowing economic growth and contraction in manufacturing.

site_title: Daniel Craig makes his final outing as James Bond
summary: Daniel Craig, 51, is set to make his final outing as James Bond in a movie due for release early next year, 14 years after "Casino Royale" in 2006. Craig is the longest-serving James Bond actor, with five movies under his belt. The casting of Craig was initially met with doubts due to his blonde hair, but he went on to become a beloved Bond.

site_title: 3M to cut 2,000 jobs globally, lowers 2019 profit outlook
summary: US manufacturing conglomerate 3M Co announced it will lay off 2,000 workers globally as part of restructuring efforts. The job cuts are expected to result in an estimated annual pre-tax savings of $225-250 million. 3M lowered its 2019 earnings forecast to $9.25-$9.75 per share, citing worsening performance in key markets. The company aims to restructure its businesses into four operating units from five.

site_title: Forest fires blight Europe amid drought fears
summary: Forest fires are sweeping across Europe, fueled by drought conditions, with Germany, Sweden, Norway, and the Czech Republic among the worst-affected countries. Experts warn of a repeat of 2018's drought, which led to crop losses of up to 80% and 93 million euros in aid. The EU's agriculture commissioner has promised support to farmers, while Scandinavian countries scramble to tackle the blazes, with some areas resembling desert landscapes. Rain is forecast for the coming days, but its impact is uncertain, leaving many fearing a devastating harvest season.

site_title: Asean region gets more attractive for global factories
summary: The Asean region, particularly Malaysia, Vietnam, and Indonesia, has become more attractive for global factories due to its low production costs. China remains the most cost-competitive manufacturing site, but the US-China trade tension has prompted companies to diversify to other low-cost alternatives. Asian countries, including Singapore, are investing in technology and innovation to remain competitive. However, concerns over intellectual property issues in the region remain, and countries in North America and Europe are expected to continue thriving as manufacturing bases.

site_title: China seeks to allay fears over Belt and Road debt risks
summary: China aims to address concerns over the Belt and Road initiative, which has been criticized for creating unsustainable debt for partner nations. Finance Minister Liu Kun announced a debt sustainability framework to prevent and resolve debt risks, and China will rely on commercial funds and follow market principles for Belt and Road financing. The framework will also promote green growth and respect global debt goals. The initiative will focus on quality and multilateralism, and visiting leaders will pledge to undertake higher-quality projects that hire local staff and respond to recipient countries' needs.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks wobble on GDP shock; won hits lowest since 2017
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index closed down 0.48% at 2,190.50 points, wiping out gains from Samsung Electronics' investment plan. The won hit its lowest since 2017 at 1,160.5 per dollar after GDP data showed the country's economy suffered its worst quarter since the global financial crisis. Foreigners sold 16.5 billion won worth of shares, while shares of SK Hynix rose 2.2% after the chipmaker expressed confidence in memory chips demand recovery.

site_title: Sri Lanka's top defence official quits: ministry source
summary: Sri Lanka's top defence official, Hemasiri Fernando, has resigned, taking responsibility for security failures that led to nearly 360 deaths in suicide bombings. Fernando submitted a letter of resignation to President Maithripala Sirisena, acknowledging his role in the failures. The move comes after a series of bombings in Sri Lanka in April. Fernando's resignation is seen as an effort to restore public trust and allow the president to appoint a new official.

site_title: Starhill Global Reit posts 0.9% rise in Q3 DPU
summary: Starhill Global Reit reported a 0.9% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.1 Singapore cents for the third quarter, driven by lower tax expenses and distributable income retained. Revenue declined 0.9% year-on-year to S$51.3 million, while net property income (NPI) fell 1.8%. The Reit's Singapore portfolio, comprising Wisma Atria and Ngee Ann City, contributed 62% of total revenue. Starhill's annualised distribution yield is 6.11%, with unitholders expected to receive their third-quarter DPU on May 30.

site_title: China says navy warned off French warship in Taiwan Strait
summary: China's navy warned off a French warship that entered the Taiwan Strait on April 7, prompting Beijing to lodge an official protest. The French frigate, Vendemiaire, was expected to participate in a naval parade but failed to show up without explanation. China views Taiwan as its territory and has been increasing diplomatic and military pressure on the island since 2016. The incident is rare for a European power to enter the Taiwan Strait, and China has traditionally been the country to defy US claims in the area.

site_title: Pricing pressure, tariffs dent Volvo's quarterly profit
summary: Volvo's quarterly profit fell 19.3% to 2.92 billion Swedish crowns due to pricing pressure and higher tariffs from the US-China trade war. The company's operating margin declined to 4.6% from 6.4% a year ago. Volvo has revised its global production plans to mitigate the impact of tariffs and expects market conditions to continue putting pressure on margins. CEO Hakan Samuelsson attributed the decline to higher tariffs and increased price pressure in many markets.

site_title: Biden announces 2020 run for White House
summary: US President Joe Biden announced his candidacy for the 2020 White House election on April 25, 2019, positioning himself as a frontrunner among Democratic candidates. Biden, a 76-year-old former Vice President, cited concerns over President Donald Trump's impact on the nation's character and democracy. He led early polls with 29.3% support, ahead of Senator Bernie Sanders, and is seen as a comforting figure for American voters. Biden's announcement comes after months of campaign planning, despite recent controversy over his tactile style.

summary:

Other news included reactions to US tariffs on Vietnam, asset seizures in Malaysia, and China's slowing GDP growth.

site_title: Singapore shares drop 0.4%, weighed by global growth concerns
summary: The Singapore stock market closed down 0.36% on Thursday, following a brief rally in US markets earlier in the week. Concerns about global growth weighed on the market, with a decline in business sentiment in Germany and weak growth data from South Korea. Key indices in the US struggled to sustain their rally, closing lower overnight. AEM Holdings surged 10.48% after announcing strong sales orders, while Suntec Real Estate Investment Trust fell 2.65%. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,350.28.

site_title: BOJ commits to very low rates at least through spring 2020, keeps policy steady
summary: The Bank of Japan maintained its monetary policy steady, committing to keep interest rates very low at least through spring 2020. The BOJ kept its short-term interest rate target at minus 0.1% and pledged to guide 10-year government bond yields around zero%. This decision aims to support the country's economy, which has been struggling with deflation. The move was widely expected and marks a continuation of the BOJ's expansionary monetary policy.

site_title: SGX Q3 net profit slips 0.8% to S$99.7m
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) reported a 0.8% decline in its Q3 net profit to S$99.7 million, despite a 2.9% increase in operating revenue to S$228.8 million. The derivatives business continued to drive growth, with daily average volume exceeding one million contracts for the first time. The Board of Directors declared an interim dividend of 7.5 cents per share, payable on May 13. CEO Loh Boon Chye attributed the performance to strong institutional demand and the expansion of derivatives products.

site_title: Putin says US guarantees unlikely to prompt N.Korea to de-nuclearise
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin stated that US guarantees would unlikely prompt North Korea to de-nuclearize, suggesting that international guarantees would be necessary. Putin emphasized that North Korea only needs security guarantees, not just from the US, but from all nations involved. He expressed confidence in the possibility of a deal on Pyongyang's nuclear program, but noted that progress would require building trust step-by-step. The talks between Putin and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un aimed to strengthen Russia's diplomatic credentials as a global player.

site_title: Hyflux receives letter of intent for S$400m investment; banks seeking judicial management
summary: Hyflux has received a non-binding letter of intent from a Middle Eastern investor for a potential S$400 million investment to support its equity and working capital. The company is also engaging with other potential investors with "synergy" with its business. Meanwhile, a group of unsecured banks is seeking judicial management for Hyflux and Hydrochem, citing concerns over the debt moratoriums. The banks' application comes as Hyflux's court-sanctioned protection from creditors expires on April 30.

site_title: Wirecard confirms profit target after publishing delayed results
summary: Wirecard confirmed its 2019 profit target of €740-800 million, despite delayed annual results due to investigations into allegations of fraud and false accounting at its Singapore office. The German payments company reported Ebitda between €740 million and €800 million for the year. This confirmation comes as Wirecard continues to face scrutiny over its business practices.

site_title: Corruption cases up slightly in 2018; private sector still dominates: CPIB
summary: The Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau (CPIB) reported a slight increase in corruption cases in 2018, with 107 new cases registered, up from 103 in 2017. The private sector accounted for 88% of cases, with construction activities and building maintenance work being the main areas of concern. A total of 112 people were charged in court, with 107 from the private sector. The CPIB emphasized that enforcement alone cannot overcome corruption and will work with industry partners and the community to tackle the issue more effectively.

site_title: Sri Lanka Catholic churches halt public services over security fears
summary: Sri Lanka's Catholic churches suspended all public services over security fears following the Easter bombings that killed nearly 360 people. Thousands of troops joined the hunt for suspects, with 16 more arrests made overnight. The government faces pressure over its failure to act on intelligence warnings about possible bombings, and recriminations have flown since the attacks. The president has asked for the police chief and top defence ministry bureaucrat to step down, but neither has done so yet.

site_title: ECB needs year of two halves with growth pickup elusive for now
summary: European Central Bank policymakers are optimistic about a potential economic recovery in the second half of 2019, despite a global slowdown and ongoing trade tensions. The ECB is looking for a year of two halves, with a decline in manufacturing and trade tensions giving way to an improvement later in the year. While low inflation poses a challenge, real pay increases and employment growth are supporting consumer demand. A potential trade deal between the US and China, as well as improved industrial production figures, could be key triggers for the recovery.

site_title: Europe: Stocks slip at open
summary: European stock markets declined at the opening on April 25, 2019, with the FTSE 100 index falling 0.2% to 7,457.21 points. The eurozone's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 indices also dropped 0.1% each. The declines were attributed to bank and healthcare sector losses. The US-EU trade tensions were a focus, with investors awaiting updates on the ongoing trade talks.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai stocks end sharply lower
summary: Hong Kong shares plummeted 0.86% to 29,549.80, while Shanghai dropped 2.43% to 3,123.83, amid concerns about China easing monetary measures. The Shenzhen Composite Index also fell 3.41%. The sell-off follows a similar decline on Wall Street and across Asia, with traders brushing off new US President Trump's threats to extend the stock rally.

site_title: Venture Corp Q1 net profit up 8.6% despite pricing pressures
summary: VENTURE Corporation reported a 8.6% increase in Q1 net profit to S$90.9 million, driven by broad-based growth across its technology domains and solid execution of customer programmes. Revenue rose 8.5% to S$928.8 million. The company attributed its sustained profitability to its differentiated engineering capabilities, lean initiatives, and astute cost management.

site_title: A Banksy rat? Tokyo city displays work 'by famous artist'
summary: Tokyo displayed a drawing believed to be the work of Banksy, featuring a rat holding an umbrella, after its authenticity was confirmed by the city's mayor. The drawing, which was spotted near a monorail station, is one of Banksy's most famous artworks. The city's public safety bureau had known about the graffiti for a long time but only realized its potential in December. The drawing is now on display at a metropolitan government building, with some viewers hoping it is genuine. The city's authenticity has not been confirmed yet, but it has been decided to keep it on display due to public interest.

site_title: Britain blocks Sainsbury's and Asda supermarket merger
summary: Britain's Competition and Markets Authority has blocked the proposed merger between Sainsbury's and Asda, citing that it would lead to higher prices and less choice for consumers. The regulator found that the deal would result in reduced competition, particularly in the online market and petrol stations. As a result, Sainsbury's and Asda have scrapped their proposed deal. The CMA's decision is seen as a victory for consumers, who would have faced increased prices and reduced options under the merger. The regulator's ruling is in line with its previous stance on supermarket mergers.

site_title: Hot stock: AEM Holdings up 9.5% after news of higher sales orders
summary: AEM Holdings' shares surged 9.52% to S$1.15 after announcing higher-than-expected sales orders of S$209 million for fiscal 2019, surpassing previous months' announcements. The company revised its revenue range upwards to S$225-250 million and capital expenditure range to S$4-7 million. Analysts forecast a revenue of S$193 million for FY2019, but Maybank Kim Eng sees upside potential from continued strong order wins and upcoming production ramp-ups for key customers, including Huawei and a US$235 billion chipmaker.

site_title: Shaving milliseconds off currency trades could make Singapore billions
summary: Singapore aims to shave milliseconds off currency trades to capture a bigger slice of the US$5.1 trillion-a-day foreign exchange market. The country is offering grants and tax incentives to encourage major foreign-exchange players to build systems in Singapore, reducing the sub-second delay caused by routing trades via Tokyo or London. The goal is to narrow the gap with other trading hubs, such as the UK and US, and tap the region's US$22 trillion wealth market. Singapore's efforts are part of a long game to expand the country's currency-trading industry and become a major hub for foreign exchange.

site_title: The BMW M850i coupe is the unicorn you've been waiting for
summary: BMW's M850i coupe is a unique sports car with a sleek design, featuring a smoothly sloped fastback roofline and aggressively angled headlights. It resembles a Ford Mustang but with a more exotic and luxurious feel. The M850i boasts a price tag of $112,895, making it a high-end option in the US market. Its performance capabilities are not detailed in the article, but its design and luxury features set it apart from more standard sports cars.

images.alt_text: Both are two-door sports cars with smoothly sloped fastback rooflines and punchy, softly rounded front ends.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Thursday afternoon at 3,358.97, down 0.1% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Thursday, edging down 0.1% to 3,358.97. The Straits Times Index fell 3.46 points, with 161 losers outweighing 141 gainers. AEM Holdings rose 9.5%, while Suntec Real Estate Investment Trust slipped 2.1%. United Overseas Bank and DBS Group Holdings also fell 0.2% each. Trading volume was 532.2 million securities worth S$491.6 million.

site_title: The Place Holdings narrows Q1 loss to S$334,000
summary: The Place Holdings reported a narrowed Q1 net loss of S$334,000, down from S$750,000 a year ago. Revenue grew 37% to S$404,000, driven by management of cultural events and activities. The group added a physical presence in Singapore to support tourism-related business activities. The Place Holdings shares closed flat at S$0.031, while loss per share remained unchanged at 0.01 Singapore cent.

site_title: Bytedance gets reprieve as Indian court lifts ban on TikTok app
summary: A Madras High Court in India has lifted a ban on the popular TikTok app, allowing Bytedance to restore access to users. The ban was imposed due to concerns over exposure to pornography and disturbing content. The court has ordered TikTok to update its privacy protection norms and address any complaints within 3-36 hours. The decision is seen as a relief for start-ups hoping to tap into India's growing smartphone market and dispels concerns about India's oversight on tech companies.

site_title: LG Electronics to shut South Korean phone factory, move production to Vietnam
summary: LG Electronics plans to shut its South Korean smartphone factory and shift production to Vietnam, joining global rivals in moving manufacturing to low-cost locations due to declining global demand. The move aims to boost Vietnam's production capacity by 83% to 11 million handsets. This decision follows similar steps by Samsung Electronics and Sony Corp, which are also ceasing operations at mobile phone plants in China and Beijing, respectively.

site_title: Scoot starts sales for flights to four new cities in China
summary: Scoot, the low-cost arm of Singapore Airlines, has launched ticket sales for flights to four new cities in China: Wuhan, Changsha, Kunming, and Fuzhou. One-way fares start from S$79 to Wuhan and S$99 to the other three cities. Flights to Wuhan will begin on May 22, while those to Fuzhou will start on July 5. Frequency of flights to these destinations will increase in the coming months, with more than 100 flights to China each week, bringing the total number of mainland Chinese cities covered to 23.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher on relief over BOJ policy
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Thursday, reversing early losses, as investors were relieved over the Bank of Japan's pledge to maintain its super-loose monetary policy for another year. The Nikkei 225 index gained 0.48%, while the Topix index rose 0.51%. This move reversed early losses, with investors reacting positively to the central bank's decision.

site_title: Thailand set to be SE Asia's hottest IPO market with US$5b of planned floats in 2H2019
summary: Thailand is expected to become Southeast Asia's hottest IPO market in 2H2019, with over $5 billion in planned floats. The country's stable economic growth, tourism boost, and low interest rates are driving investors to allocate money for equities. Key listings include PTT Oil & Retail, Charoen Sirivadhanabhakdi's hospitality business, and Central Group's retail arm, which could raise $2 billion to $5 billion. Despite short-term market volatility, Thailand's benchmark index is trading near its five-year historical PE ratio, indicating a favorable environment for IPOs.

site_title: Peru to sign MOU to join China's Belt and Road club in coming days: Chinese ambassador
summary: Peru plans to sign a memorandum of understanding to join China's Belt and Road initiative in coming days, despite US warnings. This move makes Peru one of a few Latin American nations to formally join the initiative. Vice President Mercedes Araoz stated that Peru's relationship with the US remains strong, but the country is broadening its ties with China through this cooperation model. This decision comes after Chile also joined the initiative, and follows China's efforts to deepen ties in a resource-rich region.

site_title: SoftBank invests US$125m in Alphabet venture to put cellphone antennas in the sky
summary: SoftBank is investing US$125 million in Alphabet's Loon, a spinoff working on flying cellphone antennas high in the atmosphere to provide internet in underserved areas. Loon, a balloon-based system, and SoftBank's HAPSMobile, a drone-based system, aim to provide high-speed internet where ground-based towers are unreachable. This investment supports Loon's efforts to launch its service in Japan and other countries.

site_title: France's Macron to unveil long-awaited reform plan
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron will unveil his long-awaited reform plan Thursday, six months after the emergence of the anti-government "yellow vest" movement. The plan includes tax cuts for the middle classes and re-evaluation of small pensions, as well as the closure of the ENA administration school. Macron faces a challenging task in defending his response to the crisis, with a poll showing only one in four believed the situation has improved. The stakes are high, with Macron's popularity rating stuck under 30% and his ambition to modernize France and lead Europe at stake.

images.alt_text: French President Emmanuel Macron will unveil his long-awaited response to nearly six months of humiliating street protests Thursday as he lays out reform plans that could prove decisive for his political future.

site_title: Japan court grants US$4.5m bail to Carlos Ghosn
summary: A Japanese court granted Carlos Ghosn bail of $6.1 million, allowing the former Nissan boss to prepare his defense against multiple charges of financial misconduct. Ghosn, 65, faces four charges, including concealing his salary and syphoning off Nissan funds for personal use. He denies all charges and has been detained under "cruel and unjust conditions." The court's decision may be appealed, delaying his release, but Ghosn could walk out of his detention center as early as Thursday.

site_title: World's biggest money-printer maker makes push into beverage carton printing
summary: Koenig & Bauer, a 201-year-old German company, is expanding into the beverage carton printing market with its super-fast machines. The company, which dominates the market for printing on three-piece food cans, recently secured two customers for its machines, which offer high output and reduced changeover times. This move aims to accelerate the company's presence in the flexible packaging printing segment, where it has a 9% market share. Despite the rise of digital payments, Koenig & Bauer's banknote printing machines business remains strong, with a 90% market share in high-margin security printing.

site_title: E-payments pave the way for a closer-knit Asean: Report
summary: A report by Standard Chartered highlights the potential of e-payments to improve regional transactions in Southeast Asia. Real-time payments, mobile wallets, and digitization of cash and cheques could simplify transactions and optimize working capital. The implementation of instant payments across markets in Asean makes fund transfers faster and more efficient. Analysts predict that linking up instant payment systems will drive Asean integration and create opportunities for businesses and consumers. However, cash remains the most popular payment method, with over 70% of transactions in Indonesia and the Philippines.

site_title: Tropical forest the size of England destroyed in 2018: report
summary: In 2018, the world lost an area of tropical forest nearly the size of England, with a total loss of 12 million hectares, according to a report from Global Forest Watch. The destruction rate is equivalent to 30 football fields disappearing every minute, with the equivalent of 36,000 square kilometers of pristine primary rainforest lost. The main drivers of deforestation are the livestock industry and large-scale commodity agriculture, with Brazil accounting for a quarter of the total loss. The report warns that the health of the planet is at stake, and urgent action is needed to mitigate the impacts of climate change.

site_title: China's island cities: Treasure or trouble for Asia?
summary: China is building a high-rise city, Port City, in Sri Lanka, doubling Colombo's size, as part of its Belt and Road Initiative. This project, along with others in Malaysia and the Philippines, is part of a trillion-dollar infrastructure program viewed with suspicion by countries like India and the US. The initiative has divided opinion within the EU, sparking alarm bells in Asia and beyond. The projects are expected to have significant economic and geopolitical implications, raising concerns about China's growing global influence and potential impact on regional stability.

site_title: Asian shares dip; euro weighed by sagging German business morale
summary: Asian shares slipped 0.2% on Thursday as a decline in German business morale and US Treasury yields weighed on markets, while oil prices pulled back from six-month highs. The euro hit a 22-month low against the US dollar, and investors are awaiting US GDP data for the first quarter. Despite recent rallies in global equities, hopes that the Chinese economy is bottoming out may not be enough to sustain the rally, according to analysts.

site_title: Manulife US Reit Q1 DPU up 22.8% to 1.51 US cents
summary: MANULIFE US Real Estate Investment Trust (Reit) reported a 22.8% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) for the first quarter, reaching 1.51 US cents, driven by strong leasing momentum and increases in the portfolio's occupancy. Net property income rose 27.7% to US$25.1 million, while gross revenue increased 28.5% to US$40.0 million. The Reit's portfolio occupancy stood at 97.4% as of March 31, 2019, with a weighted average lease expiry of six years.

site_title: China pledges to build 'open' financing system for Belt and Road
summary: China has pledged to build an "open" financing system for its Belt and Road infrastructure network, responding to criticism of saddling developing countries with unrepayable loans. The People's Bank of China will work with international counterparts to create a market-oriented financing system, with private sector financing expected to be the main force. Chinese financial institutions have provided over $440 billion for Belt and Road construction, with government funding to play a guiding role. The move aims to improve transparency and oversight, as Beijing seeks to polish the image of its signature foreign policy amid debt concerns.

site_title: Cache Logistics Trust posts marginal rise in Q1 DPU to 1.513 Singapore cents
summary: Cache Logistics Trust reported a 0.4% increase in Q1 DPU to 1.513 Singapore cents, driven by higher contributions from its Australia portfolio and the conversion of CWT Commodity Hub. Gross revenue rose 6.2% to S$30.8 million and net property income increased 4% to S$23.8 million. The Reit acquired a single-storey warehouse in Australia for A$41.2 million, and its occupancy rate remained at 94.8%.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei 225 index edges down at open with eyes on BoJ
summary: Japan's Nikkei 225 index opened lower on Thursday, down 0.11% or 23.98 points at 22,176.02, ahead of the Bank of Japan's policy meeting. The broader Topix index rose 0.01% to 1,612.20. Investors await the BoJ's decision on monetary policy, which may impact Tokyo's benchmark index.

site_title: Rents, prices of Singapore industrial space stable in Q1: JTC
summary: Singapore's industrial space rental prices and prices remained stable in Q1 2019, according to JTC Corp. The occupancy rate of the overall industrial property market was flat, at 89.3%, while the number of caveats lodged for industrial properties showed a 41% increase from the same period last year. Another 1.2 million sq m of industrial space is expected to come on-stream in 2019, with 80% being single-user factory space. The supply is expected to support expansion plans of industrialists, with JTC citing an uptick in transaction volume in the first quarter.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open slightly lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened 0.24 points lower at 1,637.77, with 72.46 million lots traded worth RM26.13 million. Gainers beat losers 115 to 39. This follows global market trends, with stocks down in Europe due to bank and healthcare sector drag, and US stocks edging down from records amid tariff threats.

site_title: LTA awards S$64m contract to ST Engineering, Alexander Dennis for three-door buses
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) in Singapore awarded a contract worth S$64 million to ST Engineering and Alexander Dennis for 100 three-door double-deck buses. The buses will be procured in batches, with 50 supplied by ST Engineering Land Systems and 50 by Alexander Dennis, at costs of S$30 million and S$34 million respectively. The tender was awarded after a trial period and evaluation of bids based on price, experience, and technical capabilities. The buses are expected to be deployed on the road starting from 2020.

images.alt_text: Artist's impression of the three-door double-deck buses to be procured by the Land Transport Authority.

site_title: Rich clients add US$22b to UBS this year as Q1 net profit beats estimates
summary: UBS Group reported a net profit of $1.14 billion in Q1, beating analyst estimates. The bank's wealth management division attracted $22 billion in new money, while investment banking revenues declined 27% from a year ago. Despite a challenging market environment, UBS is on track to meet its capital return objectives and plans to resume share repurchases. CEO Sergio Ermotti's dire outlook last month proved incorrect, and the bank's pivot to private banking has reduced earnings volatility. UBS aims to return up to $1 billion through share repurchases this year.

images.alt_text: UBS Group's first quarter turned out better than investors may have expected after chief executive officer Sergio Ermotti's dire outlook last month.

site_title: Grab takes strategic stake in Ninja Van
summary: Grab, a ride-hailing unicorn, has made a strategic investment in logistics provider Ninja Van for an undisclosed amount. The partnership will integrate Ninja Van's services into Grab's GrabExpress, a parcel and courier delivery service, and adopt GrabPay across its platform. The alliance aims to boost Grab's regional logistics capacity and provide a wider range of delivery options in South-east Asia. The deal also enables Ninja Van to leverage Grab's user base and offer convenient logistics services. The partnership will be rolled out in phases across the region, starting from the second quarter of 2019.

site_title: Ascendas Hospitality Trust should merge with Ascott Reit, says Quarz Capital
summary: Activist fund Quarz Capital Management is advocating a merger between Ascendas Hospitality Trust (A-HTrust) and Ascott Reit, citing A-HTrust's undervaluation due to its small size. The proposed merger, which would be structured as a trust scheme, would offer A-HTrust unitholders a 5-10% premium to book value. The merged entity would become Singapore's eighth-largest Reit by assets under management, with a market cap of S$3.6 billion. Quarz believes the merger would enable the integrated Reit manager to pursue more strategic acquisitions and qualify for index inclusion, potentially leading to a 5% jump in distribution per unit.

site_title: UK cybersecurity agency won't tell regulator about breaches
summary: The UK's National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC) has decided not to automatically share information about data breaches with the country's data privacy regulator, the Information Commissioner's Office (ICO). The decision aims to prevent chilling effects on businesses' willingness to report cyber attacks, as large fines under the EU's General Data Protection Regulation could deter companies from reporting hacks. The NCSC will instead provide free, confidential advice on how to mitigate breaches and encourage organisations to comply with the law.

site_title: Pioneering Uruguay set to begin exporting medical marijuana
summary: Uruguay, the first country to legalize recreational marijuana, is now set to begin exporting medical marijuana for the first time. The US company Fotmer, licensed to export, has harvested the first batch, which will be sent to Europe, Canada, and Australia. Uruguay aims to become a major player in the medicinal marijuana market, with plans to produce 6 tons this year and 400 tons annually. The country's liberal laws and tightly regulated production process ensure high-quality products for the pharmaceutical industry, with each packet expected to sell for $9,000 to $21,000 on the international market.

site_title: Singapore shares decline at Thursday's open; STI down 0.36% to 3,350.36
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.36% to 3,350.36 at Thursday's open, following a decline in US markets. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq slipped on mixed corporate results, with the US-EU trade situation in focus. On the Singapore bourse, 51 gainers outnumbered 46 losers, with Suntec Reit down 3.2% and AEM Holdings up 4.8%. The decline marks a reversal of the market's 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Ford bets US$500m on Tesla rival Rivian
summary: Ford Motor has agreed to invest $500 million in Rivian, an electric-car startup rivaling Tesla, to accelerate its electric vehicle development and streamline operations. Rivian plans to produce a pickup truck and SUV by the end of next year, with a full charge range of 400 miles. The partnership aims to help Ford reduce costs and increase profitability, following a decline in its stock since Jim Hackett became CEO.

site_title: Trump immigration plan may increase visas for highly skilled workers
summary: US President Donald Trump's proposed immigration plan, led by senior adviser Jared Kushner, could increase visas for highly skilled workers, aiming to reshape the visa program into a more merit-based system. The plan does not address undocumented young people brought to the US as children or those with Temporary Protected Status. Kushner has held listening sessions with conservative groups and worked with economic adviser Kevin Hassett and policy adviser Stephen Miller. The proposal may raise highly skilled visas slightly or maintain current levels, and aims to modernize ports of entry and reduce family-based immigration.

site_title: AEM Holdings' sales orders to-date for 2019 delivery hit S$209m
summary: AEM Holdings reported a 19% increase in sales orders to S$209 million as of April 25, 2019, for 2019 delivery. This surpasses previous announcements of S$174 million and S$140 million. The company revised its revenue range upwards to S$225 million to S$250 million and its capital expenditure range to S$4 million to S$7 million to support future engineering development.

site_title: Facebook beats profit estimates, sets aside US$3b for privacy penalty
summary: Facebook beat profit estimates in the first quarter with a net income of $2.43 billion, or $0.85 per share, driven by 26% revenue growth to $15.1 billion. The company set aside $3 billion to cover a potential settlement with regulators over user data sharing, but said costs could reach up to $5 billion. Despite a series of scandals, Facebook's shares rose 10% after hours, demonstrating the company's resilience. The company's operating margin fell to 22% due to increased expenses, but executives forecast revenue growth and expect expenses to taper off later this year.

site_title: Blumont reshuffles board, senior management
summary: Blumont Group has reorganized its board and senior management following the resignation of its COO and CFO. New CEO Lee Tak Meng has been appointed as an executive director, replacing Lee Boon Teck and Kek Wei Na. John Lee Yow Meng has been appointed as the new CFO and executive director. Ng Keok Chai has taken over as lead independent director, chairman of the audit committee, and remuneration committee. The reorganization comes after the company faced a spectacular collapse in 2013 and is currently involved in a penny stocks trial.

site_title: North America driving global oil and gas pipeline 'boom'
summary: A global oil and gas pipeline boom has tripled in less than two decades, with North America accounting for nearly a third of over 180,000 kilometers of pipelines in development. The "perfect storm" of declining renewable energy prices, increasing climate regulations, and shifting public opinion threatens to make investors reconsider their fossil fuel investments. Experts warn that the infrastructure projects, which total over $1 trillion, may not be "locked in" and could be delayed or mothballed if public sentiment shifts.

site_title: Iran's foreign minister believes Trump does not want war, but could be lured into conflict
summary: Iran's Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif stated that US President Donald Trump does not want war with Iran, but could be lured into conflict. Zarif made the remarks in an interview at the Iranian mission to the United Nations in New York. The White House declined to comment on Zarif's remarks. Zarif's comments come amid rising tensions between the two countries.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start with a loss
summary: Hong Kong stocks began Thursday with a loss, extending a fifth consecutive day of losses. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.46% to 29,667.52, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index declined 0.34% and 0.44%, respectively. This follows a negative lead from Wall Street. The losses are attributed to global market volatility and ongoing US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: Bank of England to refrain from rate hike until August 2020: think tank
summary: The Bank of England is likely to keep interest rates on hold until August 2020 due to a slower global economy and Brexit uncertainty, according to the National Institute of Economic and Social Research (NIESR). The think tank pushed back its previous forecast of a rate hike by a year, citing weaker global economic conditions and the impact on oil prices and imports. NIESR also trimmed its economic growth forecast for Britain this year to 1.4% and expects growth to pick up to 1.6% in 2020.

site_title: Microsoft topped US$1t in value as it predicts more cloud growth
summary: Microsoft became the first US$1 trillion company, surpassing Apple's market capitalization, after reporting strong quarterly earnings and revenue growth. The company's cloud computing business, including Azure, drove the increase, with revenue reaching tens of billions of dollars. Microsoft's shares rose 4.4% to $130.54, driven by beatings of Wall Street estimates and a shift in focus from Windows to cloud-based services. The company's earnings per share of $1.14 also exceeded expectations, solidifying its position as a leader in the tech industry.

site_title: Nissan issues fresh profit warning, slashes full-year forecast for the second time
summary: Nissan has issued its second profit warning in recent months, slashing its full-year forecast to 319 billion yen (S$5 billion) due to the adverse operating environment and impact of corporate issues. The downgrade comes as former boss Carlos Ghosn awaits his fate after prosecutors hit him with fourth charges of alleged financial misconduct. Ghosn denies the charges and claims the allegations are part of a plot by Nissan executives. The company's stock price has been affected by the Ghosn affair, which has exposed a rift in the Renault-Nissan alliance.

site_title: South Korea economy unexpectedly contracts in Q1, worst since global financial crisis
summary: South Korea's economy unexpectedly contracted in Q1, marking its worst performance since the global financial crisis, with a 0.3% decline in GDP. The contraction was driven by a downturn in the memory chips sector and slumping exports amid the Sino-US trade dispute. Capital investment fell 10.8% and construction investment decreased 0.1%, while private consumption gained 0.1%. The unexpected contraction reinforced views that the central bank may cut interest rates to counter declining business confidence and growing external risks. This is the worst performance since a 3.3% drop in late 2008.

site_title: First Sponsor Q1 profit rises 39% to S$23.8m
summary: First Sponsor Group's first quarter net profit rose 39% to S$23.8 million, driven by a strong showing in its property financing business segment. Revenue dropped 5.2% to S$45.3 million, mainly due to a drop in property sales and rental income, but was offset by revenue increases in property financing and hotel operations. The company plans to acquire a 100% equity interest in a 76,570 square meter mixed-use development site in China and will undertake a rights issue to raise S$147.9 million in gross cash proceeds.

site_title: Untested China bond structure sparks market angst after default
summary: China's dollar bond market faces uncertainty after a private sector company, China Minsheng Investment Group Corp, defaulted on a $300 million bond. The default triggers the first drawdown of a standby letter of credit (SBLC) for a public Asian bond, potentially causing a market downturn. Chinese issuers have $7.3 billion of dollar notes outstanding with SBLCs, which could lead to systemic risks for banks. Investors expect a potentially long enforcement process, leading to increased premiums on SBLC-backed bonds, and some predict a failure or delay in payments may occur.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Suntec Reit, CRCT, Far East H-Trust, First Sponsor, Sasseur Reit
summary:
Singapore stocks to watch on Thursday include:

- Suntec Reit, which raised S$200 million through a private placement of new units, with proceeds mainly going towards financing Australian property acquisitions.
- CapitaLand Retail China Trust (CRCT), which posted a 1.1% increase in gross revenue and a 7% rise in net property income.
- Far East Hospitality Trust (H-Trust), which saw a 3.2% decline in its distribution per stapled security, but a 9% increase in net property income.
- First Sponsor Group, which reported a 39% rise in net profit to S$23.8 million, driven by its property financing business segment.
- Sasseur Reit, which signed agreements to acquire additional shop units at Sasseur (Hefei) Outlets for S$19.8 million.

site_title: US calling for Goldman Sachs guilty plea in 1MDB scandal: report
summary: The US Justice Department is recommending that Goldman Sachs plead guilty to its role in the 1MDB scandal, a corruption case involving Malaysian funds. The recommendation, which could result in a $2 billion fine, is part of a potential settlement between Goldman Sachs and US authorities. The Justice Department accuses Goldman Sachs of laundering billions of dollars from 1MDB, despite the bank claiming senior management was unaware of the wrongdoing. Goldman Sachs' former employees, including Tim Leissner, have pleaded guilty or denied the allegations. The bank's response to the guilty plea recommendation was that the charges were "not warranted by the facts of the case or the law."

site_title: Anger over Brexit sparks new grassroots drive for Scottish independence
summary: Supporters of Scottish independence plan a new grassroots campaign ahead of a possible second referendum on secession from the UK. The campaign, "Voices for Scotland," aims to boost support for independence to 50-60% and capitalize on Scots' anger over Brexit. The movement, which has around 100,000 supporters, will train campaigners to engage with undecided voters and persuade those who support the union to reconsider. This comes after Scotland's First Minister Nicola Sturgeon announced plans to prepare for a second referendum by May 2021.

images.alt_text: Supporters of an independent Scotland will launch a new grassroots campaign on Thursday ahead of a possible second referendum on secession from the United Kingdom, hoping to harness Scottish voters' anger over Brexit.

site_title: Visa profit jumps, lower cross-border volume weighs on shares
summary: Visa Inc reported a 14% increase in quarterly profit to $2.98 billion, driven by higher overall consumer spending. However, cross-border volume growth declined to 4% due to lower transactions in Europe, where Visa faced regulatory scrutiny over high fees. The company raised its full-year earnings per share outlook and reaffirmed its 2019 guidance, despite lower operating expenses and higher spending on rewards and incentives.

site_title: Chooch.AI raises US$2.8m in seed round led by Vickers Venture Partners
summary: Chooch.AI, a visual recognition AI startup, has raised US$2.8 million in a seed round led by Vickers Venture Partners to expand its market and grow its team. The funds will be used to enhance its AI training platform for object and face recognition. Chooch.AI aims to be an end-to-end, deep learning visual AI solution, competing with Google Vision and Amazon Rekognition. The company plans to hire additional engineers to support its expansion across regions.

site_title: Boeing abandons outlook, takes US$1b cost hit in MAX jet crisis
summary: Boeing has abandoned its 2019 financial outlook and taken a $1 billion cost hit due to the grounding of its 737 MAX jet following two fatal plane crashes. The company halted share buybacks and lowered production, citing a blow to its reputation and financial cost of getting the planes back in the air. CEO Dennis Muilenburg expects a certification flight with the FAA in the "near term" and is open to improving aircraft development processes. The grounding has cost Boeing $1 billion so far, with production cuts and lower operating cash flow.

site_title: Oil falls from 6-month high after fears of tight market subside
summary: Oil prices fell to a 6-month high after the International Energy Agency (IEA) stated that markets are "adequately supplied" and global spare production capacity remains at comfortable levels. US crude stocks rose 6.9 million barrels, and Brent crude futures fell 33 US cents to $74.18 per barrel. The price decline came after concerns about tightening supply due to Opec output cuts and sanctions on Iran. Analysts say the market remains bullish, with prices potentially rising to $80 per barrel.

site_title: US's Pompeo says 'every indication' Islamic State inspired Sri Lanka attacks
summary: US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo stated that there is "every indication" the Sri Lanka bombings were inspired by Islamic State. Investigations suggest the attackers had sympathies and possibly contacts with the group. US agencies are collecting information on the attackers' relationship with Islamic State and trying to determine if there was any involvement by the group's central organization. The leader of the group, Mohammed Zahran Hashim, is believed to be the central figure in a photo issued by an Islamic State publicity outlet.

site_title: Oil hovers near 6 month high as US stockpile build counters supply fears
summary: US crude oil stockpiles surged to their highest levels since October 2017, countering fears of tight supply due to OPEC output cuts and US sanctions. Oil prices hovered near six-month highs, with Brent crude futures rising to $74.57 a barrel and West Texas Intermediate crude futures ending 41 cents lower at $65.89 a barrel. The build in domestic stocks countered concerns about supply, with oil prices influenced by market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions.

site_title: US measles cases at its highest since elimination in 2000: CDC
summary: The US has reported 695 measles cases as of April 24, 2019, the highest number since the disease was eliminated in 2000. The cases were primarily due to large outbreaks in Washington State and two in New York that started in late 2018. This marks a significant increase in measles cases in the country, highlighting the ongoing challenges in controlling the spread of the disease.

site_title: Suntec Reit raises S$200m in private placement
summary: Suntec Reit raised S$200 million in a private placement, with 83.8% of the proceeds allocated for potential acquisitions in Australia. The issue price was S$1.80 per unit, a 4.2% discount from the previous day's market price. The funds will be used to finance acquisitions, refinance existing debt, and fund asset enhancement initiatives. The net proceeds amount to S$195.6 million after deducting fees and expenses. The Reit's manager closed the book of orders on the private placement.

site_title: Savills IM names Alex Jeffrey as new Singapore-based CEO
summary: Savills Investment Management (Savills IM) has appointed Alex Jeffrey as its new CEO, effective late 2019, based in Singapore. Jeffrey, previously head of Asia-Pacific for M&G Investments, will lead the firm's global growth and be part of the Savills Group executive board. Under his leadership, Savills IM has grown its assets under management from £5.6 billion to over £16 billion. The appointment demonstrates the company's focus on Asia-Pacific potential, following its UK and European platform.

site_title: WHO says limited or no screen time for children under 5
summary: The World Health Organization recommends limiting or eliminating screen time for children under 5, with no screen time for infants under one year and no more than one hour of sedentary screen time for children aged 2-4. The guidelines also emphasize the importance of physical activity, sleep, and playtime to prevent childhood obesity and diseases. Experts say that achieving health for all begins with healthy habits in early childhood, and that bringing back playtime is crucial in shifting from sedentary to active lifestyles.

site_title: House panel chair accuses Trump of 'massive, unprecedented' obstruction
summary: US House Oversight Committee Chairman Elijah Cummings accused President Donald Trump of a "massive, unprecedented, and growing pattern of obstruction" after he ordered federal employees not to comply with congressional investigations. Trump vowed to resist every subpoena from House Democrats, including those investigating his administration and potential impeachment. The Justice Department rebuffed a House committee's request for an interview with an official involved in the administration's decision to put a citizenship question on the 2020 census. Trump has promised to fight all subpoenas and any effort to impeach him, even if it goes to the Supreme Court.

site_title: Three adjoining office units at Peninsula Plaza up for sale
summary: Three adjoining office units at Peninsula Plaza in Singapore are up for sale in an expression of interest exercise with a guide price of S$9.29 million. The units, located on the 12th storey, range from 1,001 to 1,776 sq ft and have a combined area of 4,262 sq ft. The 999-year tenure units offer attractive pricing compared to nearby office units, with no additional buyers' stamp duty or sellers' stamp duty imposed. The sale is expected to benefit from the ongoing rejuvenation in the City Hall area, with its centralised location and excellent connectivity.

images.alt_text: Peninsula Plaza is a mixed-use development comprising a six-storey retail podium and a 24-storey office block a short walk from City Hall MRT interchange station.

site_title: Japan's incoming imperial couple offers the nation something new
summary: Japan's Crown Prince Naruhito and his wife Masako, who is multilingual and experienced in living overseas, are expected to bring a fresh perspective to the monarchy, potentially making it more international and connected to ordinary Japanese. With a background in diplomacy and interests in water issues and conservation, they may engage in causes that push the envelope, such as climate change and environmental issues. The couple's approach will likely be gradual, building trust and empathy with the people, after the previous emperor's abdication sparked debate about the role of the emperor.

site_title: Slack is expected to file listing prospectus this week
summary: Slack Technologies Inc is expected to file its prospectus for a direct listing on the stock market as soon as this week, according to the Wall Street Journal. The company, known for its workplace instant-messaging and collaboration app, has confidentially applied with the US Securities and Exchange Commission to list shares publicly. Slack is on pace for approximately $500 million in revenue this year, according to the report.

images.alt_text: Slack Technologies Inc is expected to reveal its filing for a direct listing on the stock market as soon as this week, the Wall Street Journal reported on Wednesday, citing people familiar with the matter.

site_title: New rail facility will aim to reduce MRT testing closures
summary: Singapore to build an integrated train testing centre, the first of its kind in Asia, to be completed by 2022. The centre will be located on a 50 ha site at the former Raffles Country Club in Tuas, allowing for robust testing of new trains and rail systems without disrupting service on operational lines. The facility will be modelled on similar centres in Germany, South Korea, and Japan, and is expected to enhance service levels and reduce the need for MRT line closures.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Influence: Jaelle Ang, co-founder & CEO, The Great Room
summary: Flexible workspaces are driving demand for prime office space in Singapore, accounting for 45% of net absorption last year. Jaelle Ang, co-founder and CEO of The Great Room, attributes the growth to the shift towards co-working spaces. Ang foresees future trends including increased demand for sustainable and technologically advanced spaces, and a focus on community and wellness. The sector's growth is expected to continue, with a Q3 wave of condo launches potentially testing demand for Singapore prime projects above S$3,000 psf benchmark.

site_title: Europe: German shares hit half-year high as SAP surges, broader Europe ticks lower
summary: German shares reached a 6.5-month high on April 24, 2019, driven by SAP's 12.6% surge to an all-time high, with the company gaining 14 billion euros in market capitalization. The technology sector outperformed broader European markets, which were weighed down by a dip in crude prices. SAP's surge was attributed to activist investor Elliott Management's 1.2 billion euro stake and support for a new management efficiency drive, marking the ninth consecutive session of gains for German shares.

site_title: London has record number of unsold homes under construction
summary: London has hit a record high of 31,508 unsold homes under construction as of March 31, according to Molior London data. This marks the highest level recorded since the data began a decade ago. The housing slump in London is attributed to government measures discouraging investment purchases, property tax hikes, capital controls, and Brexit uncertainty. The average asking price for new homes in London has risen to a record £909 (S$1,600) per square foot, making them unaffordable for average Londoners, with the most expensive borough being Kensington and Chelsea.

site_title: Alibaba pushes its cloud services arm unit globally
summary: Alibaba's cloud services arm, Alibaba Cloud, is expanding globally with a US$3 billion investment, narrowing the gap with Amazon and Microsoft in the cloud computing market. The company aims to generate half its revenue outside China, driven by international cloud expansion. Alibaba Cloud has been generating triple-digit revenue growth, with a 19.6% market share in the Asia region's infrastructure as a service market, up from 13.6% in 2017. The company plans to set up data centers in Indonesia and Malaysia to cater to US companies in China and vice versa.

site_title: Bayer moving to Paya Lebar Quarter; taking up 31,000 sq ft
summary: Bayer, a pharmaceutical firm, is moving its main office to Paya Lebar Quarter in Singapore, taking up 31,000 square feet of space. The company will relocate from OCBC Centre by the end of the year. Other companies, including JLL, SMRT, and IWG, have also taken space in the mixed-use development. The move is seen as part of the trend of decentralization, driven by high rents in the Central Business District, with experts predicting further growth in this area.

images.alt_text: Artist's impression of Paya Lebar Quarter. A PLQ spokesperson said that the three office buildings in PLQ are more than 75% leased or under advanced negotiations.

site_title: Have you got the EMO for success?
summary: Entrepreneurs with a high "error mastery orientation" (EMO) are more likely to overcome problems and setbacks to create successful ventures. This mindset involves viewing errors as opportunities for learning, rather than as negative consequences. A study found that entrepreneurs with high EMO benefited from problems, using them to learn and improve, while those with low EMO reacted negatively to problems. To develop a positive approach towards problems, entrepreneurs can frame errors in a positive light, participate in training programs, and adopt a mantra of "learning fast, learning often".

site_title: AA Reit's Q4 DPU up 4.6% at 2.75 Singapore cents
summary: AA Reit posted a 4.6% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.75 Singapore cents in Q4, driven by 15% year-on-year growth in net property income to S$20.3 million. Total DPU for FY2019 dipped 0.5% to 10.25 Singapore cents, while total distributable income rose 4.6% to S$70.5 million. The company's CEO attributed the results to stabilizing industrial market conditions and ongoing redevelopment and asset enhancement initiatives.

site_title: Datapulse to take 15% stake in Seoul hotel for 8.6b won
summary: Datapulse Technology has agreed to acquire a 15% stake in Seoul's 224-room Holiday Inn Express Euljiro hotel for 8.6 billion won (S$10.2 million) in partnership with Malaysian-based Bizcentre Capital. The deal is part of a larger transaction involving Bizcentre Capital and a real estate investment trust (REF Trust), which owns the hotel. The acquisition is expected to complete by June 21, 2019, and is in line with Datapulse's expansion strategy in the South Korean hospitality market.

site_title: 'Jeopardy!' whiz makes big bets to soar past US$1m in winnings
summary: James Holzhauer, a 34-year-old professional sports gambler from Las Vegas, has surpassed $1 million in total earnings on the Jeopardy! game show, becoming the second contestant to achieve this feat. Holzhauer won $118,816 in a single game, bringing his total to $1.06 million, and has now claimed the top seven spots on the show's hall of fame. His strategy involves going for high-value clues, hunting for Daily Doubles, and betting everything he has, which has allowed him to dominate the show in just 14 games, beating the current record holder's 74-game streak.

site_title: US new home sales hit 1½-year high in March on lower mortgages, prices
summary: US new home sales rose 4.5% in March to a 1½-year high of 692,000 units, boosted by lower mortgage rates and house prices. The median new house price dropped 9.7% to $302,700, the lowest level since February 2017. Economists suggest the trend supports a potential strengthening of existing home sales and recovery in the housing market.

site_title: Far East H-Trust Q1 DPS down 3.2% to 0.91 Singapore cent
summary: Far East Hospitality Trust (H-Trust) reported a 3.2% decline in distribution per stapled security (DPS) to 0.91 Singapore cent for the first quarter, due to a 1.2% decline in income available for distribution. Despite this, net property income rose 9% to S$25.1 million, driven by an increase in master lease rental from hotels. Revenue per available room and average daily rate (ADR) also increased. The trust's CEO noted that while corporate demand was softer, the medium-term prospects of the industry remain positive, driven by government plans to drive quality tourism.

site_title: SoftBank to invest 900m euros in Wirecard
summary: SoftBank is investing 900 million euros in Wirecard, a German internet payments firm, through convertible bonds that could give SoftBank a 5.6% stake in the company. The investment also includes a strategic partnership for digital payments, enabling Wirecard to expand its reach in Japan and South Korea. The deal aims to shore up investor confidence after a series of accounting reports and could provide services to SoftBank's portfolio companies, including Uber and Alibaba.

site_title: Inclusivity is the name of the game at Toyota Motor
summary: Toyota Motor will support 12 athletes from eight countries, including Singapore, in their Olympic and Paralympic journey in Tokyo. The company aims to create a more inclusive, sustainable, and mobile society through its "Start Your Impossible" global corporate initiative. Toyota has hired athletes with disabilities to work at its facility in Japan, promoting positive social change and challenging the status quo. The company's efforts are led by Team Toyota Hero Athletes in Asia, including Singaporean para swimmer Sophie Soon, who has raised awareness on removing physical and attitudinal barriers for people with impairments.

site_title: The Great Republican abdication
summary: The article "The Great Republican Abdication" suggests that the modern Republican Party is willing to sell out America's interests for tax cuts benefiting the wealthy. This is exemplified by the party's support for President Donald Trump, who has delivered on the Republican agenda despite being a divisive figure. The article cites Steven Levitsky and Daniel Ziblatt's book "How Democracies Die," which describes this phenomenon as "the great Republican abdication." The authors argue that Republicans are willing to compromise democracy for short-term gains, and this is evident in the party's support for Trump's policies, which have been unpopular with the general public.

site_title: Egypt to turn to private sector to restore historic buildings
summary: Egypt's government plans to transfer ownership of 150 historic buildings to the private sector to refurbish and lease out for profit. The move aims to save crumbling buildings, revitalize tourism districts, and generate revenue. The plan follows the model of Al Ismaelia for Real Estate Investment, which has renovated historic buildings in downtown Cairo. The government will offer parcels of buildings to private developers on a revenue-sharing basis, with any extra proceeds used to finance restructuring plans for companies under the ministry.

site_title: Alphabet drone delivery unit gets its Wings
summary: The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has approved Alphabet's Wing, a drone delivery unit, to use drones for commercial package delivery in the US. The approval, called an Air Carrier Certification, comes after Wing demonstrated the safety of its drones in a pilot program in Australia. Deliveries will be limited to parts of southwest Virginia, with restrictions including daytime flights, clear weather, and a maximum altitude of 400 feet. Wing plans to focus on goods from local businesses and will seek community input on implementation.

site_title: A better way of doing business
summary: A Twitter user criticizes the Walt Disney Co.'s CEO, Robert Iger, for taking home over $65 million in 2018, while the median pay of a Disney worker was $46,000. The user argues that Disney's focus on profits over worker compensation is part of a broader trend of income inequality in the US. The author suggests that Disney could lead the way in a more humane approach to business by sharing executive bonuses with its low-wage workers, potentially providing a $2,000 bonus to the bottom 10% of employees.

site_title: Programme launched to develop mid-career management accountants
summary: A Professional Conversion Programme (PCP) for Management Accountants has been launched in Singapore to help mid-career individuals with accounting backgrounds develop management skills and become management accountants. The 10-month programme, developed by Workforce Singapore and partners, includes classroom and on-the-job training and is open to Singaporeans and Permanent Residents with a diploma or degree in accountancy. Upon completion, participants will receive certificates from Singapore Polytechnic and the Chartered Institute of Management Accountants. The programme aims to equip accounting professionals to respond to shifts in the workplace and stay relevant in the digital economy.

images.alt_text: Tan Choon Shian, WSG's chief executive said: "As companies undergo transformation to keep pace with the ongoing economic transformation, there is an increase in demand to use financial data to forecast and guide business decisions.

site_title: Saudi Arabia sees no need for immediate action
summary: Saudi Arabia's Energy Minister Khalid Al-Falih stated that the country has no immediate need to take action in the crude market.
