Despite the US decision to end waivers for Iranian oil imports, Saudi Arabia won't decrease its current output for May and will maintain its production level. Oil shipments for June will be allocated early next month, with a potential uptick in demand, but Saudi Arabia won't preemptively increase production. The country will respond to buyer requirements after the current output cuts expire in June.

site_title: UOB, KrisFlyer launch new credit card that rewards users with air miles
summary: UOB and KrisFlyer have launched a new credit card that rewards users with air miles for savings and spending. The KrisFlyer UOB Credit Card is available to those earning at least S$30,000 annually, earning three KrisFlyer miles for every dollar spent in select areas. There is no cap on miles earned.

site_title: PT Astra reports 5 per cent bump in Q1 earnings
summary: PT Astra International reported a 5% year-on-year increase in Q1 net income to 5.2 trillion rupiah (S$500 million) due to contributions from its financial services and heavy equipment divisions. Net revenue rose 7% to 59.6 trillion rupiah, driven by higher revenues in most business segments.

site_title: Volvo profit tops forecast as supply chain squeeze eases
summary: Volvo reported a higher-than-expected operating profit of 12.70 billion Swedish crowns (S$1.84 billion) in its first quarter, beating forecasts. The company sold more higher-priced vehicles and benefited from easing supply chain pressures. Despite a decrease in truck order intake, Volvo maintained its outlook for truck markets in 2019, citing strong key markets. CEO Martin Lundstedt attributed the results to a strong service business and high volume flexibility, which will help the company be more resilient to changes in the business environment. Adjusted operating margin rose to 11.8% from 9.3% last year.

site_title: NTUC working on retirement, re-hiring ages of 65 and 70
summary: NTUC is working on changing Singapore's retirement and re-hiring ages to 65 and 70, respectively, as part of addressing the country's ageing workforce. The changes are expected to be phased in once agreed upon by the tripartite workgroup. The move aims to encourage older workers to stay in the workforce longer, boosting productivity and economic growth.

site_title: Undeterred by Khashoggi killing, global executives return to Saudi Arabia
summary: Global finance executives, who boycotted a Saudi investment summit last year following Jamal Khashoggi's murder, have returned to Riyadh. Despite criticism over the killing, Saudi Arabia is seen as a key player in the global economy, with major investors like HSBC and Blackrock attending a two-day financial forum. The country has unveiled an industrial plan to attract hundreds of billions of dollars in investments and has seen a surge in foreign fund flows into its stock market. Riyadh has also executed 37 people in connection with terrorism crimes, sparking criticism from Amnesty International.

site_title: Accor plans 60 new hotels in Africa
summary: Accor plans to open 60 new hotels in 14 African countries over the next four years, with 30 to be located in Egypt. The move aims to capitalize on the continent's growing demand for branded hotel supply. Egypt is rebounding after a tough period, driven by improved macroeconomic management and political stability. The investment is expected to be funded with over $1 billion from the Katara Hospitality Fund, with Accor contributing $500 million. This expansion will enhance Accor's footprint in key markets such as Nigeria, Ethiopia, and South Africa.

site_title: Divided Europe faces China Belt and Road test
summary: European leaders, including Italy's Conte, Hungary's Orban, and Greece's Tsipras, are attending China's Belt and Road summit in Beijing, despite EU officials' concerns over weakening European unity against China. The summit comes after Italy's signing onto the Belt and Road in March, which infuriated Washington and much of the EU. EU diplomats see the BRI as a development that poses a risk of complications between member states, while China views it as a way to export overcapacity and draw Europe into its sphere of influence.

images.alt_text: Chinese honour guards awaiting the arrival of Myanmar's leader Aung San Suu Kyi at the Beijing International airport ahead of the Belt and Road Forum in the city on Wednesday.

site_title: ST Engineering nabs US Coast Guard shipbuilding job worth up to US$1.94b
summary: ST Engineering's US shipbuilding business, VT Halter Marine, won a US$745.9 million contract from the US Navy to design and build a heavy polar icebreaker for the US Coast Guard. The contract includes options for two additional ships, increasing the total value to US$1.94 billion. The first ship delivery is scheduled for 2024, with the second and third vessels expected to be delivered in 2025 and 2027, respectively.

site_title: Eurozone anxious over Europe's 'election of the year'
summary: Spain holds its third national election in as many years, with the ruling Socialist party likely to win the most seats but short of a majority, potentially leading to a coalition government. This adds to the eurozone's political uncertainty, mirroring instability in other large economies like France and Italy. The ongoing Brexit drama and economic concerns, including stagnating growth and a possible no-deal Brexit, further exacerbate the situation. Markets are worried about potential further uncertainty, and the outcome of the election may have significant implications for the single currency area's economic outlook.

site_title: Formula for Happiness
summary: Singaporeans' happiness levels have declined, ranking 34th globally in the 2019 World Happiness Report, despite strong GDP and life expectancy. In response, various initiatives such as happiness festivals and workshops have been launched to boost contentment. Local businesses, including a candy factory and a restaurant, are also participating in these efforts, further indicating the public's interest in improving happiness. The oversubscription of these programs suggests a growing concern among Singaporeans about their overall well-being.

site_title: A*Star enterprise arm inks deal to set up deep-tech startups
summary: A*Star's enterprise arm, A*ccelerate, signed a US$90 million agreement with Aptorum Group and Aeneas Capital to co-create deep-tech startups in healthcare and life sciences in Singapore. The partnership aims to establish up to 20 startups over five years, leveraging A*Star research and Aptorum's global network. The startups will focus on imaging solutions in surgical robotics and other areas, with a potential healthcare and life science strategic investment fund of up to US$200 million also being launched.

site_title: SGX orders independent review of issues raised by Best World short-seller
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has ordered an independent review of Best World International, following a short-seller report that questioned the company's accounting practices and sales methods in China. The review will be conducted by a reviewer reporting directly to SGX RegCo and the company's audit committee. Best World shares fell 9% on Wednesday after the report was published, with some traders selling short the stock. The review aims to provide shareholders with a complete picture and inform their investment decisions.

site_title: Samsung's reputation founders in rush for lead in folding phones
summary: Samsung Electronics scrapped the launch of its Galaxy Fold, the world's first mass-produced foldable smartphone, due to screen failures and other issues after mere days of use. The company is now investigating the cause of the problems, which include screen failures and damage from users peeling off the top layer of film. The move aims to avoid a repeat of the Note 7 debacle in 2016, which led to a global recall and billions of dollars in losses. Samsung had been racing to release the Fold ahead of Chinese rivals Huawei and Xiaomi, but the delay gives the company time to address potential issues and maintain its reputation.

site_title: Chinese tech giant Huawei opens cloud and AI innovation lab in Singapore
summary: Huawei has launched a cloud and AI innovation lab in Singapore, aiming to promote the adoption of cloud and AI technologies in the country. The lab, open to developers, university students, and companies, will provide a platform to launch projects for public benefit. Huawei has committed "hundreds of millions" worth of investment in Singapore and the Asia-Pacific market, with Singapore being one of its largest cloud nodes outside of China. The move comes as Huawei faces allegations of spying and intellectual property theft in the West.

site_title: Related to buy AT&T's WarnerMedia headquarters for US$2.2 billion
summary: Related Companies affiliate agreed to buy AT&T's WarnerMedia headquarters in Manhattan for US$2.2 billion. The 26-floor office complex, spanning 30 Hudson Yards, is expected to close in the second quarter. This deal marks one of the city's most expensive commercial real estate transactions.

site_title: Singapore shares rise, tracking US optimism
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.27% to 3,362.43, driven by US corporate earnings optimism. Gainers outnumbered losers 204 to 168, with notable movers including China Everbright Water and ST Engineering. However, analysts, such as Hussein Sayed, caution that the bull market may not last, citing potential negative factors like China reducing stimulus and the Fed changing course.

site_title: Xi'an city cuts financing for home buyers to curb speculation
summary: Xi'an city, a major Chinese tech hub, has implemented measures to curb speculation in its property market. Starting May 13, downpayments for first-time buyers will be raised to 35% and borrowing limits will be lowered, while a two-year ban on second-hand home sales has expired. The city aims to prevent speculation and contain the build-up of debt, following a resilient economic data in March. The measures are part of the government's "structural deleveraging" efforts to address concerns about the property market.

site_title: Who will be next to merge in the S-Reit universe?
summary: Singapore's real estate investment trust (Reit) sector is expected to see more mergers due to a need for scale, driven by the pursuit of inclusion in major benchmark indices. Possible candidates for mergers include Ascott Reit and Ascendas Hospitality Trust, ESR Cayman and Sabana Reit, and CapitaLand Retail China Trust and CapitaLand Mall Trust. Intra-sponsor mergers are simpler to execute, while mergers between independent Reits are harder to sell. Analysts expect consolidation activity to persist, driven by cost benefits and easier access to capital, making the Reit sector more attractive to investors.

site_title: Popular heart drugs that can cause cancer face slew of US lawsuits
summary: Dozens of lawsuits have been filed against drugmakers and sellers over generic heart medications tainted with potential carcinogens, including valsartan, losartan, and irbesartan. The FDA has recalled the medications, which were used to treat high blood pressure and other conditions, and an estimated 2,000 personal-injury cases are expected to be filed in the next two years. The lawsuits claim that millions of Americans took the contaminated medication, with at least 27 cases involving cancer diagnoses. The FDA is investigating how the chemicals were created during manufacturing and has announced plans to revamp quality control rules.

site_title: Hunt is on for 'highest calibre' BOE governor
summary: Britain's finance minister Philip Hammond is searching for a new Bank of England (BOE) governor to help steer the country's economy through Brexit. Hammond aims to appoint a candidate of the highest calibre, with the goal of starting the new governor in February 2020. The current governor, Mark Carney, has ruled out a further delay in the UK's exit from the EU. Hammond has expressed confidence in finding a suitable candidate, with former BOE deputy governor Andrew Bailey and current officials among those being considered for the role.

site_title: Mortgagee listings hit new high on loan rate hikes, weak rentals
summary: Mortgagee sale listings in Singapore reached a record high in Q1 2019, with 159 out of 362 listings being mortgagee sales, up 28.2% from the previous quarter and doubling from a year ago. Higher mortgage payments due to rising interest rates and a subdued rental market contributed to the increase. Experts believe the trend may continue, with rising supply and cooling measures expected to put downward pressure on prices. The success rate for mortgagee listings dropped to 2.5% in Q1 2019, down from 10.7% in Q1 2018.

images.alt_text: Mortagagee sale listings in Singapore reached a record high in the first quarter of 2019, according to data compiled by Knight Frank.

site_title: ESR Reit's Q1 DPU jumps 19% after Viva Industrial Trust merger
summary: ESR Reit's Q1 DPU jumped 19% to 1.007 Singapore cents following its merger with Viva Industrial Trust in October 2018. Net property income surged 104.2% to S$48.6 million, while gross revenue rose 92.9% to S$64.8 million. Total distribution available for unitholders increased 138.8% to S$32 million. The company's portfolio occupancy remained healthy at 92%, and it expects the leasing market to remain competitive due to global trade tensions.

site_title: Alternative Dispute Resolution is the way to go to resolve technology disputes
summary: The Singapore Convention is set to seal the country's reputation as a global hub for Alternative Dispute Resolution (ADR) in technology disputes. ADR mechanisms, such as mediation and arbitration, are increasingly being considered to resolve costly and time-consuming technology disputes, allowing businesses to avoid acrimonious litigation and save management and financial resources. By adopting ADR, Singapore aims to promote a more efficient and effective dispute resolution process, enhancing its global reputation as a hub for technology and business.

images.alt_text: In contrast to litigation, mediation and arbitration allow parties to exercise greater control over the dispute resolution process and outcome.

site_title: US: Wall Street edges lower, energy stocks fall
summary: US stocks edged lower on Wednesday, with the S&P 500 slipping 0.5% below its intraday record high, despite a strong start to the day. Energy stocks fell due to a drop in oil prices, while tech-heavy Nasdaq gained support from eBay's upbeat earnings and a chipmaker rally. Investors are waiting for more earnings reports from major companies, including Microsoft and Amazon. Despite a mixed bag of reports, the economy is seen as on a steady footing, with nearly 78% of reported S&P 500 companies surpassing earnings estimates.

site_title: RWDC Industries raises US$22m in Series A3 funding round
summary: RWDC Industries, a Singapore-based biotech startup, has raised US$22 million in its Series A3 funding round led by Vickers Venture Partners and Eversource Retirement Plan Master Trust. The funds will primarily be used to increase production capacity and support research into biodegradable biopolymer material solutions, specifically to eliminate single-use plastic. This is a follow-up to the US$13 million raised in the previous round, and the company expects its first commercial batch of PHA straws to be available in the market this year.

site_title: Innopac's fund raiser downsized to S$6.1m after investor pulls out
summary: MAINBOARD-listed Innopac Holdings has downsized its proposed stock placement to S$6.1 million after a second investor pulled out, extending the long-stop date to June 30. The decision follows the withdrawal of a second investor, with nine individual investors extending the deadline. This move was made through supplemental letters executed by Innopac and the investors.

site_title: Saleswhale to expand its product and team with Series A funding
summary: Singapore-based startup Saleswhale has secured US$5.3 million in Series A funding led by Monk's Hill Ventures. The funds will be used to expand the product and engineering team, with plans to grow from 28 to 70 employees in the next 18 months. Saleswhale's AI Assistant automates sales email for mid-market and large enterprises, generating 1.5 times more qualified leads and meetings for clients. The startup aims to improve integrations with enterprise systems and close the gap between sales and marketing.

site_title: Hyundai bets on US, South Korea sales as profit beats estimates
summary: Hyundai Motor reported its first profit rise in five quarters, beating estimates, as it focuses on US and South Korean sales. The company aims to revive stalled growth, with heir apparent Euisun Chung reshuffling top management. Hyundai's recovery comes despite a slump in China, and it will continue to battle challenges in the market. The company's improved outlook is a positive sign for the South Korean automaker.

site_title: HNA shelving US$1b sale of container unit Seaco: sources
summary: HNA Group has shelved the sale of its container leasing business Seaco after failing to reach an agreement on valuation. The Chinese conglomerate was seeking over $1 billion for the business, but negotiations with potential buyers, including Apollo Global Management and China Cinda Asset Management, fell through. This is the latest in a series of asset sales by HNA, which has agreed to sell over $20 billion of assets since 2018 to reduce its debt pile.

site_title: ARA plans first US hospitality trust on SGX
summary: ARA US Hospitality Trust, a Singapore-based real estate investment group, plans to list on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) with a business trust focused on US hotels under the Hyatt brand. The trust will own and run an initial portfolio of 38 hotels valued at US$719.5 million. The hotels, comprising 27 select-service hotels and 11 extended-stay hotels, have a total of 4,950 rooms and projected net property income of US$53.2 million in fiscal 2018. The trust aims to capitalize on the growing demand for transient-oriented select-service hotels.

images.alt_text: Real estate investment group ARA Group is spinning off US$719.5 million of US hotels under the Hyatt brand into a business trust that it wants to list on the Singapore Exchange (SGX).

site_title: Euro heads towards 1-month low as sentiment sours
summary: The euro has fallen towards a one-month low due to contrasting economic data, with the US dollar supported near 22-month highs. Solid US housing data and a strong US dollar index propelled the greenback higher, while weaker-than-expected inflation numbers in Australia and a low business morale in Germany weakened the euro. The US dollar is expected to remain strong, with some analysts predicting it's overvalued but still supported by economic outperformance and potential interest rate hikes.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Frasers Commercial Trust (FCRT) is maintained as neutral by RHB Research Institute due to sub-optimal Alexandra Technopark (ATP) occupancy and the need for more visibility on leases. The Reit's gearing is low, presenting good debt headroom for acquisitions. Keppel Reit (KEP) is maintained as a "buy" by DBS Group Research, with a raised target price, as office rents are expected to rise and the Reit benefits from the upturn. Keppel Reit's maiden acquisition in South Korea is seen as a positive move.

site_title: CP Group's development plan draws flak
summary: Thailand's Eastern Economic Corridor (EEC) program, a flagship project of the military regime, is under scrutiny due to allegations of dispossessing local farmers to make way for Chinese investors. CP Group, a major conduit for Chinese investment, is leading a consortium to build a 200 km rail network and has partnered with Huawei and Alibaba to develop a 5G test bed and smart digital hub. Critics argue that the EEC prioritizes Chinese interests over local needs, with some calling it a "colonial era" of Thai-Chinese investment policies.

site_title: The time hasn't come for Beto and Mayor Pete
summary: US presidential hopefuls Beto O'Rourke and Mayor Pete Buttigieg are losing steam, according to the article. Despite their initial media attention, both candidates are struggling to gain traction with voters. O'Rourke's lack of charitable donations and Buttigieg's youth and lack of Washington experience are major concerns. Additionally, Buttigieg's openness about being gay and his elitist background may not resonate with key demographic groups such as African-Americans and Hispanics. As a result, the article concludes that the time may have come to take a step back and reevaluate the candidates' chances in the 2020 presidential election.

site_title: Indian court moves to lift ban on Chinese video app TikTok
summary: An Indian state court has moved to lift a ban on the Chinese video app TikTok, reversing a decision made earlier this month. The ban was ordered due to concerns over the app's content, with some politicians and parents claiming it was inappropriate for children. However, the court found that the proportion of objectionable content was "minuscule" and TikTok's developer, Beijing Bytedance Technology Co, argued it should not be held liable for user actions. The IT ministry has instructed Apple and Google to allow TikTok to return on their platforms.

site_title: The real crisis risk at the ECB
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) faces a potential crisis risk due to the impending replacement of President Mario Draghi. Concerns arise as the ECB may not have enough tools to revive growth, with ultra-low interest rates and limited monetary policy options. However, the ECB still has options, such as reactivating net asset purchases or cutting the deposit rate further into negative territory. The risk is that the new president may be unwilling to deploy the full toolkit of unorthodox measures, leaving the euro zone with a dysfunctional monetary policy.

site_title: CapitaLand Mall Trust's Q1 DPU up 3.6%
summary: CapitaLand Mall Trust (CMT) raised its Q1 distribution per unit by 3.6% to 2.88 Singapore cents, driven by a 11.5% increase in net property income and 10% rise in gross revenue. The trust took full ownership of Westgate Mall in November 2018, contributing to the revenue increase. CMT's aggregate leverage stood at 34.4% on March 31, and the Reit manager remains cautious due to a slowdown in the global and Singapore economy.

site_title: US crackdown on Iranian oil raises risks in fragile global climate
summary: US President Trump's decision to revoke sanctions waivers on countries buying oil from Iran has led to a surge in crude oil prices, hitting a six-month high. The move is expected to cut Iranian oil supplies by over 1 million barrels a day, raising concerns about a potential supply shortage. OPEC's response is unclear, with Saudi Arabia and the UAE agreeing to offset lost barrels, but analysts expect a cautious approach. The global oil market is awaiting reassurance from OPEC, with a key meeting on May 19 and another in June.

site_title: Launch of Hong Kong offer sends China Everbright shares soaring 26%
summary: China Everbright Water launched a public offer of 104 million shares in Hong Kong, with shares soaring 26% after the listing. The shares rose to HK$3.24 apiece, with Singapore-listed shares increasing 10 cents, or 25.6%, to S$0.49. The company's Hong Kong listing is expected to raise significant funds.

site_title: Trump says he'd seek supreme court help to deter impeachment
summary: President Donald Trump stated he would seek the US Supreme Court's help to deter an impeachment effort if Congress proceeds. Trump claimed there are no "High Crimes and Misdemeanors" and no crimes committed by him. However, the Constitution grants the House wide latitude to impeach the president, and some Democrats have called for impeachment. Trump's request lacks clear legal grounds for the Supreme Court to consider.

site_title: Australia's pro-coal lobby should heed South Korea warning
summary: Australia's pro-coal lobby should heed South Korea's warning as the country shifts its energy policy to punish coal and promote renewable energies. South Korea raised its coal import tax by 28% and cut LNG import tax by 75% to boost natural gas and renewables. This shift could lead to a substantial drop in coal imports, undercutting justifications for new coal mines in Australia. The policy change across Asia raises concerns about "stranded assets" and could become a major impediment to new coal mines, related infrastructure, and power plants.

site_title: Credit Suisse ends losses in trading; posts Q1 pre-tax profit of 282m francs
summary: Credit Suisse's main trading business posted a Q1 pretax profit of 282 million francs, exceeding analyst estimates. The bank's wealth management unit also topped expectations. CEO Tidjane Thiam's three-year turnaround strategy appears to be gaining momentum, with the bank attracting 9.6 billion francs in new wealth management assets. The results are seen as a relief to Thiam, who has faced criticism over surprise trading losses. Credit Suisse rose 2.8% in Zurich trading, bringing year-to-date gains to 29%.

site_title: Investor Taizo Son leads funding in Golden Equator
summary: Venture capitalist Taizo Son led a S$24.6 million investment in Singapore-based ecosystem builder Golden Equator, despite concerns of tech bubble overvaluation. Son believes in supporting long-term investments, taking on higher risk profiles, and prioritizing future generations. The investment is part of Golden Equator's expansion plans, which aim to build a network of experienced leaders and businesses to facilitate collaboration and investments.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Sasseur Reit reported a second-quarter boost with a higher portfolio occupancy rate, increased revenue, and lower property expenses. Frasers Centrepoint Trust's distribution per unit rose 1.2% to 3.137 Singapore cents, while Suntec Reit's DPU inched up to 2.434 Singapore cents. Camsing Healthcare appointed RSM Corporate Advisory as its special auditor to investigate audit matters. Sasseur Reit also signed agreements to acquire additional shop units for approximately S$19.8 million.

site_title: Sasseur Reit acquires shop units at Hefei Outlets for 98.3m yuan
summary: Sasseur Reit has signed agreements to acquire additional shop units at the Sasseur (Hefei) Outlets in China for 98.3 million yuan, a 4.1% discount from valuation. The units have a 100% occupancy rate and a 5.4-year weighted average lease expiry. The acquisition will boost Sasseur Reit's ownership of the outlet to 81.2% and increase income stability, allowing for asset management initiatives and optimizing the tenant mix. The deal will be fully funded by existing cash.

site_title: Europe not feeling much pain from Trump tariffs, central bank says
summary: A new study by the European Central Bank found that President Donald Trump's tariffs on European steel and aluminum have had a surprisingly mild impact on European exports. While some industries, such as heavy equipment manufacturers, may have profited, the tariffs have not significantly harmed the European economy. The study suggests that the tariffs are more likely to have hurt the US economy, particularly if the US imposes tariffs on cars. The trade war has also had a significant psychological impact on European business confidence, with many fearing future protectionist measures.

site_title: Cosco eyes expansion of business operations in Malaysia
summary: Cosco Shipping International plans to expand its business operations in Malaysia by leasing a 300,000 square foot warehouse in Port Klang. The company is also in talks with a Malaysian party for potential cooperation, which could include acquiring logistics businesses or forming a logistics partnership. This expansion aims to provide end-to-end services to customers and form an integrated logistics platform. Cosco will also collaborate with other Cosco Shipping companies in Malaysia to achieve synergies.

site_title: Ayala Land to raise US$500m in country's first Reit
summary: Ayala Land, a Philippine property developer, plans to raise US$500 million in the country's first real estate investment trust (Reit) offering. The company will sell 67% of the Reit company, primarily focusing on Makati central business district assets, to the public. Ayala Land aims to acquire office assets in the Philippines' main financial hub, valued at US$13.3 billion. The Reit will distribute profits to shareholders as dividends, marking a significant step in the country's real estate market.

site_title: Savills IM names Alex Jeffrey as new Singapore-based CEO
summary: Savills Investment Management (Savills IM) has appointed Alex Jeffrey as its new CEO, based in Singapore. He will join the firm in late 2019 and become a member of the Savills Group executive board. Under Jeffrey's leadership, Savills IM has increased its assets under management from £5.6 billion in 2015 to over £16 billion today, raising £2.4 billion in new capital from clients last year.

site_title: Australia shares end at over 11-year high on rate cut hopes; NZ rises
summary: Australian shares reached an 11-year high on Wednesday, rising 1% to 6,382.10, driven by weak inflation data and expectations of a potential rate cut as early as May. The S&P/ASX 200 index was boosted by gains in banking and healthcare stocks, with the healthcare index seeing its best day in nearly four months. New Zealand's benchmark index also scaled a record peak, closing 0.7% higher. The Australian dollar tumbled to six-week lows, while mining and gold stocks led losses.

site_title: CRCT's Q1 DPU slips 5.8% to 2.59 Singapore cents
summary: CRCT's Q1 DPU dropped 5.8% to 2.59 Singapore cents, down from 2.75 cents last year. Gross revenue increased 1.1% to S$55.96 million, with net property income rising 7% to S$39.8 million. Stronger rental growth and lower operating expenses contributed to the increase.

site_title: Britain to allow Huawei restricted access to 5G network
summary: Britain has decided to allow Huawei Technologies a restricted role in building parts of its 5G network, a compromise in the dispute over the next generation of communications technology. The decision comes after the US warned allies against using Huawei's technology due to fears of Chinese spying. Huawei has denied these allegations. The move is seen as a middle ground between the US and China, with Britain's National Security Council led by Prime Minister Theresa May taking the decision.

site_title: Turin picked to host tennis's ATP Finals from 2021
summary: The ATP Finals, a prestigious men's tennis tournament, has been awarded to Turin, Italy from 2021 to 2025. Turin beat out Singapore and three other cities to secure the five-year contract, with the tournament set to be held at the 16,000-seater Pala Alpitour stadium. The first edition in 2021 will have a $14.5 million prize purse, and world number one Novak Djokovic expressed excitement about the move, calling it a "very special event".

images.alt_text: Serbia's Novak Djokovic during the quarter final tennis match of the Monte-Carlo ATP Masters Series on April 19, 2019 in Monaco. Italian city of Turin edged out Singapore and three other cities for the right to host the season-ending ATP Finals tournament for five seasons from 2021 to 2025.

site_title: Sri Lanka calls bombers 'well educated' and warns of ongoing threat
summary: Nine highly educated Sri Lankan suicide bombers carried out Easter Sunday attacks, killing over 350 people, authorities said. The Islamic State group claimed responsibility, but investigators are still determining if it provided support. The bombers, including one woman, were from different parts of Sri Lanka and were linked to an obscure extremist group. Authorities have arrested 60 people, but many remain at large, with the US and India providing assistance. Sri Lanka's defense minister warned of an ongoing threat, with some lawmakers criticizing President Maithripala Sirisena for not being informed about a prior intelligence report.

site_title: Boeing abandons 2019 outlook after 737 MAX groundings
summary: Boeing has abandoned its 2019 financial outlook due to the 737 MAX grounding, which has resulted in $1 billion in increased costs. The company halted share buybacks in March and reported below-estimated revenue and cash flow in the first quarter. The 737 MAX crashes in Indonesia and Ethiopia killed 346 people, leading to the grounding of the jets. Boeing is facing one of its biggest crises in history, with deliveries of the 737 MAX halted. The company's stock performance has also been affected by the crisis.

site_title: Sri Lankan president asks police chief, defence secretary to quit following attacks
summary: Sri Lankan President Maithripala Sirisena has asked the police chief and defence secretary to quit following the Easter Sunday suicide bomb attacks that killed 359 people. The attacks targeted churches and luxury hotels, and the president cited intelligence failures as a reason for the request. The decision comes amid accusations within the government of negligence in preventing the attacks.

site_title: Big brands dive into esports to court youth market - Nielsen
summary: Big brands, including snack companies and carmakers, are investing in esports to target the youth market. According to Nielsen, 39% of brand exposure in esports' competitive video game broadcasts came from non-gaming related companies in 2018. This trend is expected to continue, as esports enthusiasts' passion for video games surpasses other forms of entertainment.

site_title: Avengers: Endgame a fitting send-off for Marvel franchise
summary: The Marvel Cinematic Universe's 22-film series culminates in Avengers: Endgame, a fitting conclusion to the franchise. Released in 2019, the three-hour film brings together the interdependent heroes from various movies, including Iron Man, Thor, Black Widow, and Black Panther. The film's success showcases the enduring appeal of the characters, despite complex plotlines. Avengers: Endgame serves as a satisfying send-off to the Marvel franchise, solidifying its place in cinematic history.

site_title: US: Wall St opens flat after mixed earnings from industrials
summary: US stocks opened flat on Wednesday, following a record-setting rally in the previous session, due to mixed earnings from industrial bellwethers Boeing and Caterpillar. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.01%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite gained 0.01% and 0.03%, respectively. The mixed results weighed down the market, despite record highs in the previous session.

site_title: CRCT posts Q1 DPU of 2.59 Singapore cents
summary: Capitaland Retail China Trust (CRCT) reported a Q1 DPU of 2.59 Singapore cents, down from 2.75 cents in the same period last year. Gross revenue increased 1.1% to S$55.96 million, driven by stronger rental growth and 7% net property income. Tenant sales and shopper traffic grew 9.8% and 14% year-over-year, respectively, with a 97.4% portfolio occupancy rate. The trust's units closed at S$1.51, up one cent, amid a strong foundation for future performance.

site_title: Netflix junk bond offering draws US$6b of orders
summary: Netflix's junk bond offering received $6 billion in orders, exceeding the $2 billion target, as investors sought to capitalize on the company's debt sale. The 10.5-year dollar securities may yield 5.5%, while euro notes are marketed at 4%. This sale comes as Netflix aims to wind down its borrowing and shift toward profitability amid increased competition. The company has amassed $10 billion in long-term debt to invest in content and production. Despite burning through $3.5 billion in cash this year, analysts estimate this negative trend will continue through the first three months of next year.

site_title: SoftBank bets US$1b on battered payments firm Wirecard
summary: SoftBank invested $1 billion in Wirecard AG, a German digital-finance firm, securing a major European partner for the Japanese tech conglomerate. The deal, backed by convertible bonds, gives SoftBank a 5.6% stake in Wirecard and enables the company to expand into Japan and South Korea. Wirecard's shares jumped 10.9% following the agreement, which comes after months of whipsawing shares following allegations of accounting misdeeds. The investment provides a vote of confidence for Wirecard and could help shore up investor confidence.

site_title: Europe: Stocks droop at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets declined at the start of trading on Wednesday, with London's FTSE 100 down 0.1% and the Paris CAC 40 losing 0.2%. The Frankfurt's DAX 30 was marginally lower. The decline was attributed to bank and healthcare stocks, with US-EU tariffs also in focus.

site_title: Samsung plans to invest US$116b in non-memory chips
summary: Samsung plans to invest $116 billion in non-memory chips by 2030, aiming to reduce its reliance on the volatile memory chip market and develop chips for self-driving cars and AI-enabled devices. The investment will create 15,000 jobs and help the company reach its goal of becoming a world leader in logic chips by 2030. Despite its smartphone business struggles, Samsung aims to challenge rivals in contract chip manufacturing and mobile processing chips, while the South Korean government also prepares its own support programme for the non-memory chip sector.

site_title: German scientists create see-through human organs
summary: German scientists have created see-through human organs using a new technology that could pave the way to print 3D body parts. Researchers led by Ali Erturk at Ludwig Maximilians University in Munich developed a technique using a solvent to make organs such as the brain and kidneys transparent. The transparent organs are scanned by lasers to capture their structure, including blood vessels and cells, for potential transplant use.

images.alt_text: A 3D printer prints a heart with human tissue, at the University of Tel Aviv.While 3D printing is already used widely to produce spare parts for industry, Dr Erturk said the development marks a step forward for 3D printing in the medical field.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower ahead of earnings
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on April 24, 2019, amid corporate earnings season and ahead of a 10-day holiday period. The Nikkei 225 index lost 0.27% to 22,200.00, while the Topix index fell 0.67%. Investors remained cautious due to lackluster Chinese shares and concerns over corporate earnings reports. Nissan dropped 3.99% after downgrading its profit projection, while utility firms fell due to a threat to shut down nuclear plants if anti-terror measures weren't implemented by a set deadline.

site_title: Singapore shares rise 0.3%, tracking optimism in US equities
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.27% to 3,362.43, reversing initial losses, despite concerns about the US bull market's longevity. Hussein Sayed, a market strategist, suggested the current bull run may not last due to potential factors like China reducing stimulus and the Fed changing course. The bourse recovered in its final hour of trading, with 1.17 billion shares changing hands for the day.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks down at close
summary: Hong Kong shares ended the day with a 0.53% decline, closing at 29,805.83. The drop was attributed to energy firms taking a hit from a drop in oil prices. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.09% and the Shenzhen Composite Index jumped 1.10%. Despite a record performance on Wall Street, investors seemed to brush off the news, focusing on US-EU trade tensions and global economic uncertainty.

images.alt_text: The Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Limited (HKEx) flag is seen hoisted outside Exchange Square in Hong Kong. Hong Kong shares ended with losses Wednesday as investors brushed off a record performance on Wall Street, with energy firms taking a hit from a drop in oil prices.

site_title: Camsing Healthcare names special auditor to look into unresolved audit matters
summary: Camsing Healthcare appoints RSM Corporate Advisory as its special auditor to investigate unresolved audit matters, including related party transactions and licence fee recoverability. The audit matters relate to distribution agreements, consignment agreements, and a HK$15.6 million purchase agreement. The special auditor will report directly to the Singapore Exchange Regulation and provide regular updates on the status of its review. The company's shares have been suspended since April 1 following a trading halt.

site_title: Hot stock: Best World tumbles 9% after shortseller Bonitas' report
summary: Best World International shares plummeted 9% after short-seller Bonitas Research questioned the authenticity and legality of the company's profits, citing concerns over sales practices in China and the legitimacy of its main customer. The report also highlighted Best World's aggressive pricing against luxury brands. The Singapore Exchange's regulatory arm has halted trading and urged the company to conduct a full independent review.

site_title: Samsung plans US$116b splurge on chips to take on Intel
summary: Samsung Electronics plans to invest $116 billion over the next decade to become a leader in the global semiconductor industry, competing with Intel and Qualcomm. The investment will focus on logic chips, with the goal of creating 15,000 jobs and challenging Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Samsung aims to increase its market share in the logic chip market, which is dominated by Intel. The company's semiconductor division already generates three-quarters of its operating income.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 10.57 points to 1,638.01. The market saw a significant gain with 4.4 billion lots traded worth RM2.8 billion. Gainers outpaced losers 598 to 328, indicating a positive trend.

site_title: Wall Street CEOs flocking to Riyadh show, Khashoggi furor over
summary: Global finance executives, including HSBC CEO John Flint and BlackRock CEO Larry Fink, attended a Riyadh conference, six months after boycotting a similar event due to the murder of US journalist Jamal Khashoggi. The conference, hosted by Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, saw over $12 billion raised in its first bond sale, with global financiers prioritizing the kingdom's oil wealth and geopolitical importance. Despite concerns over human rights, attendees expressed optimism about opportunities in the region, with HSBC and BlackRock announcing plans to expand their presence in Saudi Arabia.

images.alt_text: The Financial Sector Conference's popularity is the latest sign that it's back to business as usual for Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman.

site_title: Saudi Arabia sees no need for immediate action on oil market
summary: Saudi Arabia's energy minister, Khalid Al-Falih, stated that the country will not significantly raise oil production in May and will stay within its OPEC production limit until June, despite US sanctions on Iran. Saudi Arabia currently pumps 500,000 barrels below its quota, and the kingdom will remain responsive to customers, particularly those under waivers. Nigeria supports a six-month extension of the current supply deal, and OPEC plans to meet in June to decide on production curbs.

images.alt_text: Saudi Arabia's energy minister Khalid al-Falih said the world's biggest oil exporter sees no need to take immediate action in the crude market, signaling a cautious response to the US decision to tighten sanctions on Iran.

site_title: Three adjoining office units at Peninsula Plaza up for sale with S$9.29m guide price
summary: Three adjoining office units at Peninsula Plaza in Singapore are up for sale with a guide price of S$9.29 million. Located on the 12th storey, the units range from 1,001 to 1,776 sq ft and have a combined area of 4,262 sq ft. The indicative price works out to S$2,180 per sq ft. The sale excludes buyers' and sellers' stamp duty, and the buyer can purchase the units individually or collectively. The units benefit from a rare 999-year tenure, central location, and excellent connectivity, making it an attractive option for trades and businesses.

images.alt_text: THREE adjoining office units at Peninsula Plaza will be put up for sale in an expression of interest exercise on Thursday at a guide price of S$9.29 million, exclusive marketing agent CBRE said.

site_title: Toll in Sri Lanka bombings rises to 359: police
summary: A series of suicide bomb blasts on Easter Sunday targeting hotels and churches in Sri Lanka has claimed 359 lives, with at least 500 injured. The Islamic State group has claimed responsibility, but Sri Lanka's government suspects a local Islamist group, National Thowheeth Jama'ath, with "international" help.

site_title: Rescuers battle to find bodies in Myanmar mudslide
summary: Rescuers in Myanmar are battling to find bodies in a mudslide that engulfed over 50 jade miners, with 54 feared dead. The landslide occurred at a mine in Hpakant township in northern Kachin state, and police initially reported that all miners were asleep when the mud lake buried them. However, they later clarified that the miners were working a night shift at the time. The site is mined by Myanmar Thura Gems and Shwe Nagar Koe Kaung companies, and the industry is plagued by corruption and fatal accidents, with dozens dying each year.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks slump on weak earnings, falling won
summary: South Korea's KOSPI stock index fell 0.9% on Wednesday, weighed down by weak corporate earnings and a weakening currency. The Korean won lost 0.8% against the US dollar, its lowest since July 2017. LG Display reported a January-march net loss of 132 billion won, while POSCO's operating profit slid 19% due to higher raw material costs. However, Hyundai Motor's shares rose 1.8% on better-than-expected net profit. Foreigners were net buyers of 23.7 billion won worth of shares, pushing the KOSPI up 7.84% so far this year.

site_title: New Zealand, France announce bid to end violent extremism online
summary: New Zealand and France have announced a joint effort to combat online violent extremism, following the March 2019 mosque attacks in Christchurch that killed 50 people. The effort aims to bring together countries and tech companies to eliminate violent content online. The meeting will be co-chaired by New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern and French President Emmanuel Macron on May 15. Ardern emphasized the need for tech companies to take responsibility for content on their platforms and for social media to not be used to promote terrorism.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher with eyes on earnings
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on April 24, 2019, due to record levels in New York, despite caution amid corporate earnings season and upcoming holidays. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.40% to 22,348.17, while the Topix index climbed 0.32% to 1,628.12.

site_title: A*Star inks US$90m deal to create deep tech startups in healthcare, life sciences
summary: A*Star's enterprise arm A*ccelerate signed a US$90 million agreement with Aptorum Group and Aeneas Capital to co-create 20 deep tech startups in healthcare and life sciences over five years. The startups will tap A*Star research and Aptorum's global network. The partnership explores surgical imaging solutions and may invest up to US$200 million in the local biotech ecosystem. A separate strategic investment fund will be launched, and the parties will also make global acquisitions in identified technologies and businesses. This agreement aims to boost Singapore's biotech ecosystem.

site_title: Hong Kong pro-democracy "Occupy" activists jailed for role in mass protests
summary: A Hong Kong court jailed nine leaders of the 2014 pro-democracy "Occupy" movement, including Benny Tai, Chan Kin-man, and Chu Yiu-ming, for 16 months and a suspended sentence for conspiracy to commit public nuisance. The convictions underscore the decline of political freedoms in the former British colony nearly five years after the 79-day protests. The ruling highlights the ongoing tension between China's authoritarian government and pro-democracy activists in Hong Kong.

site_title: Innopac extends long-stop date of placement, downsized to S$6.1m after investor pulls out
summary: Mainboard-listed Innopac Holdings has extended its long-stop date for a proposed stock placement to June 30, after a key investor, Lim Soon Huat, pulled out. The placement has been downsized to S$6.1 million, from an initial proposal of S$8.4 million. Nine remaining investors, including managing director Choo Beng Kai, will subscribe for 6.1 billion new shares, representing 57.8% of Innopac's enlarged share capital. The company's shares have been suspended on the Singapore Exchange since June 7.

site_title: Australian dollar slides, bonds surge on soft Q1 inflation; NZ$ near 4-mth low
summary: The Australian dollar slid to six-week lows after weak Q1 inflation figures, with the country's inflation rate slowing to 0% and underlying inflation averaging 1.4% for the year. This has fueled calls for a rate cut, with several banks predicting a cut as early as next month. In response, three-year bonds surged to record highs, sending yields below the cash rate. The New Zealand kiwi also fell near a four-month trough, with the country's central bank likely to cut interest rates soon.

site_title: ST Engineering nabs US Coast Guard shipbuilding contract worth up to US$1.94b
summary: ST Engineering's US shipbuilding business, VT Halter Marine, has won a US$745.9 million contract from the US Navy to design and construct a heavy polar icebreaker for the US Coast Guard. The contract includes options for two additional ships, increasing the total value to US$1.94 billion. Delivery is scheduled for 2024, 2025, and 2027, with VT Halter Marine as the prime contractor. The deal does not significantly impact ST Engineering's financials.

site_title: China Everbright Water opens Hong Kong public offer at HK$2.99-$4.35 apiece
summary: China Everbright Water launched a public offer in Hong Kong, offering 104 million shares between HK$2.99-$4.35 each, with 90% international shares and 10% for Hong Kong investors. The company plans to use proceeds for further liquidity and pipeline projects, with 85% for expanding its market share in China's water industry. The offer will close on April 29 and list on the Hong Kong mainboard on May 8.

site_title: D'oh Canada! Trudeau to be featured in The Simpsons
summary: Justin Trudeau is set to appear in an upcoming episode of The Simpsons, despite initially declining the invitation to play himself. Canadian journalist Lucas Meyer was instead chosen for the role after sending a video clip of his Trudeau impression. The episode will feature a storyline involving Trudeau's daughter Lisa Simpson being granted asylum in Canada and a subplot touching on a political scandal surrounding Trudeau ahead of October elections. This marks the second Simpsons visit to Canada, following a 2002 episode that sparked a media frenzy.

site_title: Japan's SoftBank to buy 5.6% of Wirecard for 900m euros
summary: Japan's SoftBank Group Corp will acquire a 5.6% stake in German payments company Wirecard by buying convertible bonds worth around 900 million euros. The investment aims to expand Wirecard into Japan and South Korea, and provide collaboration opportunities in digital payments and services. Wirecard's shares are up 4.8% following the announcement, which comes as the company defends itself against reports of inflated revenue in its Asian operations. A strategic partnership between the two companies has been signed, with SoftBank to help Wirecard strengthen its position in Asia.

site_title: Opportunities for Cambodia - Market Insights by Enterprise Singapore's Regional Directors
summary: Cambodia is poised for growth, with an 8% annual growth rate from 1995 to 2018 and a young population of over 16 million, with more than half under 25. The country is diversifying its economy, investing in training and human capital, and implementing business-friendly policies to attract foreign direct investment. Key opportunities include the energy sector, particularly solar and liquefied natural gas solutions, urban solutions such as waste management and connectivity, and digitalization. Despite misconceptions about its underdevelopment, Cambodia presents an attractive destination for Singapore companies, but businesses should be prepared for uncertainty, strong competition, and the need for a collaborative approach.

site_title: China navy chief takes dig at US freedom of navigation patrols
summary: China's navy chief, Shen Jinlong, criticized US freedom of navigation patrols in the South China Sea, stating that the practice should not infringe on other countries' rights. China views the US and its allies' actions as a provocation, claiming almost all of the sea is its territory. China is continuing talks on a Code of Conduct for the South China Sea with Southeast Asian states, aiming to maintain maritime peace. The US has not sent a ship to China's naval parade, seen as a low-key gesture.

site_title: Oil eases as supplies adequate for now, despite Iran sanctions
summary: Oil prices fell on Wednesday, easing concerns over global supply, despite recent highs. Brent crude futures dropped 0.5% to $74.13 per barrel, and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures fell 0.6% to $65.93 per barrel. The decline came amid signs that global markets remain adequately supplied, despite Washington's push for tighter sanctions against Iran. Oil prices had surged earlier in the week on market concerns, but the drop suggests investors are reassessing the outlook.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened with gains on Wednesday, following a strong lead from Wall Street, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reached fresh records. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.39%, while the Shanghai Composite Index added 0.16%. These gains come as traders brush off new US President Trump's threats to extend the stocks rally.

site_title: Japan's sterilised 'eugenics' victims to get payout
summary: Japan's government has passed legislation to compensate thousands of people forcibly sterilized under the country's now-defunct eugenics laws. The laws, which remained in force until 1996, resulted in the sterilization of around 16,500 mentally disabled individuals, some as young as nine, without their consent. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe expressed "sincere regret" and apologized for the policy, paving the way for the government to provide compensation to the victims.

site_title: Suntec Reit Q1 DPU inches up to 2.434 S cents
summary: Suntec Reit reported a slight increase in first-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.434 Singapore cents, up from 2.433 cents a year ago. Gross revenue declined 1.1% to S$89.7 million, primarily due to lower convention revenue, while net property income slipped 7.6% to S$58.2 million. The Reit's occupancy rates remained high at 98.9% for its office portfolio and 97.4% for its retail assets. The company expects revenue from its newly leased office space at 9 Penang Road to commence in the second half of 2020.

site_title: Canada oil sands CO2 emissions hugely underestimated: study
summary: A study published in Nature Communications found that Canada's oil sands CO2 emissions are significantly higher than previously estimated, with intensities up to 123% higher than current estimates. Environment Canada scientists took atmospheric measurements and found this discrepancy. The findings suggest that the actual emissions are much higher than industry reports, which used internationally recommended methods. This study highlights the need for more accurate assessments of greenhouse gas emissions from the oil sands.

site_title: AI sales assistant Saleswhale raises US$5.3m in Series A round led by Monk's Hill Ventures
summary: Singapore-based startup Saleswhale, which uses AI to engage and qualify leads at scale, has raised US$5.3 million in Series A funding led by Monk's Hill Ventures. The funds will be used to expand its product and engineering team and improve integrations with enterprise systems. Saleswhale has helped over 100 Fortune 500 businesses generate US$60 million in sales pipelines and has seen a 2.5x increase in qualified leads for clients such as Randstad. The company aims to double its team size and open a US office by Q4 2019.

site_title: Asia: Markets fluctuate as dealers brush off Wall Street record
summary: Asian markets fluctuated on Wednesday following a record-breaking close on Wall Street, driven by strong US earnings reports. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq scaled all-time highs, while the Dow came close. Despite positive sentiment, Asian markets shifted in and out of positive territory, with Hong Kong and Shanghai down 0.2%, and Tokyo flat. The rally in US markets has helped fuel optimism for a resolution in the US-China trade talks, which are set to resume next week. Oil prices retreated after hitting six-month highs on news of the US ending a waiver for Iran sanctions.

site_title: Related to buy AT&T's WarnerMedia headquarters for US$2.2b
summary: Related Companies has agreed to buy AT&T's WarnerMedia headquarters in Manhattan for US$2.2 billion, spanning 26 floors at 30 Hudson Yards. The deal includes a long-term lease-back until 2034 for 139,355 sqm of office space. The purchase is one of the city's most expensive commercial real estate deals, surpassing the sale of Chelsea Market to Google last year. The transaction was facilitated by Cushman & Wakefield, with the goal of reducing AT&T's debt by US$20 billion in 2019.

site_title: Credit woes, HCMC slump loom over Vietnam real estate
summary: Vietnam's real estate market is facing challenges, with lending and borrowing issues persisting despite Ho Chi Minh City's (HCMC) slower growth compared to Hanoi. Analysts attribute HCMC's issues to infrastructure bottlenecks and restrictions on expansion. In contrast, Hanoi's supply is picking up, driven by Vinhomes projects. Credit growth is slowing, with banks becoming more selective on loans to developers, and challenges arise from developing credit rating systems for mass-market buyers with low monthly incomes.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Wednesday; STI up 0.22% to 3,360.86
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.22% to 3,360.86 on Wednesday, driven by record-breaking US market closes for the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite indices. The Straits Times Index gained 7.39 points, with 91 gainers outnumbering 37 losers. About 60.2 million shares worth S$82.5 million were traded.

site_title: Top US officials heading to Beijing for trade talks: White House
summary: US officials Robert Lighthizer and Steven Mnuchin will travel to Beijing on April 30 for continued trade talks with China, led by Vice-Premier Liu He. The discussions will cover trade issues such as intellectual property, forced technology transfer, and agriculture. This is the latest in a series of shuttle diplomacy meetings between the two countries, which have imposed tariffs on over $360 billion in two-way trade since last year, affecting manufacturing sectors and global stock markets. The talks aim to address the ongoing trade war between the US and China.

site_title: ESR Reit Q1 DPU jumps 18.9% to 1.007 S cents post-Viva Trust merger
summary: ESR Reit reported an 18.9% jump in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.007 Singapore cents in Q1 2019, driven by contributions from Viva Industrial Trust's properties post-merger. Net property income surged 104.2% to S$48.6 million, while gross revenue rose 92.9% to S$64.8 million. Total available distribution for unitholders increased 138.8% to S$32 million. The company's portfolio occupancy remained healthy at 92%.

site_title: Yamada Green Resources sells stake in Chinese associate, proposes S$2.7m share placement
summary: Yamada Green Resources will book a 3.4 million yuan ($687,000) loss after selling its 45% stake in Chinese food manufacturer Fujian Tianwang Foods to Jinhai International Holdings for 39.9 million yuan (S$8.17 million). The sale price matches the amount Yamada paid for the stake in 2015. The deal will provide working capital for Yamada to start new projects and prevent further losses. The company also proposes a S$2.7 million share placement to Japanese food manufacturer Tennensozai, with proceeds used for general working capital purposes.

site_title: Didi-SoftBank taxi-hailing JV expands to 13 cities across Japan
summary: Didi Mobility Japan, a joint venture between China's Didi Chuxing and SoftBank Corp, plans to expand its taxi-hailing service to 13 cities across Japan, despite the country's ban on ride-hailing services. The app, launched in September in Osaka, will operate in cities including Tokyo, Osaka, and Nagoya. This move follows a growing trend of SoftBank-backed companies launching joint ventures with domestic telcos. The expansion aims to tap into Japan's growing market for ride-hailing services.

images.alt_text: Didi Mobility Japan, a joint venture (JV) by China's Didi Chuxing and SoftBank Corp, said on Wednesday that it would expand its taxi-hailing service to 13 cities across Japan.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Wednesday afternoon at 3,357.87, up 0.13% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Wednesday, edging up 0.13% to 3,357.87. The Straits Times Index saw 155 gains and 148 losses, with 728.2 million securities worth S$510.7 million changing hands. Notable movers included Rex International Holding (up 1.2%) and Spackman Entertainment Group (up 8.7%).

site_title: Australian inflation surprisingly cold, case builds for rate cut
summary: Australian inflation unexpectedly slowed to its lowest in three years, dropping to a flat rate in the March quarter, below forecasts for a 0.2% increase. The Reserve Bank of Australia had previously stated that a rate cut could occur if inflation didn't accelerate and unemployment increased. This outcome supports a case for an interest rate cut this year, despite the labor market remaining firm.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 6.55 points to 1,633.99. The market saw a gain-to-lose ratio of 143:33, driven by volume of 68.45 million lots worth RM30.48 million.

site_title: Trump misses tax return deadline, legal battle likely
summary: US President Donald Trump missed a deadline to deliver six years of his tax returns to Congress, escalating a battle expected to head to court. The House Ways and Means Committee had requested the returns from 2013 to 2018, but the White House refused, citing an ongoing audit. The Treasury Department said it would review the request and consult with the Justice Department, with a final decision due by May 6. Democrats have warned of potential legal action if the administration does not comply, citing a little-known law allowing Congress to review anyone's returns.

site_title: South Korea proposes 6.9t won extra budget to fight air pollution, aid exports
summary: South Korea has proposed a 6.7 trillion won (S$8 billion) supplementary budget to address air pollution and boost exports. The package includes 2.2 trillion won for pollution mitigation measures, such as replacing old diesel cars and promoting renewable energy. The remaining 4.5 trillion won will be used to increase export credit financing and create jobs. The move aims to tackle the country's air pollution issues and support exports, which have been impacted by weak global demand.

site_title: ARA seeks business trust listing on SGX for US$720m hotel portfolio
summary: ARA Group is spinning off a US$719.5 million hotel portfolio under the Hyatt brand into a business trust, ARA US Hospitality Trust, to be listed on the Singapore Exchange. The trust will hold the hotel properties and be run by ARA US Hospitality Management Trust. The initial portfolio comprises 38 hotels with 4,950 rooms and is projected to post net property income of US$42.3 million and distributable income of US$26.1 million for the eight-month period ending December 31, 2019. The listing aims to be the Singapore bourse's first hospitality trust focused on the US market.

site_title: FCT posts 1.2% rise in Q2 DPU on higher occupancy, revenue
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) reported a 1.2% increase in Q2 Distribution Per Unit (DPU) to 3.137 Singapore cents, driven by higher occupancy, revenue from Northpoint City and Changi City Point, and lower property expenses. The portfolio occupancy rate rose to 96% from 94% in the previous year. Gross revenue increased 2.3% to S$49.7 million, while net property income grew 4.8% to S$36.4 million. The company expects stable performance and resilience due to its focus on necessity shopping and steady shopper traffic.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Olam, ComfortGelGro, Mapletree Commercial Trust, UIC, FCT, AA Reit
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Several Singaporean companies saw significant developments on Wednesday. Olam International submitted a binding offer to acquire Dangote Flour Mills for S$491.09 million. ComfortGelGro acquired Australian bus service operator B&E Blanch Pte Ltd for S$27.5 million. Mapletree Commercial Trust posted a 1.8% increase in DPU, while United Industrial Corp saw a 35% year-on-year net profit growth. Frasers Centrepoint Trust and Aims Apac Reit also reported positive results, with FCT's DPU increasing by 1.2% and AA Reit's DPU rising by 4.6%. These companies' shares closed with varying changes.

site_title: Brazil court votes to reduce ex-president Lula's sentence
summary: A Brazilian appeals court reduced former president Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva's 12-year sentence for bribery and money laundering to 8 years and 10 months. Lula, 73, was convicted of accepting a bribe for helping the OAS construction company during his presidency. This decision marks the first reduction in his sentence, which he has been serving since his first year in jail earlier this month. Lula is also appealing a second sentence of almost 13 years for accepting renovation work by two construction companies.

site_title: Datapulse to acquire 15% stake in Holiday Inn Express hotel in Seoul for 8.6b won
summary: Datapulse Technology is acquiring a 15% stake in the Holiday Inn Express Euljiro hotel in Seoul for 8.6 billion won (S$10.2 million) in a joint venture deal with Bizcentre Capital. The deal is part of Datapulse's expansion strategy and aims to increase its presence in the Korean hospitality market. The hotel, operated under a franchise agreement, is strategically located in a popular retail and shopping district and has potential for growth. The acquisition is expected to complete by June 21, 2019.

site_title: US congressional leaders query Google on tracking database
summary: US congressional leaders, including top Democrats and Republicans, have written to Google CEO Sundar Pichai, expressing concerns about a massive database known as Sensorvault, which allegedly contains precise consumer location information on hundreds of millions of devices. The database, reportedly dating back to 2009, has raised questions about data sharing and usage. Google has not responded to the request for comment, and lawmakers have requested a briefing and answers by May 10. This inquiry comes amid growing concerns about data privacy and the use of consumer information by tech giants.

site_title: White House economist sees no impact on oil prices from Iran sanctions
summary: White House economic advisor Larry Kudlow stated that US sanctions on Iran will have "no material impact" on oil prices due to the country's large oil supply. Despite world oil prices reaching fresh 2019 highs, Kudlow believes US producers can quickly ramp up shale oil production to increase supply. Oil prices rose to $74.70 per barrel for Brent North Sea crude and $66.45 for US benchmark WTI. Kudlow also expressed optimism on the US economy, predicting a three percent GDP growth for the next two years despite record low unemployment rates and low inflation.

site_title: Egyptians overwhelmingly approve changes extending Sisi's rule
summary: Egyptian voters have overwhelmingly approved constitutional changes extending President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi's rule to 2030, with 88.83% voting "yes" and 11.17% voting "no". The changes, which consolidate Sisi's power, include boosting his control over the judiciary and giving the military greater influence. Rights groups have criticized the conditions surrounding the vote, citing suppression of opposition and a lack of democratic climate. Analysts warn that the amendments could have long-term negative implications for Egypt.

site_title: Indonesia, Malaysia rail projects may give China more deals
summary: China is set to showcase its high-speed rail projects in Indonesia and Malaysia at a summit of Belt and Road nations this week, as part of its effort to refocus the program on sustainable financing and green growth. The Indonesian project, valued at $6 billion, has been completed under "gold-plated terms" with a 2% interest loan from China's Development Bank. China's success in renegotiating the project with Malaysia's Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamed is seen as a key factor in its efforts to secure more business in the region.

site_title: AA Reit Q4 DPU up 4.6% to 2.75 S cents
summary: AIMS Apac Reit (AA Reit) reported a 4.6% increase in fourth-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.75 Singapore cents, driven by 15% year-over-year growth in net property income to S$20.3 million. Total DPU for FY2019 dipped 0.5% to 10.25 Singapore cents, despite a 4.6% rise in total distributable income to S$70.5 million. The company's CEO attributed the stability of the industrial market and redevelopment plans as key factors in the positive results.

site_title: Islamic State group claims Sri Lanka suicide bombings
summary: The Islamic State group claimed responsibility for the devastating Sri Lanka suicide bombings, which killed over 320 people in nearly simultaneous attacks on churches and hotels. The attacks, which targeted Christians celebrating Easter, were initially attributed to a local extremist group, but the IS group later claimed responsibility, releasing a photo and video of the alleged perpetrators. Sri Lanka's government has imposed a state of emergency and launched an investigation into the attacks, which have sparked widespread outrage and condemnation.

images.alt_text: The Islamic State group on Tuesday claimed responsibility for a devastating series of suicide attacks against churches and hotels in Sri Lanka that killed more than 320 people.

site_title: Nissan to announce large-scale cut to earnings outlook: report
summary: Nissan Motor Co will announce a large-scale cut to its earnings outlook for the fiscal year that ended in March, citing weak sales in North America and China. The Japanese automaker will slash its estimates, following a previous cut in February. This move comes as Nissan grapples with the arrest of former chairman Carlos Ghosn, adding to the company's woes. The company's board approved the move, and a spokesman declined to comment. This is the latest in a series of setbacks for Nissan, which has already predicted its lowest operating profit in six years.

images.alt_text: Nissan Motor Co will announce on Wednesday a large-scale cut to its earnings outlook for the fiscal year that ended in March, TV Tokyo reported, adding to the company's woes as it grapples with the arrest of former chairman Carlos Ghosn.

site_title: Europe: Stocks up for 8th session as oil surge boosts energy stocks
summary: European stocks rose for the 8th consecutive session, driven by a surge in oil prices, which boosted energy stocks. The pan-European Stoxx 600 index closed 0.23% higher, reaching August highs. Energy-heavy London's FTSE 100 led gains, while banks and auto stocks weighed on the region. Oil prices hit their highest since November due to the US decision to end all Iran sanction waivers by May. However, airline stocks took a hit, with Air France and Ryanair shedding between 2-6%.

site_title: Trump's son-in-law calls probe worse than Russian meddling
summary: Jared Kushner, President Donald Trump's son-in-law, has stated that Robert Mueller's probe into Russian election interference was more damaging to democracy than Russia's actual interference, which he dismissed as "a couple of Facebook ads." Kushner claimed that credit for the 2016 Trump victory belonged to the Trump campaign, contradicting Mueller's report that Russia tried to help Trump defeat Hillary Clinton. Kushner denied any wrongdoing and praised his cooperation with the Mueller probe, which found he passed along a proposal from Kremlin-linked figures after the election.

site_title: US charges Chinese engineer with stealing GE technology
summary: The US Justice Department charged Chinese engineer Xiaoqing Zheng and his partner Zhaoxi Zhang with "economic espionage" for allegedly stealing General Electric's trade secrets, including designs for gas and steam turbine technology. Zheng, an engineer at GE Power & Water, allegedly emailed proprietary files to Zhang in China. The incident comes as US and Chinese officials near the final chapter of trade agreement negotiations, with emphasis on enforcing intellectual property protections. The US is seeking to curb China's alleged state-sponsored theft of American companies' intellectual property.

site_title: US pharma bosses charged with fueling opioid crisis
summary: Two former executives of Rochester Drug Cooperative, a major US pharmaceutical distributor, were charged with fueling the opioid crisis. Laurence Doud, 75, and William Pietruszewski, 53, were charged with conspiracy to distribute controlled substances, carrying a maximum sentence of life in prison. The company, which distributes powerful prescription painkillers, entered a non-prosecution agreement and will pay a $20 million fine, agreeing to reform its practices. RDC failed to report at least 2,000 suspicious orders of drugs between 2012 and 2017, contributing to the opioid epidemic that has claimed tens of thousands of lives.

site_title: Amazon expanding partnership with French retailer Casino
summary: Amazon is expanding its partnership with French retailer Casino, with Amazon lockers to be installed in 1,000 locations across France and more Casino-branded products available on Amazon. The deal follows Amazon's purchase of Whole Foods Market last year and speculation of a potential European food retailer acquisition. Casino is selling assets to cut debt, while Amazon is strengthening its omnichannel strategy. The partnership will also extend Amazon's Prime Now grocery delivery service into new cities in France.

site_title: Oil surges amid Opec caution to offset Iran sanctions
summary: Oil prices surged to their highest in six months amid OPEC's caution to offset Iran sanctions. US President Donald Trump demanded buyers of Iranian oil stop purchases by May 1 or face sanctions, ending six-month waivers. OPEC members, including Saudi Arabia, are ready to raise output but only if there's demand to offset any shortfall. Oil prices rose 1.1% to $66.30 a barrel, with Brent crude rising 0.6% to $74.51 a barrel. The market is expected to meet in June to discuss output policy, with some analysts warning of volatility in the Middle East and international energy market.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Frasers Commercial Trust (FCOT) maintained a distribution of 2.4 Singapore cents per unit for its second quarter, despite lower occupancy and higher property taxes at Alexandra Technopark. Distribution rose 5.2% to S$21.7 million, while gross revenue and net property income declined 7.9% and 10.5%, respectively.

site_title: CapitaLand Mall Trust raises Q1 DPU by 3.6% as Westgate boosts revenue
summary: CapitaLand Mall Trust (CMT) raised its Q1 distribution per unit by 3.6% to 2.88 Singapore cents, driven by the acquisition of Westgate Mall and increased net property income of 11.5% to S$140.1 million. Gross revenue rose 10% to S$192.7 million, with Funan mall expected to contribute to earnings from the second half of 2019. Despite a cautious outlook due to economic slowdown, CMT's aggregate leverage remains stable at 34.4%.

site_title: Higher oil price erases India equity gain on economy, stoking earnings concern
summary: India's benchmark S&P BSE Sensex dropped 0.1% to 38,609.32 due to rising oil prices, erasing earlier gains. The country imports 80% of its oil requirement, making it vulnerable to oil price fluctuations. The NSE Nifty 50 Index also declined less than 0.1%. The decline stokes concerns about the economy and profits at some companies.

site_title: SoftBank to consider acquiring 5% stake in Wirecard
summary: SoftBank is considering acquiring a 5% stake in Wirecard, a German internet payment firm, through a deal that could involve buying bonds convertible into shares. The move aims to shore up investor confidence after reports of accounting wrongdoing. Wirecard has denied wrongdoing and is cooperating with German regulators. The investment would expand Wirecard's reach in Asia and provide services to companies like Uber and Alibaba. SoftBank's founder Masayoshi Son sees the deal as a strategic move to strengthen its mobile payments foray.

site_title: UIC posts double-digit Q1 net profit growth
summary: United Industrial Corp (UIC) posted double-digit first-quarter earnings growth, with net profit rising 35% to S$81.1 million. Revenue grew 12% to S$185.3 million, driven by growth in its property and IT business segments. The company's share of associated companies' results surged, offsetting a decline in joint venture contributions. UIC also completed its acquisition of Marina Square, a S$675.3 million deal that puts the company in joint control with its parent, United Overseas Land.

site_title: Should you chase this rally?
summary: The article advises against chasing the current market rally due to concerns over Sino-US trade and global growth risks. Equity valuations are seen as less attractive, and risks persist despite market optimism over a trade deal. A potential area of disappointment is that the trade agreement may be more of a ceasefire than a peace treaty, and existing tariffs may not be rolled back immediately. The market also faces uncertainties from the Q1 earnings season, with earnings per share expected to fall year-on-year for the first time since 2016.

site_title: CapBridge taps blockchain for its platform
summary: Singapore-based private securities exchange CapBridge will deploy blockchain technology on its platform to trade private company shares and register investor shareholdings. The Ethereum mainnet will be used for this purpose, allowing for interconnection with other DLT-based exchanges and creating a global liquidity pool. This initiative, in partnership with ConsenSys and Equiom Trust Services, aims to provide immutable and accurate record-keeping of share transactions. CEO Choo Haiping stated that the technology will enable real-time verification and validation of investor shareholdings, increasing transparency and accuracy.
