images.alt_text: An artisan using a traditional loom. Mali lacks the facilities and enough trained workers to transform cotton into more value-added products.

site_title: Director filings ease as attention turns to earnings
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) gained 0.4% from April 12 to 18, bringing its 2019 total return to 9.4%. In share buybacks, OCBC led with S$8.1 million, followed by Global Investments, Best World International, Hong Fok Corporation, and Straits Trading Company. Key insider transactions include The Hour Glass chairman Henry Tay Yun Chwan acquiring 9,721,000 shares, Hong Lai Huat Group deputy chairman Ong Bee Huat acquiring 948,800 shares, and Uni-Asia Group chairman and CEO Minichio Tanamoto acquiring 10,000 shares.

site_title: Uber wins US$1b investment from Toyota, SoftBank fund
summary: Uber has received a $1 billion investment from Toyota and SoftBank's Vision Fund to accelerate the development and commercialization of driverless ridesharing services. This investment, along with Toyota's existing $500 million stake, brings the total to $1.67 billion. Uber aims to transform transportation with driverless cars and expand its services beyond ridesharing to include sharing and delivery services. The investment is part of Uber's efforts to go public, with a potential IPO expected in May and a valuation of around $100 billion.

site_title: Qatar fund buys chunk of US$5.6b Manhattan portfolio
summary: Qatar's sovereign wealth fund, the Qatar Investment Authority (QIA), has acquired nearly half of a US$5.6 billion Manhattan portfolio from Vornado Realty Trust, with Crown Acquisitions also investing. The portfolio includes iconic retail spaces on Fifth Avenue and Times Square. QIA aims to boost US investments to US$45 billion, while Vornado will retain a majority stake and serve as general manager, expecting to collect US$1.2 billion in net cash proceeds. The deal is part of QIA's long-term investment strategy in the US.

site_title: China Belt and Road summit to promote sustainable financing
summary: China's Belt and Road summit in Beijing will agree to project financing that respects global debt goals and promotes green growth, according to a draft communique. The initiative, envisioned by Chinese President Xi Jinping, aims to rebuild the Silk Road with massive infrastructure spending. The summit will address concerns over the plan's sustainability and transparency, with a focus on green development and debt sustainability. 37 foreign leaders will attend the April 25-27 summit, with the US sending lower-level representatives due to unease over the scheme.

images.alt_text: The upcoming Belt and Road Forum in Beijing will address concerns among Western nations about countries being saddled with unsustainable debt through nontransparent projects.

site_title: Room to sharpen regulatory efficiency
summary: Singapore's regulatory bodies are exploring ways to improve the speed and effectiveness of investigating corporate fraud cases. Authorities believe a collaborative approach among key regulators, such as MAS, Acra, and SGX RegCo, could help expedite investigations and prosecutions. Experts suggest empowering regulators to carry out speedy investigations and increasing the range of offenses they investigate jointly. The current division of roles and functions between regulators may hinder the process, and some advocate for greater regulatory transparency and stronger enforcement powers, including temporary emergency powers to obtain information and impose sanctions.

site_title: US stocks likely to continue climbing
summary: US stocks are expected to continue their upward momentum, driven by stronger-than-expected earnings growth, reduced political uncertainty, and Chinese economic stimulus. Analysts predict a "melt-up" in the market, with rotation from credit to equity and commodities. The US economy is expected to rebound, with Chinese GDP growing at a solid 6.4% rate in the first quarter. However, some strategists warn that the market's rally may not be sustainable, with sentiment around Federal Reserve policy and the potential for a trade deal with China playing a key role.

site_title: America's Gen Z will be the ultimate pot consumers
summary: Gen Z, born between 1997 and 2012, is shaping the US cannabis industry as they begin earning steady incomes. With the majority having grown up in a world where cannabis is increasingly accepted, they're embracing legal pot to unwind or treat ailments. By 2023, Gen Z is expected to make up a larger share of the market, with corporate America and packaged food companies taking notice. As younger Americans opt for cannabis over alcohol, perceptions of the plant are shifting, with 60% of Americans now having access to some form of legal weed.

site_title: Global Invacom Group terminates proposed acquisition of Tactilis
summary: Global Invacom Group has terminated its proposed acquisition of Tactilis Sdn Bhd after failing to meet conditions precedent. The acquisition, valued at US$200 million, was to be completed through a series of convertible notes and share issues. Tactilis' flagship product is a biometric solution capturing fingerprints four times more accurately than rivals. The break fee of US$20 million under the sale and purchase agreement will be waived, with fees and costs to be borne equally by Global Invacom and the vendor.

site_title: Sri Lanka imposes curfew after Easter Sunday blasts
summary: Multiple explosions rocked Sri Lanka on Easter Sunday, killing at least 207 people, including 30 foreigners, in the worst violence since a civil war ended a decade ago. The government has imposed a curfew and arrested seven people in connection with the blasts, which targeted churches and luxury hotels. The attacks, including six in quick succession and two more hours later, were largely carried out by suicide bombers. The government warned of an impact on the economy and investment flows, with tourism expected to be affected.

site_title: Merger talks of Deutsche Bank and Commerzbank roil emotions
summary: Deutsche Bank and Commerzbank are considering a merger, sparking intense debate and emotion in Germany. Powerful labor unions, regulators, and shareholders are opposed to the deal, citing concerns over job cuts, taxpayer risk, and the banks' financial health. The European Central Bank may require new capital to be raised to ensure the merged institution is not too big to fail. Shareholders, including investment funds like BlackRock, are also wary of the risks involved, and the German government is divided on the issue.

site_title: Growing signs of correction or pause in uptrend of Reits sector
summary: The Singapore Reits sector, as represented by the FTSE ST Real Estate Investment Trust Index, has seen a 14% surge over the past five months, outperforming the Straits Times Index. However, recent developments, including a major tenant's parent company failing to make timely payments, have raised concerns about a possible correction or pause in the uptrend. The index has closed below its 20-day simple moving average and displayed a small double top reversal pattern, with a bearish MACD indicator signal. Investors are advised to approach the sector with caution due to near-historical highs in prices and yield spreads.

site_title: Sri Lanka bomber queued at hotel buffet before setting off explosives
summary: A Sri Lankan suicide bomber detonated explosives at a hotel buffet in Colombo on Easter Sunday, killing himself and at least 41 others, including many foreigners. The bomber, identified as Mohamed Azzam Mohamed, checked into the hotel under a false name and waited in a queue before setting off the blast. Other hotels and churches in the area were also targeted, with significant casualties and damage reported. Authorities have not named a suspect or group behind the attacks, but the incident has raised concerns about the country's security.

site_title: What does Uber love more: restaurants or investors?
summary: Uber's food delivery service, Uber Eats, has seen significant growth, with revenue increasing almost threefold to $1.5 billion last year, but the company faces challenges in maintaining its relationship with restaurants. Restaurants are concerned about lower profit margins due to lower beverage sales and higher commissions, which can reach 35% of the order value. To address this, Uber is exploring the concept of "dark kitchens" where restaurants operate food-preparation sites dedicated to deliveries. However, the company's long-term prospects may be at risk if it cannot find a balance between growth and profitability for its restaurant partners.

site_title: Saudi recruiter seeks to raise more than US$200m in IPO
summary: Saudi Arabia's Maharah Human Resources is seeking to raise over $200 million in an initial public offering (IPO) through a listing on the kingdom's stock exchange. The company, which has over $361 million in revenue, plans to offer 30% of its existing share capital to investors. This will be the first HR firm to list on the Saudi bourse, which is expected to benefit from the kingdom's 2030 diversification plan. The IPO application has been approved by the Saudi regulator, with Samba Financial Group underwriting and advising on the sale.

site_title: More needed to create businesses that promote 'human experience'
summary: Only 15% of South-east Asian business leaders believe they can create a company that promotes a 'human experience'. A Deloitte report found that 94% of leaders in the region consider reinventing learning as important, but only 12% of organisations are "very ready" to address this. Only 49% of workers globally and 38% in South-east Asia are satisfied with their job design, and 25% of respondents lack autonomy to make good decisions. Deloitte advises organisations to shift to team-based working and connect employees' aspirations with the impact they create at work.

site_title: Rate cut may not save ringgit bond rally as index outflow looms
summary: Malaysia's bond rally may stall as an interest-rate cut may not be enough to counter fears of capital flight, following FTSE Russell's potential removal from its world bond index. The country's currency, ringgit, has lost 1.3% in April, and global funds continue to sell Malaysian stocks, amid concerns over palm oil exports and inflation. A rate cut may be considered if inflation data shows consumer prices fell for a third month, but investors are bracing for an outflow of nearly US$8 billion if Malaysia is dropped from the index.

site_title: Risk of no-deal Brexit remains despite delay, says EC president
summary: European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker expresses concern over the risk of a no-deal Brexit, citing uncertainty and potential economic impact on Europe. Despite a six-month delay to October 31, Juncker urges Britain to work out the details of its departure, warning of a hard Brexit without a withdrawal treaty. The UK's rejection of the Withdrawal Agreement has led to a stalemate, with Juncker predicting a "lively discussion" at the G-20 meeting with US President Donald Trump.

images.alt_text: THERE is a still a concern that Britain may leave the European Union without a deal to smooth the way, the bloc's chief executive said on Saturday, urging Britain to take advantage of a six-month delay to work out the details of its departure.

site_title: Frasers Property's hackathon a win-win for all
summary: Frasers Property Limited's inaugural hackathon, Inclusive Spaces, has chosen team ENpower as the winner. The team, consisting of students and individuals with physical disabilities, proposed a solution called Blurring Social Barriers, which utilizes barrier-free furniture and digital pre-booking to make shopping malls more inclusive. The winning team received a cash prize of S$2,000 and will work with Frasers Property to refine their solution. The hackathon aims to build inclusive communities and will be an annual innovation challenge focusing on different themes and community groups.

images.alt_text: Vivien Ang

site_title: Singapore banks' FX volumes surge on strong Asian growth
summary: Singapore banks' foreign exchange volumes have surged due to strong Asian growth and global flows. Major banks report double-digit increases in FX volumes, especially emerging market currencies. Despite low volatility in G10 currency markets, Singapore's economic fundamentals and regulatory support have attracted global investors. The city-state aims to become a global FX trading hub, with banks like DBS and Standard Chartered expanding their operations. Singapore's status as Asia's FX hub is expected to remain, despite London's dominance in offshore renminbi transactions. The country's efficiency and favorable policies have contributed to its growth as a global FX center.

images.alt_text: Mr Lim: "Digitisation of DBS' FX transactions was a key driver of the strong growth in FX volumes."

site_title: Hundreds sign online petition supporting woman suing JD.com CEO in rape case
summary: Hundreds of people have signed an online petition supporting University of Minnesota student Liu Jingyao, who filed a civil lawsuit against JD.com CEO Richard Liu, alleging he raped her in August 2018. Liu had previously been cleared of criminal charges by prosecutors. The lawsuit, filed in a Minneapolis court, marks the first time the student has publicly identified herself. The two Lius are not related.

site_title: US intelligence says Huawei funded by Chinese state security: Report
summary: US intelligence has accused Huawei Technologies of being funded by Chinese state security, citing a source. The CIA claims Huawei received funding from China's National Security Commission, the People's Liberation Army, and a Chinese state intelligence network. Huawei denied the allegations, stating they have "zero evidence" from anonymous sources. The accusation comes amid trade tensions between the US and China and concerns over Huawei's equipment being used for espionage. US authorities are probing Huawei for alleged sanctions violations and have already arrested its CFO, Meng Wanzhou.

site_title: China's pledged share risks recede in first quarter: Shenzhen exchange
summary: China's pledged share risks decreased in the first quarter due to sharp stock market gains and relief funds. Outstanding loans against shares dropped 5.6% to 1.23 trillion yuan (US$183 billion) at the end of March, as shareholders repaid debts. Relief funding of 500 billion yuan boosted share prices of 148 listed firms. Despite this, the Shenzhen Stock Exchange cautioned against lingering credit risks from highly leveraged shareholders, planning to strengthen oversight of such risks.

site_title: Datapulse Technology enters into settlement with three former directors
summary: Datapulse Technology has settled with three former directors, Ng Cheow Chye, Ng Cheow Leng, and Si Yok Fong, in a full and final settlement of their claims. The former directors agreed to drop the lawsuit in exchange for payment of the agreed sum. The settlement does not affect the company's financials, as a provision had been made in the previous financial year to cover the claims. The former directors initially demanded S$751,118, but the company paid S$589,000, leaving a balance of S$161,308 under dispute, which is now settled.

site_title: Comedian Zelenskiy wins Ukrainian presidential race by landslide: Exit polls
summary: Ukrainian comedian Volodymyr Zelenskiy has won the presidential election by a landslide, securing 73% of the vote, according to exit polls. Zelenskiy, 41, who has no political experience, will become the leader of a country at war with Russia. He has promised to end the war, root out corruption, and keep Ukraine on a pro-Western course. The victory is a bitter blow to incumbent Petro Poroshenko, who conceded defeat but vowed to continue fighting. Zelenskiy's presidency will be closely watched by the West, Russia, and the International Monetary Fund, which will be monitoring his economic policies and potential reforms.

site_title: New GPS-based procedures for Seletar Airport to be rolled out
summary: Malaysia and Singapore have agreed to implement GPS-based instrument approach procedures for Seletar Airport, replacing the Instrument Landing System (ILS) procedures. The new system will be rolled out within 6-12 months, allowing Firefly, the only airline operating turboprop flights to Singapore, to increase daily flights from two to six. The move is seen as a boost to Firefly and a symbol of strong bilateral relations between the two countries. The GPS procedure will enable planes to land safely in bad weather and is expected to be jointly developed by the civil aviation authorities of both nations.

site_title: China to accept applications for restricted scrap metal imports from late May: Association
summary: Chinese authorities will start accepting applications for licenses to import restricted scrap metal from late May, with eight types of scrap including copper and aluminum to be restricted from July 1. The move aims to reduce foreign solid waste and address shortages for Chinese buyers. Provincial units will collect applications, while the Ministry of Ecology and Environment will formally approve them from July 1. The goal is to achieve basically zero imports of solid waste by the end of 2020.

site_title: Man who stopped a global cyberattack pleads guilty in US to writing malware
summary: A British security researcher, Marcus Hutchins, who helped stop a 2017 global ransomware cyberattack, pleaded guilty in the US to writing malicious software. Hutchins, known as "MalwareTech," was arrested at the Las Vegas airport in 2017 and had been hailed as a hero for his role in stopping the attack. He pleaded guilty to writing malware in a separate case, showing a darker side to his past actions. Hutchins' actions helped protect millions of computers worldwide from the ransomware attack.

site_title: Property agents hope Brexit extension will dispel housing market gloom
summary: Property agents in London are optimistic that a Brexit extension will boost the housing market, as static property prices and cheap fixed-rate mortgages may encourage buyers to take advantage of the situation. The market has been under pressure due to tightened regulations on foreign corporate purchases and Brexit sentiment. However, a rebound in UK homebuyer demand to a six-month high suggests that the market is slowly recovering. Agents hope the extension will dispel the current gloom and stimulate activity in the market.

site_title: Global Invacom Group's proposed acquisition of Tactilis terminated
summary: Global Invacom Group (GInva) has terminated its proposed acquisition of Tactilis Sdn Bhd after failing to meet conditions in the sale and purchase agreement. The deal, valued at US$200 million, would have given GInva control of Tactilis' biometric solution, the Tactilis Touch, which captures fingerprints more accurately than rivals. GInva will bear the break fee of US$20 million and split costs with the vendor. The acquisition was stalled after GInva's unusual share price movements and concerns over the vendor's financials.

site_title: Apple slammed Qualcomm in public, but praised it in private
summary: Apple publicly criticized Qualcomm's technology as worthless during a two-year legal battle, but internal documents show the company privately praised Qualcomm's engineering and unique patent share. Apple and Qualcomm settled their dispute with a six-year licensing agreement and a multi-year supply agreement, with Apple making an unspecified payment. The documents raise questions about Apple's methods to undermine Qualcomm, including a plan to reduce Apple's net royalty to Qualcomm and create evidence by licensing other patents at lower rates. The settlement has led to a significant increase in Qualcomm's stock price, while Apple faces potential antitrust allegations.

site_title: US refiners planning major plant overhauls in 2nd quarter
summary: US oil refiners are planning significant maintenance overhauls in the second quarter, with a 8.5% decline in production compared to the start of the year. This is to avoid fall and winter shutdowns as they prepare for low-sulfur standards and the International Maritime Organization's 2020 regulations, which will reduce air pollution. The maintenance schedule may push winter turnarounds into 2020, and an average of 1 million barrels per day of crude oil refining capacity could be offline during the second quarter, affecting US gasoline prices.

site_title: Fresh prospects in Australian student housing for Wee Hur
summary: Wee Hur Holdings, a Singapore-based property group, has successfully entered the Australian student housing market, developing a $1.1 billion portfolio of six purpose-built student accommodation (PBSA) properties with 5,000 beds. The company's flexible and nimble approach allowed it to capitalize on the market's crisis in 2014. Wee Hur's dual construction and development capabilities give it an edge in the relatively young Australian PBSA market, with the group partnering with local operators to manage the properties. The company expects to continue expanding its PBSA business in Australia and may consider listing its PBSA Master Trust as a Singapore real estate investment trust (Reit) in the future.

site_title: Fiat Chrysler recalls 300,000 cars that may roll unexpectedly
summary: Fiat Chrysler is recalling over 300,000 Dodge Dart compact cars from 2013 to 2016 due to a potential cable issue that may cause the car to roll away unexpectedly when shifting to park. The recall affects six-speed automatic transmission models and will be notified to customers starting May 31. Dealers will replace the faulty piece at no cost to owners, and Fiat Chrysler advises owners to shut off the engine and set the parking brake before leaving the cars. No related crashes or injuries have been reported.

site_title: Data breaches won't derail Singapore's tech push: Minister
summary: Singapore's efforts to build a "Smart Nation" won't be hindered by recent data breaches, including one involving HIV patient details leaked. Minister Vivian Balakrishnan emphasized the need for openness and corrective measures to regain public trust. He stated, "If people lose confidence in the integrity and security of the system, then all these aspirations cannot be fulfilled." Despite the breaches, the government remains committed to testing and investing in the latest technology to achieve its Smart Nation goals.

site_title: Sabana Reit announces Q1 DPU of 0.75 cent per unit
summary: Sabana Reit reported a Q1 distribution per unit (DPU) of 0.75 Singapore cent, down from 0.88 cent in the same period last year. Gross revenue fell 11.8% to S$18.52 million, while net property income (NPI) declined 13.3% to S$12.65 million. The decline is attributed to lower occupancies and a planned exit of a significant tenant at 151 Lorong Chuan. The company expects a muted performance in H1 2019 but anticipates an improved performance in the latter half of the year or early 2020 following an enhancement initiative.

site_title: Nanshan-backed W Capital has more than 10 IPO pipeline deals
summary: Singapore-based investment firm W Capital, backed by China's Nanshan Group, has secured issue manager and Catalist sponsor accreditation from the Singapore Exchange (SGX), a rare feat requiring the hiring of at least three professionals with corporate finance advisory experience. W Capital has more than 10 IPO pipeline deals, including companies from Singapore, Australia, Indonesia, South Korea, and Sri Lanka, and plans to attract more listings with pre-IPO fundraising and listing in Singapore. The firm aims to build an international financial group with a presence in key Asia-Pacific financial centers.

site_title: Joe Biden begins taking money for a 2020 presidential campaign
summary: Former US Vice President Joe Biden has begun accepting financial donations for a 2020 presidential campaign, signaling his intention to challenge President Donald Trump. The move comes ahead of his expected announcement next week. Democratic donors and party fundraisers have been encouraged to write sizable checks, contrasting with other candidates' focus on small donors. Biden's allies aim to secure significant financial support from wealthy contributors, a strategy that may be politically risky given the Democratic primary's emphasis on limiting the influence of big donors.

images.alt_text: Former Vice President Joe Biden has begun accepting financial donations for a 2020 presidential campaign, an unambiguous sign that he intends to begin his challenge to President Donald Trump within days.

site_title: Boeing 737 MAX joint governmental review will begin April 29: US FAA
summary: The US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) will begin a 90-day joint governmental review of the grounded Boeing 737 MAX on April 29, involving 9 international aviation regulators. The review will assess the safety of the aircraft, grounded after two deadly crashes in Indonesia and Ethiopia, and evaluate the certification of its automated flight control system. The team, chaired by former National Transportation Safety Board chairman Chris Hart, will determine compliance with regulations and identify future enhancements. The review aims to provide a uniform response to the globalisation of the aircraft and address concerns over the MCAS system.

site_title: Sabana Reit posts lower Q1 DPU
summary: Sabana Reit reported a 15% decline in distribution per unit (DPU) to 0.75 Singapore cents in Q1 2019, due to lower revenue and net property income (NPI). Gross revenue fell 11.8% and NPI dropped 13.3%, mainly attributed to reduced rental income from lower occupancies. The Reit expects a "muted performance" in H1 2019 but anticipates improvement in the latter half of the year or early 2020 with the proposed enhancement initiative. Occupancy levels stood at 82.4% at end March, down from 84.4% in December.

site_title: Germany's Leica is latest to draw fire in China over ad
summary: German camera maker Leica has apologized for an advertisement deemed offensive in China, distancing itself from a short film featuring the iconic "tank man" photo from the 1989 Tiananmen protest crackdown. The promotional film, produced by Brazilian agency F/Nazca Saatchi Saatchi, sparked angry comments from Chinese netizens, who view the subject as taboo. Leica's spokeswoman said the video was not officially sanctioned, but the company regrets any misunderstandings. This incident joins a growing list of foreign companies to learn about China's political sensitivities, including Mercedes-Benz, Dolce & Gabbana, and Marriott.

site_title: Climate change protesters descend on France's SocGen, energy companies
summary: Climate activists blocked entrances to French bank Societe Generale, state-run utility EDF, and oil giant Total, protesting against company links to the oil and gas industry and its impact on global warming. Greenpeace criticized Societe Generale for financing oil and gas projects, while EDF claimed 96% of its power was carbon-free. Total acknowledged the climate change protests, stating it's trying to address the issue through efficiency improvements and renewable energy development. Police pepper-sprayed protesters, who used creative tactics to obstruct entrances.

site_title: Tourists follow 'Game of Thrones' trail in Northern Ireland
summary: Tourists in Northern Ireland are following the "Game of Thrones" trail, visiting coastal caves and ruined castles where the show was filmed. The trail has drawn 120,000 visitors in 2016, generating £30 million in revenue. The province's tourism board estimates one in six visitors now comes to see shooting locations. With the final season ending, spin-off projects and a studio tour are expected to continue the tourism boom, with the chief executive saying the association with the series has "longevity" and improved the province's global image.

images.alt_text: Since the blood and guts series began its rise to prominence in 2011, fans have started to flock to the coastal caves and ruined castles of the British province where much of the HBO television production was shot.

site_title: Wimbledon embraces web, plans online public ballot: FT
summary: Wimbledon is introducing an online public ballot to attend the tournament, aiming to modernize the process for next year's event. Currently, applicants must complete a paper form and wait weeks for a reply. The change is part of the All England Lawn Tennis Club's efforts to relax its traditional image. The club has previously made changes, such as installing a TV screen in 1997 and a retractable roof in 2009. The online ballot is expected to be introduced this month, offering a more efficient way for fans to secure tickets to the prestigious event.

site_title: Aging Japan to see 25 per cent of breadwinners turn 75 or older by 2040
summary: Japan's rapidly-aging society will see a quarter of its breadwinners turn 75 or older by 2040, with 12.17 million head-of-households expected to reach this age. The number of single-person households, including those 75 or older, will reach 19.94 million, or two-fifths of the total. This trend highlights the need for a social security system and infrastructure revamp. The labor shortage, exacerbated by low unemployment, is being felt across industries, prompting the government to consider low-skilled foreign workers.

images.alt_text: Japan's rapidly-aging society will see a quarter of its breadwinners turn 75 or older by 2040, the Nikkei reported, citing a study from the National Institute of Population and Social Security Research.

site_title: Tesla proposes series of changes to board of directors
summary: Tesla proposes changes to its 11-member board of directors at its annual shareholder meeting. The proposed changes include reducing director terms to two years from three, allowing for more frequent performance evaluations. Directors Brad Buss, Linda Johnson Rice, and Steve Jurvetson, whose terms expire in June and 2020, do not plan to seek re-election, potentially reducing the board to nine members.

site_title: PepsiCo results beat as new CEO's ad push lifts sales
summary: PepsiCo Inc's quarterly sales and profit beat Wall Street estimates, driven by a successful advertising and marketing push that lifted sales of snacks, sparkling waters, and low-sugar sodas globally. Core sales grew at the fastest pace in over three years, with shares reaching a record high of $125.92. The company's efforts to focus on healthier snacks and beverages, including modified recipes and product size changes, are paying off as consumers increasingly prioritize health.

site_title: Tokyo: Japan, China shares climb in thin holiday trade
summary: Tokyo and Shanghai stocks closed higher on Friday, with the Nikkei 225 index up 0.50% and the Shanghai Composite Index gaining 0.63%. Nintendo surged 14% on reports its Switch console will be available in China, while Chinese stocks also rose despite concerns over China's slowing economy. The Japanese market stayed positive, but some investors adjusted their positions due to the Easter holiday closures and lack of fresh market clues.

site_title: Game of Thrones reigns supreme in Northern Ireland's tourism boom
summary: Northern Ireland's tourism industry has experienced a boom following the popularity of Game of Thrones, with fans flocking to coastal caves, ruined castles, and sleepy village shops to re-enact scenes from the show. Since 2011, the series drew 120,000 visitors in 2016, generating £30 million in revenue. Today, one in six visitors comes to Northern Ireland to visit shooting locations, with tour operators offering immersive experiences like axe-throwing and photo opportunities with wolves. The tourism board attributes the success to the province's association with the global hit series, which may have a lasting impact on the local economy.

site_title: Seagram heiress Clare Bronfman pleads guilty in New York sex cult case
summary: Seagram heiress Clare Bronfman, 40, pleaded guilty to harboring an illegal immigrant and enabling credit card fraud as part of the alleged Nxivm sex cult. She agreed to forfeit $6 million and not appeal a prison sentence of 27 months or less. Bronfman's guilty plea comes after several others, including actress Allison Mack and former Nxivm president Nancy Salzman, pleaded guilty to related charges. Nxivm founder Keith Raniere, 58, remains a defendant, facing sex trafficking and child pornography charges.

site_title: Total plans to use artificial intelligence to cut drilling costs
summary: Total SA plans to launch a digital factory in the coming weeks to utilize artificial intelligence in exploration and production projects, aiming to save hundreds of millions of dollars. The digital factory will employ 200-300 engineers and build on successful North Sea pilot projects, optimizing equipment use and reducing maintenance costs. The move follows a successful partnership with Alphabet's Google to develop AI solutions for subsurface data analysis. Total aims to cut drilling costs and attract young talent to the industry amid fears of a production glut and economic slowdown.

site_title: Commodity firm Trafigura jumps into chemical trading with new JV
summary: Trafigura, a global commodities firm, has formed a joint venture with Altis Group International to enter the petrochemicals trading market. The venture will focus on bulk liquid chemicals, such as sulphur byproducts, and will have units in Houston and Geneva. The move aims to capitalize on the growing global petrochemical market, valued at $729 billion, driven by increasing demand from emerging markets. The partnership serves as a bridge between Trafigura's industrial metal interests and oil business, and is expected to benefit from a new cap on sulphur content in shipping fuels set to come into effect next year.

site_title: Second death in Novartis gene therapy trials under investigation
summary: Novartis is investigating a second death in its gene therapy trials for spinal muscular atrophy (SMA), following a patient's death in the US trial. The death occurred in the context of a severe respiratory infection, and an autopsy is pending. The company has expanded its clinical trial program, involving 22 babies with Type 1 SMA, and interim results show encouraging progress in motor skills. Novartis is seeking FDA approval for its gene therapy, Zolgensma, despite the deaths, which could impact its pricing and availability. The company estimates that 50% of babies with SMA Type 1 will not survive without treatment.

images.alt_text: Novartis AG, which this week announced positive interim trial results for its experimental gene therapy for spinal muscular atrophy, on Friday said investigation is underway into whether a second trial death could be related to the treatment.

site_title: Ancestry.com apologises for ad showing slavery-era interracial couple
summary: Ancestry.com apologized for a video advertisement that seemed to romanticize slavery-era interracial relationships, depicting a white man and a black woman escaping together. The ad drew criticism for whitewashing the nature of these relationships, which often involved rape and exploitation. Ancestry.com removed the ad from television and YouTube, and issued an apology, stating it was intended to represent a story from history but caused offense. The company is committed to telling important stories from history and appreciates feedback, but the ad's problematic portrayal of slavery-era relationships sparked widespread criticism.

site_title: Ransomware 'hero' pleads guilty to US hacking charges
summary: Marcus Hutchins, a British computer security researcher, pleaded guilty to US hacking charges related to his activity in 2014 and 2015. Hutchins, known by his alias "MalwareTech," was once hailed as a "hero" for helping stem a ransomware outbreak in 2017. However, he was accused of creating malware to attack the banking system and distributing a hacking tool on dark markets. Hutchins could face up to one year in jail and financial penalties for his actions, which he described as a "mistake" and accepted full responsibility for.

site_title: Social media boycott as footballers in England say 'enough' over racism
summary: Premier League footballers in England and Wales have led a 24-hour social media boycott to combat racist abuse online. The boycott, coordinated by the England's Professional Footballers' Association, urges players to stay off all social media from 9:00am on Friday. The campaign aims to tackle racism in football and is not just limited to those who use social media to air racist views, but also at the social media companies and football authorities. The boycott follows incidents of abuse, including racist chants during a Euro 2020 qualifier and Islamophobic abuse by Chelsea fans.

site_title: S.Korea: Stocks edge higher on bargain hunting; down 0.8 pct for week
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index rose 0.11% to 2,216.15 on Friday, driven by bargain hunting after a previous session's losses. Foreigners were net sellers, while local investors were net buyers. The benchmark bond yield rose, and the won held steady. The Kospi lost 0.76% for the week, snapping two weeks of gains.

site_title: Flying the flag high for women riders
summary: The Fahrenheit Performance Development Team, Singapore's first all-female cycling team, is set to compete in the OCBC Cycle 2019 event on May 11-12. Led by team captain Elizabeth Hodges, the team aims to promote cycling among women, addressing common concerns such as feeling unskilled or apprehensive about riding in groups. The team's main goal is to encourage women to take up cycling, with Hodges envisioning a supportive community that makes women feel comfortable and safe on the road.

site_title: Qatar's sovereign fund, Crown Acquisitions named as investors in US$5.6b New York deal
summary: Qatar's sovereign fund, Crown Acquisitions, have invested in a US$5.6 billion deal with Vornado Realty Trust, acquiring a 24% stake in a portfolio of prime New York retail properties. The deal, valued at US$1.31 billion, involves a portfolio of stores along Fifth Avenue and Broadway in Times Square. The investment is part of Qatar's ambition to boost its US investments to US$45 billion, with QIA chief executive Mansoor al-Mahmoud stating that the deal underlines the fund's belief in New York City's long-term possibilities.

site_title: Can Bhutan take its happiness brand to the next level?
summary: Bhutan's "happiness brand" is a global phenomenon, but the country faces challenges in applying this brand to growth sectors and motivating ordinary citizens to contribute to nation brand-building. Key issues include ensuring consistency between brand promise and delivery, leveraging brand attributes to sectoral branding, and engaging Bhutanese people through public education and enlisting them as country brand ambassadors. By addressing these challenges, Bhutan can take its happiness brand to the next level and promote sustainable and equitable socio-economic development.

site_title: SM Investments to sue Hyflux for alleged breach of agreement
summary: SM Investments plans to sue Hyflux for allegedly breaching an agreement to rescue the debt-laden water treatment group. The agreement, worth S$530 million, was canceled on April 4, with both parties claiming the other had breached the deal. SM Investments is seeking a S$38.9 million deposit placed in escrow. Meanwhile, Maybank will appoint receivers and managers for Tuaspring assets, excluding the desalination plant, after terminating its collaboration agreement with Hyflux.

images.alt_text: Former white knight SM Investments (SMI) will sue debt-laden Hyflux for cancelling the S$530 million rescue deal, it said in a statement on Friday.

site_title: Accor's Q1 RevPAR held back by weakness in Asia, N America
summary: Accor, Europe's largest hotel group, reported a 1.6% increase in revenue per available room (RevPAR) in Q1 2019, despite weakness in Asia and North America. The company attributed the decline to oversupply in major cities, upcoming elections, and Chinese outbound travel. RevPAR in Asia Pacific fell 0.6%, while China saw a 3% decline. Accor expects RevPAR to improve to around 3% for the full year 2019, driven by recovery in Asia and expansion in the luxury market. Revenue rose 8.8% on a like-for-like basis to 987 million euros.

site_title: The lazy hysteria of social media
summary: A historic image of a black hole overshadowed by online outrage and narcissism, with Katie Bouman, the researcher behind the algorithm, becoming the face of the moment. Despite her efforts to clarify that no one person made the image, she was subjected to sexist and misogynistic attacks. Meanwhile, a bubble tea trend on Taobao, where users paid to have others eat or drink on their behalf, demonstrated the banality and superficiality of social media, highlighting the tension between genuine curiosity and online vitriol.

images.alt_text: For the social-media herd, there is cheap vanity to peddle, cheap jokes and insults to tell, and cheap lines to draw across ideologies.

site_title: 2018 Bordeaux are exceptional: here's what to invest in now
summary: The 2018 Bordeaux vintage is exceptional, with wines combining plushness and ripe structure. Tasting barrel samples, experts found fantastic examples from chateaux like Lafite Rothschild and Vieux Chateau Certan, while some wines have bitter tannins or high alcohol. The style of the wines is characterized by freshness, juiciness, and density, with long growing seasons and gentle winemaking. Key buys include Lafleur, Petrus, and Vieux Chateau Certan, with many more stunning wines available at various price levels.

site_title: Can a preacher walk a Godly path in Yeezys?
summary: A pastor-led Instagram account, PreachersNSneakers, has sparked controversy over the financial displays of prominent pastors wearing expensive sneakers, often selling for thousands of dollars. The account, which has gained over 100,000 followers, has led to discussions on materialism, faith, and the presentation of oneself in the world. Pastors have defended their choices, stating that they have the right to spend their money as they see fit, while others have criticized the account for sowing discord and promoting vanity. The debate has highlighted the tension between the church's teachings and the pursuit of material wealth.

site_title: Singapore SMBs most 'digitally mature' in region: Cisco
summary: Singapore's small and medium businesses (SMBs) are the most digitally mature in the Asia-Pacific region, according to a new index by Cisco. The APAC SMB Digital Maturity Index found that 60% of SMBs in Asia-Pacific have started to embrace digitalization. Singapore's firms are classified as "digital observers," with top digital investments in cybersecurity, cloud technology, and analytics. Despite obstacles such as a lack of digital skills and talent, 41.4% of respondents in Singapore are aware of government initiatives supporting SMB digitalization.

site_title: Turf houses are Iceland's architectural jewels
summary: Iceland's turf houses, a traditional architectural style introduced by the first Nordic settlers in the 9th century, are being preserved as cultural heritage sites. These unique buildings, made from cut turf and stone foundations, blend seamlessly into their natural surroundings. With a lifespan of around 20-70 years due to Iceland's harsh weather, only a small fraction of the original 5,500 turf homes remain, with 14 currently on the tentative list of Unesco World Heritage sites. Efforts are being made to maintain these historic structures using traditional techniques.

site_title: Samsung's review phones fail, delivering a PR nightmare
summary: Samsung's latest flagship phone, the Galaxy Fold, has failed to impress reviewers, with several reporting issues with the device's screen after only a few days of use. The phone's foldable design, which allows the screen to be folded and unfolded like a book, has been marred by complaints of a dead screen, unusable device, and damage to the display. Samsung has scrambled to address the issues, stating that the main display has a protective layer that can be damaged if removed or if adhesives are added to the main display. The company has promised to thoroughly inspect the units and ensure that customers are aware of the potential risks.

images.alt_text: Devices with flexible displays have been more fragile because they expose the screens to broader angles of impact, says Kyle Wiens, chief executive of iFixit, a company that offers instructions for people to repair their devices.

site_title: Hyundai hires former Ghosn ally Munoz as global COO, Americas head
summary: Hyundai Motor Co has appointed Jose Munoz as global chief operating officer and Americas head, bringing in a former ally of Nissan's ousted Chairman Carlos Ghosn. Munoz, 53, joins Hyundai amid a management overhaul due to plunging sales in China and the US. He will succeed William Lee and report to top leadership in Seoul, with a focus on delivering profitable growth and improving overall performance. Munoz's appointment comes as heir-apparent Euisun Chung strengthens control of the conglomerate, following a series of promotions of executives from Samsung Electronics and BMW.

site_title: Thai growth on track if next govt formed by June: Central bank
summary: Thailand's economy is forecasted to grow 3.8% this year if the next government is formed by June, according to the central bank governor. Low inflation is not a concern, with the central bank focusing on growth and financial stability risks. The outcome of the general election, held on March 24, remains uncertain, with official results due on May 9. The central bank's stance suggests a positive outlook for Thailand's economic growth, despite the election uncertainty.

site_title: Is the '996' work culture the way to go in Singapore?
summary: Chinese billionaire Jack Ma sparked controversy by supporting the "996" work culture, where employees work 12 hours a day, six days a week, to succeed. Ma claimed that those who don't subscribe to this philosophy "won't taste the happiness and rewards of hard work." The views were met with backlash, with netizens denouncing them as draconian and exploitative. The article raises questions about the balance between hard work and overall well-being in the workplace.

site_title: Qualcomm's joint venture with Chinese province to shut down
summary: A joint venture between Qualcomm and China's Guizhou province, Huaxintong Semiconductor, will shut down by April 30 due to slowed or stalled work on future chips. Qualcomm and Guizhou invested a combined $570 million in the venture, formed in 2016 for advanced server technology. The decision follows a report of the CEO's replacement and reduced chip development efforts. Qualcomm declined to comment, and HXT could not be immediately reached for comment.

site_title: Cosmopolitan in the city
summary: The Cosmopolitan, a classic cocktail, remains a contemporary favorite, featured on the International Bartenders Association's official cocktail list. Its origins are unclear, with proposed birthplaces including Minneapolis and Provincetown, Massachusetts, in the 1970s or 1980s. A Tom Cruise-themed bar, Risky Business, incorporates the Cosmo into its menu, alongside other Cruise-inspired cocktails. The bar's owner, Jamie Gripton, drew inspiration from Cruise's 1988 film Cocktail. The Cosmo's simplicity and timeless appeal have contributed to its enduring popularity, with experts arguing it helped start the modern cocktail culture.

site_title: Preparing for the future of the investment profession
summary: The investment industry is undergoing a structural transformation, akin to an "industrial revolution," with continuous disruption. To prepare for the future, employers must allow for horizontal career growth and skills acquisition, while employees need an explicit strategy for career management. This shift is driven by technological advancements and changing market conditions, requiring a proactive approach to talent development and engagement. By prioritizing productivity gains and adapting to emerging trends, the industry can unlock wealth creation and drive long-term success.

site_title: Brokers that can make you rich
summary: Stockbrokers are evolving beyond mere trading services, offering comprehensive financial guidance and portfolio management to clients. Some brokers help clients organize their finances, identify suitable investments, and improve their portfolios. Corporate brokers also specialize in servicing businesses, helping them raise funds, identify merger targets, and float on the stock market. However, brokers can struggle during bear markets, and their profits are heavily influenced by market conditions. The industry's high net income margins, averaging $9 in profit for every $100 invested, are driven by leverage and the sale of exotic trading products. The current valuations of brokers appear rich, with an average price-to-earnings ratio of 20, making them a potential buy for those expecting the bull market to continue.

site_title: Indonesia's 'smooth' polls a democratic beacon in sea of strongmen: analysts
summary: Indonesia successfully held a one-day election with a record 245,000 candidates, resulting in a high voter turnout of 82% and cementing its status as a democratic beacon in a region dominated by authoritarian governments. President Joko Widodo is expected to win a second term, but his rival Prabowo Subianto has vowed to challenge the results. Despite challenges such as militant Islam and ethnic tensions, Indonesia's democratic progress remains a significant achievement, but experts warn of potential erosion of democratic quality over the next five years.

site_title: Transport is star performer YTD among industrials
summary: Transport firms in Singapore have been the top performers among industrials in the year-to-date period, with an average return of 27.6% among the top five firms. SBS Transit and ComfortDelGro led the pack with returns of 68.3% and 25.8%, respectively, driven by their recovery in margins and earnings. Analysts attribute the rally to factors such as increased public transport fares, rising ridership on the Downtown Line, and the shift to the bus contracting model.

site_title: Singapore hotels don't kid around when it comes to family vacations
summary: Singapore hotels cater to families with kids-centric attractions, offering themed pool zones, scavenger hunts, sandcastle-building, and special children's brunches. Many hotels, including Club Med, Far East Hospitality, and Shangri-La Hotel, have launched family-focused packages and play spaces, such as Nestopia and Ritz Kids Play Land. These investments boost occupancy and build long-term relationships with clients, as children become loyal customers. The trend is driven by research showing that parents prioritize their children's well-being during family vacations.

site_title: Japan inflation edges higher but BOJ still in a bind
summary: Japan's core inflation rose 0.8% in March, slightly above forecasts, but still below the Bank of Japan's 2% target. The central bank is in a bind due to years of heavy money printing, which has hurt bond market liquidity and commercial banks' profits. Economists warn that if other economic indicators worsen, the BOJ may need to fine-tune its policy. With core consumer inflation potentially grinding to a halt in coming months, the BOJ may face pressure to come up with measures to boost prices.

site_title: Aramco hype meets reality as bonds drop despite bumper sale
summary: Aramco's unprecedented debt sale of $12 billion has led to a slump in its bond prices, with all five maturities falling since trading started last week. Despite bidding at $100 billion, investors are now paying the price for the discrepancy, with bond prices dropping by more than two US cents on the dollar. This marks a stark contrast to the Saudi government's yields, which are generally lower. The drop in Aramco's bond prices highlights the challenges of navigating the corporate bond market in the Saudi energy giant's unique circumstances.

site_title: Uber wins US$1b investment from Toyota, SoftBank fund
summary: Uber has secured a $1 billion investment from Toyota and SoftBank Vision Fund, with Toyota contributing $667 million and SoftBank Vision Fund adding $333 million. The investment aims to accelerate the development of automated ridesharing services. Uber's CEO, Dara Khosrowshahi, stated that driverless cars will transform transportation, making streets safer and cities more livable. The investment is part of Uber's efforts to go beyond car rides and become the "Amazon of transportation."

site_title: Premium New Zealand honey producer admits adding chemicals
summary: A New Zealand company, Evergreen Life Ltd, pleaded guilty to adding artificial chemicals to its premium manuka honey, a high-value export. The company's products were pulled from shelves in 2016 after the Ministry for Primary Industries detected "non-approved substances". This case marks a flagship prosecution for the country. The incident highlights concerns over the quality and authenticity of manuka honey, which has gained popularity globally for its potential health and cosmetic benefits. The company faces unspecified penalties for its actions.

site_title: TT International seeks extensions for moratorium, scheme of arrangement
summary: TT International, a consumer electronics retailer, is seeking a fourth extension of a moratorium until July 31, 2019, and a new long stop date for its scheme of arrangement. The scheme involves selling shares to Celestial Palace. The company has already had trading suspended since August 2017. TT International is seeking to facilitate assessment of the impact of amendments to the scheme and address creditor concerns. The company will make further announcements as material developments occur.

site_title: Rights group condemns US 'vigilantes' treatment of migrants on border
summary: A US rights group, the American Civil Liberties Union of New Mexico, has condemned a group of armed citizens, the United Constitutional Patriots, for detaining migrants at the US-Mexico border. The group, claiming to be mainly military veterans, has been patrolling the border since February, detaining migrants until US Border Patrol agents arrive. The ACLU calls them a "fascist militia organisation" and urges New Mexico Governor Michelle Lujan Grisham and Attorney General Hector Balderas to investigate. US Customs and Border Protection Commissioner Kevin McAleenan said his agency does not need the group's help policing the border.

site_title: Maybank intends to appoint receivers and managers for Tuaspring assets
summary: Maybank intends to appoint receivers and managers for Tuaspring assets, following the termination of its collaboration agreement with Hyflux and Tuaspring. Maybank is Tuaspring's only secured creditor and had agreed to refrain from commencing enforcement proceedings until a binding agreement was executed. With the extended deadline passed, Maybank claims a breach and is now entitled to terminate the agreement, leading to the appointment of receivers and managers over Tuaspring's assets, excluding the desalination plant and shared infrastructure.

site_title: Yield curve inversion = Imminent recession?
summary: The yield curve inversion, a common indicator for impending recession, has sparked concerns among economists and investors. However, a detailed analysis of past occurrences suggests that a yield curve inversion does not necessarily predict a recession, with only 77.78% of inversions leading to a recession. In fact, a bear market often precedes an inversion, and the timing tool's accuracy is limited to one to four years. The article concludes that the yield curve inversion is not a reliable predictor of a recession, making it a less useful tool for market timing.

images.alt_text: Since equity markets have a tendency to anticipate and discount future events, equity bear markets always start well before a recession. This happens because economic recessions are based on GDP data, which is backward looking.

site_title: Goldman study works out best times to enter, exit earnings trades
summary: Goldman Sachs has released a study analyzing the best times to enter and exit earnings trades, finding that the five days preceding an earnings day offer the most attractive days to access liquidity in a single stock. Strategists recommend pre-positioning for earnings moves but waiting four to six days after to exit. The study also highlights opportunities in the options market, particularly with low volatility levels, and identifies 25 "most differentiated" ideas for the next earnings season.

site_title: Metro JV acquires Grade-A Tampines office building
summary: Metro Holdings unit Metrobilt Construction has entered a 50:50 joint venture to acquire 7 and 9 Tampines Grande, a Grade-A office property in Singapore, for S$395 million. The investment aims to gain exposure to Singapore's decentralised office market and is expected to contribute to Metro's stable income stream with potential positive rental reversion. The deal is not expected to have a significant impact on Metro's financial performance, and the property will be held as a whole for long-term investment or sale as individual strata units.

images.alt_text: 7 and 9 Tampines Grande comprises two blocks of eight-storey office towers linked by an entrance lobby with retail, as well as food and beverage outlets on the ground floor.

site_title: Gold prices slump over positive global cues
summary: Gold prices plummeted due to strong risk sentiments, boosted by better-than-expected Chinese economic releases and US-China trade negotiations. Robust US economic data and corporate earnings further fueled market optimism, shifting investor focus away from gold. As a result, gold prices are poised to trade lower, with safe haven appeal diminished. However, the author remains optimistic on gold prices in the longer term, citing negative global economic momentum and subdued equities.

site_title: China bans Boston Marathon trio in latest cheating scandal
summary: China has banned three runners from participating in all road running events for life after they were caught cheating at the Boston Marathon. The runners were accused of giving China a bad name and will be subject to further crackdowns on cheating in the country. China's athletic association has implemented facial-recognition technology to clamp down on cheating, which has become a growing issue in the country's rapidly expanding marathon scene, with over 500 Chinese runners participating in the Boston Marathon.

site_title: China approves 1.67 gigawatts of new subsidised rural solar power
summary: China has approved the construction of 3,961 village solar power plants with a total capacity of 1.67 gigawatts, part of a programme aimed at alleviating rural poverty and promoting clean energy. The projects, the second batch of a "photovoltaic poverty relief" programme, should be completed by the end of this year. These projects will remain eligible for state support despite China's efforts to reduce subsidies for the solar power sector. The approval aims to reduce rural poverty and promote clean energy in China.

site_title: India rice prices dip as demand slows, Bangladesh to review export ban
summary: India's rice prices dropped due to lower demand, with prices for 5% broken parboiled rice quoted at $377-$380 per tonne. Bangladesh is reviewing its export ban, which has been in place since 2008, after strong pleas from traders. The country's rice exports for April-February dropped 9.4% from a year earlier. Thailand's rice prices eased slightly to $393-$411 per tonne, while Vietnam's 5% broken rice prices remained flat at $360 per tonne. The review of Bangladesh's export ban may lead to an increase in rice exports.

site_title: Thai growth to be on track if next government formed by June: central bank chief
summary: Thailand's central bank chief, Veerathai Santiprabhob, expects the country's economy to grow 3.8% this year if the next government is formed by June. The bank will focus on growth and financial stability risks, rather than inflation concerns. Thailand's economy has been growing, with a 4.1% growth in 2018, but still lags behind neighboring countries. The central bank has maintained its interest rate at 1.75% since December and will review policy on May 8.

site_title: Ex-white knight SM Investments sues Hyflux for breaching agreement terms
summary: Former white knight SM Investments will sue Hyflux for breaching an agreement to rescue the debt-laden water treatment group for S$530 million. SM Investments claims Hyflux wrongfully tried to walk away from the deal, citing "termination events" and failing to meet conditions to satisfy creditors. The dispute could result in both parties seeking the S$38.9 million deposit placed in escrow. The court-sanctioned debt moratorium set to expire on April 30 adds pressure to the situation.

site_title: US envoy 'disappointed' by collapse of inter-Afghan peace meeting
summary: US envoy Zalmay Khalilzad expressed disappointment over the collapse of a planned peace meeting between the Taliban and Afghan politicians in Qatar, citing deep divisions hindering efforts to end the war. The meeting was cancelled due to disagreements over participant lists, with Qatar's authorities authorizing a list that differed from Kabul's. The Taliban refused to engage with the Western-backed government in Kabul, and rival politicians' suspicions ahead of presidential elections further undermined preparations. The collapse exposed tensions hampering peace talks.

site_title: Japan government bond yields rise as BOJ trims debt purchase amount
summary: Japan's government bond yields rose after the Bank of Japan trimmed the amount of debt it offered to buy at a regular market operation, with yields on 10- to 25-year bonds gaining half a basis point. The central bank reduced its purchase of 25- to 40-year bonds, impacting yields on these bonds. The benchmark 10-year JGB yield rose to minus 0.025%, while the 20-year, 30-year, and 40-year yields increased to 0.390%, 0.575%, and 0.605%, respectively.

site_title: Meal replacement company Soylent launches new 'mini-meal' protein bar
summary: Soylent, a meal replacement company, has launched a new product called Soylent Squared, a 100-calorie, chewable "mini-meal" bar. The product, which is not a cube, represents a next step from Soylent's liquid meal replacement drink. The company aims to expand its product line to include solid food options, echoing its trajectory from being a step beyond traditional food to a more conventional snack. Soylent Squared will be available online and is part of the company's efforts to innovate and introduce new products, including a carton of low-calorie, protein-rich Soylent in beverage form.

site_title: HNA denies embezzlement claims as it fights for control of HK Airlines
summary: Chinese conglomerate HNA Group has denied accusations of embezzlement and financial irregularity by a rival group of shareholders in Hong Kong Airlines (HKA). The allegations, made by Zhong Guosong and Frontier Investment Partner, claim HNA Group parties misappropriated HKA assets. HNA stated the allegations are false, and an investigation has been launched into the claims. The dispute comes as HKA struggles to survive, with executives warning of a need for at least HK$2 billion to avoid losing its operating license.

site_title: Mueller report gives Democrats political ammunition but they are split on how to use it
summary: The Mueller report provides extensive details on President Donald Trump's efforts to thwart the 2016 US election probe, giving Democrats significant political ammunition against him. The report concludes that Trump obstructed justice but stopped short of concluding a crime was committed. Despite this, party leaders are cautious about impeachment, with some prominent Democrats, including Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, pushing for it. The report's findings are likely to be repeated on the campaign trail, but Democratic presidential candidates have been cautious in their responses.

site_title: Chinese farmer breeds cockroaches for the table
summary: A Chinese farmer, Li Bingcai, breeds cockroaches for human consumption, selling them as a food item in Sichuan sauce for adventurous eaters. The insects, known as "Little Strong" due to their high immunity, are also consumed for medicinal purposes, such as treating stomach ulcers and respiratory problems. Li's farm, which houses over 10 million cockroaches, is part of a growing niche industry in China, with some farms using artificial intelligence to monitor the insects' movement and environmental conditions.

site_title: HNA denies embezzlement claims as it fights for control of Hong Kong Airlines
summary: HNA Group, a Chinese conglomerate, has denied accusations of embezzlement and financial irregularity made by rival shareholders in Hong Kong Airlines (HKA). HNA claims the allegations are false, stating it adheres to the highest standards of integrity. The dispute comes as HKA struggles financially, requiring at least HK$2 billion to avoid losing its operating license. HNA holds 29% of HKA's shares, and the rival group controls 61%. An investigation has been launched into the allegations, which were made by Zhong Guosong and Frontier Investment Partner.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 5.27 points to 1,625.00 at 9:41am on Friday, driven by a 498.5 million lots worth RM276 million. Gainers outpaced losers 262 to 91, as the market opened higher.

site_title: Soylent's new product is food, and it's square
summary: Soylent, a food replacement company, has launched its new product, Soylent Squared, a 100-calorie, chewable "mini-meal" in the form of a perfect square. The product represents a next step from liquid to solid, and is a compromise between a snack-size protein bar and a meal replacement drink. Soylent's CEO Bryan Crowley stated that the company prioritizes innovation and is working to ensure its products are not only safe but also tasty and enjoyable. Soylent Squared will be available online and costs $30 for 30 bars, with flavors including Chocolate Brownie, Citrus Berry, and Salted Caramel.

site_title: T-Mobile's CEO defends US$26.5b Sprint merger to US officials: sources
summary: T-Mobile US CEO John Legere defended the $26.5 billion merger with Sprint to top Justice Department officials, addressing concerns that the deal could harm consumers. The meeting followed staff attorneys' vetting of the merger, which raised concerns about reduced competition and higher prices. A parallel review by the Federal Communications Commission is nearing its end. Despite opposition from groups like the Communications Workers of America and Dish Network Corp, Legere argues the merged company will be a stronger rival to Verizon and AT&T, and will advance 5G technology deployment.

images.alt_text: T-Mobile US Inc chief executive officer John Legere defended his planned takeover of Sprint Corp to top Justice Department officials in a bid to head off worries the combination of the two wireless carriers could harm consumers, according to two people familiar with the matter.

site_title: Trump to be first foreign leader to meet Japan's new emperor
summary: US President Donald Trump will be the first foreign leader to meet Japan's new Emperor Naruhito after his elevation to the throne on May 1, 2019. Trump will visit Japan from May 25 to 28, followed by a visit from Prime Minister Shinzo Abe to Washington on April 26-27. This marks the first state visit by a foreign leader to Japan since the emperor's enthronement. The visit aims to strengthen bilateral relations between the two countries.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump and his wife Melania will be the first foreign state guests to visit Japan and meet with Crown Prince Naruhito after his elevation to emperor, the White House said Thursday.

site_title: Nissan plans global output cut of about 15%
summary: Nissan plans to cut global output by around 15% for the fiscal year to March 2020, citing a shift away from an aggressive expansion campaign. The move would result in producing around 4.6 million units, the lowest level in nine years. Nissan will cut production in China by 8% and overseas by 20%, while maintaining output in Japan. The move may impact earnings and throw a shadow over Nissan's alliance with Renault SA.

site_title: Sichuan, Henan got most fiscal support from China central government in 2018: report
summary: China's central government provided the most fiscal support to Sichuan and Henan provinces in 2018, with Sichuan receiving 477.97 billion yuan and Henan receiving 425.28 billion yuan. Total transfer payments stood at almost seven trillion yuan. The government has lowered its economic target to 6-6.5% for this year. Western regions, including Tibet and Qinghai, rely heavily on transfer payments, while northeastern provinces like Liaoning and Heilongjiang are reliant on government subsidies for pension payments. Beijing aims to help struggling companies and slow economic growth.

site_title: Facebook says it stored 'millions' of unencrypted Instagram passwords
summary: Facebook revealed that millions of Instagram users had their passwords stored in unencrypted form on internal servers, contradicting its previous estimate of tens of thousands. The company stated that the stored passwords were not internally abused or improperly accessed. Facebook, Instagram's parent company, had previously admitted to storing unencrypted passwords of hundreds of millions of users, following the Cambridge Analytica scandal. The social network has announced moves to tighten data handling, including eliminating data-sharing partnerships.

site_title: Crude oil touted as health cure in Azerbaijan
summary: Azerbaijan's Naftalan town is known for its crude oil baths, believed to cure conditions like polyarthritis. Visitors, including a Russian woman with polyarthritis, bathe in heated oil for 10 minutes, with some reporting improvement. However, Western doctors have condemned the method as potentially carcinogenic, citing the oil's high naphthalene content. Despite controversy, the town's oil baths remain a popular health treatment option, with costs ranging from 100 to 1,000 euros per week.

site_title: Uber lands US$1 billion from SoftBank, Toyota for self-driving unit
summary: Uber's autonomous vehicle unit, Advanced Technologies Group (ATG), has raised $1 billion from SoftBank Group Corp, Toyota Motor Corp, and Denso Corp, valuing ATG at $7.25 billion. This investment will help Uber cover the substantial cost of developing self-driving cars, addressing investor concerns. The funding also paves the way for Uber's upcoming initial public offering (IPO), expected to raise $10 billion at a $90 billion to $100 billion valuation.

site_title: China says Belt and Road project not geopolitical tool, understands concerns
summary: China's Belt and Road project is not a "geopolitical tool" or a debt crisis, but a platform for cooperation, according to Chinese State Councillor Wang Yi. The project, envisioned by President Xi Jinping, aims to rebuild the Silk Road with massive infrastructure spending. Despite criticism from the US, which views it as a means to spread Chinese influence and saddle countries with unsustainable debt, Wang welcomed constructive suggestions and said the project has brought real benefits to participating countries. The April 25-27 summit in Beijing will feature 37 foreign leaders, including some closest allies, with the US sending low-level representatives.

site_title: US wins WTO ruling against China grain import quotas
summary: The US won a World Trade Organization (WTO) ruling against China's use of tariff-rate quotas for rice, wheat, and corn, which limited market access for US grain exports. A WTO dispute panel found that China's system for administering these quotas was inconsistent with WTO rules, violating its obligation to do so on a "transparent, predictable, and fair basis." The ruling could help American farmers compete on a more level playing field, with an estimated $3.5 billion worth of corn, wheat, and rice that could have been imported in 2015.

site_title: Asian markets closed for holiday
summary: Asian financial markets, including those in Australia, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, New Zealand, the Philippines, and Singapore, are closed on Friday for a public holiday. This closure follows a week of market activity that saw stocks in Singapore rally for five consecutive days ahead of GDP data, and US stocks edge down from records despite tariff threats. Markets in Europe are also experiencing volatility, with mining and healthcare stocks propelling shares higher, while US-EU trade talks remain a focus.

site_title: South Korea steps up shift to cleaner energy, sets long-term renewable power targets
summary: South Korea sets a long-term renewable power target of 35% by 2040, a significant increase from the current 8% of renewable energy in its production. The plan aims to reduce the country's reliance on coal and nuclear power, while expanding gas power generation. The Ministry of Trade, Industry and Energy plans to finalize its energy policy revision after public hearing feedback. This move follows a 2017 plan to increase renewable energy to 20% by 2030, and comes as the country aims to move towards cleaner and safer energy.

site_title: US dollar steadies after upbeat US data amid holiday-thin trade
summary: The US dollar steadied against a basket of currencies on Friday, rising to a two and a half week high overnight due to upbeat US data. The dollar index reached 97.485, its highest level since April 2. The euro was dented by weak European manufacturing activity. Financial markets were closed for the Good Friday Easter holiday, resulting in light trading volume.

site_title: Shares in Brazilian card processors fall sharply after rival cuts interest rate for merchants
summary: Shares in Brazilian card payment processors Cielo SA, PagSeguro Digital Ltd, and StoneCo Ltd plummeted after rival Itaú Unibanco Holding SA cut interest rates for small and medium-sized merchants. StoneCo and PagSeguro fell 22.5% and 11.5%, respectively, while Cielo dropped 8%. The move, which advances payments in two days with no interest, is expected to increase competition in the payments sector, hurting all card processors' results. Analysts estimate a 32% annualized net profit impact for Stone and 19% for Cielo, with PagSeguro potentially experiencing less pain due to its existing micro-merchant payment service.

site_title: Woman killed after shots fired in Londonderry riot
summary: A 29-year-old woman was killed in Londonderry, Northern Ireland, after shots were fired during a riot. The incident occurred in the Irish nationalist Creggan area, where police were attacked with petrol bombs and other missiles. Police launched a murder investigation, treating the incident as a terrorist attack. The riot was in response to a house search by officers, and local leaders condemned the killing. US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi was in the city for a visit to show support for the 1998 peace agreement.

site_title: Nintendo shares soar as Tencent wins Switch game approval in China
summary: Nintendo's shares surged 15% after China's Tencent Holdings Ltd won approval to distribute the test version of New Super Mario Bros U Deluxe for the Switch console. This approval is seen as a significant growth opportunity for Nintendo in China, where gamers have historically favored smartphones and PCs over consoles. Tencent's potential alliance with Nintendo could boost Switch hardware and software sales, and analysts predict the Japanese company may build a closer relationship with the Chinese gaming giant, including in mobile games.

site_title: Three world-class climbers presumed dead in Canadian avalanche
summary: Three world-class climbers, Jess Roskelley, David Lama, and Hansjörg Auer, are presumed dead after an avalanche in Canada's Rocky Mountains. They were attempting to climb the east face of Howse Peak in Banff National Park. The climbers, known for their expertise in mountaineering, likely started their ascent on Tuesday but were reported overdue on Wednesday. Search and recovery efforts are delayed due to bad weather and avalanche risk, with "strong evidence" suggesting all three were deceased.

site_title: Coming soon to China: the car of the future
summary: China is poised to become a laboratory for the "car of the future," a hyper-connected, autonomous, and shared vehicle designed for on-demand transport. Global automakers, including Renault, Toyota, and Volkswagen, are competing to develop new technologies and interiors tailored for the on-demand world. Didi Chuxing, China's dominant ride-hailing service, is driving the demand for such vehicles, with on-demand transport reaching $28 billion in turnover last year. Manufacturers are also exploring autonomous vehicles, with Valeo receiving orders for "robot-taxis" and partnering with Meituan to develop a robotic vehicle. The concept is expected to accelerate the development of autonomous vehicles and change how cars are bought and sold.

site_title: Fantastic Flowers
summary: Floral Fantasy, a new attraction at Gardens by the Bay, combines flowers, art, and technology for a fantastical experience. The attraction features four diverse garden landscapes, including a rainforest-inspired Waltz garden with a dart frog vivarium. Visitors can also experience a 4D ride, Flight of the Dragonfly, with special effects and 3D glasses. Located at Bayfront Plaza, tickets can be found on gardensbythebay.com.sg. This immersive experience aims to delight both young and old with its unique blend of art, technology, and nature.

site_title: Mueller says UBS executive told Trump team of Kremlin 'approach'
summary: UBS executive Bob Foresman, a vice chairman in New York, told Donald Trump's team about a "Kremlin approach" in 2016, according to Robert Mueller's report. Foresman had previously worked for Barclays and Renaissance Capital in Moscow, and had established a "private channel" between Vladimir Putin and George W Bush. He met with Trump's office to discuss "concrete things" but did not set up a back channel between Trump and Putin. Mueller's report found no evidence of underlying crime related to Russian interference in the 2016 election.

site_title: With Kim-Putin summit, Moscow eyes role in North Korea
summary: Russia's Vladimir Putin is set to meet with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un for the first time, with Moscow eyeing a major role in the Korean peninsula. The talks follow a failed second round of negotiations and Pyongyang's recent resumption of weapons testing, which comes after a historic meeting between Kim and US President Donald Trump last year that backed de-nuclearisation. The summit is seen as a significant opportunity for Russia to increase its influence in the region, amid a period of regional instability.
