The talks aim to rebuild frayed relations amid escalating tensions, with the EU seeking to avoid new tariffs on foreign automobiles and car parts. The US had threatened to impose tariffs on EU goods worth 10.2 billion euros, while the EU was considering retaliatory measures. The talks could expand US exports to the EU and boost shipments between the two regions.

site_title: Foxconn is poised to begin mass production of iPhones in India
summary: Foxconn, the largest assembler of Apple Inc.'s iPhones, is set to begin mass production of iPhones in India this year, diversifying its manufacturing footprint away from China. The move comes as India becomes the fastest-growing smartphone market in the world and Apple seeks to expand its presence in the country. Foxconn will initially invest $300 million to set up the assembly line, which will produce both local and export markets. The move is expected to help Apple avoid import duties and meet India's 30% local sourcing rule to open its own stores in the country.

site_title: Sing-dollar perps flying off the shelf as prices surge
summary: Singapore's bond market has seen a surge in demand for perpetual bonds, with two recent deals oversubscribed and prices rising. The Markit SGD corporates total-return index has risen 2% since the start of 2019, with yields tightening due to low interest rates and ample liquidity. Investors are drawn to perpetual bonds for their higher coupons and low interest rate environment, but experts caution that these bonds can be riskier than traditional bonds due to their extension risk and potential conversion into equity.

site_title: AB InBev adds Citi, BAML to banks working on US$5b Asian IPO: sources
summary: Anheuser-Busch InBev, the world's largest brewer, has added Citigroup and Bank of America Merrill Lynch to a team of banks working on the sale of its Asia-Pacific business in a planned Hong Kong initial public offering (IPO) that could raise up to $5 billion. The IPO aims to reduce the brewer's leverage, which stood at $102.5 billion at the end of December, and bring its net debt/Ebitda ratio to around two times. The IPO is expected to file with the Hong Kong stock exchange in the first half of the year.

site_title: Musk tweets another Tesla forecast in middle of talks with SEC
summary: Elon Musk tweeted that Tesla plans to produce over 500,000 cars in the next 12 months, similar to a previous forecast that led to a federal judge's warning. This tweet comes amid ongoing talks with the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) over his Twitter use. Musk's statement is reminiscent of a previous tweet that led to a settlement with the SEC last year, raising concerns about his compliance with the regulator.

site_title: Tiffany is training Africans to cut diamonds sourced from region
summary: Tiffany & Co. is training Africans to cut diamonds sourced from the region, a move that marks the luxury brand's commitment to local production. The company has factories in Botswana and Mauritius, employing over 375 people who undergo intensive two-year training. This is the only Western luxury brand that doesn't outsource production of its African stones, with over a quarter of its 1,500 global diamond cutters and polishers now based in Africa.

site_title: Bullish mood hits safe havens; yen, Swiss franc fall
summary: The yen fell to a 2019 low of 112.09 per dollar, while the Swiss franc reached its weakest in nearly a month, as a rally in global markets cut into demand for safe-haven currencies. Market volatility has eased, with optimism over US-China trade negotiations and strong Chinese economic data driving investors into riskier currencies. The dollar index dropped 0.1% to 96.858, while the euro rose 0.1% to $1.1309, and sterling rose to $1.31.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% due to investors weighing market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions. In other news, US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats, while Europe's stocks declined with bank and healthcare sectors dragging down the market. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received 9.8 times oversubscription. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss in the second half of the year. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for its £10 billion upgrade, and Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case.

site_title: Petronas acquires Singapore-based Amplus Energy
summary: Malaysian state-owned oil and gas firm Petronas acquired Singapore-based solar energy company Amplus Energy Solutions Pte Ltd, aiming to move into renewable energy and diversify its business. Amplus Energy has a cumulative solar power capacity of over 500 megawatt (MW) across India, the Middle East, and South-east Asia. The acquisition is part of Petronas' strategy to pursue high-growth renewable energy business and complement its mainstay operations.

site_title: MSCI Emerging Markets Index could double in value by 2023: fund manager
summary: Fund manager Rob Mumford predicts the MSCI Emerging Markets Index could double in value by 2023, driven by economic growth in China, India, and Brazil. Mumford, who has 57% of his personal wealth invested in emerging markets, believes compound returns will be in the double-digit range, with a bull scenario potentially doubling the index's value. He cites improving credit quality, higher capital flows, and the International Monetary Fund's "bright spot" assessment of emerging markets as supporting his bullish view.

site_title: Iran eyes 5 oil project deals with local firms: report
summary: Iran plans to award up to five oil exploration and production contracts to local firms, with the first deal expected within months. This comes after foreign energy companies, including Total, suspended plans to invest in Iranian oil and gas projects due to US sanctions. The move aims to boost domestic oil production and reduce reliance on foreign investment.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: PCI's acquisition by Pagani Holding III was approved by the court on April 15, 2019. The scheme of arrangement will become effective on April 29, following the lodgement of a court order. Trading will be suspended from April 25, and transfer books will be closed on April 26 to determine shareholder entitlements.

site_title: What really caused the financial crisis?
summary: The global financial crisis of 2008 was not solely caused by Wall Street greed or lax government oversight, as previously believed. Instead, the crisis was largely the result of the economy's success, which led to widespread optimism and increased risk-taking. The authors of the book "Firefighting" argue that the crisis was caused by a combination of factors, including excessive leverage, runnable funding, shadow banking, and outdated regulation. The convergence of these factors, fueled by the "Great Moderation" and rising wealth, led to a consumption boom and excessive borrowing, ultimately resulting in the crisis.

site_title: The economic challenges facing Indonesia as voters head to the polls
summary: Indonesia's presidential election, set to take place on Wednesday, is dominated by economic policy issues. Incumbent President Joko Widodo and challenger Prabowo Subianto have proposed differing economic strategies, with Widodo focusing on infrastructure and social welfare spending, and Prabowo promising tax cuts and import curbs. The new administration will face significant economic challenges, including slowing world growth, unresolved US-China trade tensions, and a growing underemployment problem. Indonesia's current account deficit remains a key vulnerability, and the country needs foreign investment to fund its development.

site_title: Keen for trade deal, US softens demand for China subsidy cuts
summary: US negotiators have softened demands for China to curb industrial subsidies as a condition for a trade deal, according to two sources briefed on discussions. Instead, they are focusing on ending forced technology transfers, improving intellectual property protection, and widening access to China's markets. The US has slapped tariffs on $250 billion worth of Chinese goods, and while China has agreed to end market-distorting subsidies, details on how it will achieve this goal are unclear. The talks aim to secure a deal in the next month, with the US seeking to keep some tariffs on Chinese goods.

site_title: Asian Pay TV Trust up 22% as Foxconn-linked manager mulls options
summary: The manager of Asian Pay Television Trust (APTT) is exploring options for the trust and its sole operating asset, Taiwan Broadband Communications (TBC), following a surprise dividend cut last November. A special committee will oversee a strategic review, which aims to extract greater value for unitholders. The move comes amid concerns over "privatization on the cheap" and speculation about the endgame of Foxconn-linked manager Terry Gou. Analysts believe TBC could be worth more to Foxconn than its current market value, and privatization may be a possibility.

site_title: Beleaguered London home sellers hope for boost from Brexit delay
summary: London home sellers experienced a 1.1% rebound in asking prices in April, with average values rising after a 1.1% drop in March. Despite this, prices remain 2.2% lower than last year. The number of sales agreed by real-estate agents fell 5.6% in April. The Brexit delay is seen as a potential boost to the property market, with sellers expressing optimism for the coming months.

site_title: Facebook suffers third major global outage this year
summary: Facebook suffered its third major global outage this year, affecting users worldwide and causing inaccessibility to its services, including Facebook, Instagram, and WhatsApp. The outage started at 6:30am on Sunday morning and lasted for several hours. Facebook apologized for the inconvenience and stated the issue was resolved. The outages add to Facebook's woes, already facing criticism over user data security and the spread of disinformation.

site_title: No-sale licence issued to Normanton Park project
summary: Kingsford Huray Development, a Singaporean developer, has been issued a no-sale licence for its 1,882-unit project at the former Normanton Park site. The licence prohibits the sale of units until a Temporary Occupation Permit (TOP) is obtained. The decision was made after the developer failed to meet requirements, with other projects, such as Kingsford Waterbay, also facing issues with building compliance and safety. The no-sale licence includes conditions for strict compliance with regulations and prior approval from the Controller of Housing before selling units.

images.alt_text: He said the Building and Construction Authority (BCA) had found that at the developer's other project - Kingsford Waterbay - some building works such as windows, barriers and common storey shelter "had deviated from requirements under the Building Control Act and Regulations".

site_title: Yinson could pull plug on Ezion's lifeline
summary: Malaysia-listed Yinson Holdings, a potential white knight, may pull the plug on its proposed lifeline to struggling offshore and marine group Ezion Holdings. Yinson's subsidiary, Yinson Eden Pte Ltd, failed to enter debt assignment agreements with Ezion's lenders by the April 14 deadline, allowing Yinson to terminate the conditional debt conversion agreement. The deal would erase Ezion's $916 million debt and grant Yinson new shares at 5.5 Singapore cents apiece, making it the controlling owner of Ezion.

site_title: Moon says it's time to prepare for talks with Kim
summary: South Korean President Moon Jae-in stated that it's time to prepare for talks with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, amid efforts to restart stalled nuclear negotiations. Moon believes Kim is committed to denuclearization and that a top-down peace process is necessary. The two leaders' February summit collapsed without a deal, and Trump rejected calls for confidence-building economic projects with North Korea. Moon will work to prepare for an inter-Korean summit once North Korea is ready, with the goal of sitting down together regardless of venue.

images.alt_text: "As soon as North Korea is ready, I hope the two Koreas will sit down together regardless of venue and form," says Mr Moon.

site_title: Ireland's Green REIT up for sale in bid to maximise value
summary: Ireland's Green REIT, the country's first real estate investment trust, is putting itself up for sale to maximize shareholder value. The firm, which manages €1.5 billion in commercial properties in Dublin, has seen its share price discounted by over 3 years. The sale process began immediately with JP Morgan Cazenove as lead financial adviser, with analysts predicting ample interest due to the quality of its assets and strong fundamentals of Dublin's office and logistics markets. The company's shares rose 5.6% on the news.

site_title: China rail project revived to avoid US$5b penalty: Mahathir
summary: Malaysia has revived a China-backed rail project worth $5 billion after agreeing to a 30% cost reduction. The 640-km east coast rail link will connect northern Malaysia to a port near Kuala Lumpur. Under the new deal, China Communications Construction Company will assist with operation and maintenance, easing financial burdens on Malaysia. The project cost has been reduced to $7.15 billion, and Malaysia will still need to take a loan from a Chinese state-owned bank to fund it.

site_title: Regulator taking light touch on fast-moving telco sector
summary: Singapore's regulator, the Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA), is taking a light-touch approach to regulating the country's fast-moving telecom sector, citing the need for a review of the industry's consolidation and competition. The regulator is also keeping an eye on the use of data and algorithms, which could potentially entrench companies' market presence. A public consultation on a joint code to govern both telecom and media industries is underway, with the aim of updating Singapore's rules to address emerging trends such as service bundling and the rise of new digital services.

site_title: BM Mobility on finance chief's notice period
summary: BM Mobility, an electric transport group, said its former financial controller Lim Gwo Bin, also known as Robb Lim, was "unresponsive and uncooperative" after submitting his resignation on March 25. Despite a six-week notice period, Lim failed to respond to company requests for information until April 5. The company adjusted Lim's last day of employment to April 9. Lim claimed he had responded to a request on March 26 but was not contacted again until April 5. The audit committee found no unresolved issues between Lim and the company, but he cited fear of retaliation for not disclosing issues during his tenure.

site_title: 2 Bartley projects to launch at around S$2,000 psf
summary: SingHaiyi Group is set to launch two freehold projects in Bartley, Singapore, with prices ranging from S$1 million to S$3.3 million per unit. The 250-unit The Gazania and 80-unit The Lilium will be launched at "plus or minus" S$2,000 per square foot (psf), with The Gazania closer to Bartley MRT. The projects' freehold status and proximity to the MRT are touted as selling points, with SingHaiyi estimating they are the only new freehold project launches in District 19 for the past five years.

site_title: KIT sinks into the red but maintains Q1 DPU at 0.93 cent
summary: KEPPEL Infrastructure Trust (KIT) reported a net loss of S$16.2 million for the first quarter of 2019, despite maintaining its total distribution per unit (DPU) at 0.93 Singapore cents. The loss was attributed to transaction costs related to the acquisition of Australian chemicals group Ixom. Revenue increased by 99% to S$318.5 million, driven by the consolidation of Ixom's results. KIT's adjusted net asset value per unit was marginally higher at 27.1 Singapore cents.

site_title: Despite polarisation, the political centre is alive
summary: A recent article suggests that the political center in the US Democratic Party remains alive, despite efforts to portray it as dead. Former Vice President Joe Biden's candidacy for the 2020 presidential election was initially threatened by allegations of misconduct, but a recent YouGov survey found that half of Democratic-leaning voters identify as moderate or conservative, not liberal. The article argues that the media's focus on progressive and left-leaning voices has created a skewed narrative, eroding the power of pragmatic politicians who seek compromises. This narrative has led to increased polarization and makes it difficult to reach common ground on key issues.

site_title: Notre-Dame's main structure 'saved and preserved': Paris fire official
summary: The main structure of Notre-Dame cathedral in Paris has been saved after a devastating blaze, according to Paris fire brigade chief Jean-Claude Gallet. The two main towers appear to have been saved, and the main task now is to cool the temperature inside the cathedral. Deputy Interior Minister Laurent Nunez defended not using water-bombing planes, citing a "major danger" to the structure. The fire has decreased in intensity, but extreme caution is still advised.

site_title: Gold slips to 1-week low as global slowdown fears ease
summary: Gold prices fell to a one-week low on Monday, dropping 0.2% to $1,288.08 per ounce, as stronger-than-expected Chinese data and a positive start to the US earnings season eased concerns about a global economic slowdown. Improved macro-economic data favored risk-taking, causing gold to lose appeal. US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin also expressed optimism about a US-China trade agreement, further supporting risk-on sentiment.

site_title: Parent of South Korea's Asiana Airlines puts its stake up for sale
summary: The top shareholder of South Korea's Asiana Airlines has announced it will sell its entire stake in the debt-ridden airline to keep it afloat. The move follows weeks of financial uncertainty, including a failed audit of Asiana's 2018 financial statements, which triggered warnings of credit rating downgrades and the resignation of the parent group's chairman. Asiana's shares rose 30% after the announcement, while its budget arm also saw significant gains.

site_title: Hyflux: Laundry list of warnings says little about the likelihood of events
summary: Hyflux's financial collapse has left approximately 34,000 investors, mostly retail investors, holding worthless perpetual securities and preference shares, resulting in significant losses for retirees. Experts attribute the issue to a lack of investor education, marketing by DBS Bank, and the assumption that Hyflux, a water treatment company, was too important to fail. However, financial professionals, including bank credit officers, fund managers, and auditors, also failed to recognize the risks, highlighting the need for diversification and risk appreciation in investing.

site_title: Election slogan humour masks serious issues in India
summary: The ruling Bharatiya Janata Party's (BJP) election slogans in India have been met with laughter due to the party's failure to address economic issues, including rising unemployment and a slowing economy. The party's focus on national security instead is seen as a distraction from these pressing concerns. The BJP's slogans, such as "Main bhi Chowkidar" (I'm a guard too) and "Namumkin ab mumkin hai" (Impossible is now possible), are ironic given the party's inability to deliver on economic promises. The real issues are not being taken seriously, leaving voters concerned.

site_title: Revised voter rolls for next General Election open for viewing
summary: Singapore's updated voter rolls for the next General Election are now open for public inspection. The revised voter rolls contain 2,594,740 eligible electors, with 80,000 more people added since the last revision in 2017. Those whose names were removed from the register can apply to have them restored before the election period. Overseas electors must register with the Elections Department to vote at designated polling stations. The revised voter rolls can be viewed online or at Elections Department premises, community centers, and community clubs.

site_title: Keppel DC Reit's Q1 DPU up 6.7%
summary: Keppel DC Reit reported a 6.7% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.92 Singapore cents for Q1 2019, driven by a 29.9% growth in distributable income to S$27.1 million. Gross revenue rose 26.4% to S$48 million, with gross rental income increasing 23.8%. The company's portfolio occupancy rate remained at 93.2% and weighted average lease expiry remained at eight years.

site_title: Cromwell E-Reit's manager names new CFO
summary: Cromwell E-Reit Management has appointed Shane Hagan as its new Chief Financial Officer (CFO), effective May 1, 2019. Hagan, with over 20 years of experience in the real estate industry, will succeed Daniel Donner, who is returning to Cromwell Property Group. Donner had played a key role in setting up Cromwell E-Reit's financial reporting framework and its initial public offering in 2017. Hagan will work with the management team to formulate strategic plans and apply capital management strategies to support the Reit's financial health.

site_title: Apple to spend over US$500m for its games subscription service
summary: Apple plans to spend over $500 million to acquire new video games for its Apple Arcade subscription service, with the company offering exclusive deals to game developers in exchange for exclusive rights to their content. The service, set to launch in the fall, will feature over 100 games, including titles from Sega, Cartoon Network, and Lego, and will be available on iPhones, iPads, Macs, and Apple TVs. The move aims to establish Apple as a major player in the subscription-based gaming market, competing with platforms like Google and Tencent Holdings.

site_title: No job cuts seen at Italy's Magneti Marelli after Calsonic takeover - unions
summary: Italy's Magneti Marelli, a unit of Fiat Chrysler, has confirmed industrial plans for its Italian operations without job cuts after a pending takeover by Japan's Calsonic Kansei. The deal, worth 6.2 billion euros, is expected to be concluded in the second quarter of 2019. Trade unions stated that the 8,815 Magneti Marelli workers in Italy will see no changes to their contracts, citing no production overlaps with Calsonic.

site_title: Kingsford Huray gets no-sale licence for Normanton Park project
summary: Kingsford Huray Development has been issued a no-sale licence for its Normanton Park project, prohibiting the sale of units until the Temporary Occupation Permit (TOP) is obtained. The licence was issued due to the developer's failure to meet requirements, including building works deviations at another project, Kingsford Waterbay. The no-sale licence allows for construction to begin, but units cannot be sold off-plan without COH approval. The developer must obtain Quality Mark certificates for all units and comply with conditions set by the COH before selling units.

site_title: Sunvic appoints EY Advisory to probe guarantees for 222.5m yuan loans
summary: Sunvic Chemical Holdings has appointed Ernst & Young Advisory to investigate corporate guarantees for 222.5 million yuan (S$44.3 million) loans. The investigation follows letters of demand from creditors of two companies, Jiangsu Donglai and Jiangsu Dahe, related to the guarantees provided by Sunvic's subsidiaries. Trading in Sunvic shares has been suspended since January 14. EY Advisory will report directly to the audit committee and provide regular updates on the investigation. The company will provide further updates to shareholders on developments.

site_title: Evian, Nestle race to cut plastic bottle waste
summary: Danone's Evian and Nestle Waters are developing innovative solutions to reduce plastic waste in the water industry. Evian's in-home water appliance, Evian Renew, features a recyclable balloon-like container that contains 66% less plastic than a traditional bottle. Nestle Waters' out-of-home dispensing system, set to launch next year, allows consumers to access filtered water with customizable flavors or carbonation. The moves come as governments worldwide step up action to reduce plastic waste, with the European Parliament set to ban single-use plastic consumer items by 2021.

images.alt_text: Environmental group Greenpeace protesting against Nestle at its annual general meeting last week for its reliance on single-use plastic. They urged the world's largest food company to invest in alternative delivery systems based on refillable containers.

site_title: Halloween Brexit extension - more 'trick' than 'treat'?
summary: The UK and EU have agreed on a six-month Brexit extension, set to expire on October 31, with the possibility of further extensions. The deadline, dubbed the "Halloween deadline," has been met with skepticism, as it may not deliver a decisive breakthrough on the UK's withdrawal deal. European Council President Donald Tusk has hinted at the possibility of another extension beyond October, with a potential deadline of March 31, 2020. The agreement reflects the varying interests of EU states, including France's opposition to the UK's exit and its own economic plans to compete with London as a financial hub.

site_title: US online lenders reduce risk on concern over looming recession
summary: US online lenders such as LendingClub, Kabbage, and Avant are taking precautions due to concerns over a potential recession. They are scrutinizing loan quality, securing long-term financing, and cutting costs. The lenders fear escalating credit losses, liquidity crunch, and higher funding costs, which could test their business models. As the industry is relatively nascent, these measures aim to mitigate the risks associated with a potential economic downturn.

site_title: Japan urged to rely on sales tax hike for extra revenue
summary: The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) has urged Japan to rely on raising the sales tax to generate extra revenue, potentially increasing it to 26% to achieve a large primary surplus. The OECD warned that the Bank of Japan's quantitative easing policies may distort the stock market and erode market discipline. Japan's government debt is more than twice its economy, and policymakers need to curb healthcare spending and raise revenue to pay down debt while maintaining sustainable inflation.

site_title: Singapore is committed to mitigating climate change
summary: Singapore commits to mitigating climate change, aiming to reduce its Emissions Intensity by 36% from 2005 levels by 2030 and stabilise emissions to peak around 2030. Despite its small size and land constraints, the country is working with partners like ExxonMobil to develop new, cleaner technologies and increase renewable energy deployment, such as solar power. Singapore's climate action responsibility is taken seriously, with a focus on improving energy efficiency, developing low-carbon solutions, and pushing for further climate efforts in partnership with businesses and the community.

site_title: Nissan Leaf's battery supplier builds factory in China
summary: Automotive Energy Supply Corp (AESC), the battery supplier for Nissan's Leaf vehicles, is building a factory in China to triple its global capacity. The factory, in Wuxi's Jiangsu province, will have a planned annual capacity of 20 gigawatt-hours, enough to power 400,000 electric cars a year. AESC aims to secure orders from other global carmakers, including Tesla and Volkswagen, while continuing to supply Nissan's Leaf. The factory is scheduled to begin mass production next year, with Envision Group's CEO Zhang Lei stating that China lacks EV battery makers with products that people feel safe to use.

site_title: Starbucks is investing in solar farms and buying power from others
summary: Starbucks is investing in solar farms through a portfolio of eight Cypress Creek Renewables LLC projects in Texas, with the goal of using renewable-energy credits to offset tax liabilities. The company will also buy solar power from two of the projects, generating enough energy to power 360 Starbucks stores. This move is part of Starbucks' efforts to boost its investments in clean power.

site_title: Morgan Stanley sees two reasons low volatility will end
summary: Morgan Stanley strategist Andrew Sheets warns that low volatility may not last due to two main reasons: low market liquidity and complacency among investors. The Cboe Volatility Index has fallen 50% this year, but Sheets believes this could be unsustainable. He notes that the market has not fully absorbed the implications of low interest rates and increased economic stimulus, which could lead to a rebound in volatility. Sheets cautions that investors may be overly complacent, having sold off volatility, and that a sudden shift could occur if central banks remain dovish and data weakens.

site_title: Pakistan reaches an "agreement in principle" with IMF over bailout package - minister
summary: Pakistan has reached an "agreement in principle" with the IMF over a bailout package, according to the country's state minister for revenue. A staff mission from the IMF is set to visit Pakistan this month to finalize technical details. The agreement comes after talks stalled last year due to concerns the conditions attached to the proposed IMF loans could hurt economic growth. The visit of the IMF staff mission is seen as a significant step forward in securing the bailout package, which Pakistan has been seeking to stabilize its economy.

site_title: ADB chief sees Asian econ growth as 'solid' despite trade war
summary: Asian Development Bank (ADB) President Takehiko Nakao stated that regional economies in Asia are sustaining solid growth despite the negative effects of the Sino-US trade war. The growth is driven by domestic demand and the services sector. However, Nakao acknowledged that China's economy is slowing due to trade friction between the US and China, a trend expected to continue.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens flat after Goldman's disappointing results
summary: US stocks opened flat on Monday after Goldman Sachs reported disappointing results, offsetting gains in healthcare stocks. The Dow Jones fell 0.02%, the S&P 500 rose 0.03%, and the Nasdaq Composite gained 0.04%. The flat opening was the first since Goldman's earnings announcement, which missed expectations. The market's focus remains on US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: Goldman sees lower credit costs for Indian lenders
summary: Goldman Sachs analysts predict a decline in credit costs for Indian banks, from 3.3 trillion rupees (S$64 billion) in FY18 to 1.9 trillion rupees in FY20. This decrease is expected to boost bank profitability, enhance credit extension, and bolster economic growth by 60 basis points in FY20, driven by increased loan growth and investment growth. The measures to improve bad loan recovery and recapitalization plans will support lenders' capacity to extend loans and stimulate growth in India, the world's fastest-growing major economy.

site_title: STI ends lower after bright start
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) in Singapore ended 0.2% lower on Monday, closing at 3,325.86, despite a strong start. Investors closed positions on blue chips and large cap stocks ahead of earnings reports, with 17 of the 30 blue chips ending in the red. The broader market fared better, with advancers outnumbering decliners 211 to 186. Defensive plays like real estate investment trusts and telco counters gained, while luxury timepiece retailer The Hour Glass closed flat.

site_title: Ying the Label taking art beyond paper and clothes
summary: Ying the Label, founded by Phuay Li Ying, is a fashion brand that combines art and storytelling through wearable and usable art pieces. The brand, which started in 2015, has seen significant growth, with revenue doubling year on year and profit increasing by 35-40% annually. Ying's art pieces are created through a mix of self-taught painting techniques and digital printing. The brand has collaborated with other artists and labels, and Ying aims to expand its reach by taking on more corporate projects and branding itself as a print designer.

site_title: US: Wall Street slips as bank earnings disappoint
summary: US stocks declined on Monday, led by financials, as underwhelming bank earnings disappointed investors. Goldman Sachs fell 3.8% and Citigroup Inc dropped 0.1% despite Citigroup's higher-than-expected earnings. Analysts now expect the S&P 500 to post a 2.1% year-on-year decline in profits, marking the first annual decline since 2016. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.1%, while the Nasdaq Composite dropped 0.1%. The S&P 500 remained within a percent of its record high.

site_title: Oil rally takes a breather as US drilling activity picks up
summary: US oil drilling activity increased, causing oil prices to fall as much as 0.8% after a 14% gain over the previous six weeks. The number of working rigs targeting crude in the US rose for the second week, despite a global economic slowdown forecast by the IMF. Oil prices have rallied around 40% this year due to OPEC production cuts and supply disruptions, but the demand outlook remains shaky. US crude fell to $63.66 a barrel, while Brent fell to $71.46 a barrel.

images.alt_text: The number of working rigs targeting crude in the US rose for a second week following six weeks of declines, according to data on Friday from oilfield services provider Baker Hughes.

site_title: Sterling rises above US$1.31 with Brexit talks in focus
summary: The British pound rose above US$1.31 on Monday, driven by Brexit talks, despite a lack of significant developments. The pound's volatility has decreased since the EU and British government announced a six-month Brexit delay. Goldman Sachs analysts believe the pound has more upside potential, citing progress in negotiations. However, uncertainty remains, with Labour market data and inflation numbers set to be released this week, potentially impacting the pound's value.

site_title: Dubai financial services authority says investigation into Abraaj is ongoing
summary: Dubai's financial services authority (DSFA) is continuing its investigation into collapsed private equity firm Abraaj Capital Ltd. The investigation involves former executives Arif Naqvi and Mustafa Abdel-Wadood, who were arrested on US fraud charges. The DSFA has stated it has the power to impose administrative sanctions but does not have criminal jurisdiction, meaning it cannot lay charges or make arrests. The investigation remains ongoing.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Hyflux sues SM Investments over repudiation of rescue deal, claiming S$38.9m deposit. In Singapore, private home sales rose 47% in March to 1,054 units. APTT is conducting a strategic review for its pay-TV-focused trust. TEE International plans to spin off and list its infrastructure business. UOB and Qoo10 joined forces to drive e-commerce growth in South-east Asia. The STI closed 0.2% lower on Monday at 3,325.86.

site_title: Keppel DC Reit Q1 DPU up 6.7%
summary: Keppel DC Reit posted a 6.7% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.92 Singapore cents for Q1 2019, driven by a 29.9% growth in distributable income to S$27.1 million. Gross revenue rose 26.4% to S$48 million, with gross rental income increasing 23.8% to S$45.7 million. Net property income rose 26.8% to S$43.2 million. Portfolio occupancy remained at 93.2%, and the manager expects asset enhancement works to improve energy efficiency to be completed by 2020.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start week with losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks started the week with losses, with the Hang Seng Index slipping 0.33% to close at 29,810.72. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also fell, with losses of 0.34% and 0.84%, respectively. The losses came despite optimism over corporate earnings and China-US trade talks.

site_title: Mercedes goes for offroad looks on compact SUV in China
summary: Mercedes-Benz unveiled a concept compact SUV, the GLB, at the Shanghai auto show, targeting the gap between the GLA and GLC models. The GLB features a rugged design and can accommodate up to seven passengers. China has been a key market for Mercedes, with deliveries up 2.6% through March, defying a global market slump. The GLB's third row of seats offers comfortable seating for two medium-sized occupants, despite its relatively moderate size, and marks the brand's continued expansion in the compact-car segment.

images.alt_text: The GLB prototype, featuring 17-inch wheels, harks back to the unveiling of the Mercedes-Benz GLA crossover in Shanghai six years ago, which heralded the brand's successful shakeup of its compact-car offerings.

site_title: Measles cases rose nearly four-fold in first quarter 2019 - WHO
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) reported a nearly four-fold increase in measles cases worldwide in the first quarter of 2019, with 112,163 cases recorded. This surge has been observed in all regions, with fresh outbreaks in 10 countries, mostly among young children. The WHO attributed the rise to lower vaccination coverage, with global coverage of the first dose stalled at 85% and 25 countries lacking a second dose in their national programs. The organization appealed for better vaccination efforts to prevent further outbreaks.

site_title: India's Jet extends cancellations after lenders fail to release funds
summary: India's Jet Airways has extended its cancellation of international flights due to lenders failing to release funds, leaving thousands of passengers stranded. The airline, with debts over $1 billion, has only seven operational jets after dozens were seized by creditors. A board meeting is scheduled for Tuesday to discuss next steps, with pilots and staff threatening to strike if emergency funds are not injected. The State Bank of India-led lenders have pledged $218 million in funding support, but most of the funds have not been released, putting Jet's survival at risk.

images.alt_text: Hundreds of staff protested in New Delhi and Mumbai over the weekend demanding to be paid and calling for Jet Airways to be rescued. The airline appeared to be edging closer to collapse Monday after lenders failed to take a decision on whether to release crucial funds to keep the debt-laden carrier flying.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.2% lower on Monday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed 0.2% lower on Monday, with 211 advancers and 186 decliners. The benchmark index fell to 3,325.86, despite strong gains in Japan and South Korea. Investors are waiting for upcoming US bank earnings, leading to lower trading volume. Genting Singapore slipped 0.5% and DBS Group Holdings rose 0.1%, while Singtel rallied 0.3%.

site_title: Actress Lori Loughlin pleads not guilty in college admissions case
summary: Actress Lori Loughlin, 54, and her husband Mossimo Giannulli have pleaded not guilty to charges in the US college admissions scandal. They face allegations of using bribery and cheating to secure spots at universities like Yale and USC for their daughters. Loughlin and Giannulli agreed to pay $500,000 to have their daughters named as crew team recruits, despite having no rowing experience. 33 parents have been charged, with 14 agreeing to plead guilty, including actress Felicity Huffman. The case is part of the largest college admissions scandal uncovered in US history.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Monday afternoon at 3,333.38, up 0.04% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Monday at 3,333.38, up 0.04% on the day, with the Straits Times Index advancing 1.4 points. Gainers outnumbered losers 200 to 137, driven by 674.9 million securities worth S$406.6 million changing hands. Notable movers included Asian Pay Television Trust, up 14.0%, and DBS Group Holdings, up 0.4%.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 1.16 points to 1,631.33. The market saw a trading volume of 3.1 billion lots worth RM1.7 billion, with 595 losers beating 311 gainers.

site_title: SIA and Garuda expand codesharing to include Singapore-Jakarta flights
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) and Garuda Indonesia have expanded their codeshare agreement to include flights between Singapore and Jakarta, offering 175 weekly scheduled services. The partnership, which started in 2010, aims to provide seamless travel experiences for customers. SIA and Garuda Indonesia will operate a combined total of 175 weekly services, with the expanded agreement reflecting the airlines' efforts to work together and make Indonesia more accessible to travelers worldwide.

site_title: More needed to create businesses that promote the 'human experience'
summary: Only 15% of South-east Asian business leaders recognize the need to create companies that promote the 'human experience' in the workplace, according to Deloitte's 2019 Global Human Capital Trends report. Despite this, 94% of leaders in the region cited reinventing learning as important or very important, highlighting a disconnect between recognition and action.

site_title: KIT sinks into the red but maintains Q1 DPU at 0.93 cent
summary: KEPPEL Infrastructure Trust (KIT) reported a flat total distribution per unit (DPU) of 0.93 Singapore cents for the first quarter of 2019, despite a net loss of S$16.2 million due to transaction costs related to the acquisition of Australian chemicals group Ixom. Revenue increased by 99% to S$318.5 million, driven by the consolidation of Ixom's results, but expenses rose by 115% to S$333.4 million. KIT maintained its DPU despite a dilution in equity and a 230% increase in staff costs.

site_title: Malaysia revived China-backed railway to avoid US$5b penalty: PM
summary: Malaysia has revived a China-backed railway project worth US$5 billion after agreeing to a 30% cost reduction. The 640-kilometre east coast rail link will run from northern Malaysia to a port outside Kuala Lumpur, with China Communications Construction Company forming a joint venture with a Malaysian firm to operate and maintain the line. The revised deal will reduce Malaysia's financial burden and improve ties with China, which had been strained after the ousting of former Prime Minister Najib Razak.

site_title: Indian minister says extreme poverty falling, to end by 2031
summary: India's finance minister, Arun Jaitley, claims that extreme poverty will drop to below 15% by 2021 and nearly disappear by 2031 due to the country's fast economic growth and rapid urbanization. The number of people living on less than $1.90 a day decreased from 21% in 2011 to 15% in the next three years, according to Jaitley. This comes as India prepares for a general election, with the main opposition party rejecting the government's optimistic poverty reduction claims.

site_title: Hyflux sues SM Investments over repudiation of rescue deal, claims S$38.9m deposit
summary: Hyflux has filed a lawsuit against SM Investments in the Singapore High Court, claiming the latter repudiated a rescue deal worth S$38.9 million. The water treatment company says SM Investments denied repudiating the agreement, which was struck in October 2018. Hyflux is seeking to recover the deposit placed into escrow after the deal was signed. SM Investments has stated it is "surprised" by Hyflux's claim and will seek legal advice.

site_title: DBS partners China's Sinosure for Belt and Road project push
summary: DBS Group Holdings has partnered with China Export & Credit Insurance Corporation (Sinosure) to support projects under the Belt and Road Initiative (BRI), particularly those from ASEAN. Sinosure will provide credit insurance for DBS's mid and long-term financing activities, facilitating project finance and investment opportunities with Asean partners. This partnership aims to strengthen DBS's business in mainland China and capitalize on the numerous business opportunities offered under BRI.

site_title: Tokyo's Nikkei jumps more than 1.3% on US rallies, cheaper yen
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei index rose 1.37% to 22,169.11, driven by US rallies and a cheaper yen. The broader Topix index also gained 1.40%. Japanese shares are optimistic about US-China trade negotiations and the upcoming talks between US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer and Japan's Economy Minister Toshimitsu Motegi. Key exporters such as Sony and Toyota also saw gains, with Sony rising 0.36% and Toyota increasing 0.61%.

site_title: Europe: Stocks hold steady with market bulls keeping 'upper hand'
summary: European stocks held steady on Monday, with the Stoxx Europe 600 Index little changed, as market bulls maintained their upper hand. The banking sector added to Friday's rally, and the media sector was boosted by Publicis Groupe SA's plans to purchase Epsilon for $4.4 billion. Investors remain focused on US-China trade talks, with Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin open to facing repercussions if the US doesn't meet its commitments.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks rises for 12th straight session; won gains 0.6%
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index rose for the 12th consecutive session, with the benchmark index climbing 9.43 points to 2,242.88 points. The won gained 0.6% and foreign investors bought 180.7 billion won worth of shares. The announcement of a 1.4 trillion won stake sale by Saudi Aramco in Hyundai Oilbank also boosted the market. The Kospi has risen 9.89% so far this year, driven by risk appetite after strong US earnings.

site_title: Sunvic Chemical appoints external auditor to probe guarantees for loans worth 222.5m yuan
summary: Sunvic Chemical Holdings has appointed Ernst & Young Advisory to investigate corporate guarantees for loans totaling 222.5 million yuan (S$44.3 million). The investigation was initiated by the company's independent directors after receiving letters of demand from creditors. The special investigative committee will report directly to the audit committee and provide updates on developments. Trading in Sunvic Chemical shares has been suspended since January 14. The company will provide further updates to shareholders on the case in due course.

site_title: Miners weigh on Aussie shares; NZ gains on consumer stocks
summary: Australian shares ended flat on Monday as investors took profits from recent gains in mining stocks. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 6,251.40, unchanged from the previous day. Mining stocks declined for a fourth straight session, while gold miners weighed on the benchmark. Meanwhile, New Zealand shares rose 0.8% as consumer stocks, particularly dairy exporters, gained. Analysts expect stronger credit growth in China to boost metal demand, but investors are awaiting production data from major resource majors.

site_title: Singapore's fake news bill set to become law in second half of the year
summary: Singapore's fake news bill is set to become law in the second half of this year, aiming to equip citizens with facts for public discourse. The bill, which was drafted in consultation with tech companies, grants broad powers to the government to compel online sites to remove false content. Critics, including Facebook and Google, have expressed concerns over the law's impact on freedom of expression and speech. The law requires online sites to show corrections to false claims and take down falsehoods in serious cases, with account restrictions and court appeals available for those who disagree.

site_title: Singapore's new private home sales, launches up in March
summary: Singapore's private home sales increased in March, with 1,054 units sold, a 47% rise from the same period last year. This surpasses February's 455 units sold, partly due to the Chinese New Year festive lull. In March, 1,812 private homes were launched, with 1,062 units sold including executive condominiums. This marks a significant boost in the market, following a slower February.

site_title: TEE International proposes to spin off and list infrastructure business on Catalist
summary: TEE International plans to spin off its infrastructure business and list it on the Catalist board, maintaining a controlling interest. The spun-off group will independently raise funds to finance expansion, allowing TEE International to redeploy resources to other businesses. TEE International's infrastructure business includes stakes in G3 Environmental, Global Environmental Technology, and PowerSource Philippines Distributed Power Holdings. The company has engaged PrimePartners Corporate Finance and Rajah & Tann Singapore LLP for the transaction.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars boosted by US hopes for trade deal with China
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars have seen a boost due to US hopes for a trade deal with China, potentially ending the Sino-US tariff war. The Australian dollar is near its highest level in almost seven weeks, while the New Zealand dollar has risen for a second consecutive day. US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin expressed optimism about a trade deal, and reduced US demands on China to curb industrial subsidies. This may support commodity prices and underpin risk sentiment, benefiting the AUD and NZD.

images.alt_text: The Australian dollar hovered near its highest in almost seven weeks while the New Zealand dollar also held firm, helped by US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin voicing optimism for a trade deal with China to end a tariff war.

site_title: Hot stock: Asian Pay Television Trust units up 15.5% in early session
summary: Asian Pay Television Trust (APTT) units rose 15.5% in the early session on Monday after its trustee-manager announced an independent strategic review of the trust and its main asset, Taiwan Broadband Communications Group. The review aims to address declining cable TV subscribers and revenue. APTT's units traded at 14.9 cents at the midday break, on 24.9 million units traded. The review is expected to be led by an independent financial adviser, with updates to be made if material developments occur.

site_title: UOB, Qoo10 join hands to drive e-commerce growth in South-east Asia
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) and Singapore-based e-commerce platform Qoo10 have formed a strategic regional alliance to drive e-commerce growth in South-east Asia. The partnership aims to simplify loan applications for small businesses and provide consumers and merchants with easier access to financial services. UOB will explore AI-powered credit assessment, while Qoo10 will use UOB's financial solutions to enhance its online platform. The alliance also offers exclusive benefits to UOB cardmembers shopping on Qoo10's platforms, including additional Q*coins. The partnership is expected to provide greater financial flexibility for Qoo10 merchants and customers.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks open with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose at the start of Monday, driven by healthy Chinese trade data and optimism over US-China tariffs talks. The Hang Seng Index climbed 0.7% to 30,119.85, while the Shanghai Composite Index jumped 1.41% to 3,233.46. The gains were also influenced by recent positive market trends in Europe and the US, despite ongoing US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: Asian shares supported by global growth hopes, eyes on earnings
summary: Asian shares rose on Monday, boosted by better-than-expected Chinese data and hopes for a global economic growth. China's exports rebounded in March to a five-month high, and new bank loans jumped by more than expected. The MSCI Asia-Pacific index climbed 0.1% and Japan's Nikkei jumped 1.3%, while the US dollar eased. Investors are now looking to China's March-quarter GDP data and corporate earnings from major US companies. The positive news boosted Wall Street, with the Dow and S&P 500 indices reaching fresh records.

site_title: Australia shares soften as gold stocks weigh; NZ up
summary: Australian shares remained flat at 6,247.40 in early trade on Monday, despite a strong Wall Street and gains in financials, as losses in gold stocks countered the rally. The benchmark had soared 0.9% on Friday, its biggest weekly gain in seven. New Zealand's benchmark index advanced 0.4% to 9,809.35, driven by gains in dairy firms. US stocks closed near records after JP Morgan Chase reported strong quarterly numbers, alleviating concerns about corporate earnings.

site_title: Potential white knight Yinson could pull plug on Ezion lifeline
summary: Ezion Holdings, a troubled offshore and marine group, said potential white knight Yinson Holdings has not entered into debt assignment agreements with its lenders by the April 14 deadline. This means Yinson can terminate its conditional debt conversion agreement, canceling its proposed share subscription and option grant. Yinson is still in negotiations with Ezion's lenders for a rescue package that would wipe off US$916 million of Ezion's debt in exchange for new shares. The deal aims to rescue Ezion, which secured a US$2 billion refinancing package from six secured lenders last year.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Monday, up 5.78 points or 0.35% to 1,634.95. The index saw a trading volume of 150.8 million lots worth RM39.7 million. Gainers outpaced losers 198 to 49.

site_title: The Fed takes a second look at its good-news story on American jobs
summary: The US Federal Reserve is re-examining its job growth strategy, as recent data shows inflation remains below the central bank's target. Fed Vice Chairman Richard Clarida is exploring the connection between monetary policy and the labor share, which has yet to rebound after decades of low levels. Critics argue that the Fed's focus on pushing unemployment below the "natural rate" has led to insufficient vigilance in fighting unemployment, and that this approach may be too narrow. The review may lead to a broader understanding of the Fed's maximum employment and price stability goals, potentially incorporating Marxian economics.

site_title: Yen near this year's lows as risk appetite improves
summary: The yen hovered near its lowest level this year as investors abandoned the safe-haven currency to seek higher returns, driven by stabilisation in the Chinese economy and an upbeat US earnings season. The US dollar strengthened to 112.02 yen, while the euro and US dollar rose against the Swiss franc. Chinese data showed exports rebounded sharply and new bank loans increased, cementing hopes that the Chinese economy is bottoming out. The positive mood offset concerns about upcoming trade talks between the US and Japan.

images.alt_text: The yen hovered near its lowest level this year on Monday as more signs of stabilisation in the Chinese economy and an upbeat start to the US earnings season prompted investors to abandon the safe-haven currency to seek higher returns elsewhere.

site_title: Gold slips to 1-week low as global slowdown fears ease
summary: Gold prices fell to a one-week low on Monday as stronger-than-expected Chinese data and a robust US earnings season eased concerns about a global economic slowdown. Spot gold dropped 0.2% to $1,288.08 per ounce, while US gold futures fell 0.3% to $1,291 an ounce. Improved macroeconomic data and hopes for a US-China trade agreement boosted risk-taking sentiment, making gold less appealing as a safe-haven asset.

site_title: AIDA raises Series A capital from Mastercard, Kuok, SGInnovate; eyes Philippines, Japan
summary: AIDA Technologies, a machine learning data analytics startup, has completed a Series A funding round with undisclosed terms from Mastercard, Kuok Ventures, and SGInnovate. The funds will be used to expand into new markets, including the Philippines and Japan, and deepen capabilities in existing ones. AIDA plans to raise its next round of funds after two years to solidify its track record. The investment strengthens Mastercard's AI-focused strategy and provides access to AIDA's AI platform and toolkit for joint product development.

site_title: Volkswagen CEO plots major China push as trouble looms at home
summary: Volkswagen CEO Herbert Diess is planning a major push into China as the company faces challenges at home. China is expanding its role as a production hub, and Diess aims to allocate more research and development operations to the country. VW wants to be the number one electric mobility brand in China and beyond, and is considering increasing stakes in local joint ventures to expand its presence. Chinese authorities are easing restrictions for foreign manufacturers, making it a favorable time for VW to boost its equity ties in the country.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Monday's open; STI up 0.29% to 3,341.55
summary: Singapore stocks opened stronger on Monday, with the Straits Times Index advancing 0.29% to 3,341.55. Gainers outnumbered losers 115 to 24, driven by gains in Singtel, ComfortDelGro Corp, DBS Group Holdings, and Venture Corp. The rally came ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Jack Ma again endorses extreme overtime as furore rages on
summary: Billionaire Jack Ma has again defended China's extreme overtime culture, encouraging tech workers to adopt a 12-hour, six-day workweek routine. Ma, co-founder of Alibaba Group Holding, dismissed criticism, saying some workers have found their passion beyond monetary gains. The comments sparked a social media backlash and a protest on GitHub, with some calling for better labor conditions. Industry figures, including JD.com's CEO Richard Liu, have also weighed in on the controversy, with some echoing Ma's views and others expressing support for workers' rights.

site_title: Malaysia ex-PM Najib's 1MDB graft trial resumes
summary: Malaysia's former Prime Minister Najib Razak resumed his trial on corruption charges related to the 1MDB scandal, accused of stealing billions of dollars from a sovereign wealth fund. Najib, 65, denies seven charges and has consistently denied any wrongdoing. The US Department of Justice estimates $4.5 billion was looted from 1MDB, with the case playing a significant role in the ousting of Najib's corruption-plagued coalition in historic elections last year. The trial is part of several court cases Najib is expected to face over the scandal.

site_title: Industry veteran Shane Hagan named CFO of Cromwell E-Reit's manager
summary: Cromwell European Real Estate Investment Trust (Cromwell E-Reit) has appointed industry veteran Shane Hagan as its new chief financial officer (CFO) as of May 1, 2019. Hagan replaces Daniel Donner, who will return to Cromwell Property Group, the Reit's sponsor. Hagan has over 20 years of experience in the real estate industry, previously holding executive positions in several Singapore-listed Reits. Donner played a key role in setting up Cromwell E-Reit's financial framework and its 2017 listing.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on US rallies, cheaper yen
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 1.23% on Monday, driven by US market rallies and a cheaper yen. The Nikkei 225 index gained 269.38 points to 22,139.94, while the Topix index rose 1.31% to 1,626.43. The US market's positive start was seen as a boost to Tokyo's trading, with traders brushing off new Trump threats to extend the stocks rally. The cheaper yen also contributed to the Tokyo market's gains.

site_title: Another warning is flashing on Asia's 11% stock-market rally
summary: Asia's 11% stock market rally has lost momentum, with equity ETF inflows dwindling and a second monthly net outflow recorded in March. Despite concerns about global economic strength and regional equity valuations, market watchers expect the rally to continue, citing improving policy fundamentals and moderate equity valuations. However, early earnings results and global fund withdrawals paint a cautionary tale, and some investors are quietly pulling out of the surge. The rally may be stymied by China's delayed transition to the MSCI China All Shares Indexes and a potential government response to the country's high leverage.

site_title: Trump's 2020 campaign raises over US$30m in first quarter
summary: US President Donald Trump's 2020 re-election campaign raised over $30 million in the first quarter of 2019, exceeding his predecessors' fundraising periods. The campaign now has over $40 million and aims to reach a $1 billion goal. Nearly 99% of donations were under $200, with an average contribution of $34. This surpasses the combined fundraising of top Democratic candidates Bernie Sanders and Kamala Harris. Trump is also raising funds for the Republican National Committee, which brought in $45.8 million in the first quarter.

site_title: London landlords invest outside capital to escape high tax bill
summary: London landlords are shifting their investments outside the capital due to high taxes and property prices. Nearly 60% of London-based landlords bought properties elsewhere in the UK in the last year, a significant increase from 2010. The trend is driven by the 24,600-pound stamp duty land tax in London, compared to 5,330 pounds outside the capital. This has led to money flowing into the north of England and the Midlands, with lower entry costs and higher yields enticing investors to look further afield.

site_title: Oil edges lower, supply concerns check losses
summary: Oil prices edged lower on Monday, despite reaching a five-month high, due to concerns over global supplies. Brent crude futures fell 0.2% to $71.40 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures dropped 0.5% to $63.60 a barrel. Libya's National Oil Corp warned that renewed fighting could disrupt crude production, while Opec and Russia may consider boosting production to fight for market share, which could push oil prices as low as $40 per barrel.

images.alt_text: Oil prices edged lower on Monday after international benchmark Brent hit a fresh five-month high in the previous session, but concerns over global supplies provided a floor to losses.

site_title: Tritech to sell specialist engineering unit to meet working capital requirements
summary: Tritech Group is selling its specialist engineering unit, Presscrete Engineering, to Lim Wen Heng Construction to meet working capital requirements. The sale price will be determined by several factors, including the audited net asset value and intangible assets of Presscrete. A refundable deposit of S$1.2 million is paid upon signing the framework agreement, with the completion of the sale conditional on shareholder and regulatory approval. The sale will allow Tritech to re-strategize its financial and capital resources and does not contemplate the sale of its entire engineering business.

site_title: CIMB Bank Singapore launches insurance for pet dogs and cats
summary: CIMB Bank Singapore has launched CIMB My Paw Pal, a pet insurance coverage for dogs and cats, with annual premiums ranging from S$74.90 to S$428. The insurance provides coverage for accidents and illnesses, with no medical check-up required. The basic plan covers accidental death, medical expenses, and burial expenses, while optional covers include loss of pet due to theft and illness-related expenses. The coverage is immediate upon submission of the pet's microchip ID.

site_title: American Airlines to cancel 115 flights daily over 737 MAX
summary: American Airlines will cancel 115 daily flights due to the Boeing 737 MAX grounding until August 19. The airline initially planned to keep the planes grounded until June 5 but extended the cancellations to plan for the peak travel season. American Airlines chairman and CEO Doug Parker expressed confidence in the aircraft's recertification prior to the deadline. The cancellations affect approximately 1.5% of American's total flights daily this summer, with the airline anticipating bringing the MAX aircraft back on line as spares after recertification.

site_title: Betting on a soft landing: key takeaways from the IMF meetings
summary: Global finance chiefs expressed concern over the current state of the world economy, but remain optimistic that it will soon rebound. The IMF cut its forecast for global expansion to the slowest pace since the financial crisis, but predicted growth will pick up in the second half of the year. Officials cited a shift away from tighter monetary policy, recent stimulus in China, and easing trade tensions as reasons for hope. Despite warnings of a "delicate moment" and "self-inflicted wounds," IMF managing director Christine Lagarde and World Bank chief economist Pinelopi Koujianou Goldberg expressed confidence in the economy's ability to recover.

site_title: Mobike's backpedal, and a lesson on ambition
summary: Mobike, a Chinese bike-sharing firm, retreated from its expansion plans in Singapore, Malaysia, and Thailand after failing to replicate its success in China. Despite being cautioned by investors, Mobike pursued ambitious expansion, citing the abundance of capital in the market. However, the infrastructure in Southeast Asia was deemed unsuitable for the bike-sharing model, leading to significant losses. Experts warn that venture players often miscalculate the challenges of changing founders' ways, and CEOs may be poor in management despite technical expertise.

site_title: Lyft pulls electric bikes in three US cities after complaints about braking
summary: Lyft is recalling approximately 3,000 electric bikes in New York, Washington, and San Francisco due to reports of stronger than expected braking force, which could cause falls. The company is replacing the electric bikes with traditional ones to prevent service interruptions. The move comes after a small number of riders reported the issue, prompting Lyft to pause the service of the affected bikes out of caution. Lyft is working on a new electric bike model that will be deployed soon.

images.alt_text: Lyft Inc is recalling several thousand electric bikes in its bike-share programme in New York, Washington and San Francisco because of a braking problem, the ride-hailing company said on Sunday.

site_title: The US$18b electric-car bubble at risk of bursting in China
summary: China's electric vehicle (EV) market, which has seen billions of dollars in investments, is at risk of bursting due to the government's subsidy cuts and intense competition. Over 486 EV manufacturers are registered in China, with many start-ups facing financial challenges. The market's growth is projected to reach 1.6 million units this year, but experts warn that only a few dozen companies can sustain themselves. The cut in subsidies, which could total $7,500 per vehicle, will likely eliminate some start-ups, while established manufacturers like BYD are better equipped to withstand the competition.

site_title: Citigroup sees US treasury yields falling toward 2.3%
summary: Citigroup predicts US Treasury yields will fall toward 2.3% due to disappointing economic data and a pause in Federal Reserve rate hikes. Strategists believe the 2.54% recent yield high has peaked, and yields may extend to 2.30-2.35%. The Fed's decision to hold rates may indicate more rate cuts than expected, as the labor market shows signs of weakness despite robust employment numbers.

site_title: Former Citigroup Asia CEO Francisco Aristeguieta heads to State Street
summary: State Street appoints Francisco Aristeguieta as CEO for its international business, effective July. He previously led Citigroup's Asia business. Aristeguieta will oversee strategy, client engagement, and growth in Europe, Middle East, Latin America, and Asia-Pacific regions. He will also join State Street's management committee. The appointment aims to make State Street a more nimble organization for clients, supporting its goal of growth and expansion.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CapitaLand, UOL, ST Engineering, Heeton, YZJ Shipbuilding, NGSC
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Several Singaporean companies saw developments that may affect trading of their shares. CapitaLand's proposed acquisition of Ascendas-Singbridge was approved by shareholders, while UOL Group acquired parts of the Marina Square complex for S$675.3 million. ST Engineering was allowed to buy a US-based engine nacelle systems manufacturer. Heeton Holdings acquired the Crowne Plaza London Kensington hotel for S$148.9 million. Yangzijiang Shipbuilding's executive chairman donated 3.8% of his shares to a trust. Lian Beng reported a 55.3% lower profit for the quarter, while NGSC's former CEO is facing efforts to remove him from the board.

site_title: The end of Fed debt unwind is set. So what's next?
summary: The US Federal Reserve is expected to resume growing its balance sheet after a planned reduction ends in September. Strategists predict a turning point in October, where the Fed will need to start increasing assets to prevent disruptions in funding markets. This could lead to additional Treasury purchases, reducing the government's need for public funding and influencing Treasury maturities. The Treasury is seeking guidance from bond dealers on the Fed's expected actions, including the long-run composition of its balance sheet and the path to returning to its pre-crisis approach of holding only government debt.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks hit over 6-month high as slowdown worries ease
summary: South Korean stocks reached a six-month high, closing 0.75% higher at 2,250.19 points on Monday. The rally was driven by positive US corporate results easing concerns over an economic slowdown. The Korean won strengthened, and foreign investors bought 126.3 billion won worth of shares. Shares of Asiana Airlines surged 30% after its parent group agreed to sell a stake in the airline. The Kospi has risen 10.25% this year, and the benchmark bond yield rose to 1.925%.

site_title: Tiger Woods takes the Masters in a win for the ages
summary: Tiger Woods won the Masters title, his fifth Masters and 15th major, in a comeback victory after nearly a decade of personal and professional struggles. At 43, Woods became the second-oldest winner of the Masters, overcoming back and leg injuries that led to addiction and surgery. He finished 13 under par with a final round of 70, one stroke ahead of Dustin Johnson, Brooks Koepka, and Xander Schauffele. Woods' win marks a new lease on his career, with his next two majors at courses where he has won before, and is seen as a pivotal moment in his career.

site_title: ECB policymaker sees no need for tiered rates to help banks
summary: European Central Bank policymaker Vitas Vasiliauskas stated that there is no need for tiered interest rates to help commercial banks, despite their profitability being squeezed by the ECB's negative interest rate policy. Vasiliauskas believes the policy remains a positive tool and doesn't see a need for changes, citing limited evidence of credit supply being curbed. Other ECB officials, including Klaas Knot and Jens Weidmann, have also expressed doubts about the need for policy responses, with some arguing that the policy has stimulated credit growth.

site_title: "Gangnam style" sex crime: K-pop scandals uncover dark side of Seoul's flashiest district
summary: A wave of sex crimes and other illegal activities has exposed the dark underbelly of Seoul's Gangnam district, where K-pop stars and businessmen are alleged to have colluded in tax evasion, bribery, and prostitution. Investigations have led to the closure of several clubs, including Burning Sun and Arena, and the resignation of four K-pop stars. Over 500 people have been investigated for drug use and sexual assault, and more than 200 have been arrested. President Moon Jae In has called for a thorough investigation into possible collusion between police, tax authorities, and celebrities.

site_title: Global carmakers face bumpy road as China hosts auto show
summary: Global carmakers are facing a sales slump in China, the world's largest vehicle market, with car sales falling 2.8% in 2018 to 28.1 million units. The decline is attributed to a slowing economy, US trade tension, and a Chinese crackdown on shady credit practices. Despite this, major carmakers still see potential in electric vehicles (EVs), with many launching new models in Shanghai. China's government plans to phase out policies encouraging the purchase of "green" vehicles, increasing competition in the EV market, where Tesla is expanding its presence with a new factory in Shanghai.

site_title: Keppel makes first LNG cargo import from North America under spot import policy
summary: Keppel Gas has completed its first liquefied natural gas (LNG) cargo import from North America under Singapore's spot import policy, marking the company's first diversification of its supply portfolio beyond South-east Asia. The 160,000 cubic metre cargo was sourced from an LNG liquefaction project in North America and will be regasified as feedstock for downstream customers over 30 days.

site_title: Strategic review underway for APTT and Taiwan cable TV investment
summary: ASIAN Pay Television Trust (APTT) is conducting an independent strategic review of its options and investment in Taiwan Broadband Communications Group (TBC). A special committee of independent directors and CEO Brian McKinley will oversee the review, with an independent financial adviser to be selected in the near future. The review aims to explore options for the pay-TV-focused trust, following a review of its investment in TBC.

site_title: Does the US market have enough upward momentum to test new highs this week?
summary: US stocks are poised to test new record highs this week as earnings season and Chinese trade talks continue on track. The bulls have overcome several concerns, including Brexit developments and inflation data. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin's comments on resolving the foreign-exchange issue with China has boosted market sentiment. However, President Trump's threat of tariffs on Airbus and other European imports may keep the bulls in check. Aggregate earnings are expected to retreat by 2.3% from a year earlier, with the financial and healthcare sectors reporting the highest growth.

site_title: Chevron deal highlights revival of American energy
summary: Chevron's $33 billion acquisition of Anadarko Petroleum Corp makes the US company the largest producer in the Permian Basin, a region twice the size of Los Angeles. The deal fuels speculation about rival Exxon Mobil Corp's next move and cements the region's dynamic force in the global energy market, with output forecast to grow by millions of barrels. The acquisition represents a significant turnaround for Chevron and signals Big Oil's renewed focus on growth, with other companies, including BP and Royal Dutch Shell, also increasing spending and ambition.

site_title: Global finance chiefs to 'act promptly' on growth
summary: Global finance chiefs have pledged to "act promptly" to support growth in the face of downside risks, including trade tensions. Despite projected firming growth in 2020, risks remain tilted to the downside, with factors such as limited policy space, high debt levels, and heightened financial vulnerabilities. Officials will continue to mitigate risks, enhance resilience, and act to shore up growth if necessary. The IMF's statement reflects growing concern, following a forecast cut and warnings from Christine Lagarde to avoid "self-inflicted wounds" like tariffs.

site_title: GE finalises US$1.5b DOJ settlement over old subprime unit
summary: General Electric (GE) has agreed to pay $1.5 billion to settle a US Justice Department investigation into its defunct subprime-mortgage business, WMC Mortgage. The company, which first revealed the agreement in principle earlier this year, did not admit liability. The settlement resolves claims that WMC misrepresented the quality of mortgage-backed securities, contributing to the 2008 financial crisis. The agreement is part of GE's efforts to reduce debt and strengthen its balance sheet under new CEO Larry Culp. The settlement marks a significant step in GE's turnaround effort.

site_title: Big bank earnings reflect strength in US economy
summary: US banks report strong earnings, indicating the country's economy remains strong despite the government shutdown and President Trump's trade war with China. JPMorgan Chase and PNC Financial Services Group saw revenue increase by 15% and 3% respectively, driven by consumer and business banking services. Other major banks, including Bank of America and Citigroup, will report their quarterly performances soon. While some experts caution against drawing conclusions from the banks' earnings, the data suggests the economy's growth could continue for years, with consumer confidence and borrowing on the rise.

site_title: Google's Sensorvault helps police track where you've been
summary: Google's Sensorvault database collects location records from hundreds of millions of devices worldwide, potentially sweeping up innocent bystanders. The database is connected to Google's Location History feature, which collects data from Android and Apple devices when Location History is enabled. Law enforcement officials are using Sensorvault to track suspects near crime scenes, but the practice raises concerns about data collection and privacy. Users can view and manage their Location History data, but it's unclear how to fully disable data collection.

site_title: Money, money, money: the tycoon factor in India's election
summary: India's election is becoming increasingly expensive, with corporate donations playing a significant role. The ruling Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) received 93% of donations above 20,000 rupees, with Prime Minister Narendra Modi's re-election bid receiving huge financial backing from corporate India. Analysts warn of worrying conflicts of interest and a trend towards plutocracy, with experts estimating the 2019 contest could top $7 billion, making it one of the priciest elections globally. The lack of transparency in corporate donations is also raising concerns, with the government's efforts to crack down on "black money" seen as ineffective.

site_title: Urban farming: a viable option
summary: Singapore aims to achieve its "30 by 30" local food production target by harnessing opportunities in the agri-tech industry. Experts emphasize the need for creativity, innovation, and collaboration to overcome physical constraints. Key strategies include: adopting technologies to boost urban farming, integrating agri-tech farming in developments, leveraging precision agriculture and smart farming, and investing in new production technologies such as indoor and closed-system farming, data-driven innovative supply chains, and genetically modified organisms. Successful implementation will require partnerships between the government, private sector, academia, and consumers to drive scale economics, improve revenue streams, and reduce environmental impact.

site_title: Heeton consortium buys Crowne Plaza London Kensington
summary: Heeton Holdings, a Singaporean developer, has acquired the Crowne Plaza London Kensington hotel for £84.3 million, with Heeton holding a 60% stake. The acquisition, valued at nearly the same as Heeton's market capitalisation, will not require shareholder consent as it is in the ordinary course of business. The 163-room hotel will continue to be operated by InterContinental Hotels Group, with no plans for rebranding.
