The deal marks Heeton's largest yet and brings its global hotel portfolio to 12 properties, including eight in Britain.

images.alt_text: The 163-room freehold property at 94-106, Cromwell Road in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea is now operated by InterContinental Hotels Group.

site_title: Nintendo returns to VR with US$40 DIY headset
summary: Nintendo has returned to the virtual reality market with the US$40 DIY Labo VR Kit, a build-it-yourself set of cardboard goggles and controllers for the Switch console. The system is designed to work within the Switch's processing power, aiming to minimize dizziness and sickness. After a disastrous first foray into VR 25 years ago, Nintendo's new kit has the potential for bigger things, offering an affordable and accessible entry point to virtual reality.

site_title: Canadian couple, brewer create Atlantic Ocean salt beer
summary: A Canadian couple, Colin Duggan and Audrey, have teamed up with a brewmaster, Stefan Gagliardi, to create a salt beer called Le Passage, which is infused with Atlantic sea salt harvested from their home in Nova Scotia. The beer is a gose-style German sour wheat ale, reminiscent of traditional German brews that disappeared during World War II. It will be available in Canada's Atlantic coast provinces starting May 1, and if successful, may be distributed to the rest of Canada and the US.

site_title: Money FM podcast: The Hot Seat: Food protein alternatives - insects
summary: The Money FM podcast, "The Hot Seat," discusses the use of insects as an alternative source of protein due to global population growth and declining farmland productivity. Co-founders of Asia Insect Farm Solutions, Raavee Shankar and Yuvanesh Tamil Selvan, share their insights on the potential benefits and challenges of insect farming. They highlight the environmental advantages and nutritional value of insect-based protein, and discuss the need for further research and regulation to ensure the industry's sustainability and safety.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for the week ending April 12, 2019, shows a modest gain in the Capesize market, with the Baltic Capesize Index (BCI) 5TC rising to $5,737. Improved Atlantic-tightness and an open Colombia coal arbitrage contributed to the gains, while the Pacific market remained firm. The Panamax market saw increased period activity, with several modern Kamsarmaxes fixed for five to eight months at around $11,500. The Supramax market continued its downward trend, with some areas showing more resilience than others. The Handysize market also fell, with negative sentiment evident throughout the week.

site_title: China will maintain prudent monetary policy: PBOC official
summary: China's central bank will maintain prudent monetary policy this year, keeping the yuan in line with fundamentals, according to Deputy Governor Chen Yulu. The economy has been "generally stable" and authorities will use fiscal tools to spur growth, focusing on cutting taxes and fees. The government aims to strengthen the financial sector by opening up to foreign investment and treating local and foreign-funded institutions equally. This follows the passage of a new foreign investment law and progress on state-owned enterprises, with over 1,900 "zombie enterprises" exiting the market last year.

site_title: Don Don Donki not fazed by tight labour, pricey rentals here
summary: Japanese discount chain Don Don Donki has expanded rapidly in Singapore despite stiff labor and rental challenges. The retailer's success lies in its appeal to both workers and landlords, with Donki offering lower rents in exchange for drawing crowds to quieter mall areas. With 700 employees across three outlets, Donki has not faced difficulty hiring and plans to open 10 stores in Singapore by 2020. The company's parent, Pan Pacific International Holdings, aims to open 200 stores overseas in the next five years. Don Don Donki's founder, Takao Yasuda, attributes the retailer's success to its ability to treat employees as managers and offer them autonomy, setting it apart in Singapore's challenging retail scene.

site_title: Indonesia polls thrust China's Belt and Road push into the spotlight
summary: Indonesia's upcoming presidential election has brought China's Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) to the forefront, with opposition candidate Prabowo Subianto criticizing pro-China policies that he says saddle the country with bad debt. Indonesia has signed $23 billion in BRI contracts, including infrastructure projects, and has pledged $91 billion worth of projects to Chinese investors. Prabowo has vowed to review these deals, sparking concerns among investors and analysts. His nationalist rhetoric has raised fears of an outright anti-China policy, which could impact foreign investment in the country.

site_title: Small firms in Vietnam and Indonesia most optimistic about 2019: survey
summary: Small businesses in Vietnam and Indonesia were the most optimistic about 2019, according to a survey of 3,600 small firms across 10 Asia-Pacific markets. Vietnam had the highest growth rate, with 9 in 10 respondents reporting growth, while Indonesia and the Philippines followed closely. Global trade tensions were a concern, but Indonesia was more optimistic about the impact of trade tensions on its business. Small businesses that did well in 2018 were more likely to invest in technology and mobile payment technologies.

site_title: WhiteCoat clinches AIA group healthcare deal
summary: WhiteCoat, a Singapore-based digital healthcare start-up, has secured a partnership with AIA to become its exclusive telehealth provider for 1.2 million employees and dependents. The deal marks a significant milestone for WhiteCoat, which has seen its client base grow from 50,000 to 1.2 million. The partnership offers on-demand access to qualified doctors via a smartphone app, covering diagnosis, treatment, and delivery of medicines. The deal is expected to accelerate WhiteCoat's plans to expand in Southeast Asia and push its estimated market value past S$100 million.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua

site_title: Mexico to stay on course for sound budget surplus
summary: Mexico has ruled out easing its 1% primary fiscal surplus goal, citing a need to stabilize debt as a portion of its economy. Finance Minister Carlos Urzua stated that a smaller surplus could lead to a credibility crisis in the medium to long term. The move comes as Mexican President Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador faces pressure to boost economic growth, forecasted to slow to less than 2% this year. The strategy of cutting costs to increase investment in infrastructure and social programs is seen as unfeasible by many economists.

site_title: Europe's risk of paralysis in slowdown puts Germany on the spot
summary: Germany and France disagree on how to address Europe's slowing economy, with France pushing for joint fiscal measures to stimulate growth and Germany viewing the slowdown as temporary. Germany's Finance Minister Olaf Scholz believes a skilled workforce will find jobs, while French Finance Minister Bruno Le Maire wants countries to use their "fiscal space" to spend more. The IMF warns of a loss of momentum in the region, and the ECB is preparing more support for lending to the real economy. The European economy is expected to continue contracting, with Germany's growth forecast cut to 0.8% this year.

site_title: Japan tells global finance leaders it will raise sales tax as scheduled
summary: Japan's Finance Minister Taro Aso has pledged to proceed with a scheduled sales tax hike from 8% to 10% in October, despite weakening global growth. The economy is expected to "continue to recover moderately" due to a tight job market and strong corporate earnings. The tax increase aims to achieve fiscal consolidation and promote inclusive growth by funding free early-childhood education. This move is crucial for Japan to address its huge public debt and rising welfare costs for an ageing population.

site_title: ECB's Draghi, in rare move, sounds concern over Fed's independence
summary: European Central Bank president Mario Draghi expressed concern over the potential undermining of the Federal Reserve's independence, citing the US President Donald Trump's frequent criticism of Fed Chairman Jerome Powell. Draghi emphasized the importance of central bank independence in making objective economic decisions. The IMF managing director, Christine Lagarde, also highlighted the benefits of central bank independence, while other central bankers, including South African Reserve Bank governor Lesetja Kganyago and Swiss National Bank president Thomas Jordan, agreed that independence is crucial for accountability and effective monetary policy.

site_title: Brexit can-kicking leaves pound's prospects in suspended animation
summary: The pound's prospects remain uncertain due to the threat of longer-term economic damage from Brexit and heightened domestic political risks. Sterling strengthened slightly after the UK and EU agreed to extend the Brexit deadline to October 31, but its gains were short of expectations. Analysts predict the currency will struggle to lift off from current levels in the next six months, with a risk of a snap election or leadership challenge to Prime Minister Theresa May. UK data, including inflation and jobs reports, will be key market focus.

site_title: French clamour for tax cut: poll
summary: In a French poll, 82% of respondents favour a decrease in income tax, while 62% support scrapping privatisations, including Paris airports operator ADP. The poll, conducted after a 10-week series of debates with citizens, also showed that 82% want President Emmanuel Macron to change his economic and social policies. Prime Minister Edouard Philippe stated that the "clear message is that taxes must fall and fall fast" following the poll's findings, which also revealed a significant shift in public opinion compared to November.

site_title: Daimler faces probe over 'new cheating software'
summary: Daimler, the German carmaker, is facing a regulatory probe over allegations of installing "cheating software" in some of its vehicles. The Federal Motor Transport Authority has initiated a formal hearing procedure after discovering a previously unknown type of pollution trickery software, affecting around 60,000 Mercedes-Benz GLK 220 CDI models produced between 2012 and 2015. The software allegedly reduced emissions during testing but increased emissions on the road, violating regulatory limits. Daimler is cooperating with the investigation and reviewing the facts, amid a larger diesel scandal in Germany.

site_title: China not prepared for iron ore shortage: industry adviser
summary: China's steel industry is unprepared for a looming iron ore shortage, according to industry adviser Wu Wenzhang. Iron ore prices have surged to a five-year high, with prices expected to continue to rise due to mine closures in Brazil and a market deficit in the second half of the year. Disruptions are estimated to amount to 60 million tonnes, and Wu warns that a slide below 100 million tonnes in Chinese stockpiles could trigger devastating price volatility. With current stockpiles totaling nearly 150 million tonnes, Wu urges steelmakers to prepare for the shortage.

site_title: Be discerning on funds' income payouts
summary: Investors should be cautious when evaluating income payouts from their portfolios, as not all income is created equal. Many investors have lost capital by chasing high-yielding investments, such as bonds or scams, which can result in permanent losses. To avoid this, it's essential to understand the source of the income and assess the associated risks. This discernment is crucial in generating long-term income and supplementing the income of savers and retirees, especially with paltry bank interest rates.

site_title: Coffee price crisis means hipsters could lose their specialty blends
summary: A coffee price crisis is threatening specialty blends used by hipsters, with arabica coffee prices near a 13-year low due to oversupply from Brazil and Central America. This glut has led to farmers selling coffee at unsustainable prices, eroding profits for specialty growers. If producers pull back, prices may recover, but most investors expect a prolonged rout, with hedge funds holding a record short position of 74,110 arabica futures and options.

site_title: Positive vibe from Wall Street expected to lift shares
summary: The Straits Times Index is expected to start the trading week on higher ground, following a Wall Street rally. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 closed up 1.0% and 0.7%, respectively, while the Nasdaq Composite Index rose 0.5%. Investors are optimistic about the market outlook, with some expecting a "very positive vibe" in Singapore and Asia. However, companies in Singapore are due to report their first quarter performance, leading to potential profit-taking. Key data releases include March non-oil domestic export data in Singapore and industrial production data for China.

site_title: Stratolaunch, world's largest airplane by wingspan, takes flight
summary: The world's largest airplane, Stratolaunch, took its first flight on Saturday, flying for 2.5 hours over the Mojave Desert in Southern California. The twin-fuselage plane, made from reassembled parts of two used Boeing jetliners, reached speeds of 304 km/h and altitudes of 5,182 meters. Designed to carry rockets to space, the plane's large wingspan is longer than a football field. The successful flight marks a milestone for the company, which was initially funded by Microsoft co-founder Paul Allen, and paves the way for launching commercial satellites into space.

site_title: Mnuchin hopes US-China trade talks nearing 'final round'
summary: US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin expressed hope that a US-China trade agreement is nearing its final round of negotiations, which would go "way beyond" previous efforts to open China's markets to American companies. The agreement would address issues such as intellectual property, forced technology transfers, and industrial subsidies. Mnuchin said the deal would have "real enforcement on both sides" and the US would be open to penalties if it failed to keep its commitments. A deal is seen as a significant change in the trading relationship between the two countries in 40 years.

site_title: Asean's top venture lender InnoVen increases its tempo
summary: InnoVen Capital, Southeast Asia's top venture debt firm, plans to increase its deal flow and loan disbursements in 2019, aiming for 25-30 loans worth over $50 million. The firm, backed by Temasek Holdings and UOB, has seen no defaults from its portfolio since its inception in 2015 and focuses on providing debt to high-growth companies. Venture debt offers founders an alternative to equity dilution, allowing them to boost growth without giving up equity. InnoVen's internal rate of return is 12-14%, and it assesses startups based on financial projections, team strength, and competitive advantage.

site_title: More VCs pour into Asean, but await elusive exits
summary: Venture capital firms from China and India are investing heavily in Southeast Asian startups, drawn by the region's growth potential. However, industry players warn that exits through IPOs or trade sales are slow due to high valuations. This has left some investors waiting for elusive exits, which could lead to a rude shock if valuations were to decline. Despite this, many startups continue to secure funding, with some reporting significant raises, such as AI Hay's US$10 million Series-A funding.

site_title: 20 director acquisitions filed; 12 stocks conduct buybacks
summary: Over five trading sessions from April 5 to 11, the Singapore Stock Exchange Index (STI) gained 0.4%, surpassing regional indices, while 12 stocks conducted share buybacks totaling S$11.6 million. Notably, director acquisitions and substantial shareholder transactions were reported for approximately 40 primary-listed stocks, with 20 director acquisitions and 20 acquisitions by substantial shareholders. Key transactions included executive chairman Henry Tay's acquisition of 500,000 shares of The Hour Glass and managing director Loh Yi's acquisition of 22,512,956 shares of Acesian Partners.

site_title: Drugmakers stockpiling for Brexit ask, how long do we wait?
summary: Pharmaceutical companies in the UK are stockpiling life-saving medicines in preparation for a potentially chaotic Brexit, with uncertainty surrounding the UK's withdrawal from the European Union dragging on. Companies like Novo Nordisk and Sanofi are holding inventories of over 16 weeks, at a significant cost, due to the risk of border delays and potential shortages. The pharma sector warns of ongoing pain and costs involved, with some companies considering cutting back on stockpiles if the risk of a no-deal Brexit decreases.

site_title: Dollar weakens as euro rides demand linked to cross-border deal
summary: The US dollar weakened against the euro, reaching its lowest level since March 26, as investors sought riskier assets amid economic stabilization in China and a strong start to the US corporate earnings season. The euro rose 0.4% to US$1.1295, driven by speculation over a Japanese bank's planned purchase of a German aviation finance business. The dollar also rose against the Japanese yen and the Australian dollar, while the British pound rallied as Brexit risks receded.

site_title: Saudi wealth fund to seek bridge loan of US$5-8b
summary: Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund (PIF) is seeking a bridge loan of $5-8 billion to fund new investments as part of its economic diversification plan, known as Vision 2030. The loan will be repaid with proceeds from the sale of its stake in Saudi Basic Industries Corp (Sabic) to Saudi Aramco. This move aims to reduce the kingdom's reliance on oil and control over $2 trillion by 2030. The talks with banks are at an early stage, and the final loan size will depend on their response.

site_title: ST Engineering unit gets US government go-ahead to buy engine parts maker
summary: ST Engineering's US subsidiary, Vision Technologies Aerospace Incorporated, has received US government clearance to buy MRA Systems, a maker of critical aeroplane engine parts, for $630 million. The acquisition is expected to close in the coming week and will scale up ST Engineering's aerospace capabilities. MRA Systems holds single-source contracts for both mature and next-generation nacelle programmes, including engines for Airbus' A320neo. The deal is earnings-accretive and aims to drive new growth areas for ST Engineering.

site_title: Iran peddling millions of barrels of oil again
summary: Iran is offering 6 million barrels of oil on its exchange, with only one deal closing at 35,000 barrels, amid US sanctions and further curbs on exports. Exemptions for importing countries like Japan and China have partially cushioned the blow, but foreign investors are steering clear. Iranian officials acknowledge it's nearly impossible to sell oil due to sanctions, and the exchange is struggling to offload oil to domestic buyers. Another 1 million barrels of light crude is being offered, but buyers must secure tanker and insurance.

site_title: USDCAD may continue upwards to retest the 1.3460 high
summary: USDCAD is expected to continue upwards, potentially retesting the 1.3460 high, as it moves sideways within a narrowing range. The pair has formed a potential triangle pattern, traditionally indicating a continuation of the previous movement. However, a critical support level at 1.3320 may influence the pair's direction, and further reaction to this level will be crucial in determining the next move.

site_title: Indonesians ready for world's biggest single-day polls
summary: Indonesians are set to vote in the world's biggest single-day election, with over 192 million people participating in presidential and parliamentary elections. President Joko Widodo, who has a double-digit lead in most opinion polls, is running against ex-general Prabowo Subianto, who has disputed survey findings. The opposition has raised concerns over electoral irregularities, which could lead to protests and a brief slump in the Indonesian market. The election is seen as a test of Indonesia's democracy, with analysts warning that an unexpected win for the challenger could elevate tensions and pressure the currency.

site_title: Renting flat-pack furniture? Ikea's push to go green
summary: IKEA plans to become a circular business by 2030, aiming to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions by 70% per product and eliminate single-use plastics by 2020. The company will start renting and recycling furniture worldwide, expanding its pilot leasing project to all 30 markets. While some experts see this as a genuine attempt to go green, others are skeptical, citing concerns over the company's current carbon footprint and production practices. IKEA's efforts aim to promote sustainable consumption and reduce waste, but critics argue that the company's business model may be at odds with these goals.

site_title: Struggling Ryobi Kiso will sell joint-venture unit to raise funds
summary: Ryobi Kiso Holdings, a debt-hit construction firm, will sell its 74.1% stake in Ryobi Geotechnique to its founder, Wang Hou, for S$14.5 million, below the book value of S$12.8 million. The sale aims to raise working capital and prevent further deterioration of the joint venture's value. The deal will yield a net gain of nearly S$1.76 million but will reduce the company's net tangible asset per share.

site_title: Microsoft's work with Chinese military university triggers concerns
summary: Microsoft has collaborated with researchers from China's National University of Defence Technology, a military-backed university, on artificial intelligence projects, raising concerns that US firms are contributing to China's high-tech surveillance and censorship apparatus. The research covers face analysis and machine reading, which could contribute to China's crackdown on minorities in Xinjiang. Microsoft claims its researchers conduct fundamental research with leading scholars worldwide, complying with US laws and publishing results for transparency. Experts argue that the research is open and publicly accessible, but also note that China's advancements in AI make it difficult for researchers to avoid collaborating with the country.

site_title: NGSC's chairman, ex-CEO and others face removal from board
summary: NGSC's chairman, former CEO Vicente S Ku, and other directors, including Andrew Coulton and Raymond Lai Chik Fan, face removal from the board. Shareholders have called a vote to oust these directors, along with anyone else named between April 10, due to unresolved differences of opinion and material matters. The NGSC board is seeking professional advice on the requisition notice from Sri Tjintawati Hartanto and Telemedia Pacific Group, which hold 17.3% of the company's shares. The move comes after Ku's termination as CEO and managing director in March.

site_title: Dominant Hamilton wins 1,000th race in Mercedes one-two
summary: Lewis Hamilton won the 1,000th Formula One grand prix, taking the lead from Valtteri Bottas at the first corner and powering to victory in Shanghai. Hamilton secured his sixth Chinese Grand Prix win and second in a row this season, with Ferrari's Sebastian Vettel third. The victory marked Mercedes' first one-two finish in the 1,000th grand prix, with Hamilton taking the world championship lead.

site_title: Jokowi's election fight shows Indonesia's Islam identity crisis
summary: Indonesia's presidential election on April 17 pits incumbent President Joko Widodo, known as Jokowi, against former army commando Prabowo Subianto. Jokowi has sought to bolster his religious credentials by picking Ma'ruf Amin, Indonesia's most senior Islamic cleric, as his running mate. However, social media-driven rumors about his faith and secular policies have threatened to sway voters. Analysts predict that a conservative Islamic agenda may gain traction, potentially leading to laws outlawing same-sex relations, despite Jokowi's efforts to maintain a moderate stance.

site_title: Finnish voters may pave way for leftist premier but he will likely struggle to form a coalition
summary: Finland is set to elect a leftist premier, with the Social Democrats likely to win the top spot, but their ability to govern may be hindered by the nationalist Finns Party's surge in support. The Finns Party is riding an anti-immigrant wave, threatening to shake up EU policymaking. The Social Democrats' leader, Antti Rinne, favors work-related immigration and raising taxes to fund welfare, but faces challenges in forming a coalition with the Finns Party and other parties, including the National Coalition.

site_title: Google takes on 'Africa's challenges' with first AI centre in Ghana
summary: Google has opened its first artificial intelligence research laboratory in Ghana, dubbed "Africa's challenge," with the goal of addressing economic, political, and environmental issues across the continent. The lab, located in Accra, will focus on healthcare, education, and agriculture using AI to develop solutions such as disease diagnosis and crop management. Google is collaborating with local organizations and policymakers to enhance AI development in Ghana and other regional countries, with the aim of fostering a new generation of AI developers.

site_title: Empowering young designers to design for good
summary: The Asia Young Designer Awards (AYDA) recognizes young designers who create projects that improve the lives of people. This year's winners, Tanay Narendra Bothara from India and Dang Huu Trong from Vietnam, received the Asia Young Designer of the Year award for their projects, "Children Uprooted" and "Future-Forward, Culturom," respectively. Both projects aim to transform war-torn spaces and remote areas into playgrounds and educational centers, promoting art, architecture, and cultural accessibility. AYDA, started by Nippon Paint in 2008, aims to bridge the gap between skills and the private sector, empowering young designers to design for good.

site_title: Wall St gives Fed a passing grade even as Trump continues to pressure Powell
summary: Wall Street has given the Federal Reserve a passing grade, with 67% of primary dealers rating its communication as "effective" or "very effective" since its shift to a "patient" approach in January. The 3.4 composite score is below Chairman Jerome Powell's average grade of 3.6 but above his predecessors Janet Yellen and Ben Bernanke's averages. The Fed's message is seen as improving, but President Trump continues to pressure Powell to change course, citing concerns over economic growth.

site_title: Keppel screens award winning documentary on the circular economy
summary: Keppel, a Singapore-based conglomerate, screened the world's first feature-length documentary on the circular economy, "Closing the Loop," at the Singapore Botanic Gardens. The event was held in support of Earth Day 2019 and aligned with the Singapore government's push for a circular economy. The documentary showcases innovative applications of technology and process improvements to design out waste and pollution. Keppel's CEO, Loh Chin Hua, and Minister for the Environment and Water Resources, Masagos Zulkifli, attended the event, emphasizing the importance of a circular economy in achieving a sustainable environment and creating new business opportunities.

site_title: North Korea's Kim open to third Trump summit: KCNA
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un is open to a third summit with US President Donald Trump, but only if Washington has the "right attitude." Kim stated he would wait until the end of the year for the US to make a decision on another meeting, following the breakdown of the February summit in Vietnam. The US blamed North Korea's demands for sanctions relief, while Pyongyang said it only wanted some sanctions eased in exchange for limited nuclear disarmament.

images.alt_text: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un is willing to meet with US President Donald Trump a third time if Washington comes to the table with the "right attitude", state media reported on Saturday.

site_title: Squatters occupy Venice homes in housing protest as tourism surges
summary: Squatters in Venice, Italy, are occupying unoccupied buildings to protest the city's high rents and tourism-driven displacement of long-time residents. With a population of 50,000, Venice has 8,000 Airbnb apartments catering to tourists, exacerbating the issue. Residents, including families with children, are being priced out of their homes, with many opting to become squatters to fight for affordable housing. The city council has introduced an entrance fee to help with upkeep, but residents and housing activists argue that the measures do not address the root issue of unaffordable housing.

images.alt_text: Patrizia Zaniol, 56, in her illegally occupied apartment in the Casette neighbourhood in Venice. The city's residents complain that their city is being overrun by tourists while they have to pick up the bill for cleaning and security.
Patrizia Zaniol (left), 56, and Nicola Ussardi, 41, co-founder of a group that helps Venetians find homes, walking through the only land entrance to an area of about 20 illegally occupied apartments.
Alessandro Dus, 34, in his illegally occupied apartment. He says: "When we move to an abandoned apartment, we renovate it and we make it habitable again."

site_title: UOL wins full control of Marina Mandarin hotel, as UIC unit buys out OUE and others
summary: United Industrial Corp (UIC) has acquired the majority stake in Marina Centre Holdings, gaining control of the Marina Mandarin hotel for $675.3 million. UIC will own 77.34% of Marina Centre Holdings and 75% of Aquamarina Hotel, while UOL Group retains a 25% stake. The deal includes the sale of OUE's minority interests in the Marina Square complex for $390 million. UIC plans to capitalize on the Marina Centre precinct's growth potential and explore asset enhancement opportunities, including potential rebranding of the Marina Mandarin hotel.

site_title: Kuroda brushes aside view BOJ has run out of tools to ease monetary policy
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated the central bank is ready to expand monetary stimulus if needed, despite concerns that it has limited ammunition to combat economic downturns. Kuroda brushed aside the notion that the BOJ has exhausted its policy tools, citing the need for flexibility in response to financial developments. He reaffirmed the BOJ's commitment to maintaining powerful monetary easing, including its forward guidance and yield curve control policies, which aim to keep interest rates low and stabilize the economy.

site_title: Europe: Shares end higher boosted by banks and auto stocks
summary: European shares rose for a third consecutive day, boosted by banks and auto stocks. The Stoxx 600 index closed 0.16% higher, with Italy's MIB and Germany's DAX leading gains. Banks, including JP Morgan and StanChart, rallied after beating profit estimates, while the auto sector followed suit with gains from BMW, Daimler, and Fiat Chrysler. China's exports rebounded to a five-month high, but imports shrank for a fourth month, painting a mixed economic picture.

site_title: Vietnam woman in Kim brother murder to be freed on May 3
summary: A Vietnamese woman, Doan Thi Huong, accused of killing North Korean leader Kim Jong Un's half-brother, will be freed on May 3, following the dropping of a murder charge by Malaysian prosecutors. Huong, a 30-year-old former hair salon worker, pleaded guilty to causing injury and was given a 3-year and 4-month jail term. The move comes after diplomatic pressure from the Vietnamese government, and Huong will be flown to Hanoi after her release. The trial's outcome also marked the end of a long-running case involving the two women, who claimed to be innocent pawns in a plot.

site_title: Quake-hit Indonesians refuse to leave high ground: official
summary: Quake-hit Indonesians refuse to leave high ground due to fears of another tsunami. A 6.8 magnitude quake triggered a brief tsunami warning, prompting residents to flee to higher ground. While some 1,300 families have returned home, others remain in the hills, and at least one resident died after falling while trying to flee. The disaster agency reported no confirmed deaths or injuries, and minor damage was reported in some areas, with the situation returning to normal.

site_title: Oil rises 1% on tightening crude supply, upbeat economic data
summary: Oil prices rose 1% on Friday as supply cuts from Venezuela, Iran, and Libya supported market perceptions of a tightening crude market, while upbeat Chinese economic data eased concerns about waning demand. Brent crude oil futures rose 1.02% to $71.55 a barrel, and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures gained 0.5% to $63.89 a barrel. Geopolitical tensions, including the conflict in Libya, are expected to support prices, potentially reaching $80 per barrel this summer.

site_title: Heeton-led consortium buys London hotel for £84.3 million
summary: A Singaporean consortium, led by Heeton Holdings, has acquired the Crowne Plaza London Kensington hotel for £84.3 million. Heeton, along with KSH Holdings and Ho Lee Group, holds a 60% stake in the 163-room hotel. The acquisition, announced on April 11, brings Heeton's international hospitality portfolio to eight assets in Britain, Japan, and Thailand. Heeton CEO Eric Teng stated that the deal reaffirms the group's intention to be a strategic player in the international hospitality sector, adding value to its current portfolio.

site_title: Strong earthquake hits off Indonesia, one reported dead
summary: A 6.8-magnitude earthquake struck eastern Indonesia on Friday, killing one person and triggering a brief tsunami warning. The quake occurred at a shallow depth of 17km off the east coast of Sulawesi island, where a 7.5-magnitude quake-tsunami last year killed over 4,300 people. Three aftershocks followed the initial quake, with panicked residents fleeing to higher ground.

site_title: Facebook more than doubles Zuckerberg compensation to US$22.6m
summary: Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg's compensation for 2018 more than doubled to US$22.6 million, with nearly half attributed to personal security. Meanwhile, Facebook's board will see changes, with Netflix CEO Reed Hastings vacating his seat and PayPal's Peggy Alford nominated in his place. These moves come as Facebook continues to expand its video push. Despite the changes, Facebook shares closed at US$179.07 on the day the news was released.

site_title: 'Star Wars: Rise of Skywalker' sees return of emperor Palpatine
summary: Disney revealed the title and first footage of the ninth "Star Wars" film, "The Rise of Skywalker," at the "Star Wars Celebration" convention. The movie will feature the return of Emperor Palpatine, played by Ian McDiarmid, and conclude the story that began in 1977. Director J.J. Abrams said the film takes place after "The Last Jedi" and will focus on the new generation's inheritance of the light and dark. The movie will be released in December, and Abrams used unused footage of Carrie Fisher's character, Princess Leia, to continue her story.

site_title: How Grab can outwit the incumbents
summary: Grab, a Temasek-backed unicorn, has outsmarted "old-economy" thinking and worked within regulatory boundaries, much to the surprise of investors. Despite regulatory changes, Grab continues to attract drivers with flexible incentives, outmaneuvering traditional taxi companies. The company's CEO, Anthony Tan, has raised $6.5 billion in funding, a mix of debt and equity, as the market prepares for potential downturns. Vertex Ventures' CEO, Chua Kee Lock, notes that startups must focus on building great companies, rather than timing the market, to achieve long-term success.

images.alt_text: Grab expects to raise US$6.5 billion of total capital this year, with the funding a mix of debt and equity.

site_title: Trump says could send illegal migrants to 'sanctuary cities'
summary: US President Donald Trump announced on Twitter that the US is considering sending detained illegal migrants to "sanctuary cities" that oppose his immigration policies. This reversal comes after a previous White House assurance that the idea had been dropped, citing Democrats' unwillingness to change immigration laws. Trump's statement was met with criticism, with the idea seen as political retribution against cities led by opposition Democrats. The move is expected to have significant implications for the cities and the ongoing immigration debate.

site_title: Lifestyle sector tapping govt schemes to ease labour crunch
summary: The lifestyle sector in Singapore, including food and beverage, retail, and hotels, is tapping government schemes to ease a labour crunch. Since 2017, over 140 firms have utilized the Lean Enterprise Development Scheme, which offers grants for job redesign and productivity solutions. Workforce Singapore has also introduced job redesign frameworks for the food services and retail sectors, and the Capability Transfer Programme to bring in foreign specialists or send Singaporeans overseas for skills training. In 2018, over 400 locals found jobs in the sector through the Adapt and Grow schemes.

site_title: Warning issued on industrial plants as 'Triton' hack resurfaces
summary: Security researchers have confirmed new activity by hackers using "Triton" malware, capable of causing real-world damage to oil, gas, or water plants. The malware was previously spotted in 2017, and FireEye identified an additional intrusion at a critical infrastructure facility without disclosing the target. This warning comes as the US-China trade tensions and tariffs continue to impact the energy and commodities market. The incident highlights the ongoing threat of cyberattacks on critical infrastructure and the need for increased security measures to protect against such attacks.

site_title: China, Malaysia to resume East Coast Rail Link project for RM21b less
summary: China and Malaysia have agreed to resume the East Coast Rail Link project at a reduced cost of RM44 billion (S$14.5 billion), down from the original RM65.5 billion. The project, which aims to connect Malaysia's eastern coast to a major port near Kuala Lumpur, was cancelled earlier due to budget concerns. The deal is seen as a boon for China's Belt and Road Initiative, and will benefit Malaysia by lightening its financial burden. The project's resumption is also expected to boost Malaysia's economic growth.

site_title: Video gaming can benefit students: study
summary: Research suggests that video gaming can have cognitive benefits, particularly when played during weekends as a leisure activity, rather than displacing time for school work. A study found that adolescents who frequently play video games on weekends perform better in mathematics, reading, and science. However, excessive weekday gaming was linked to poorer academic performance, indicating that moderation and active parental involvement are crucial to avoid negative effects.

site_title: Ode to my alma mater
summary: A Singaporean alumna reflects on her alma mater, Singapore Chinese Girls' School, and its unique school song. The song, which she sang every morning for 10 years, is a simple yet profound celebration of life's small joys, such as the sky being blue and dew falling. Unlike other school anthems, which often boast of grandeur and achievement, the SCGS song's humility and focus on gratitude make it genius. The alumna argues that the song's wisdom is that being virtuous human beings who appreciate the little things is the key to a fulfilling life.

site_title: ECB model suggests euro zone growth could slow further: sources
summary: The European Central Bank's internal model suggests euro zone economic growth could slow further in the second quarter, with quarterly growth potentially below 0.2% in the first three months of the year. This delay in recovery may prompt the ECB to maintain its stimulus measures, rather than raising interest rates as previously planned. The ECB has already backtracked on rate hikes and is seeking to boost confidence during the euro zone's soft patch.

images.alt_text: But the weakness may last longer than thought even just a few weeks ago, underpinning ECB President Mario Draghi's generally dovish tone, the sources said, as global finance leaders gathered in Washington for the International Monetary Fund and World Bank spring meetings.

site_title: MAS maintains monetary policy, cuts core inflation forecast to 1 - 2%
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has maintained its monetary policy stance, downgrading its core inflation forecast to 1-2% for 2019 due to weaker global oil prices and a stronger-than-expected effect of the open electricity market. MAS expects Singapore's GDP growth to come in slightly below its mid-point forecast range. The central bank is maintaining the current rate of appreciation of the Singapore dollar and will review its policy in October. Economists generally see the MAS as likely to maintain its current stance, with most expecting no further tightening.

site_title: Pure Group to open 8th facility in Suntec City
summary: Pure Group is set to open its 8th facility in Singapore, a 30,000 sq ft gym in Suntec City, focusing on circuit training, high-intensity workouts, and personal training. The outlet is expected to open by the end of this year or early 2020. The group will invest an additional S$20 million over the next two years to expand its reach in the country. This investment comes as the company aims to further establish itself in Singapore, with plans for additional gym outlets in the coming months and years.

site_title: Qatar seeks to transform diabetes care with 'whole nation' project
summary: Qatar is launching a nationwide project to transform diabetes care, with a database of children with diabetes, the first of its kind in the region and possibly the world. Led by Professor Khalid Hussain, the project aims to recruit every child with diabetes in Qatar, with the ultimate goal of improving treatment and management of the disease. The project is unique in the region and could have a significant impact on Qatar's healthcare system.

site_title: Showbiz stalwart
summary: Singaporean Ricky Ow, former child actor in a Chinese drama, has been overseeing the Asia-Pacific portfolio of Turner, a global media and entertainment giant, for five years. Ow, who has no talent for acting, credits his aunt's influence in securing his first role on Radio and Television Singapore. As president of Turner Asia Pacific, he oversees brands like CNN, Cartoon Network, and Boomerang, making him one of the region's largest international TV broadcasters.

site_title: China exports rebound after holiday, imports warn of fragility
summary: China's exports rebounded 14.2% in March from a year earlier, while imports fell 7.6% in dollar terms, resulting in a trade surplus of $32.65 billion. The data suggests a tentative sign of resilience in the global economy, but the continued slump in imports raises concerns about the domestic economy's fragility. Analysts expect the first quarter to mark the low point, with more stimulus to filter through, but warn that external demand and global trade are likely to remain sluggish throughout the year.

site_title: Architect Moshe Safdie on the paradise garden theme for Changi Airport's Jewel
summary: Canadian-Israeli architect Moshe Safdie designed Jewel Changi Airport's paradise garden theme, aiming to create a timeless and universal attraction. The 40-meter-high HSBC Rain Vortex, a world's tallest indoor waterfall, and the Shiseido Forest Valley, a terraced garden with walking trails and waterfalls, are among the features. Safdie emphasized the need for separate retail and garden spaces, and the building's design incorporates sustainable elements, such as fogging devices and air-conditioning, to maintain a comfortable temperature. Jewel has received multiple awards for its innovative and iconic design.

site_title: MPA pumps in S$650,000 for startups to develop innovative maritime solutions
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) has invested S$650,000 in seed funding for 13 tech startups to develop innovative maritime solutions, with a focus on addressing key challenges in Singapore. The startups, who received S$50,000 each, will use the funding to support prototype development and further develop their solutions. The funding aims to drive innovation and digitization in the maritime industry, with MPA and NUS Enterprise working together to create a more targeted approach for incubation and collaboration with venture capitalists.

site_title: Industry's bright spark: Adding bite to additive manufacturing
summary: Singapore's additive manufacturing (AM) industry is a tale of two domains, with research and development institutions highly adopting the technology, but industrial use still in its infancy. To change this, industry players suggest focusing on high-mix, low-volume production, complex parts, and customization. Examples include 3D-printed aerospace turbine blades, spare parts, and customized medical implants. The industry also needs more technical support, design for AM (DFAM) expertise, and streamlined certification processes. Despite obstacles, the ecosystem has rapidly built up, and there is optimism for future growth as the industry approaches a point of true disruption.

site_title: Singapore Q1 GDP growth hits decade low
summary: Singapore's Q1 GDP growth hit a decade low, growing at the slowest clip since the global financial crisis. Services remained resilient, while construction returned to positive territory. However, a decline in manufacturing due to a gloomy global environment has raised concerns about the sector's future. Analysts warn that factories have not yet hit rock bottom. The slow growth has prompted economists to question if the worst is yet to come.

site_title: US: Banks, oil shares lead stocks higher
summary: US stocks rose on Friday, driven by strong earnings from JPMorgan Chase and Chevron's acquisition of Anadarko. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 1.0% to 26,412.30, while the S&P 500 advanced 0.7% to 2,907.41. JPMorgan jumped 4.7% and Chevron's shares surged 6.7% after the acquisition. Disney's shares rocketed up 11.5% after announcing its new video streaming service. Oil shares also rose, with EOG Resources and Devon Energy surging 6.7% and 7.4% respectively.

site_title: Upcoming supply tamps down property prices in Sydney
summary: Sydney property prices face "further downward pressure" due to a large apartment pipeline, increasing risk to Australian households. The Reserve Bank cites a "sharper downturn" in the global economy and weak housing market conditions as key threats. While bank profits remain healthy, the central bank warns of a "greater-than-usual uncertainty" about their outlook. Housing prices in Sydney and Melbourne are expected to stay 40-50% higher than in 2012, but a surge in apartment supply will put downward pressure on prices, posing a risk to households with little financial buffer.

site_title: BMW M850i Convertible review: Top this if you can
summary: The BMW M850i Convertible boasts a powerful twin-turbo V8 engine, producing 530 horsepower, and features a range of advanced technologies, including air suspension and four-wheel steering. With its sleek design and agile handling, it competes with high-end rivals like the Porsche 911, Mercedes-AMG GT, and Aston Martin DB11 Volante. Despite its impressive performance, the M850i's versatility and luxurious interior make it a compelling choice for those seeking a posh and sporty driving experience.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Lian Beng, a Singaporean construction firm, reported a 55.3% lower profit of S$3.6 million for the quarter ended February due to higher cost of sales and a S$3.1 million loss from associates and joint ventures. Revenue was up 0.4% to S$91 million. Earnings per share decreased to 0.73 Singapore cents from 1.62 Singapore cents in the previous year. The firm received a notice of nomination for three directors from a shareholder, and Keppel Corporation's acquisition of Keppel Telecommunications & Transportation was approved by the court.

site_title: Singapore firm launches 'blank cheque' company IPO on Nasdaq
summary: Singapore-based firm 8i Enterprises Acquisition Corp has launched a special purpose acquisition company (SPAC) IPO on Nasdaq, raising $50 million. The company aims to acquire growth companies in Asia, focusing on sectors like healthcare, energy, and consumer retail. Investors can expect a potential return of 5-8 times forward EBITDA, with a 12-18 month acquisition timeline. SPACs have seen a resurgence in popularity, with 12 IPOs raising $2.64 billion in 2023, and have averaged an annualized return of 8.35% since 2015.

site_title: Big China is watching, and rating you
summary: China is developing a nationwide Social Credit System to rate citizens based on their behavior, aiming to implement it by 2020. The system combines existing measures, including a blacklist of those who defy court orders, a personal credit rating system, and a tourism blacklist, to assign lifelong scores. Those with low scores may face disciplinary measures, including restricted financing, and those with high scores may receive rewards. Several cities have already experimented with the concept, and the system is expected to influence various aspects of citizens' lives, including access to loans, housing, and travel.

images.alt_text: Several Chinese cities have been experimenting with the social credit concept for years. People have points added or deducted depending on their everyday social behaviour.

site_title: Venezuela's recovery from 'economic implosion' could take decades: IMF
summary: Venezuela's economic recovery from its "economic implosion" is expected to take a decade or decades, according to the IMF's head, Alejandro Werner. The country faces catastrophic conditions, including 61% contraction since 2013, 10 million percent hyperinflation, and over 40% unemployment. The IMF plans to provide humanitarian aid and rebuild the economy, but a loan of $80 billion is not imminent due to the need for a government in control of economic policy. The country's oil industry is expected to fall to 600,000 barrels per day, and the economy's collapse was caused by the destruction of institutions and productive systems.

images.alt_text: Recovering from its "economic implosion" will take Venezuela "a decade or decades," a top International Monetary Fund official told AFP on Friday.

site_title: Beware the unicorn IPO stampede
summary: Unicorns are poised to enter the initial public offering (IPO) market, adding to major large-cap indexes and influencing portfolios with retirement savings. With over 150 unicorns in the US and globally, these companies often have uncertain paths to profitability and may be at risk of failure. Lyft's upcoming IPO, despite a net operating loss of $911.3 million in 2018, is expected to be a record year for unicorn IPOs. Analysts and investors need to be aware of the risks and potential rewards associated with VC investing as these companies enter the public market.

site_title: US mortgage rates inch higher for a second week
summary: US mortgage rates rose for a second week, increasing to 4.12% for 30-year fixed-rate mortgages, 3.6% for 15-year fixed-rate mortgages, and 3.8% for 5-year adjustable-rate mortgages. Despite recent economic news indicating slower growth, Freddie Mac chief economist Sam Khater expects rates to remain low, in line with 10-year Treasury yields. However, some experts, such as Les Parker, believe rising oil prices could lead to lower mortgage rates. Mortgage applications decreased 5.6% last week, with the refinance index falling 11%.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint Trust's manager names Richard Ng as CEO-designate
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust's manager, Frasers Centrepoint Asset Management, has appointed Richard Ng as CEO-designate, effective April 15, to succeed retiring CEO Chew Tuan Chiong. Ng, 51, brings 27 years of experience in the real estate industry, including a 14-year tenure with CapitaLand Group. Chew, who is retiring on July 1, led FCT since 2010, delivering consistently good performance and achieving higher distribution per unit and net asset value every year. Ng will work with the board and team to build on FCT's strong track record.

site_title: STI adds 0.3% in range-bound week of trading
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed 0.3% higher at 3,331.98 on a range-bound week of trading, with 14 of its 30 constituents ending in the black. Local banks, including DBS Group Holdings, OCBC Bank, and United Overseas Bank, drove the gains. The market was influenced by China's March trade figures and US economic estimates, with some analysts suggesting the STI may face weakness in April despite a slight uptick.

site_title: Weary Man City pay heavy price for quadruple push
summary: Manchester City manager Pep Guardiola's decision to play a conservative team against Tottenham Hotspur in the Champions League quarter-final first leg has raised concerns about the team's ability to win all four major English trophies. The 1-0 loss, which saw City's key players feeling fatigued, was attributed to Guardiola's unusual team selection and defensive strategy. The City boss cited the need to protect his players from fatigue, but former Arsenal defender Martin Keown questioned the decision, saying it was "linked to that loss at Anfield." City now face a grueling six-day span with crucial matches against Crystal Palace, Tottenham, and Liverpool.

site_title: Competition is all around you
summary: Business leaders must adapt to a broader view of competition, considering not just direct rivals but also emerging technologies, consumer trends, and changing market dynamics. Companies must stay creatively alert to the impact of technology on their products and services, and be proactive in identifying new opportunities and threats. A more nuanced understanding of competition can help businesses stay agile, innovate, and thrive in an ever-evolving market landscape.

images.alt_text: It didn't require a genius back in the 1980s to see that Brand's Essence of Chicken was going to be challenged by well-known competitors adding herbal remedies to the basic product. It required market research for Brand's to steal a march by asking what the consumer believed.

site_title: Julian Assange's seven strange years in self-imposed isolation
summary: WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange's seven-year stay in the Ecuadorean Embassy in London came to an end after Ecuador revoked his asylum status due to his repeated violations of international conventions and embassy protocols. Assange, 47, had lived in the embassy with his cat, conducting news conferences and hosting famous visitors, but his behavior had become increasingly disruptive. He was charged in the US for conspiracy to hack a government computer and was arrested by British police on Thursday. The move was seen as a significant blow to Assange's efforts to remain a free speech champion and martyr.

site_title: Gold whipsaws over robust US economic data
summary: Gold prices experienced volatile trading this week, influenced by shifting market expectations and economic data. The IMF's downward global growth forecasts and trade protectionism concerns initially diminished risk appetites, but the release of stronger-than-expected US economic data led to a rebound in the US dollar and gold prices retreated. Despite subdued global economic momentum, gold prices are expected to remain vigorous due to mounting economic and geopolitical uncertainties, with technical analysis suggesting a potential bearish correction if gold prices fail to hold above $1,302.00.

site_title: Atlantic Navigation 'reasonably confident' of repaying debt on time
summary: Atlantic Navigation, a Singapore-based marine services company, is "reasonably confident" it can repay its debt on time. The company expects no capital expenditure this year and its net current liability position is expected to be reduced from $25.9 million to $22.9 million. This follows the settlement of a loan deferment and sale of a vessel. The company has access to financing avenues, including bank financing, to ease any liquidity issues, and its gearing ratio remains stable at 57%.

site_title: CapitaLand's acquisition of Ascendas-Singbridge gets overwhelming nod from shareholders
summary: CapitaLand has secured overwhelming approval from shareholders to acquire Ascendas-Singbridge for nearly S$6.04 billion. The deal, valued at S$11 billion, will vault CapitaLand into the top 10 real estate investment managers globally. Shareholders raised concerns over dilution to net asset value and the potential for overpaying, but CapitaLand's CEO assured that the enlarged entity can unlock value through synergies and earnings growth. The deal is expected to boost earnings per share and return on equity, but net debt/equity is projected to rise.

site_title: KFC operator QSR Brands aiming to revive IPO this year: sources
summary: QSR Brands, the operator of KFC and Pizza Hut outlets in Southeast Asia, aims to revive its initial public offering (IPO) in the fourth quarter of 2019, according to sources. The company had shelved its IPO in Malaysia earlier this year without giving a reason. QSR Brands plans to raise up to $600 million in the IPO, which would boost fundraising in Malaysia, where IPO deals have been low this year. The company's earnings in the next two quarters will determine the IPO timing.

site_title: The cash party is almost over for unicorns like Uber
summary: Uber's upcoming IPO marks the end of an era for unicorns, as the ability to raise funds becomes less of a differentiator for startups. With over 340 unicorns, valued at over $1 billion, the influx of low US interest rates and low venture investment caps have fueled the growth of high-growth tech startups. The influx of capital has enabled companies like Uber to differentiate themselves through their bank accounts, leading to a self-fulfilling cycle where successful startups receive more capital. However, some venture capitalists argue that excessive investment can create more problems than it solves.

site_title: NauticAWT's auditor flags material uncertainty, doubts ability to continue as going concern
summary: NauticAWT's auditor, Deloitte & Touche, has flagged a material uncertainty related to the company's ability to continue as a going concern due to a US$4.6 million shortfall between current liabilities and assets. The company recorded a US$5 million loss for the financial year ended Dec 31, 2018, and was in a capital deficiency position of US$3.1 million. Deloitte & Touche noted that the company's ability to continue as a going concern depends on securing additional funding and new contracts.

site_title: YZJ Shipbuilding chairman donates 150m shares to set up senior mgt trust
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding's chairman Ren Yuanlin has donated 150 million shares worth S$241.5 million to a senior management trust, reducing his effective shareholding to 21.61%. The donation aims to incentivize the company's senior management team, who have contributed to the company's achievements over the past few decades. The trust, held under Xinyangchuan International, will reward senior management based on their lengths of service and overall contributions. Ren Yuanlin remains the largest shareholder, with the donation accounting for 3.8% of the company's total issued voting shares.

site_title: China court fines media company for 'violating' building's fengshui laws
summary: A Chinese court has fined a media company nearly $30,000 for publishing an article that claimed a Beijing building violated ancient fengshui laws, bringing misfortune to its occupants. The article, written by a fengshui expert, argued that the building's design was "heart-piercing" and "noxious." The court ruled that the media company damaged the reputation of the building's developer, SOHO China, and ordered the company to pay the fine. The case highlights the importance of fengshui in the real estate business in China and the government's efforts to control independent media and stop the spread of misinformation.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% due to market uncertainty and ongoing trade tensions. Global stocks declined, with European markets weighed down by bank and healthcare stocks, while US stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Companies like Creative Technology warned of potential revenue and operating loss issues. Meanwhile, Heathrow Airport plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade, and Indonesia detained an employee of Trafigura in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case.

site_title: Reits
summary: Key real estate and finance news include rising US mortgage rates, a Q3 wave of condo launches in Singapore, record Manhattan rents, and a rebound in UK homebuyer demand. In Asia, New World is selling China property assets and Goldman Sachs acquired a hotel and retail portfolio in Seoul. WeWork secured new tenants at its Singapore property, and a Q3 condo launch in Singapore will test demand above the S$3,000 psf benchmark. These developments indicate ongoing market shifts in the global real estate sector.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Yanlord Land Group's Q1 contracted sales more than doubled to 7.06 billion yuan, driven by improved Chinese property market sentiment. The company's Riverbay Gardens project achieved a 100% sellout on its first day of launch. Analysts see Yanlord as a beneficiary of the market recovery, but note it may be a laggard play given its quality land bank and strong fundamentals. Meanwhile, Ascott Residence Trust (ART) was upgraded to a "Buy" rating due to its disciplined capital recycling, defensive attributes, and yield-accretive acquisitions.

site_title: Don't call it dieting. It's 'biohacking'
summary: Twitter founder Jack Dorsey has revealed he typically fasts on weekends and eats only one meal a day, consuming fewer than 1,000 calories. This eating habit has been referred to as a "biohack" by some, sparking debate about whether it's a healthy or disordered behavior. The trend of intermittent fasting has gained popularity among Silicon Valley executives, with some companies marketing it as a performance-enhancing strategy. However, critics argue that this approach is not a healthy or sustainable way to manage weight, and that it perpetuates the stigma surrounding eating disorders.

site_title: Manager of Frasers Centrepoint Trust names Richard Ng as new CEO
summary: Richard Ng has been named as the new CEO-designate of Frasers Centrepoint Trust, replacing Chew Tuan Chiong who is retiring after leading the trust since 2010. Ng's appointment takes effect on Monday, according to a regulatory filing by Frasers Centrepoint Asset Management.

site_title: Indonesia issues tsunami warning after magnitude 6.8 quake off Sulawesi
summary: Indonesia issued a tsunami warning after a magnitude 6.8 earthquake struck off the coast of Sulawesi, prompting evacuations to higher ground. The quake, 280 km south of Gorontalo, had tsunami potential, with residents advised to leave immediately. Despite the warning, no immediate damage or casualties were reported. The geophysics agency is monitoring for high waves, stating the first wave may not be the biggest.

site_title: Commonwealth Bank mulls plans to cut more than 10,000 jobs
summary: Commonwealth Bank of Australia is reportedly planning to cut over 10,000 jobs and A$2 billion in costs, potentially closing up to 300 of its 1,000 branches. The move, part of a 25% workforce reduction, could impact 10,000-12,000 positions in coming years. The bank's plan is not officially confirmed, but details were reported by TheAustralian newspaper.

site_title: Sterling lifted above US$1.31 as immediate Brexit risks recede
summary: The British pound rose above $1.31 due to receding Brexit risks after a European Union agreement to a six-month delay. Despite this, volatility expectations remain low, and analysts predict consolidation in the pound's trading range. A potential second Brexit referendum has also boosted the pound, but MUFG analyst Lee Hardman notes that without fresh Brexit cues, the currency is unlikely to move significantly higher. Implied volatility has plummeted, and experts predict a possible test of 88 pence per euro and $1.27 for sterling.

site_title: Rejuvenating CBD with new integrated buildings 'visionary': JLL
summary: Singapore's CBD Incentive Scheme could introduce state-of-the-art buildings, including new homes and hotel rooms, replacing ageing office buildings. The scheme aims to meet modern demands for hospitality, health, and lifestyle amenities. JLL Research estimates 20 buildings could be redeveloped, yielding 4-5 million sq ft of office space and 3,000 new homes and hotel rooms. The initiative may accelerate decentralisation, reduce commuting, and widen the rental gap between CBD and suburban hubs, potentially leading to increased office rents.

images.alt_text: The CBD Incentive Scheme, as part of the recently released draft Master Plan 2019, could kickstart urban renewal momentum and could be extended beyond the initial five-year implementation period, giving owners and investors more time to take advantage of it.

site_title: Indian IT giants Infosys, TCS see profits soar
summary: Indian IT giants Infosys and Tata Consultancy Services (TCS) reported a surge in net profits, with TCS seeing a 17.7% increase and Infosys a 10.5% rise. Both companies attributed the growth to strong revenue and big new deals. TCS's CEO Rajesh Gopinathan noted the company's strongest revenue growth in 15 quarters, while Infosys' CEO Salil Parekh credited the growth to the company's focus on digital, positioning, and client relationships. The strong performance reflects the Indian IT sector's resilience despite automation and new technologies.

site_title: UN torture expert warns over Assange extradition to US
summary: UN torture expert Nils Melzer has warned that Julian Assange's extradition to the US is not guaranteed to be fair, citing the US justice system's credibility in national security cases and concerns over torture practices. Melzer also criticized Ecuador's termination of Assange's diplomatic protection, stating it broke international norms. The US request for extradition is set to be heard in British court on May 2, with Melzer expressing concerns over the national security implications and the use of the death penalty.

site_title: Lower tax rate prompts China Jinjiang to revise up 2018 profit by 23.9m yuan
summary: China Jinjiang Environment Holding Company revised its 2018 profit up by 23.9 million yuan to 565 million yuan, following the receipt of a national high-tech enterprise certification for its subsidiary, Hangzhou Kesheng Energy Technology Co. The certification led to a lower corporate income tax rate, which was retrospectively applied. This resulted in a higher audited profit compared to the unaudited financial statements. The company's shares closed flat at S$0.58.

site_title: Alibaba founder defends overtime work culture as "huge blessing"
summary: Alibaba founder Jack Ma defended the company's grueling overtime work culture, calling it a "huge blessing" for young workers. The 9 am to 9 pm workday, six days a week, is known as the '996' schedule, which Ma defended during a speech to Alibaba employees. This comes as the tech sector slows after years of rapid growth, sparking debate about work-life balance. Ma's stance has sparked a mixed reaction, with some praising the dedication required to succeed in the industry, while others criticize the culture as unsustainable.

site_title: Acromec seals S$6.75m contract with private lab service provider
summary: Acromec secured a S$6.75 million contract with a private laboratory service provider in Singapore to outfit two clinical laboratories. The contract, expected to be completed by mid-June 2019, will enhance operational efficiencies with automation systems and controlled environment parameters. This is Acromec's second contract win in less than a month, raising its order book to about S$27 million. The company's shares closed up 32.5% on the news.

site_title: IMF wants China-US trade deal to address structural issues
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) is urging a long-lasting trade deal between China and the US to address structural issues such as intellectual property and fair trade. Director Changyong Rhee warned that a failure to reach a deal could trigger a sharp market reaction, despite growing optimism over US-China trade talks. For a substantial deal, tariffs should be reduced or not increased, and the agreement should be consistent with multilateralism, not bilateralism. The IMF believes a longer-lasting agreement is better, as bilateral agreements can be short-lived and may not address underlying structural issues.

site_title: Trump considered Ivanka for World Bank as she's 'good with numbers'
summary: President Donald Trump considered nominating his daughter Ivanka Trump for the World Bank due to her skills in numbers. Trump mentioned she would have been great at the World Bank and the United Nations, but was dissuaded by concerns of nepotism. Ivanka Trump was involved in World Bank initiatives and worked closely with the bank's leadership, but was not a contender for the job. The World Bank's new president, David Malpass, was nominated by Trump and has emphasized worldwide economic growth.

site_title: Japan slams WTO ruling on South Korea Fukushima food row
summary: Japan has criticized a World Trade Organization (WTO) ruling that upheld a South Korea ban on some Fukushima seafood, calling it "extremely regrettable." The WTO's highest court overturned an earlier decision, giving Seoul a final victory in a long-standing dispute. Japan demands South Korea lift all restrictions, but Foreign Minister Taro Kono acknowledged Japan has no further legal recourse. The ban was imposed due to fears of radioactive contamination after the 2011 Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster.

site_title: Fiat Chrysler CEO gives upbeat outlook for year
summary: Fiat Chrysler CEO Michael Manley provided an upbeat outlook for the year, confirming the company's operating performance is on track to exceed 2018 record results. Despite initial doubts raised by weaker-than-expected guidance in February, Manley expressed confidence in meeting the 2020 goals set by late CEO Sergio Marchionne. Industrial free cash flow is expected to be over 1.5 billion euros, down from last year's figure. The company's shares rose 2.6% following the announcement, with Chairman John Elkann reiterating the family's willingness to take bold decisions to drive the company's future.

site_title: Japan court extends Carlos Ghosn's detention until April 22
summary: The Tokyo District Court extended Carlos Ghosn's detention until April 22, allowing prosecutors until then to bring formal charges against the former Nissan Motor Co. boss. Ghosn, awaiting trial on charges of financial misconduct and breach of trust, denies all allegations. He was initially released on $9 million bail in March but was rearrested on suspicion of trying to enrich himself at Nissan's expense. Ghosn's defence team has launched a fierce battle against prosecutors, calling the latest arrest "illegal."

site_title: Shareholders vote in favour of CapitaLand's acquisition of ASB
summary: CapitaLand's acquisition of Ascendas-Singbridge (ASB) from Temasek Holdings was approved by independent shareholders at an Extraordinary General Meeting, with a cash payment of S$3.017 billion and the issuance of new shares valued at S$3.50 per share. The deal has an enterprise value of S$11 billion. CapitaLand's president and CEO Lee Chee Koon stated that the transaction will strengthen the company and provide access to capital partners, markets, and asset classes, enabling future growth and investment.

site_title: Even "Perfect" portfolios underperform nearly half the time
summary: Investors who picked the top 10 stocks in Asia and the US in 1988, including YMG Trading, Unilever Indonesia, and Samsung Electronics, would have seen their $10,000 investment grow to $403,000 over 30 years, with an annual compounded return of 13.1%. This outperforms the MSCI Asia Pacific ex-Japan Index, which grew 6.3% per year with dividends reinvested. The results highlight the potential for investors to achieve high returns by taking calculated risks and embracing volatility in their investment portfolios.

site_title: Protests as lesbian conference kicks off in Ukraine
summary: Protesters from far-right and religious groups disrupted an international lesbian conference in Kiev, Ukraine, on Friday. Dozens of demonstrators, holding signs with anti-LGBT messages, tried to block access to the hotel hosting the European Lesbian Conference, but were held back by police. The event, which began on Thursday, aimed to raise awareness about LGBT+ rights in Ukraine and eastern Europe, with around 350 participants from 40 countries attending. Despite the protests, conference organizers said the event would proceed with a peaceful march on Saturday.

site_title: China announces tax breaks for trading of depositary receipts
summary: China's finance ministry announced tax breaks for trading of depositary receipts (CDRs) to support domestic floatation of overseas-listed Chinese tech firms. Individual investors will be exempt from personal gains tax for three years on profit from trading CDRs, while institutional investors will be exempt from corporate taxes on gains from dividends and trading. The measures aim to encourage CDR listings, following the introduction of rules in June 2018. No company has yet issued CDRs, with smartphone maker Xiaomi Corp postponing a planned listing in June 2018.

site_title: Indonesia president leads in polls, as ballot tampering accusations probed
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo leads in polls with a double-digit lead over challenger Prabowo Subianto, 54-57% vs 32-37%, five days ahead of the general election. The opposition disputes the findings, claiming data irregularities and accusing the government of ballot tampering. Investigations are underway in Malaysia, where thousands of voting papers were found stuffed in bags, with some already marked in favor of Widodo.

site_title: MPA pumps in S$650,000 for startups to develop innovative maritime solutions
summary: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) has invested S$650,000 in seed funding for 13 tech startups, including Claritecs, to develop innovative maritime solutions. The funding will support prototype development and market roll-out. The startups were selected from the Smart Port Challenge 2018 and will receive S$50,000 each. The funding aims to address key maritime challenges in Singapore, with a focus on enabling platforms, port and cargo operations, and crossed industry or border innovation.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher on JPMorgan results, big energy deal
summary: US stocks opened higher on Friday, driven by JPMorgan's better-than-expected results, a $33 billion energy deal, and signs of stability in the Chinese economy. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.82%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite gained 0.43% and 0.46%, respectively. The positive momentum followed a strong week for US stocks, which edged closer to records despite ongoing trade tensions.

site_title: Indian election parties hit by TV and funding clampdown
summary: India's Supreme Court ordered parties to name anonymous donors behind tens of millions of dollars in funding, amid a clampdown on Prime Minister Narendra Modi's TV channel and rival parties' spending of up to $7 billion on the election. The court gave parties seven weeks to disclose donors behind "electoral bonds" that are controversial due to their anonymity. The ruling Bharatiya Janata Party is the biggest beneficiary of the bonds, and experts estimate that at least $150 million was bought in the months leading up to the election.

site_title: Final Israel election results leave Netayahu on course
summary: Israel's final election results show Benjamin Netanyahu on course to remain prime minister, despite a centrist challenger, Benny Gantz, winning one more seat than Netanyahu's Likud party. The right-wing and religious bloc commands a total of 65 seats, with the possibility of forming a broad government of national unity. Netanyahu's narrow right-wing coalition is still a possibility, but a grand alliance with the center is also an option. The looming prospect of indictments in corruption cases makes Netanyahu vulnerable to concessions from smaller party allies.

images.alt_text: Final results from this week's Israeli election published Friday left Benjamin Netanyahu on course to remain prime minister although there were reports of pressure on him not to form another narrow right-wing coalition.

site_title: An Australian billionaire dynasty confronts the end of an empire
summary: Australian billionaire James Packer's casino operator Crown Resorts Ltd is in talks to sell for A$9.99 billion to Las Vegas-based Wynn Resorts Ltd, marking the potential end of the Packer dynasty's corporate empire. The sale comes after a tumultuous period marked by a crackdown in China, a split with his fiancée, and a public battle with his mental health. If the sale goes through, Packer would be selling his 46% stake in Crown, which would give Wynn control of the company.

site_title: Singapore shares end flat on Friday, up 0.3% on the week
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index closed at 3,331.98, up 1.16 points or 0.03% on Friday, marking a flat session. The index gained 9.34 points or 0.3% on the week, driven by encouraging March trade data from China. Trading volume was 1.25 billion securities, with 14 of 30 constituents ending the day in the black, led by DBS Group Holdings and OCBC Bank.

site_title: YZJ Shipbuilding exec chairman sets up trust for senior mgt with 150m shares
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding's executive chairman Ren Yuanlin has donated 150 million shares, worth 3.80% of the company's total issued voting shares, to a trust for the company's senior management. The trust aims to reward employees based on their lengths of service and contributions. Ren's effective shareholding has been reduced to 21.61%, but he remains the largest shareholder. The trust's beneficiaries will be determined according to their qualifications, which were not specified. Ren believes the trust will incentivize the management team to continue working towards the company's vision of becoming the world's best shipbuilding group.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 5.94 points to 1,630.17, driven by higher shares. The index closed with 3.3 billion lots traded worth RM2.1 billion. Losers beat gainers 411 to 399, marking a mixed session.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Friday afternoon at 3,325.92, down 0.15% on day
