summary: Singapore stocks closed down 0.15% on Friday at 3,325.92, following a 766.3 million securities worth S$412.6 million traded. Losers outnumbered gainers 177 to 147, with Jiutian Chemical Group and Imperium Crown gaining 11.1% and 15.8% respectively. DBS Group Holdings and United Overseas Bank were among active index stocks, with DBS down 0.3% and UOB up 0.4%.

site_title: South-east Asian banks most used to receive funds from fraudulent transactions: SWIFT
summary: Global payments network SWIFT reported that 83% of fraudulent transactions in 2018 and 2019 were received by South-east Asian banks, with the remaining 17% in Europe, North America, and the Middle East. Hackers used these accounts, known as "mule" accounts, to materialize funds extracted from financial systems. The attacks were often in the reconnaissance phase, where hackers compromised user workstations before launching an attack. The value of attempted fraudulent transactions decreased to between $250,000 and $2 million, with 70% of transactions in US dollars.

site_title: Volvo to build XC40 SUV in China as demand grows
summary: Volvo Cars is expanding its manufacturing capacity in China by building the XC40 SUV in Luqiao, south of Shanghai, starting April 8. This move aims to cater to growing demand and alleviate capacity constraints at its Ghent plant in Belgium. Volvo CEO Hakan Samuelsson stated that demand for the XC40 has exceeded expectations, and the new facility will add flexibility to the company's global network. The XC40 has sold over 100,000 units since its launch in 2017, with Volvo's parent company Geely also planning to use the platform for other models.

site_title: Europe: Shares edge lower as Unicredit, Banco Santander fall
summary: European shares fell 0.2% on Friday, led by banks Unicredit and Banco Santander, which dropped 1% and 0.8% respectively. Global growth concerns were reinforced by central banks' dovish stances and warnings of risks to the economy. The US earnings season is set to begin, with Wall Street banks JP Morgan and Wells Fargo reporting results. The pan-European STOXX 600 index is on track to end the week lower after two weeks of gains.

images.alt_text: European shares ticked lower on Friday, dragged down by banks, while lingering worries over global growth kept investors on edge before the crucial earnings season in the United States.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei index close higher
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index rose 0.73% to 21,870.56, driven by a weaker yen and a rebound in the dollar. Fast Retailing's strong earnings report boosted the main index, while Toshiba's decision not to sell its US liquefied natural gas operations fell 2.71%. Panasonic jumped 2.75% after suspending Tesla's battery plant expansion plans due to weak demand. The broader Topix index fell 0.07%.

site_title: Acromec seals S$6.75m contract with private lab service provider
summary: Acromec secures a S$6.75 million contract to outfit two clinical laboratories in Singapore, raising its order book to about S$27 million. The contract, from a private laboratory service provider, is expected to contribute positively to the company's earnings per share and net tangible assets per share for the current financial year. The project is expected to be completed by mid-June 2019, and Acromec's shares surged 35% following the announcement.

site_title: Squatters occupy Venice homes in housing protest as tourism surges
summary: Squatters in Venice occupy unoccupied homes in a housing protest, citing high rents forcing families out as tourism surges. The city's population has declined from 175,000 to 50,000, while 25 million tourists visit annually, with 14 million staying just one day. Residents claim the city's housing authority is preventing renovation by occupying homes. The city council has voted to impose an entrance fee to help with upkeep and limit visitor numbers. Squatters argue that vacant homes are being extracted from the community, and their actions are a response to the city's gentrification.

site_title: Australia's Commonwealth Bank working on secret plan to cut 10,000 jobs: report
summary: Commonwealth Bank of Australia is reportedly working on a secret plan to cut 10,000 jobs and A$2 billion in costs, including closing up to 300 branches. The 25% workforce reduction could impact 10,000-12,000 jobs, which would be politically sensitive given the current banking industry struggles to regain public trust. The plan, initially intended to be kept secret until after the May national elections, has been confirmed by the bank's CEO, Matt Comyn, who wants to avoid sparking public outcry.

site_title: New Zealand's state pension fund to sell off stakes in gun makers
summary: New Zealand's state pension fund, NZ Super Fund, plans to sell off NZ$19 million (S$17.3 million) in investments from gun makers, including American Outdoor Brands Corp and Sturm, Ruger & Co Inc, following the country's tough new firearms laws. The move is a response to the ban on military-style semi-automatic guns and assault rifles, which were used to kill 50 worshippers in Christchurch. The fund has already excluded holdings in tobacco and munitions companies from its investment mandate.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's economy grew 1.3% in Q1, its slowest since 2009 due to weak manufacturing. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) maintained monetary policy, downgrading core inflation forecast. Retail sales dropped 10% in February, reversing January's 7.6% growth. The Singapore dollar's appreciation rate was maintained by MAS. Mobile payments use in Singapore rose 12 percentage points to 46% in 2019, according to a PwC survey. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed flat on Friday, up 0.3% on the week.

site_title: Lian Beng Q3 net profit halves to S$3.6m
summary: Lian Beng's third-quarter net profit plummeted 55.3% to S$3.6 million due to higher cost of sales and a S$3.1 million loss from associates and joint ventures. The listed main contractor's cost of sales rose 6.5% year-on-year, mainly due to increased construction costs. The firm's share of results from associates and joint ventures turned from a profit to a loss, primarily due to losses from property development adjustments and lower joint venture profits.

site_title: MAS maintains monetary policy as expected, downgrades core inflation forecast
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) maintained its monetary policy as expected, keeping the Singapore dollar's current rate of appreciation and unchanged policy band. MAS downgraded its core inflation forecast to 1-2% due to weaker global oil prices and mild inflationary pressures. The central bank expects Singapore's GDP growth to come in slightly below its potential this year. Economists largely expect the MAS to maintain its current stance, with some predicting a slight dovish tone, but none anticipating a change in policy in the near future.

site_title: 'No special treatment' for Assange, says Australian PM
summary: Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison stated that WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange will receive "no special treatment" from his home country, despite his extradition to the US. Assange faces a year in prison for breaching bail conditions in 2012 and is also wanted by US authorities for his work with Chelsea Manning. Morrison said the extradition is a US matter and that Assange will receive the same consular support as any other Australian citizen in trouble overseas.

images.alt_text: WikiLeaks founder and Australian citizen Julian Assange will receive "no special treatment" from his home country following his dramatic arrest in Britain, Prime Minister Scott Morrison said on Friday.

site_title: China exports rebound to 5-month high but imports fall more than expected
summary: China's exports rebounded to a 5-month high in March with a 14.2% gain, but imports fell 7.6% from a year earlier, the sharpest decline in four months. The trade surplus widened to $32.64 billion, contrary to forecasts of $7.05 billion. Despite a slight boost in export growth, economists warn that Chinese exporters will still face weak global demand and may struggle to regain lost market share. The IMF has downgraded its 2019 global growth forecast to 3.3%, citing the Sino-US trade war's limited impact.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close up
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed higher on Friday, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.24% to 29,909.76, as investors prepare for the US corporate earnings season. The Shanghai Composite Index edged down 0.04%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index closed 0.11% lower. The gains were seen as a relief after earlier losses, with investors focusing on the start of the earnings season in the US.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks pared earlier losses to close higher Friday, with investors preparing for the start of the corporate earnings season which is set to get underway in the United States.

site_title: Tesla begins offering leases for Model 3
summary: Tesla began offering leases for its Model 3 sedan in the US, allowing customers to lease any variant with a small down payment and monthly payments, without the option to buy. The company also announced that all Model 3 cars will come with the autopilot feature, now included in all cars for less than the previous cost. This move aims to increase Tesla's customer base and provide a new financing option for customers.

site_title: China, Malaysia to resume East Coast rail for RM$44b
summary: China and Malaysia have agreed to revive the East Coast Rail Link project at a reduced cost of RM$44 billion (S$14.47 billion), down from the original 65.5 billion ringgit. The project aims to connect Malaysia's eastern coast to a major port near Kuala Lumpur. The deal, signed by China Communications Construction Co and Malaysia Rail Link Sdn, covers engineering, procurement, construction, and commissioning aspects. The project's revival is seen as a boon for China's Belt and Road Initiative, and is expected to benefit Malaysia's economy.

site_title: Uber losing US$1.8b a year, IPO filing reveals
summary: Uber disclosed its financial losses, revealing a $1.8 billion loss in 2018, excluding certain transactions, on revenue of $11.3 billion. The company's IPO filing values it at around $100 billion, but its rocket-ship trajectory for revenue growth is slowing. Uber is heavily dependent on just five cities for nearly a quarter of its total bookings and faces concerns about its sustainability. The company has also struggled with losses, including $4 billion in 2017, and has been criticized for its treatment of drivers. Uber's IPO is expected to be the largest since Alibaba's in 2014.

site_title: Atlantic Navigation says 'reasonably confident' of repaying debt on time
summary: Atlantic Navigation, a marine services company, is reasonably confident it can repay its debt of US$25.9 million by the end of 2019. The company expects to improve its operating cashflows to US$15 million and reduce its net current liability to US$22.9 million. It also has access to additional financing options, including bank financing and selling its vessels, to alleviate liquidity issues. The company has the support of its chairman and bankers, and its gearing ratio remains stable despite the higher value of its marine vessels.

site_title: Japan seen hiking sales tax to 10% in October, Q4 GDP to contract
summary: Japan is set to hike its sales tax to 10% in October, likely causing the economy to contract in the fourth quarter, according to a Reuters poll. Despite this, the government has allocated 2 trillion yen for spending to mitigate the impact. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has repeatedly stated that the hike will proceed, despite previous postponements.

site_title: Huationg Global seeks 60-day extension to hold AGM
summary: Huationg Global, a civil engineering firm, is seeking a 60-day extension to hold its annual general meeting (AGM) for fiscal 2018, from April 30 to June 29, 2019, due to staff turnover and increased business activities. The extension application is made to complete audited financial statements and other information needed for its 2018 annual report, citing stretched manpower resources.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed after fluctuating through week
summary: Asian markets closed mixed on Friday as the week's volatility continued, with few fresh developments in China-US trade talks. Investors are awaiting the release of Chinese trade data, which could impact global outlook. Despite a run of positive releases from Beijing, including forecast-beating factory activity and inflation, markets were influenced by US President Trump's threats of tariffs against Europe. The business reporting season in the US begins, with low expectations for corporate earnings. Markets were mixed, with Tokyo up 0.6%, while Hong Kong, Singapore, and Wellington dipped.

site_title: Singapore 5th out of 6 Asean countries in growth of mobile payments use: PwC survey
summary: Singapore ranks 5th among 6 Asean countries for mobile payments growth, with a 12 percentage point increase to 46% in 2019, according to PwC's Global Consumer Insights Survey 2019. This growth is attributed to government efforts in driving digital payments since 2017.

site_title: Japan urged G-20 to strengthen global coordination: Aso
summary: Japanese Finance Minister Taro Aso urged G-20 countries to strengthen global coordination to address potential economic risks during the group's meeting in Washington. Aso also announced Japan's plan to proceed with a scheduled sales tax hike in October, despite concerns about its economic impact. The G-20 finance leaders will not issue a communique at their meeting, which concludes on Friday. Aso's comments come as the world economy faces challenges, including US tariffs, slowing GDP growth in China, and a shrinking UK economy.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks edge down at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened 0.11% lower, with the Hang Seng Index dipping to 29,806.35, following a negative lead from Wall Street. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also fell 0.16% each. Investors await Chinese trade data release later in the day, amid US-EU tariff concerns.

site_title: Australia: shares rise on soaring financials
summary: Australian shares rose 0.85% on Friday, pushing the benchmark to its biggest weekly gain in seven weeks. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 52.6 points to 6,251.3, driven by a surge in financial stocks after reports that Commonwealth Bank of Australia planned to cut over 10,000 jobs to boost profitability. Financial stocks surged 1.6% and the "Big Four" banks rose, with Westpac up 1.4%, Australia and New Zealand Banking Group up 2%, and National Australia Bank up 1%.

images.alt_text: Australian shares rallied on Friday as reports that the country's biggest lender was shedding jobs to cut costs boosted financial stocks, pushing the benchmark to its biggest weekly gain in seven weeks.

site_title: Sydney property prices face further drop, RBA says
summary: Sydney property prices are expected to face a further drop due to an extended apartment construction pipeline, according to the Reserve Bank of Australia. The central bank cited increased risks to Australian households, with weak housing market conditions and rising financial stress. Housing loans in arrears have also increased, despite low levels of financial stress outside mining-exposed regions. This assessment comes as the global economy faces a "sharper downturn" risk, with banks' profits remaining healthy despite increased scrutiny.

site_title: Singapore retail sales sink 10% in February after earlier Chinese New Year
summary: Singapore's retail sales declined 10% in February, reversing the 7.6% growth in January. This was largely due to the Chinese New Year festive season occurring in early February, affecting sales. Motor vehicle sales were also excluded, leading to a further 10.7% decline. Food retailers were the hardest hit, with a 24.8% drop in sales. Every retail category saw a year-on-year decline, with some industries experiencing declines of up to 14.9%.

site_title: Chevron buys Anadarko in US$33b bet on shale oil, LNG
summary: Chevron Corp agreed to buy Anadarko Petroleum Corp in a $33 billion deal, intensifying its battle with Exxon Mobil Corp to become America's top energy company. The acquisition adds acreage and production in the Permian shale basin, increasing Chevron's exposure to liquefied natural gas. The deal puts Chevron neck-and-neck with Exxon and Royal Dutch Shell, measured by cash flow. Chevron plans to sell $15 billion to $20 billion of assets to reduce debt and return cash to investors, generating a combined $36.5 billion with Anadarko last year.

images.alt_text: Chevron Corp agreed to buy Anadarko Petroleum Corp in a US$33 billion bet on the Permian shale-oil region and liquefied natural gas, intensifying a battle with Exxon Mobil Corp to be America's top energy company.

site_title: Malaysia KFC operator aiming to revive IPO this year
summary: QSR Brands (M) Holdings Bhd, the operator of KFC and Pizza Hut in Southeast Asia, plans to revive its initial public offering (IPO) in the fourth quarter of 2019, with the potential to raise up to $600 million. The company had previously shelved its IPO in Malaysia, but discussions with bankers have resumed. The IPO would be a boost to fundraising in Malaysia, which has seen a significant decline in IPO deals in recent years. The company's earnings in the next two quarters will play a key role in determining the timing of the IPO.

site_title: Boeing to meet with US airlines over 737 Max
summary: The US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) will meet with US airlines that use the Boeing 737 Max, which has been grounded since mid-March following two accidents that killed 346 people. The meeting aims to gather facts and information to determine what needs to be done before returning the aircraft to service. Boeing CEO Dennis Muilenberg has stated that the changes being worked on will make the 737 Max "even safer" and has conducted 96 test flights of the modified aircraft. The FAA has formed an action committee with NASA and international authorities to certify the fix to the MCAS anti-stall system.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 0.28 points to 1,624.51 on Friday, with a trading volume of 33.51 million lots worth RM13.89 million. Gainers outpaced losers 99 to 45.

site_title: Uber sets IPO in motion, seeks to 'ignite opportunity'
summary: Uber filed documents for its highly anticipated initial public offering (IPO), seeking to raise around $10 billion at a valuation of nearly $100 billion. The ride-hailing giant aims to "ignite opportunity" by expanding into new markets, including meal deliveries, freight, and electric bikes. Uber's IPO comes after Lyft's lackluster market debut and amid growing competition from autonomous vehicle firms. Despite its growth, Uber continues to lose money from operations, and analysts warn of a challenging road to profitability.

site_title: Back To Nature
summary: Sir David Attenborough's new series, Our Planet, is now streaming on Netflix, offering a dire warning about environmental destruction. At 92, the legendary broadcaster takes on a more urgent tone, frequently narrating about the beauty of nature's wonders that may not last if we don't act. The series features spectacular shots of flora and fauna, along with compelling depictions of animal behavior, but also emphasizes the need for immediate action to protect the planet.

site_title: Tokyo: Main stock market opens higher
summary: Tokyo's main stock market opened higher on Friday, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index rising 0.22% to 21,759.11, driven by the dollar's rebound. However, the broader Topix index fell 0.20%. Investors await fresh news to move the market, amid ongoing US-EU trade talks and tariff threats.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CapitaLand Mall Trust, China Jinjiang, Singapore Myanmar Investco
summary: CapitaLand Mall Trust's chairman Teo Swee Lian took over on April 12, 2019, after Richard Rokmat Magnus stepped down. China Jinjiang Environment Holding reported a 23.9 million yuan difference in 2018 net profit due to a subsidiary receiving a lower tax rate after being certified as a national high-tech enterprise. Singapore Myanmar Investco sold its telecommunications towers in Myanmar for US$8 million, terminating an earlier deal.

site_title: New Zealand manufacturing activity cools in March: BNZ survey
summary: New Zealand's manufacturing activity declined in March, according to a Bank of New Zealand-Business NZ survey, with the seasonally adjusted Performance of Manufacturing Index (PMI) falling to 51.9 from 53.7 in the previous month. This is the lowest level of activity recorded since July 2018, indicating a contraction in manufacturing activity.

site_title: China Jinjiang revises reported 2018 profit up by 23.9m yuan on unit's lowered tax rate
summary: China Jinjiang Environment Holding Company revised its 2018 net profit upwards by 23.9 million yuan, from 541.1 million yuan to 565 million yuan, due to a subsidiary receiving a lower corporate income tax rate after being certified as a "national high-tech enterprise" in 2018. The tax rate was retrospectively applied after the unaudited financial statements were released. This resulted in higher earnings per share of 41.81 RMB cents, up from 40.04 RMB cents previously stated.

site_title: Tesla shares fall on report plant expansion has been iced
summary: Tesla shares fell 2.8% to $268.42 after a report stated the company and Panasonic suspended plans to expand a battery plant in Nevada due to weak demand for Tesla vehicles. The move comes as concerns about weakening demand at Tesla mount on Wall Street. The freeze affects the Gigafactory 1 battery factory, which was intended to boost capacity. The news led to a decline in Tesla's stock price, with investors reacting to the potential impact on the company's production and future growth.

site_title: Disney+ streaming service to launch early next year
summary: Disney+ is set to launch in the US early next year, followed by a gradual international rollout, with its European debut expected later than initially anticipated. The streaming service, a Netflix rival, was initially expected to debut this year.

site_title: No path for Trump's Federal Reserve pick Cain as four Republicans oppose
summary: US President Donald Trump's Federal Reserve pick, Herman Cain, faces opposition from four Senate Republicans, effectively blocking his confirmation. Trump has urged the Fed to lower interest rates, and Cain was chosen to fill a seat on the board. The opposition has raised concerns about the politicization of the Fed, which has led to tensions between the president and the nation's central bank. The move may also impact the Fed's ability to implement its monetary policies.

site_title: Bezos upbeat on Amazon Go physical stores
summary: Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos expressed optimism about the company's cashierless retail stores, Amazon Go, citing customer feedback as "magical" and plans to expand to 10 more locations. Bezos also challenged top retailers to match Amazon's $15 minimum wage and $16 minimum wage challenge, aiming to benefit everyone. Meanwhile, a group of Amazon employees called on the company to take a leading role in corporate action against climate change, including transitioning away from fossil fuels and making sustainability a priority in business decisions.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Friday, STI down 0.02% to 3,330.23
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.02% to 3,330.23, with the Straits Times Index retreating 0.59 points. The market saw 38.6 million shares change hands, with 56 gainers and 48 losers. JCG Investment Holdings traded flat, while Jadason Enterprises rose 8.11% and Genting Singapore rose 0.52%.

site_title: IMF chief says Brexit delay avoids 'terrible outcome'
summary: IMF Managing Director Christine Lagarde stated that a six-month delay of Britain's exit from the European Union avoids a "terrible outcome" of a "no-deal" Brexit, which would have further pressured a slowing global economy. The delay does not resolve uncertainty over the final outcome, and the IMF cut its global growth forecast for 2019 to 3.3%, citing risks from trade tensions, high debt, and the consequences of Brexit.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Mind Your Business: Bridging the limitations of AI
summary: A Money FM podcast discusses bridging AI limitations with human operators. Michael Sayre of Cognicept Systems aims to close the gap between physical and virtual worlds using robotics. Cognicept provides robotics-based human-in-the-loop error handling systems, enabling AI to perform tasks that were previously impossible. This approach could revolutionize industries and improve business operations. By integrating human operators into AI systems, limitations can be overcome, and innovation can flourish.

site_title: IMF, World Bank urge caution with China loans
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) and World Bank are urging caution on China's increasing lending to developing nations, citing concerns over growing debt burdens and onerous conditions. Newly-installed World Bank President David Malpass warned that 17 African countries are at high risk of debt distress due to lack of transparency in loan amounts and terms. The institutions are calling for greater transparency and cautioning governments against relying too heavily on debt. This comes as China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers to address the issue.

site_title: Singapore Myanmar Investco sells TPR telco assets for US$8m
summary: Singapore-based company SMI sells its 99.99% owned Myanmar telco assets, TPR Myanmar, to Irrawaddy Green Towers for US$8 million. The sale allows SMI to focus on "less capital intensive" businesses, aiming for faster returns. The assets, comprising 3,000 telecommunications towers, will be sold in three phases, with the first phase requiring a 10% payment within 15 days. The sale is subject to regulatory approvals and will be used to fund working capital and other operating requirements, with net proceeds totaling US$7.9 million.

site_title: Rice Bowl
summary: Andaz Singapore's Teppan Chef's Table restaurant has opened on the 25th floor, offering a weekday lunch deal for S$22, featuring a donburi set with salad, miso soup, and fresh fruit. For dinner, reservations are required with a minimum spend of S$1,500, offering omakase and specialty cocktails, including the Best G&T In The World.

site_title: Weak manufacturing drags Singapore economy to 1.3% growth in Q1, slowest since 2009
summary: Singapore's economy experienced its slowest growth in 11 years, with a 1.3% year-on-year GDP growth in Q1 2019, according to the Ministry of Trade and Industry. This is below market expectations of 1.4% growth. The weak manufacturing sector contributed to the slowdown, marking a disappointing start to the year.

site_title: Misleading to label perps safe to be bought through ATMs
summary: A professional investor argues that perpetual securities, also known as perps, are complex products that should not be labeled as safe to buy through automated teller machines (ATMs). The author believes that the current labeling sends a misleading signal to investors, particularly "mom and pop" investors, and that a warning about the potential loss of capital should be included in the prospectus and ATM screen. The author questions whether regulators have adequately protected unsophisticated investors by relying on complex document analysis.

site_title: Facebook trying to stop its own algorithms from doing their job
summary: Facebook is introducing new features to reduce the spread of misinformation and borderline content on its platforms. The company will tweak its algorithms to flag and reduce traffic to little-known websites with sudden surges of traffic, and expand fact-checking features for images. Facebook will also add privacy features to Messenger and take action on "borderline" content, such as removing sexually suggestive content from Instagram's Explore tab. The moves aim to combat the spread of false information, with some research suggesting a significant drop in Americans visiting fake news websites during the 2018 congressional elections.

site_title: Oil tankers leave Venezuela for Cuba despite sanctions: document, data
summary: Venezuela's state-run PDVSA has shipped 1 million barrels of oil to Cuba despite US sanctions on vessels and firms involved in exports to the island. Two tankers, Trident Hope and S-Trotter, left Venezuelan ports on Wednesday and Thursday, bound for Cuba's state-run company Cubametales. The shipments include 600,000 barrels of Zuata 300 crude and 400,000 barrels of Merey crude. Three other vessels were waiting to load with crude or refined products off Venezuela, but were not sanctioned by the US. The shipments contradict US efforts to halt oil trade between Venezuela and Cuba.

site_title: The Logo Effect
summary: Monograms are making a comeback in fashion, marking a shift from minimalism to a more nostalgic and luxurious approach. Luxury brands such as Burberry, Dior, Fendi, and Gucci are reviving their iconic monogram logos, with new designs and interpretations emerging. Designers like Alessandro Michele and Maria Grazia Chiuri are leading the trend, while new monograms have been introduced by Miuccia Prada, Riccardo Tisci, and Stella McCartney. This revival is driven by the current fashion climate's emphasis on 90s nostalgia and the desire for timeless luxury.

site_title: 'Natural' winemakers showcase rugged beauty of Aussie vintage
summary: In Australia's Adelaide Hills, a thriving wine counterculture has emerged, with producers rejecting mainstream winemaking techniques to create natural, organic wines. Producers like Alex Schulkin and Sam Vinciullo prioritize minimal intervention, biodynamic farming, and organic or biodynamic practices. The movement is not defined by a single goal, but by a shared desire to farm with respect for nature and make wine with as little intervention as possible. Despite controversy over the use of sulfur dioxide, natural winemakers continue to produce beautiful, complex wines that challenge traditional notions of winemaking.

site_title: Oil prices slip as Opec mulls output hike, US stocks build
summary: Oil prices fell on Thursday, with West Texas Intermediate crude dropping $1.03 to settle at $63.58 a barrel, and Brent settling at $70.83 a barrel. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) may raise oil output from July if Venezuelan and Iranian supplies fall further, due to concerns that extending production cuts could overtighten the market. US crude inventories surged to a 17-month high, and prices dropped below $63.71 a barrel, triggering automatic sales.

site_title: Chinese Delights
summary: The 7th Singapore Chinese Film Festival will feature over 60 films screened over 11 days, including Oliver Chan's "Still Human" and Lee Cheuk-Pan's "G Affairs". The festival will also showcase works by Taiwanese filmmakers, including Edward Yang's "In Our Time" and Chang Yi's "A Dog's Life". The festival will run from April 18 to 28 at various venues, with more information available on the festival's website.

site_title: Europe: Shares recover, airline stocks zoom on Brexit delay
summary: European shares rose 0.1% on Thursday, boosted by gains in bank and travel stocks following a Brexit delay. Luxury stocks, including LVMH, surged 4.6% after strong first-quarter sales. European Central Bank official Francois Villeroy de Galhau expressed willingness to support the euro zone, reassuring investors. Airline stocks, particularly EasyJet and Ryanair, jumped 8.4% and 5.1% respectively, while basic resources stocks fell 1.4%. The delay lifted uncertainty over the travel industry, which is expected to be impacted by a potential hard Brexit.

site_title: Clozette lands US$10m in Series C funding
summary: Clozette, a Singapore-based beauty and lifestyle media firm, has secured US$10 million in Series C funding from the Cool Japan Fund. The investment will support scaling the company's data-driven content and analytics platform, expanding into new markets, and developing an interactive Cool Japan Ecosystem. The ecosystem will promote Japanese fashion, beauty, food, and travel, and aims to provide a more authentic and interactive experience for consumers. This funding follows previous investments of US$3 million in Series B and US$1.5 million in Series A funding.

images.alt_text: Clozette's CEO Roger Yuen said: "Content is king. Consumers today are blocking ads, but consuming content at unprecedented rates on their platform of choice.

site_title: Calling industry advocates to push bugs-as-food campaign
summary: Singapore's food story is shifting towards producing 30% of its nutritional needs by 2030, driven by technological advancements and alternative proteins. The government-funded Research, Innovation and Enterprise 2020 plan focuses on plant-based protein, microbial protein, and cell-based cultured meat. However, opinions on these alternatives are mixed, with some consumers reluctant to accept "artificially-produced" forms of protein. Insect protein, despite being more sustainable, may prove a hard sell, while plant-based protein is more likely to gain acceptance. Industry champions, such as Noma, are needed to promote and support these alternative proteins.

site_title: Tibetan Page-turner
summary: Taschen has released a massive, 70cm by 50cm book on Tibet's rare and ancient murals, priced at US$12,000. The book, "Murals Of Tibet," features over 300 detailed images of murals, some as old as 1,000 years, and contains precious information about Buddhist thought, practices, and culture. Written and photographed by American journalist Thomas Laird, who spent 10 years searching for and documenting the murals, the book is a rare glimpse into Tibetan culture and has been blessed and signed by the Dalai Lama.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: KrisEnergy's Chief Operating Officer James Parkin has resigned, effective October 3, to pursue other interests. Parkin was a founding member of the company's management team in 2009. No replacement has been named yet.

site_title: Tesla falls on report of Panasonic factory expansion freeze
summary: Tesla Inc. fell after a report stated the company and Panasonic Corp. were suspending plans to expand the US$4.5 billion American plant due to uncertain demand for electric vehicles. The planned 50% capacity increase by 2020 was put on hold, and Panasonic will instead provide technical support and limited batteries from the existing gigafactory. Tesla's stock dropped 4.7% in pre-market trading and 3.4% to $266.80, following a record drop in deliveries during the March quarter and concerns about slackening demand for the Model 3.

site_title: NTUC Income, China's ZA Tech team up to develop digital insurance products
summary: NTUC Income has partnered with ZA Tech Global Limited, a Chinese insurer, to develop digital insurance products in Singapore. The partnership aims to launch a lifestyle insurance product for the tourism sector in the second quarter of 2019, leveraging ZhongAn's cloud-based insurtech solution. The collaboration will enable Income to reach customers typically less receptive to traditional insurance offerings and expand its digital footprint. The partnership is expected to expedite the digitalisation of the insurance sector in South-east Asia.

site_title: Night Fever
summary: Marquee, a New York nightlife institution, opens its first Asian outpost at Marina Bay Sands in Singapore on April 12. The three-floor club features an indoor Ferris Wheel and will host a star-studded grand opening party over three weekends. Performers include Tiësto, Afrojack, Above & Beyond, Steve Aoki, and Kaskade. The club is located at Marina Bay Sands, with a minimum age requirement of 18 years. Reservations can be made at www.marqueesingapore.com.

site_title: US: Stocks end lower as market awaits earnings
summary: US stocks ended the day mostly lower, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average dipping 0.1% to 26,143.05, as investors await first-quarter bank earnings. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index were flat at 2,888.32 and 7,947.36, respectively. Analysts have lowered earnings expectations, setting a low bar for bank results, with JPMorgan Chase and Wells Fargo reports kicking off the reporting season. Despite this, some stocks rose after solid earnings from Delta Air Lines, while Tesla fell 2.8% amid concerns over weakening demand for its electric vehicles.

site_title: China's Geely angles for global success with new Geometry brand
summary: China's Geely unveiled its new electric car brand, Geometry, in Singapore, launching the Geometry A, a battery-powered car designed to rival Tesla's Model 3. The car features a 120 kilowatt motor and can travel up to 500 km on a single charge. Geely has appointed Hong Seh Motors to distribute the Geometry A in Singapore, with plans to expand to Argentina, France, and Australia. The company expects to sell around 300 cars in its first year, targeting eco-minded drivers and the private hire car market.

images.alt_text: The car will be on display until Saturday at Hong Seh's showroom and over the weekend at Marina Square.

site_title: STI inches up amid global woes
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 3.17 points to 3,330.82, driven by a gain from Singtel, which closed 1.9% higher at S$3.17. The blue chip index was boosted by Singtel's 8% weightage, but later faded as prices fell below the 3,330 resistance level. Investors took to profit-taking, with some counters like Keppel Corp and DBS Group Holdings experiencing a correction. Despite a higher-than-average trading volume, the market closed with a slight gain, as investors await a potential correction.

site_title: Why the Masters is a unique event
summary: The Masters golf tournament, held annually in April at Augusta National, is a unique event among the four Majors. It has a small field of around 90 players, with qualifying criteria determining participation. The tournament has several traditions, including the green jacket awarded to the champion, who must return it the following year. Other notable traditions include the Champions Dinner and the honorary tee shot on the first day of play. The Masters has been won by notable golfers such as Jack Nicklaus, Arnold Palmer, and Tiger Woods, with six, four, and four wins respectively.

images.alt_text: Rolex Testimonee Tiger Woods celebrating after winning his maiden Major at the Masters, 1997.

site_title: Singapore is second priciest city for private property: CBRE
summary: Singapore remains the world's second most expensive housing market after Hong Kong, according to CBRE's annual report. Hong Kong's average residential property costs US$1.235 million, while Singapore's costs US$874,372. Average price growth in Singapore was 1.1%, slower than the global average.

site_title: Unwrap The Past
summary: A new exhibition at the National Museum of Singapore, "Packaging Matters: Singapore's Food Packaging Story," showcases the country's heritage through food packaging. The exhibit, featuring over 150 artefacts, chronicles the development of food packing from the late 19th to 20th century to the 1960s-70s light industries. It explores how packaging influences consumer choices, changes in design, and the rise of supermarkets. The exhibition also touches on sustainability, inviting visitors to reflect on eco-friendly practices and innovative packaging that reduces waste. The exhibit runs until September 15, 2023.

site_title: Designer Gourmet
summary: Culina, a luxury supermarket at COMO Dempsey, has opened its new 15,000 sq ft space, featuring a stylish and modern design by architect Paola Navone. The supermarket offers a wide range of high-quality meats, seafood, cheeses, and baked goods, as well as a separate wine section and bar. The store's design includes quirky graphic posters, giant paper lanterns, and a "bread curtain" made of baked goods. Culina aims to create a bustling atmosphere and infectious vibes, similar to a European street market, and offers cooking sessions and corporate events. The store's opening complements the COMO Dempsey complex, which also features Kids21 and Maggie & Rose children's stores, set to open on April 16.

site_title: Brokerage Shenwan Hongyuan seeks up to HK$9.8b in Hong Kong listing
summary: SHENWAN Hongyuan Group Co, China's sixth largest brokerage, is seeking to raise up to HK$9.8 billion in a Hong Kong listing, offering 2.5 billion shares at HK$3.63 to HK$3.93 apiece. The deal, valued at US$1.3 billion, is the largest first-time share sale in Hong Kong this year, attracting 13 cornerstone investors and joint sponsors Goldman Sachs Group Inc and others. Proceeds will be used to develop its securities business, international business, and make principal investments.

site_title: Xnergy's contactless charging for AGVs
summary: Xnergy has developed a contactless charging system for automated guided vehicles (AGVs), addressing the downtime issue that can cost companies thousands of dollars. The system eliminates the need for manual recharging, reducing downtime and increasing productivity. This innovation is particularly beneficial for larger firms with extensive AGV fleets. With this solution, companies can optimize their factory operations and streamline their processes, aligning with the Industry 4.0 transformation goals.

site_title: Easter Traditions At Frieda
summary: The Capitol Kempinski Hotel Singapore presents an authentic German Easter celebration at Frieda restaurant, featuring unique dishes, artisanal chocolate treats, and an Easter Egg Quest. The semi-buffet spread showcases traditional German delights, including devilled eggs, Wiener schnitzel, and Germanic desserts. The hotel also offers free-flow Taittinger Champagne, house pour wines, and pints of German Beer, with prices starting from S$78 for one main course and S$128 for free-flow drinks.

site_title: Trump signs orders to speed up oil and gas pipeline construction
summary: US President Donald Trump signed two executive orders to speed up the construction of oil and gas pipelines, despite criticism from environmentalists who say it would exacerbate climate change. The orders aim to ease regulations on pipeline construction and transfer authority for international pipelines to the president, with the goal of increasing energy production and exports. The actions are likely to attract legal challenges from state governments and environmental groups.

site_title: Sweet-Faced Scammer
summary: Elizabeth Holmes, the founder of Theranos, was a successful entrepreneur who fooled many investors with her fake blood-testing technology. At her peak, her company was valued at $9 billion, with endorsements from influential figures like Rupert Murdoch and Henry Kissinger. However, by 2016, Theranos was under investigation, and Holmes and CEO Sunny Balwani were indicted for fraud and conspiracy in 2018, exposing her as a white-collar criminal. The HBO documentary portrays Holmes as one of the most fascinating and deceitful figures in history.

site_title: China Vanke mulls US$1b property management IPO
summary: China Vanke Co, the country's largest developer by market capitalization, is considering a Hong Kong listing of its property management business, which could raise up to $1 billion. The move comes as China's property market shows signs of a recovery, with home sales surging in March. This would be the latest in a trend of Chinese developers spinning off their management units, which are less prone to government policy changes and economic cycles. The offering is still in its early stages, with details yet to be confirmed.

site_title: Thai And Thai
summary: Chef Thitid "Ton' Tassanakajohn's restaurant Le Du in Bangkok partners with fellow Thai chef Ian Kittichai to present a 6-course menu from April 11-14, showcasing reinvented Thai favorites with local produce. The S$180++ menu features dishes like lobster in Southern Thai curry sauce, seared scallops, and Hunglay iberico pork with tamarind. This collaboration aims to highlight the versatility of modern Thai cuisine and the use of local ingredients.

images.alt_text: Thai cuisine.

site_title: Britain's new political parties: 'them' and 'us'
summary: The UK's withdrawal from the European Union has led to a deepening divide between Remainers and Leavers, with nearly one-third of voters identifying with neither a party nor an ideology. This identity-driven politics is fueled by conflict and competition, rather than policy differences. Research shows that Remainers and Leavers often view each other as hypocritical and close-minded, with no change in their opinions on Brexit despite new information. This identity-driven politics is a departure from the traditional party affiliations of the past, with Brexit serving as a catalyst for the formation of these competing identities.

site_title: Casino bidding war looms for Crown after Wynn backs away
summary: Crown Resorts, controlled by billionaire James Packer, has sparked a potential bidding war after a US gaming giant, Wynn Resorts, pulled out of a proposed A$9.99 billion takeover offer. Rival suitors, including Hard Rock International and Malaysia's Genting Bhd, are expected to engage, according to analysts. The deal would be the industry's biggest acquisition in over a decade and could give Wynn a foothold in the Asian gaming market. With governments tightly controlling new gaming licenses, a takeover of Crown could be a strategic move for companies seeking to expand in the region.

site_title: Cyber insurance market hobbled by lack of data, experience, clarity
summary: The cyber insurance market is hindered by a lack of data, experience, and clarity, making it difficult for insurers to price accumulation risk and understand the gap between insured and uncovered cyber exposures. Despite growing demand, the market's profitability is uncertain, with some insurers expecting it to level off due to the increasing number of claims. The "silent cyber" risk, where cyber exposures are implicit in traditional property and liability insurance, poses a significant challenge, particularly in the Asia-Pacific region, where companies often underestimate the impact of cyber attacks.

site_title: Evonik 'confident' about China probe outcome
summary: German specialty chemicals giant Evonik expresses confidence in the outcome of China's anti-dumping probe into methionine imports from Japan, Malaysia, and Singapore. Evonik supports the investigation and will cooperate fully, despite being a major supplier of methionine to China. The company operates two methionine plants in Singapore, which will double its production capacity to 300,000 metric tons per year. The investigation will last a year, concluding by April 10, 2020.

site_title: Merging of same-stable Reits is the way to go
summary: The Singapore bourse's Reit Listings, comprising over 30 counters across various sectors, require market consolidation due to liquidity problems and high running costs. The proposed merger of two OUE-stable Reits is seen as a positive step, following the successful merger of ESR and Viva Industrial Trust. Conglomerates with multiple listed Reits can benefit from economies of scale, lower borrowing costs, and increased institutional interest, ultimately leading to greater value for shareholders. Merging fellow stable Reits can result in entities valued over S$10 billion, enhancing profitability and stability in the Reit sector.

site_title: Changi Airport's Jewel sparkles for first visitors
summary: Changi Airport's Jewel, a 51:49 joint venture between Changi Airport Group and CapitaLand, welcomed its first visitors on April 11, 2019, ahead of its April 17 official opening. The 135,700 square meter, 10-storey development features a retail-dining-play concept set among greenery, including the world's tallest indoor waterfall, Rain Vortex. With 26 airlines offering early check-in counters and a lounge, Jewel aims to enhance the passenger experience, particularly for transit passengers, and attract more stop-over visitors and tourists to Singapore.

images.alt_text: A view of the Shiseido Forest Valley, which houses more than 900 trees and palms and about 600,000 shrubs, and the 40-metre HSBC Rain Vortex, the world's tallest indoor waterfall.
The Discovery slides at the Canopy Park, which also includes sky nets, hedge and mirror mazes. These attractions open on June 10.

site_title: Modi favourite as India's incredible election begins
summary: India's massive election, the largest in history, began with Prime Minister Narendra Modi seeking a second term, despite facing a tough challenge from scions of the Nehru-Gandhi dynasty. Modi, 68, is the favourite but his poor record on jobs and rural poverty is being exploited by his opponents. The election, held in seven phases, will be fought in 543 constituencies across the 1.3 billion people, with results due on May 23. Modi's right-wing Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) faces criticism for its Hindu agenda, while his opponents, including Rahul Gandhi, promise to end poverty and provide jobs.

site_title: Body & Spirit
summary: The Kalari Kovilakom and Kalari Rasayana luxury wellness centres in Kerala, India, offer bespoke healing experiences based on the ancient practice of Ayurveda. The resorts deliver 360-degree programmes for stress management and various health issues, aligning mental, physical, and emotional well-being for long-term health. Located within historic grounds and coconut groves, CGH Earth's resorts aim to provide a holistic approach to wellness, distinct from digital warriors' short-term fitness solutions.

site_title: The Eco-Preneurs
summary: Ahead of Earth Day, the article highlights eco-preneurs making a business out of saving the planet. Arthur Huang, founder of Miniwiz, upcycles discarded materials into recycled composite materials for store interiors, while also wearing clothes made from trash. His 14-year research and experimentation have led to innovative solutions for upcycling consumer trash and industrial waste. These eco-conscious entrepreneurs are driving change towards a zero-waste future, demonstrating the potential for business to be a force for environmental sustainability.

site_title: Singapore's APEX to launch first fuel oil futures contract
summary: Singapore-based Asia Pacific Exchange (APEX) is set to launch its first fuel oil futures contract, denominated in US dollars and targeting regional and international industry participants. The contract, for 10 tonnes of high-sulphur fuel oil, will expire on the day before each respective month and will be physically deliverable. The move aims to cater to both large and small investors, particularly from China, amid growing trade liquidity in fuel oil futures in China. APEX may subsequently launch similar contracts for low-sulphur fuel oil and marine gasoil, responding to International Maritime Organization (IMO) rules that require ships to use fuel with 0.5% or less sulphur content.

site_title: Solange Shines
summary: Solange's new album, When I Get Home, showcases her experimental style, blending musical influences from her hometown of Houston, Texas, including blues, swing, and country. The album features dreamy, stream-of-consciousness pop, with Solange reconstructing sounds from memory rather than sampling them. The result is an evocative, ghostly portrayal of places and people she loves. The album is available on various music platforms and marks a significant step in Solange's career, solidifying her position as a prominent artist in her own right, distinct from her famous sister Beyonce.

images.alt_text: When I Get Home by Solange.

site_title: LVMH sends positive luxury signal with Q1 sales beating estimates
summary: LVMH reports a 11% rise in Q1 sales to 12.5 billion euros, beating analyst estimates, driven by growth in its fashion and leather division. The key fashion unit posted a 15% gain, with new designs and collaborations from designers like Virgil Abloh and Kim Jones contributing to the increase. The luxury industry's growth is attributed to China, where high-end fashion sales continue to thrive despite economic challenges. Analysts expect the growth to sustain LVMH's upward momentum in the shares.

site_title: Home Additions
summary: Vitra, a Swiss family-owned design company, has opened its first standalone store in Singapore at the Tan Boon Liat Building, in partnership with W. Atelier. This marks the company's first retail presence in the city-state after years of being a shop within another shop.

site_title: Personal Challenge
summary: The Chapman's Challenge 2019 is an annual resort event held at Pangkor Laut Resort in Malaysia. The challenge commemorates Colonel Spencer Chapman's escape from the Japanese army during World War II, where he swam 45m out to sea to be rescued. Participants run 3.8km, trek 2.4km through a rainforest, swim 1km in open water, and sprint to the finish line, receiving prizes including bragging rights and a three-night stay at the resort.

site_title: Pacific Radiance's auditor flags going concern issue, cites 'material uncertainties'
summary: Pacific Radiance's auditor, Ernst & Young, has declined to express an opinion on the company's 2018 financial results due to material uncertainties surrounding its restructuring exercise. The company's going concern assumption is deemed uncertain, and if the assumption is not appropriate, the financial statements may need to be revised, potentially affecting asset and liability values. As of December 31, 2018, Pacific Radiance had significant current liabilities exceeding its current assets by $486.8 million and a total liability-to-asset ratio of $158.5 million. The company is in the process of completing its restructuring plans.

site_title: The rise and rise of the Birkin
summary: The Hermes Birkin bag, once considered rare and exclusive, has become more accessible through the rise of the fashion resale market. Resale sites such as Prive Porter, The RealReal, and StockX have made luxury Birkins available to consumers, with over 1 million bags now in the market. Despite concerns about dilution and devaluation, the Birkin's value and allure seem to be intact, with demand rising and Hermes' bottom line unaffected. The resale market has become a "happy loop" of aficionados, with collectors paying premium prices for rare bags, fueling the luxury industry's growth.

site_title: BM Mobility dismisses CFO after two months
summary: BM Mobility, a Singapore-listed electric transport firm, has dismissed its CFO, Lim Gwo Bin, just two months into a controversial appointment. The board cited no reason for the dismissal and stated there were no material differences in opinion. The company will outsource its accounting and finance function while searching for a replacement. This move follows queries from the Singapore Exchange regarding the appointment, which included questions about Lim's qualifications and ties to Malaysia, where the market contributes significantly to the company's revenue.

site_title: Indofood Agri gets buyout offer from Indomie maker at S$0.28 per share
summary: Indofood Sukses Makmur, controlled by Indonesian tycoon Anthoni Salim, is offering S$0.28 per share to take Singapore-listed Indofood Agri Resources private, valuing the agribusiness group at around S$390.9 million. The offer is conditional upon obtaining control over at least 90% of the target company and represents a 7.7% premium to Indofood Agri's last traded price. The deal is expected to be completed within 14-21 days, with no major changes to the existing business planned.

site_title: Industry's bright spark, in BT Weekend
summary: The article discusses the slow adoption of 3D printing technology in industrial applications in Singapore, despite its potential to transform manufacturing. Industry players are optimistic about its future use, particularly in sectors such as aerospace and healthcare. In other sections, a broadcasting veteran shares his insights on the future of show business, and a columnist advises investors to accept volatility as a given for potential returns. Additionally, articles cover topics such as corporate purpose, financial literacy, and zero-waste living.

site_title: US, China to set up trade deal enforcement offices: Mnuchin
summary: The US and China have agreed on a mechanism to enforce any trade agreement, including establishing new enforcement offices. US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin stated progress continues in talks focusing on intellectual property rights, services, and cyber theft. Although a deal could be ready by the end of April, Mnuchin declined to set an arbitrary deadline, focusing on getting the "right deal." The enforcement structure's details, including the right to reimpose tariffs without retaliation, remain unclear.

site_title: Wikileaks founder Julian Assange arrested in UK
summary: Wikileaks founder Julian Assange was arrested in London on Thursday by British police after Ecuador withdrew his asylum. Assange, 47, had been living in the Ecuadorean embassy since 2012 to avoid extradition to Sweden over a sexual assault investigation. He was arrested for breaking bail rules and faces extradition to the US, where federal prosecutors are investigating WikiLeaks. Assange's health has been a concern due to cramped living conditions, and his supporters see him as a hero for exposing government abuse.

site_title: The new Rahm is in the Masters groove
summary: Jon Rahm, the 24-year-old golfer, is considered a front-runner for the prestigious Augusta Major, the Masters, after a phenomenal rise in his career. Rahm's calm and composed demeanor, along with his newfound motivation, has earned him a spot alongside other top contenders like Dustin Johnson, Jordan Spieth, and Justin Thomas. The Masters, which has a history of rewarding big-hitters, is expected to be a challenging event for golfers, with a 20% chance of a winner among the 21 Rolex Testimonees in the field of 87 players.

site_title: US dollar, euro steady on Fed, ECB caution
summary: The US dollar and euro remained steady on Thursday amid the Federal Reserve and European Central Bank's cautious stance on interest rates, citing trade tensions and slowing growth. The pound traded flat despite the European Union's extension of the Brexit deadline, with investors awaiting key economic data from China and the potential impact of a UK general election. The dollar index and euro remained flat at 96.95 and 1.1278 respectively, while commodity currencies like the Aussie were boosted by rising commodity prices.

site_title: Prabowo asks supporters to reject result if Jokowi wins
summary: Former Indonesian general Prabowo Subianto has urged his supporters to reject the election result if Joko Widodo wins, stating he will not "accept an election that is stolen." Prabowo's team is preparing a legal challenge if he loses, indicating a potential challenge to the outcome of the April 17 presidential election in Indonesia.

site_title: Fed signals patience in 2019 amid mounting risks to growth
summary: Federal Reserve officials signaled patience in interest rate policy, leaving the target range unchanged for the remainder of 2019 amid mounting risks to growth, including slowing European growth, Brexit, and the Trump trade war. Despite a forecasted above-trend economy with low unemployment, policymakers are concerned about decelerating inflation and labor market slack. The decision reflects a cautious approach, with officials indicating they may not raise rates even if some risks resolve, and may instead wait for signs of inflation pressures to continue being limited.

site_title: Tencent's not the only tech stock rallying in Asia
summary: Asian technology stocks, excluding Tencent, are driving the sector's rally this year, with gains exceeding 20% in some cases. Other notable tech stocks, such as Creative Technology and NTT DC Reit, have also seen significant increases. The rally is attributed to various factors, including regulatory approvals, new game releases, and upgrades in the sector.

site_title: Australian premier sets election for May 18
summary: Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison has called a national election for May 18, setting the stage for a contentious campaign focused on climate and the economy. The conservative government seeks a third term, while polls indicate a strong lead for the center-left Labor party, led by Bill Shorten. The election will be closely contested, with key marginal seats and the performance of independent candidates potentially deciding the outcome.

site_title: Hyflux yet to seek extension of debt moratorium
summary: Hyflux will restart talks with its creditors to explore outcomes other than liquidation, but has not decided on seeking an extended debt moratorium from the Singapore High Court. The company terminated a rescue deal with Indonesian investor group SM investments, which failed to commit to injecting S$530 million into Hyflux. Hyflux's new search for a saviour will begin with parties who previously submitted rescue offers. A judge has stated that he will need to see a feasible plan before agreeing to extend the moratorium, set to expire on April 30.

site_title: Millions rush to join new health plan from Jack Ma's Ant Financial
summary: Jack Ma's Ant Financial has launched Xiang Hu Bao, a health insurance plan that has attracted 50 million people since its October inception, surpassing the population of New York City. The plan, which offers payouts of up to 300,000 yuan, operates like a collective, with members contributing evenly to payouts and disputes resolved by volunteer members. Ant aims to sign up 300 million users within two years, representing 20% of China's population, and plans to take an 8% administrative fee from payouts.

site_title: Trump-Bibi bromance still on honeymoon
summary: US President Donald Trump's close friendship with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has been reinvigorated following Netanyahu's re-election for a fifth term. Netanyahu's victory, despite corruption charges and a strong opposition, has boosted Trump's hopes for a "Deal of the Century" peace agreement between Israelis and Palestinians. However, Netanyahu's right-wing allies may reject concessions to Palestinians, threatening the deal's success. The outcome of the Israeli election has strengthened ties between Washington and Jerusalem, with Trump now more popular among Israelis than he is in the US.

site_title: Sabrina Tan
summary: Sabrina Tan, founder and CEO of Skin Inc, has led the company to success with its customized approach to skincare. Since its founding in 2008, Skin Inc has experienced double-digit growth and a strong online presence, thanks to its "skin-tel" database that provides tailored skincare recommendations. The company has over 200 outlets globally, including at 136 Sephoras across 48 cities. Tan attributes the brand's success to its ability to marry technology with beauty, leveraging data to create products that resonate with a universal audience. She emphasizes the importance of staying ahead in the competitive beauty industry and advises her younger self to focus on impact rather than details.

site_title: Halloween Brexit casts uneasy spell over businesses, investors
summary: The UK and European leaders have agreed to delay Brexit until October 31, providing businesses and investors with a temporary reprieve from uncertainty. However, the deal comes with new uncertainties, including a potential general election and a hard-left Labour government. Businesses warn that a Labour victory could drive away foreign investment and boost the state budget deficit. The pound remains volatile, and the stock market has recovered from initial losses, trading flat. UK Prime Minister Theresa May must now win over MPs on the withdrawal treaty or face a no-deal Brexit on June 1.

site_title: Apple adds more suppliers to clean energy programme
summary: Apple has nearly doubled the number of suppliers using clean energy for production work, with 44 companies now participating in the program. This includes major suppliers like Hon Hai Precision Industry Co Ltd (Foxconn) and Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co Ltd (TSMC). Apple aims to add 4 gigawatts of renewable energy to its supply chain by 2020, and has a goal of "well over" 5 gigawatts. The company encourages suppliers to build their own renewable energy projects or sign power-purchase agreements with new renewable energy projects.

site_title: Fitch lowers ThaiBev's outlook to 'negative' from 'stable'
summary: Fitch Ratings has lowered its outlook for Thai Beverage (ThaiBev) to "negative" from "stable" due to a slower-than-expected pace of deleveraging following a series of acquisitions in 2018, which increased the company's debt. ThaiBev acquired several businesses, including Saigon Beer-Alcohol-Beverage Corporation, the Grand Royal Group, and 252 KFC outlets in Thailand.

site_title: 'China's Manhattan' borrows heavily, but the people have yet to arrive
summary: China's Yujiapu Financial District, dubbed "China's Manhattan," struggles with debt and underutilized office space, despite a grand opening of the Juilliard School's second campus. The district, built with an estimated $4.5 trillion in debt, faces a slowdown in economic growth, with many businesses and residents yet to arrive. Officials are struggling to manage debt and find alternative ways to spur growth, as the "build it and they will come" model that fueled China's prosperity in the past may no longer be effective.

images.alt_text: Four-fifths of the office space in Yujiapu Financial District stands empty. Construction on other buildings has also stopped, leaving skeletons in the sky.

site_title: Uber IPO listing joins year of the unicorn IPOs
summary: Uber Technologies Inc is set to join the public markets with a potential IPO, raising about US$10 billion, as part of a surge of initial public offerings (IPOs) in the US. Since the federal commission reopened, 15 companies have raised over US$5.5 billion in the past three weeks, with Pinterest and Zoom also considering listings. The year is expected to see a record-breaking US$80 billion in IPOs, more than double the yearly average since 1999.

site_title: House prices in London forecast to keep falling
summary: London house prices forecast to continue falling for another year due to Brexit gloom, with demand and supply declining and prices remaining in negative territory. A survey by the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (RICS) found anxious buyers, reluctant sellers, and agents struggling to negotiate agreements. A modest recovery is expected, but a subsequent growth is unlikely in the southeast, where the market is in its worst slump since the financial crisis. Brexit remains a major drag on the market, with uncertainty deterring potential buyers.

site_title: Corporations are cheating the global tax system
summary: Corporations are exploiting loopholes in the global tax system, resulting in a loss of $600 billion in revenue for governments worldwide. This translates to approximately $400 per family of four. The lack of effective global cooperation in taxing corporate income has led to widespread tax evasion, with digital companies being the biggest offenders. To address this issue, the IMF suggests that major nations make a commitment to have highly profitable corporations pay a base level of at least 15% of their reported profits to governments.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: DBS Group Holdings is maintained as a "Buy" with a target price of S$29.60 due to expected net interest margin (NIM) widening in Q1 2019 from January's mortgage rate rise. First Reit's Q1FY2019 distribution per unit of 2.15 Singapore cents is in line with expectations, and its robust balance sheet is expected to support acquisitive growth opportunities.

site_title: China producer inflation picks up for first time in 9 months
summary: China's factory-gate inflation rose for the first time in nine months in March, driven by global commodity price increases and signs of government efforts boosting domestic demand. Consumer inflation also quickened, with pork prices soaring due to swine fever. This eases deflation fears, but analysts note that better data and more support from Beijing are needed for sustained economic recovery.

site_title: Land mass or population size irrelevant to emissions target
summary: Singapore's Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing made a concerning statement about the country's emissions target under the 2016 Paris Agreement. He implied that Singapore was allocated a "quota" for carbon emissions, which is not true. The Paris Agreement calls for nationally determined contributions, and Singapore's target is based on emissions intensity, not land mass or population size. This reactive response to climate change raises questions about the country's commitment to environmental protection and may deter Singaporeans from supporting climate action.

site_title: Chip sector on the mend? Economists hold mixed views
summary: Singapore's electronics sector may be nearing a recovery, with tentative signs that the global electronics downturn is easing, according to economists. Maybank Kim Eng and Mizuho analysts suggest the worst of the downturn may be over, with a potential uplift in the second half of the year. However, Citi analysts predict a moderation in the industry's downward cycle, while others warn that the East Asian numbers may be too preliminary and that the global tech slowdown is still ongoing. The sector's growth prospects remain uncertain, with some predicting a significant moderation in the industry's decline.

site_title: Crypto coin sales stage revival after bursting of ICO bubble
summary: Cryptocurrency startups are reviving the fundraising process through Initial Exchange Offerings (IEO), a method similar to Initial Coin Offerings (ICO) that has been largely declared dead. Instead of directly marketing coins to investors, companies are partnering with crypto exchanges to vet projects and offer tokens to approved customers. This curated approach aims to recreate the fundraising model before the ICO bubble burst. The new method is seen as a way for entrepreneurs to raise millions from investors despite regulatory pushback and the demise of traditional ICOs.

site_title: Makino Asia launches smart factory in Tuas
summary: Makino Asia has launched a smart factory in Tuas, Singapore, with IIoT capabilities to increase productivity and connectivity. The facility, which consists of an existing assembly factory and a new machining factory, is expected to nearly double machine production capacity. The smart factory features energy-saving solutions, including solar panels and a digitised inventory system, and includes an IoT Centre for remote monitoring and predictive maintenance. The facility is part of Makino Asia's S$100 million digital transformation plan and is expected to be replicated in other factories in China and India.

site_title: Shell sells stake in Gulf of Mexico field for US$965m
summary: Royal Dutch Shell has agreed to sell its 22.45% stake in the Caesar Tonga field in the Gulf of Mexico for US$965 million to Delek Group's subsidiary. This deal is part of Shell's US$30 billion divestment plan, which began in 2015 after the takeover of BG Group Plc. The Caesar Tonga field has 30 years of life and 78 million barrels of oil equivalent reserves, and the sale is subject to the right of refusal by Anadarko Petroleum Corp, Equinor ASA, and Chevron Corp.

site_title: Real estate among top gainers YTD but further rally unlikely
summary: The Singapore real estate sector has been among the top performers this year, with top developers rising 24% since the start of the year. However, analysts expect limited upside due to muted sentiment and attractive valuation levels. Contributing factors include the US Federal Reserve's dovish interest outlook and the Urban Redevelopment Authority's draft master plan 2019, which may lead to increased property sales and development projects. Despite this, analysts remain cautious, predicting a range-bound market with limited upside and potential re-rating if sales volumes or take-up rates pick up.

site_title: National Enquirer for sale as tabloid feels heat from its own scandals
summary: The owner of the National Enquirer, American Media Inc, is considering selling the tabloid amid scandals, including admitting to paying hush money to help Donald Trump's election and attempting to blackmail Jeff Bezos. The company has cooperated with federal prosecutors and is exploring "strategic options" for the weekly and other brands. The National Enquirer has faced criticism for its reporting on Bezos' affair with Lauren Sanchez, and the publication has been accused of trying to blackmail Bezos with the threat of publishing intimate photos.

site_title: E-scooter startup Lime picks Singapore as Asia-Pacific HQ
summary: Lime, an e-scooter startup, has chosen Singapore as its Asia-Pacific headquarters, set to open in the third quarter of 2019 in the central business district. The move aims to expand the company's capabilities and lay the groundwork for its Asia-Pacific expansion. With over 10 million sign-ups and 34 million rides taken, Lime plans to establish a presence in government relations, partnerships, brand, and operations in Singapore. The location is seen as a strategic choice due to Singapore's strong potential for growth, infrastructure readiness, and progressive government support.

site_title: 737 Max's wings stay clipped until FAA gives the all-clear
summary: The US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has not set a timeline for clearing Boeing's 737 Max jets for flight again, pending the completion of a software upgrade on the flawed flight control system. Transportation Secretary Elaine Chao stated that the FAA will not approve Boeing's proposed changes until it is satisfied with the safety of the planes. The FAA grounded the fleet after discovering evidence of a flaw in the planes, with Chao defending the agency's decision, which was one of the last major regulators worldwide to ground the fleet.

site_title: Inequality among factors that weigh on dreams of being part of middle class
summary: The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) warns that middle-class life is becoming unfair, expensive, and uncertain. The middle class's share of total income is falling, and core costs such as housing, education, and health are rising. Over-indebtedness is increasing, and automation threatens jobs, making it harder for people to climb the social ladder. The OECD defines middle class as households with incomes between 75% and twice the national median, and finds that real income growth for the middle class has been dismal, with a 0.3% annual increase since the financial crisis.

images.alt_text: According to the the OECD, over the last 30 years, incomes have increased a third less than the average of the richest 10%. Analysts warn of revolutions as disparity in wealth fuels conflict and populism as in the case of France. Demonstrators there are expected to hit city streets again for a 19th consecutive week of nationwide protest against President Emmanuel Macron's policies.

site_title: It's time for the 'First World' hypothesis to be rewritten
summary: The "First World" hypothesis, which has been used to classify countries based on economic and infrastructure factors, is being reevaluated due to changing global circumstances. The traditional definition no longer accurately reflects the complexities of modern societies, which prioritize factors such as political freedom, inclusivity, and environmental sustainability. As various countries face challenges like corruption, income inequality, and environmental degradation, a revised definition of "First World" is needed to better capture the essence of a good life and well-being. This reevaluation aims to move beyond the traditional economic lens and consider the broader social and environmental implications.

site_title: Carousell eyes Hong Kong, Philippines for revenue growth
summary: Online marketplace Carousell is expanding its operations in the Philippines and Hong Kong to boost revenue growth. The seven-year-old startup, valued at over US$550 million, has announced a US$56 million deal with OLX Group, taking a 10% stake. Carousell aims to increase revenue from its three streams, including advertising and premium visibility services, in the Philippines. The company's co-founder and CEO Quek Siu Rui expects revenue to grow simultaneously with increased costs, but does not have a specific timeline for profitability.

site_title: New Airbus CEO takes charge with leaner structure
summary: Airbus has appointed new CEO Guillaume Faury, who has introduced a simplified management structure with a 12-person executive committee. The changes aim to prepare the company for intensified competition with Boeing and incorporate digital technologies. Faury has lifted engineering, communications, and sales to the top table, while sidelining procurement. Analysts say the shift focuses on production methods from the car industry as output rises, marking a departure from market-share battles. Faury's goal is to modernize Airbus's manufacturing systems.

site_title: What's for dinner? The Masters winner decides
summary: Patrick Reed hosted his first Champions Dinner at Augusta National Golf Club, 15 years after winning the Masters. The dinner, a private affair, featured a menu of bone-in rib-eye, mac-and-cheese, and creamed corn, chosen by Reed to "fatten up" the players. The meal selections often reveal a player's personality, geography, and cultural background, as seen in past winners' choices, such as Gary Player's South African-inspired braai and Phil Mickelson's paella in honor of Seve Ballesteros. The dinner is a long-standing tradition, started by Ben Hogan in 1952, where the defending champion selects the menu and hosts the event.

images.alt_text: Gary Player of South Africa looks on during the Par 3 Contest prior to the Masters at Augusta National Golf Club on Wednesday, in Augusta, Georgia. The meal choices of the winners often reveal something about the player: where they're from, what they miss and what they simply really want to eat. Player selected his menus to show respect to all players and countries and to take note of how international the Masters has become.

site_title: IMF warns of 'dangerous' results as Trump criticises Fed
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) warned that US President Donald Trump's criticism of the Federal Reserve could lead to "dangerous" monetary policy mistakes. Trump has called for lower interest rates and the restoration of quantitative easing, but the IMF supports the Fed's current stance. The fund's Global Financial Stability Report notes that easy monetary policy and high debt levels may raise the risk of a deeper economic downturn. The IMF emphasizes the importance of central bank independence, as undermining it could lead to policy mistakes.

site_title: Exxon in talks to build LNG platform in Israel
