Under CEO Serena Wee, the company aims to increase access to cancer treatments, particularly in Asia, where incidence rates are expected to rise by 70% over the next 20 years.

images.alt_text: 'Icon has a strong platform to continue growing in the ASEAN region, introducing additional capabilities and providing the latest cancer treatments using the newest technology and drugs to continue delivering the best care possible to people in the region.' - Serena Wee, CEO of Icon SOC (second from left).

site_title: China's sweet-toothed millennials lure giant sugar player MSM
summary: Asia's largest sugar refiner, MSM Malaysia Holdings Bhd, is in talks to sell sugar in China due to the country's growing demand from millennials. The company aims to supply sugar for popular snacks and healthier sweeteners. Executive director Khairil Anuar Aziz confirmed the talks, indicating the potential for partnerships in China's downstream sugar industry.

site_title: Buyout group Apollo prepares bottle maker Verallia for possible 4b-euro IPO: sources
summary: Apollo, a private equity firm, is preparing French glass bottle maker Verallia for a potential 4 billion-euro IPO, possibly in September. Verallia could be valued at 7-8 times its core earnings. Apollo acquired a controlling stake in Verallia in 2015, and the company is expected to post core earnings of 550 million euros this year. The IPO may be one of the largest French listings this year, despite wobbly market conditions.

images.alt_text: Verallia counts Pernod Ricard, champagne house Dom Perignon and chocolate spreads maker Nutella among its clients.

site_title: Beijing is on track to 'China-ise' the West
summary: China is increasingly "China-ising" the West by leveraging its growing wealth and economic influence to promote its currency, the renminbi. Beijing has promoted the renminbi through various means, including including it in the International Monetary Fund's special drawing right and incentivizing governments and central banks to buy it. This strategy is aimed at increasing the renminbi's global presence and making it a more significant player in international trade and finance. China's success in this area may undermine the US dollar's dominance and pose a challenge to Western economic interests.

site_title: Crude oil price rally propels commodity currencies
summary: Crude oil prices surged to five-month highs, boosting commodity currencies like the Australian and Canadian dollar. The Australian dollar rose 0.3% to US$0.7151, while the Canadian dollar firmed to C$1.3293, its strongest since March 21. Analysts attribute the rally to tightening global supplies due to fighting in Libya, OPEC-led cuts, and US sanctions on Iran and Venezuela. The US dollar fell for a second consecutive day, while the euro rose 0.2% ahead of the European Central Bank meeting.

site_title: STI ekes out gains amid lack of local catalysts
summary: The Singapore benchmark index, the Straits Times Index (STI), closed 10.18 points up at 3,325.60, despite lacking local catalysts. Asian markets ended mostly higher due to optimism about Chinese economic growth measures. US earnings season for Q1 is expected to be a key driver of share price performance, with markets potentially remaining lackluster until clarity is achieved. Local blue-chip stocks, such as Singtel and Keppel Corp, reached multi-week highs, while oil prices continued to rise due to global supply tensions.

site_title: Workplace safety in Singapore: Name and shame our way to the top
summary: Singapore aims to become one of the world's best workplaces in terms of safety and health, following a record 41 workplace injuries in 2018, with 14 fatalities in the construction sector. The country plans to "name and shame" errant employers with poor safety records, sharing their names with private developers and adjusting premiums based on safety records. The government also proposes introducing a Code of Practice for company directors, incentivizing contractors to improve supplier WSH capabilities, and empowering workers to report unsafe conditions.

site_title: Asian investors putting more money in sustainable investing
summary: Asian institutional investors are increasing their commitment to sustainable investments, with 55% expecting to allocate 50-75% of assets to ESG funds in two years. Currently, only 15% hold between 50-75% of investments in ESG funds. The trend is driven by long-term returns and a desire for sustainable investments. Green bonds are a key part of the investment strategy for 36% of respondents, and demand is also growing among Asia's wealthy, with 29% of rich Singaporeans planning to invest in sustainable investments.

site_title: State-of-the-art training centre for national golfers
summary: The Singapore Golf Association (SGA) has partnered with Laguna National Golf and Country Club to establish a state-of-the-art training centre for national golfers. The centre will serve as the home base for the SGA's National, Development, and Junior Squads, as well as five professional golfers under the SGA Rookie Professional Programme. This is a first for golf in Singapore, providing a dedicated facility for golfers to hone their skills and compete at a high level.

site_title: Hi-P shares drop 14% following Maybank Kim Eng's downgrade
summary: Hi-P International shares dropped 14% after Maybank Kim Eng downgraded the stock to "sell" with a target price of S$1.22, citing the company as "overvalued" compared to global peers. The downgrade followed Hi-P's 47% gain since its full-year results announcement.

site_title: Burger King pulls chopsticks ad after social media furore
summary: Burger King pulled a promotional video in New Zealand showing customers trying to eat burgers with chopsticks after sparking outrage in China, with demands for an apology. The video, posted on Instagram, was deemed insensitive and not representative of the brand's values. Chinese social media users viewed the hashtag "Burger King apology" over 50 million times, comparing it to a similar Dolce & Gabbana ad that sparked controversy last year. Burger King removed the video and apologized, citing its brand values regarding diversity and inclusion.

site_title: IMF cuts global growth outlook to lowest since 2009
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has cut its global growth outlook to 3.3% for 2019, the lowest since the 2009 financial crisis, amid a decline in major advanced economies and signs of higher tariffs weighing on trade. The fund also lowered its forecast for the US, euro area, and UK, while raising its projection for Chinese growth. Despite a potential trade truce between the US and China, the IMF warns that risks are skewed to the downside, with a range of threats to the global economy, including the "no-deal" Brexit scenario.

site_title: Pinterest dials down expectations as IPO nears
summary: Pinterest set a lower-than-expected initial public offering (IPO) price range of $15-$17 per share, valuing the company at $11.3 billion. This dampens investor enthusiasm for prominent but unprofitable technology companies, following Lyft's recent IPO. Investors are now focusing on business fundamentals, and a lower valuation could spell a loss for some early investors. Pinterest's CEO Ben Silbermann owns 11.4% of the company and stands to gain $825 million at the midpoint of the pricing range.

site_title: Private resale prices now just 0.6% below July 2018 peak: SRX
summary: Singapore's private resale property market experienced its largest recovery in activity since the last cooling measures, with resale non-landed private homes sold in March up 59.3% to 830 units. Resale prices rose 0.6% below their July 2018 peak, with a 1.3% increase in outlying areas and 0.1% in prime districts. This brings resale prices 3.5% higher than a year ago, with sales volume expected to pick up further in selected locations as new projects are launched.

site_title: EU leaders expected to agree on Brexit delay by a year
summary: EU leaders are expected to agree on a Brexit delay that could last until the end of June, with a no-deal exit considered unlikely due to its economic and strategic implications. Prime Minister Theresa May has failed to secure parliamentary support for the withdrawal deal, and her efforts to negotiate with opposition leader Jeremy Corbyn have been unsuccessful. The UK's economic and financial markets have remained relatively stable despite the uncertainty, with the pound holding above its post-2016 referendum low.

site_title: Wynn drops takeover talks for Australia's Crown Resorts
summary: US casino giant Wynn Resorts has dropped its takeover talks with Australia's Crown Resorts, just hours after the discussions were made public. The talks, valued at A$9.99 billion, were ended due to the premature disclosure of preliminary discussions. Analysts described the move as "purely defensive" and Wall Street had expressed skepticism about the potential deal. Wynn shares fell 4.7% in New York, while Crown's shares rose 20% in Sydney. The deal would have marked an end to Crown's 47% owner James Packer's 12-year foray into casinos and given Wynn a foothold in a market popular with Chinese tourists.

site_title: SPH growth strategy on track, even as Q2 profits slip
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) reported its second-quarter profits were lower, but its growth strategy remains on track, according to CEO Ng Yat Chung. The group's non-media businesses, digital revenues, and aged care segment showed positive momentum, offsetting a decline in print revenues. This strategy aims to diversify the company's income streams and adapt to the changing media landscape. Despite the profit dip, SPH's growth strategy is expected to continue, driving the company's future prospects.

site_title: CapLand to build on S$11b ASB deal in Singapore, China, India, Vietnam
summary: CapitaLand, a Singapore-based property giant, plans to acquire industrial and commercial real estate player Ascendas-Singbridge (ASB) from Temasek Holdings for S$11 billion. The deal aims to expand CapitaLand's exposure in industries such as logistics and business parks. The proposed acquisition will enable CapitaLand to cross-sell across various asset classes and countries, further solidifying its position in the global property market. The deal is set to be presented to shareholders for approval on Friday.

site_title: Beyond 'Love Island': TV crosses a new sex frontier
summary: Television is pushing boundaries with new shows that explore intimate topics, including sex, relationships, and family dynamics. Shows like "Mums Make Porn," "Parental Guidance," "Family or Fiance," and "21 Again" feature parents, partners, and families navigating sensitive issues. The BBC's "Sex On the Couch" and "Dance Therapy" also delve into relationships and intimacy. These formats aim to spark conversations and help viewers address their own relationships and sex lives, blurring the lines between reality TV and therapy.

site_title: Jaguar starts high-end rentals in London to travel in style
summary: Jaguar Land Rover has launched an app, 'The Out', allowing Londoners to rent high-end vehicles, including 50 Land Rover Discovery Sports, delivered directly to their front doors. The service caters to a premium market with specific car needs, such as weddings or festivals. This is part of Jaguar's push into new services, following similar moves by peers like Volvo and Mercedes-Benz. The company aims to target car-less Londoners, where car ownership is rare, with 41% of households in the capital owning no vehicle.

site_title: Investors tiptoe as equity rally stretches on
summary: Investors are cautiously optimistic about the ongoing equity rally, with the MSCI Asia Pacific Index rising 2% in April, its strongest first quarter since 2012. The Shanghai Composite Index has surged 30% this year, rebounding from last year's losses. However, a disconnect between retail investors and market returns is growing, with weak fund flows and a decline in investor participation. Earnings reports from major US companies, including JPMorgan Chase and Wells Fargo, are expected to be a concern, particularly in the technology sector. Despite this, strategists believe the US and global economy will recover from the second quarter of 2019.

site_title: Israelis consider 'King Bibi' vs 'Bibi fatigue'
summary: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is set to face a record fifth term or potential dethronement in an election that may not be decided immediately. Netanyahu, dubbed "King Bibi," has rallied a rightist camp, but critics warn of "Bibi fatigue" and argue for fresh faces in high office. Centrist candidate Benny Gantz, a former chief of the armed forces, has gained popularity, promising clean government and social cohesion. After the election, Israel's president will consult party leaders to form a government, potentially ending Netanyahu's 13-year rule.

site_title: Wynn ends deal talks with Crown Resorts
summary: Wynn Resorts Ltd terminated takeover discussions with Australia's Crown Resorts after preliminary talks were prematurely disclosed. Crown Resorts reported Wynn made an A$10 billion (S$9.6 billion) takeover approach. Wynn's shares dropped 3.2% following the announcement. The deal talks were halted due to the premature disclosure, and both companies have ended discussions.

site_title: China promises EU companies equal treatment
summary: Chinese Premier Li Keqiang promised EU companies equal treatment, pledging to stop forcing foreign companies to share sensitive know-how in China and addressing industrial subsidies. This marks a significant shift, following similar offers to the US, and was welcomed by EU leaders as a breakthrough. Li also agreed to set up a dispute mechanism and engage in discussions on WTO reform, addressing EU concerns over Chinese dominance in strategic industries.

images.alt_text: European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker (L) and Chinese Premier Li Keqiang attend a signature ceremony between EU and China at the European Council in Brussels, Belgium. Mr Li promised his European Union hosts on Tuesday that Beijing will no longer force foreign companies to share sensitive know-how when operating in China and was ready to address industrial subsidies.

site_title: StarMed Specialist Centre provides one-stop ambulatory care
summary: HMI Group's regional growth strategy is being implemented through the establishment of StarMed Specialist Centre in Singapore, a one-stop ambulatory care centre. Ms Chin Wei Jia, Group CEO, spearheaded the project to provide high-quality, cost-effective, and convenient healthcare services. This move aligns with the global trend of ambulatory care, offering a comfortable experience for patients and their families. StarMed is part of HMI's regional presence in Singapore, Malaysia, and Indonesia, further solidifying the company's position in the private healthcare sector.

site_title: Yahoo strikes US$117.5m data breach settlement after earlier accord rejected
summary: Yahoo has agreed to a US$117.5 million settlement with millions of people affected by the largest data breach in history, which exposed 3 billion accounts from 2013 to 2016. The settlement includes US$55 million for out-of-pocket expenses, US$24 million for credit monitoring, and up to US$30 million for legal fees. The deal covers 194 million people in the US and Israel, and Verizon, Yahoo's parent company, has agreed to spend US$306 million on information security between 2019 and 2022.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 2.41 points to 1,641.94. The decline followed a 5-day rally, with losers beating gainers 430 to 390. Total volume was 3.5 billion lots worth RM2.4 billion.

site_title: Positioning Singapore's maritime sector for the future
summary: Singapore's maritime sector is facing challenges and needs to boost other sectors of the shipping economy to remain a leading global maritime hub. The country's Minister for Trade and Industry, Chan Chun Sing, emphasized the need for Singapore to rethink its maritime strategy and navigate the challenges of rising protectionism, technological changes, and climate change. To succeed, Singapore must foster a multifaceted connectivity that includes data, talent, technology, and finance flows, and defend an open, rule-based trading order.

site_title: Ford likely to end independent India business with new Mahindra deal
summary: Ford is nearing a deal with Mahindra & Mahindra to form a new joint-venture company in India, which will likely see Ford cease independent operations in the country. Ford has invested over $2 billion in India but has struggled to gain market share, currently holding 3%. Under the deal, Ford will hold a 49% stake, while Mahindra will own 51%. The transaction is expected to close within 90 days and will transfer Ford's Indian automotive business to the new entity, including assets and employees.

site_title: Ascott bags contracts to manage 14 properties across 8 countries
summary: The Ascott Ltd, a serviced residence arm of CapitaLand, has secured contracts to manage 14 properties with over 2,000 units across eight countries. Three new properties under the co-living "lyf" brand will be added in Fukuoka, Japan, Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, and Shanghai, China, targeting millennials. This marks the company's first foray into Changchun, China, and its entry into Germany with the 100-unit Ascott Riverpark Tower Frankfurt. The new properties are expected to open in 2020 and 2022, further expanding Ascott's presence in Asia-Pacific, Europe, and the Middle East.

site_title: SPH reports lower Q2 net profit
summary: SPH, a Singapore-based media and property company, reported a 25.7% year-on-year decline in Q2 net profit to S$29.69 million, driven by lower revenue and a fair-value change on investment properties. Operating revenue fell 4.4% to S$223.33 million, while operating expenses decreased 5.6%. Despite this, digital revenue grew 13.1% and the property segment saw a 15.3% increase in revenue. The company declared an interim dividend of 5.5 Singapore cents per share.

site_title: Principal Financial to buy Wells Fargo's retirement unit for US$1.2b
summary: Principal Financial Group to buy Wells Fargo's retirement unit for US$1.2 billion, gaining a strong foothold in mid-sized employer markets. The deal includes an earnout of up to US$150 million and is expected to add US$425 million in annual net revenue. The acquisition will serve 7.5 million US retirement customers and integrate in 2022. The deal is financed with cash and debt, adding to net income and adjusted earnings per share in 2020.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's top-performing stocks, including Hi-P International and SBS Transit, have returned 49% year-to-date. The country is set to start talks on maritime boundary delimitation with Malaysia within a month. Meanwhile, Hyflux's default has raised concerns about the Singapore bond market, and CapitaLand's acquisition of Ascendas-Singbridge may see a 50:50 cash and share mix. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed 0.3% up at 3,325.60, while the global market looks on with news of slowing China's GDP growth and the UK economy shrinking for the second month.

site_title: Australian shares flat amid caution ahead of US earnings; NZ falls
summary: Australian shares remained flat on Tuesday, closing 0.4 point or 0.01% higher at 6,221.8, amid caution ahead of the US earnings season. Financials slipped 0.3%, while energy stocks rose 2% to a two-week high. New Zealand's benchmark index fell 0.2% as investors braced for potential earnings weakness. Analysts attribute the cautious mood to macro issues including US-China trade talks and declining earnings expectations.

site_title: Aramco to issue US$12b of bonds amid unprecedented demand
summary: Saudi Aramco is issuing $12 billion in bonds, the most oversubscribed debt deal of all time, with investor orders exceeding $100 billion. The debt sale, managed by JPMorgan Chase & Co. and others, will raise funds to finance Saudi Arabia's economic agenda after the kingdom's initial public offering was postponed. The 30-year bond yields 155 basis points over US Treasuries, allowing Aramco to pay less for its debt than the Saudi government, a rare occurrence for a state-owned entity. This marks a comeback for Saudi Arabia after being shunned by investors last year.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close flat as Sony soars on fund stake report
summary: Tokyo stocks closed flat, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.19% to 21,802.59, ahead of key events including the EU summit and IMF growth forecast. Sony surged 9.26% to 5,250 yen on a report that US hedge fund Third Point plans to increase its investment in the company, aiming to raise $500-1 billion. Investors are shifting focus to earnings releases from major Japanese firms, particularly those affected by the US-China trade war.

site_title: Europe: Stocks edge lower as threat of US tariffs hits Airbus, suppliers
summary: European stocks edged lower on Tuesday, with Airbus and suppliers taking a hit from proposed US tariffs, weighing down the pan-European STOXX 600 index by 0.07%. Airbus shares dropped 2.5% after the US Trade Representative proposed tariffs on European Union products, including large commercial aircraft and parts. Meanwhile, Total SA rose after signing a deal with Papua New Guinea to start work on a US$13 billion liquefied natural gas project.

site_title: IMF cuts global growth outlook to lowest since financial crisis
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has cut its global growth outlook to 3.3% for 2019, the lowest since the 2009 financial crisis, due to weaker growth in major advanced economies and higher tariffs weighing on trade. This marks the third downgrade in six months. The IMF's previous forecast for 2019 was 3.5%.

site_title: BreadTalk Group acquires strategic interest in NPPG (Thailand) Public Company
summary: BreadTalk Group acquired a strategic interest in NPPG (Thailand) Public Company, purchasing 380 million shares at 1.50 Thai Baht per share, equivalent to a 15% stake. The acquisition will be completed in two tranches, with BTG initially assuming two seats on NPPG's board. The deal is expected to provide BreadTalk with a distribution network and access to the Thai market, complementing its existing presence in the region. The total cost of the acquisition is approximately 570 million Baht (S$24.16 million).

site_title: China plans to ban cryptocurrency mining in renewed clampdown
summary: China's National Development Reform Commission plans to ban cryptocurrency mining due to concerns over resource waste and environmental pollution. The move, which could take effect as soon as May 7, comes after a two-year campaign to curb the industry amid concerns over speculative bubbles, fraud, and energy consumption. The ban affects an industry that was once home to 70% of Bitcoin mining and 90% of trades, with many miners shifting to the US and Canada. The decision is part of a broader crackdown on the crypto industry, following previous bans on initial coin offerings and virtual currency trading.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end with more gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.27% to close at 30,157.49, building on previous day's gains, as investors await the release of Federal Reserve minutes. The Shanghai Composite Index dipped 0.16%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.72%. The gains come despite ongoing US-EU trade tensions and uncertainty surrounding Trump's tariff threats.

site_title: Singapore shares add 0.3% on Tuesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.3% on Tuesday, closing at 3,325.60, driven by optimism over Chinese economic growth measures. Despite US-China trade concerns and a lackluster earnings season, 22 of 30 blue chips in the index ended in the black. The gains followed a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data and came as traders brushed off new Trump threats to extend the stocks rally.

site_title: Lenders take control at UK department store Debenhams
summary: UK department store chain Debenhams has been taken over by lenders after falling into administration, marking the latest high street retailer to struggle with fierce online competition, rising business property taxes, and Brexit uncertainty. Lenders will inject £200 million ($354.2 million) into the business, allowing it to continue trading as normal and proceed with turnaround plans. The move wipes out the stakes held by all shareholders, including a last-gasp takeover bid from tycoon Mike Ashley.

images.alt_text: British department store chain Debenhams has been taken over by lenders after falling into administration, it said Tuesday, amid tough times on the UK high street.

site_title: In first public address, Ghosn says he is innocent and victim of backstabbing
summary: Carlos Ghosn, the ousted Nissan boss, made his first public address, stating he is innocent and a victim of backstabbing and conspiracy. He accused former colleagues of plotting against him, fearing he would bring Nissan closer to Renault SA. Ghosn claimed he was not motivated by greed, but by a desire to merge the companies. He was re-arrested on fresh allegations of using company funds to enrich himself, with prosecutors accusing him of embezzling US$5 million.

site_title: Keppel to develop its first autonomous vessel for operations in Singapore
summary: Keppel Offshore & Marine (Keppel O&M) is developing Singapore's first autonomous vessel, a tugboat, in partnership with the Maritime Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) and Technology Centre for Offshore and Marine, Singapore (TCOMS). The project, valued at up to S$2 million, aims to be completed by 4Q 2020. The tug will be equipped with advanced systems, including digital pilot vision, collision detection, and remote control capabilities, and will be operated by Keppel Smit Towage. The project marks a significant step forward in Singapore's maritime industry innovation.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower on worries over trade, earnings
summary: Wall Street's main indexes opened lower on Tuesday, as trade concerns resurfaced and investors braced for the first quarterly earnings contraction since 2016. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 97.48 points, or 0.37%, to 26,243.54, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also dropped, with the S&P 500 down 9.19 points, or 0.32%, and the Nasdaq down 29.11 points, or 0.37%.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Tuesday afternoon at 3,318.88, up 0.1% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Tuesday, opening 0.1% higher at 3,318.88, driven by gains from Ying Li International Real Estate and AusGroup. Losers outnumbered gainers 169 to 147, with 624.4 million securities worth S$500.5 million changing hands. Key gainers included OCBC Bank (0.2%) and DBS Group Holdings (0.5%).

site_title: Seletar Aerospace Park to offer indoor testbeds for commercial use of drones
summary: JTC and the Association of Aerospace Industries Singapore (AAIS) have announced indoor testbeds within Seletar Aerospace Park for commercial drone use. The indoor spaces will provide a safe environment for companies to conduct trials and demonstrations. The initiative aims to support the development and commercialization of drone technologies, particularly in smart cities, security, agriculture, and resource management. Companies can register their interest through AAIS. This move is expected to catalyze industry partnerships in Singapore.

site_title: Singapore, Malaysia to start talks on maritime boundary delimitation within a month
summary: Singapore and Malaysia will begin negotiations on delimiting their maritime boundaries within a month, following measures to de-escalate tensions at sea. The two countries have suspended overlapping port limits and ceased anchoring government vessels in the area. They also agreed to work together on sustainable water supply, airspace issues, and connectivity projects, including the cross-border rail link project. The leaders reaffirmed their commitment to a cooperative bilateral relationship, citing strong family and business ties between the two nations.

site_title: 50:50 cash and share mix for Ascendas-Singbridge most prudent: CapitaLand CEO
summary: CapitaLand CEO Lee Chee Koon said a 50:50 cash and share mix for the S$11 billion acquisition of Ascendas-Singbridge is the most prudent approach, avoiding over-gearing and a potential stock discount. This approach was chosen over a potential rights issue to shareholders, which would have required a 20-25% discount. The deal is part of CapitaLand's acquisition of Ascendas-Singbridge from Temasek Holdings.

site_title: 5 best-performing billionaire stocks returned 49% year to date: SGX
summary: The Singapore Exchange reported that the top 5 billionaire stocks in Singapore have returned 49.0% year-to-date, with Hi-P International leading at 89.8%. The top 10 worst-performing stocks averaged a -9.1% return. 36 billionaire stocks have dividend yields of 4.5% or higher, with 28 being Reits and 8 being companies. The highest-yielding Reits include Hutchison Port Holdings trust and Netlink NBN Trust, while the highest-yielding companies include StarHub and Singtel.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks flat at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened flat on Tuesday morning, following a tepid lead from Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index inched down 11.16 points to 30,065.99, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also edged down. Investors await developments in the China-US trade talks, contributing to the flat market.

site_title: Joo Chiat freehold commercial building up for sale with S$20m indicative price
summary: A freehold four-storey commercial building at 118 Joo Chiat Road in Singapore has been launched for sale with an indicative price of S$20 million (S$1,077 per sq ft). The property sits on a 4,686 sq ft site zoned for commercial use and features a mechanical car park. The site is a 10-minute walk from Paya Lebar and Eunos MRT stations, and the expression of interest exercise closes on May 14, 2019.

site_title: Ascott bags contracts to manage 14 properties across 8 countries
summary: The Ascott Ltd, a serviced residence arm of CapitaLand, has secured contracts to manage 14 properties across 8 countries with over 2,000 units. The properties include 3 new lyf co-living properties in Fukuoka, Japan; Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia; and Shanghai, China. Ascott aims to expand its presence in Asia Pacific, Europe, and the Middle East, with a target of 160,000 units by 2023. The company expects strong demand for its lyf-branded co-living properties, driven by the growing millennial generation.

site_title: Singapore PM says 1962 Water Agreement 'sacrosanct'; both sides to seek amicable solution
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the 1962 Water Agreement as a "sacrosanct" document, stating that changing it would be a "very high hurdle." He acknowledged Malaysia's desire to review the price of water under the agreement, but expressed Singapore's perspective on its importance. Both leaders agreed to seek amicable solutions, including arbitration, to address concerns over the Johor River's pollution and water yield, and will discuss this issue through their attorneys-general. They aim to find a constructive way forward to manage their water relationships.

site_title: Travel booking startup Klook bags US$225m in Series D+ funds
summary: Klook, a travel activities and services booking platform, secured US$225 million in Series D+ funding led by SoftBank Vision Fund, bringing its total Series D round fundraise to US$425 million. The company plans to use the funds to scale its operations into new geographical locations, expand in its existing Asian markets, particularly in Japan ahead of the 2020 Summer Olympics, and deepen its investments in the Japanese market. Klook, which achieved unicorn status last year, employs over 1,000 staff across 20 offices worldwide and has raised over US$520 million from investors.

site_title: China Aircraft Leasing says has not put Boeing 737 Max order on hold
summary: China Aircraft Leasing Group Holdings Ltd (CALC) has not put its order for 100 Boeing 737 Max jets on hold, contrary to a report by the South China Morning Post. CALC chairman Chen Shuang was misquoted, and the Hong Kong-listed lessor has not stopped payment, but deliveries are currently on hold. The company's chief executive, Mike Poon, confirmed this in an updated statement, clarifying the situation.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 0.81 points to 1,645.16 at 9:01am on Tuesday, driven by a 130-54 gainer-to-loser ratio. The market opened higher with 107.2 million lots traded at RM42.88 million.

site_title: Hong Kong "Occupy" protest leaders found guilty for role in mass rallies
summary: A Hong Kong court found three leaders of the 2014 "Occupy" civil disobedience movement guilty of conspiracy to commit public nuisance for their role in mass protests. Benny Tai, Chan Kin-man, and retired pastor Chu Yiu-ming were convicted in a trial that comes as the city's civil liberties face mounting pressure. The guilty verdict was handed down amidst growing concerns over the erosion of freedoms in Hong Kong.

site_title: Asia: Markets struggle as traders await catalysts
summary: Asian markets struggled on Tuesday due to a lack of catalysts, with traders waiting for developments in the China-US trade talks and an upcoming EU summit. The US threatened tariffs on billions of dollars' worth of European goods, while the pound remains stable despite Brexit uncertainty. Oil prices rose to six-month highs, boosted by hopes for the China-US talks and output cuts. Earnings season kicked off, with expectations low but observers hoping for positive forward guidance.

site_title: Hmlet snags former CPIB headquarters as its largest co-living space in Singapore
summary: Hmlet, a Singapore-based co-living company, has signed a new property in Tanjong Pagar, its largest co-living space to date. The 150-room serviced apartment unit will open in July, increasing its member count to over 2,400 by year-end. The former CPIB headquarters, now located at 150 Cantonment Road, has been renovated and will feature amenities such as a swimming pool, gym, and in-house cafe. The property is part of the Singapore Land Authority's public tender and marks a growing trend of co-living options in Singapore.

site_title: US judge blocks Trump policy of returning asylum seekers to Mexico
summary: A US federal judge blocked President Donald Trump's policy of returning asylum seekers to Mexico to wait out the processing of their cases, saying the Department of Homeland Security overstepped its authority. The ruling, effective Friday, comes after several hundred people were returned to Mexico under the Migrant Protection Protocols. Rights groups welcomed the decision, citing inadequate safeguards for asylum seekers. The ruling was a rebuke to the Trump administration's efforts to stop migrant flow and can be appealed.

site_title: Surbana Jurong partners AeroLion Technologies to develop drone solutions
summary: Surbana Jurong, an urban and infrastructure consultancy, has partnered with drone startup AeroLion Technologies to develop drone solutions for built and natural environments. The partnership aims to integrate drone solutions into Surbana Jurong's processes to raise productivity and offer advanced data-driven solutions to its global clients. The solutions will be developed for applications such as land reclamation, workplace safety, and fault detection in enclosed areas. The partnership will combine operational data with the drone's artificial intelligence platforms.

site_title: CME bitcoin futures volume hits record high as prices rebound
summary: CME Group Inc's bitcoin futures contract trading volume reached a record high of 22,542 contracts on April 4, equivalent to 112,710 bitcoin with a notional value of US$546 million. This surge in trading volume followed a 30% increase in bitcoin prices over the previous two trading days. The increased interest in bitcoin futures comes after rival CBOE Global Markets Inc reviewed its approach to cryptocurrency derivatives and decided not to list more contracts. The record-breaking trading volume highlights a renewed interest in the cryptocurrency market.

site_title: Developers China Evergrande, Sunac issue 4th dollar bonds in 6 months
summary: China Evergrande Group and Sunac China Holdings issued $2 billion and $750 million in senior notes, respectively, in the fourth dollar bond issuance in six months. The dollar bond market has seen a surge in Chinese property developers' issuance due to a broad stock market rally and lower interest rate expectations. Evergrande's bonds have coupon rates of 9.5%, 10%, and 10.5% for three, four, and five-year terms.

site_title: Hot stock: Hi-P shares down 7.4% following Maybank Kim Eng's downgrade to 'sell'
summary: Hi-P International shares dropped 7.4% in early trading after Maybank Kim Eng downgraded the stock to "sell" with a target price of S$1.22, citing it as overvalued compared to global peers. The downgrade comes as the contract manufacturer faces downside risks to S$1.46 and potentially lower prices to S$1.28-1.32.

site_title: March resales of private non-landed homes highest since July 2018 cooling measures: SRX
summary: Singapore's private resale property market saw its largest recovery in activity since July 2018, with 830 units sold in March, a 59.3% jump from February. Resale prices rose 0.1% in March, bringing them 3.5% higher than a year ago. The market's resilience was attributed to the impact of new project launches, particularly in outlying areas, which spurred buying interest in the secondary market.

images.alt_text: Meanwhile, the resale prices of condominiums and private apartments edged up 0.1 per cent rise in March from the previous month, for a third straight month-on-month increase.

site_title: A China hedge fund manager is betting big on floating flamingos
summary: A China hedge fund manager, Jen Lai, is betting big on Hong Kong-listed Bestway Global Holding Inc., a maker of swimming pool flamingos and bouncy castles. Lai's firm, Dalton Investments, has bought more shares of Bestway after discovering the stock in 2018, citing its growth potential and low analyst coverage. The stock's profit may increase by 22% this year and 18% in 2020, according to analysts. Lai believes in the long-term growth of China's economy and sees Bestway as a promising investment opportunity.

site_title: Sony shares surge after Reuters reports Third Point building stake again
summary: Sony shares surged over 7% in early trade after Reuters reported that hedge fund Third Point LLC, led by Daniel Loeb, was building a stake in the Japanese electronics conglomerate to push for changes. Third Point aims to raise $500-$1 billion for a dedicated investment vehicle to buy more Sony shares. The move comes as investors seek Sony's next profit pillar, amid concerns over its gaming business and the near-end of its PlayStation 4 console lifecycle.

site_title: Annica auditor qualifies opinion on recoverability of S$1.6m due from disposal of business unit
summary: The auditor of Annica Holdings, Baker Tilly, has qualified its opinion on the recoverability of S$1.6 million due from the disposal of a business unit. The receivable is secured by a charge over shares and a personal guarantee, but the auditor was unable to obtain sufficient evidence to determine the expected credit loss. Annica's financial statements, except for this matter, were found to be true and fair. The company has received two tranches of payments and is considering enforcing the security if the remaining payment is not made.

site_title: As time catches up with rock's greats, can the genre survive?
summary: Rock music is facing a decline in popularity and relevance, with many of its legends passing away or struggling with health issues. Despite the presence of new bands, such as The Black Keys and The Killers, rock groups failed to occupy a spot in the top 10 of 2018's most-streamed acts, according to Nielsen Music. The influential festival scene has also shifted its focus away from rock, with Coachella and other festivals featuring more pop, rap, and electro acts. However, some argue that rock's influence will live on, and that its spirit will continue to inspire new generations of artists.

site_title: Hyflux default signals more trouble ahead for Singapore bond market: S&P
summary: S&P Global Ratings warns of potential financial distress in Singapore's bond market, citing Hyflux's default as a "first wagon in a train of financial distress cases." The credit agency notes that lending conditions are becoming less favorable due to the economic slowdown, and investors are becoming more selective. With close to S$4 billion of Singapore-dollar corporate bonds maturing by the end of 2019, S&P estimates that more defaults could occur in Singapore over the next 12-18 months, particularly among smaller companies with high leverage and short-term debt.

site_title: China to begin product safety crackdown following Jiangsu blasts
summary: China has launched a nationwide inspection of industrial product safety, focusing on high-risk products and systemic safety risks. The campaign, which will last until October, aims to ensure quality and safety of major industrial products, maintaining social stability and promoting economic development. Firms found incapable of making required rectifications will have their operation licenses revoked. The move follows two deadly blasts in Jiangsu province that killed 85 people, putting China's chemical industry under intense scrutiny.

site_title: Anchor Resources proposes S$2.2m share placement for bond repayment
summary: ANCHOR Resources is raising S$2.2 million through a S$2.15 million share placement at S$0.0153 apiece to 18 subscribers, including investor Tan Ong Huat, to repay debts. The issue price represents a 10% discount to the company's volume weighted average price. The funds will be used to redeem S$1.655 million of bonds held by Tan and to repay other investors. The placement will withdraw an earlier plan to draw down a redeemable equity-linked notes facility, citing the need for fundraising and improving the company's financial position.

site_title: Head of US Secret Service to quit job: White House
summary: The US Secret Service head, Randolph 'Tex' Alles, is stepping down, with President Trump selecting James M. Murray as his replacement. Alles, a former Marine general, denied being pushed out, but no reason was given for his sudden departure. Murray will take over as director in May.

site_title: US proposes new tariffs on EU products over Airbus subsidies: statement
summary: The US has proposed new tariffs on European Union products in response to subsidies received by aircraft maker Airbus. The US Trade Representative's office stated that the World Trade Organization had repeatedly found EU subsidies to Airbus to cause adverse effects on the US. This move comes after 14 years of litigation, with US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer saying "the time has come for action." The proposed tariffs are a countermeasure to the EU's own tariffs on US products.

site_title: Three words to help avoid the tragedy of mistaking a killer's car for your Uber
summary: A South Carolina college student, Samantha Josephson, was murdered after mistaking a killer's car for her Uber. To avoid such tragedies, experts recommend that students make "What's my name?" a habit when getting into ride-hailing vehicles. The policy aims to improve safety, following a series of similar attacks in the US, and a proposed law requires ride-hailing drivers to display illuminated signs when in service. By asking the driver's name, students can verify the driver's identity and potentially avoid harm.

site_title: Brexit clock fails to faze pound traders
summary: The UK currency, pound, is up on Monday, with a gauge of expected short-term sterling volatility near a two-week low, despite the looming Brexit deadline. Investors are increasingly confident that Britain will secure an extension, and the market has taken it as a given that Parliament will block Brexit. Sterling has gained over 2% this year and reached a nine-month high of $1.3381 in March, with the possibility of a return to these levels if an extension is granted.

site_title: UOB prices US$600m 3.75% notes due 2029
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) priced its US$600 million subordinated notes due 2029 at 99.657% of principal, with a 3.75% interest rate payable semi-annually. The notes are intended as Tier 2 regulatory capital and are expected to be rated A2 by Moody's, BBB+ by Standard & Poor's, and A+ by Fitch. The first call date is April 15, 2024, and maturity date is April 15, 2029. The notes will be listed on the Singapore Exchange Securities Trading.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Tuesday, STI up 0.16% to 3,320.78
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Tuesday, advancing 5.36 points, or 0.16%, to 3,320.78 as at 9:02am. Gainers outnumbered losers 70 to 61, with about 50.9 million shares worth S$74.9 million changing hands. Ying Li International Real Estate led the gains, up 0.72%, followed by Rex International, which rose 1.25%.

site_title: Oil gains up to 2% to five-month high as Libyan output threatened
summary: Oil prices surged up to 2% on Monday, reaching a five-month high, amid concerns over Libya's oil output being threatened by fighting. Global supplies are expected to tighten due to Opec-led cuts and US sanctions on Iran and Venezuela. Brent futures rose 76 cents to $71.10 a barrel, while WTI crude futures gained $1.32 to $64.40 a barrel. Market analysts attribute the price increase to the potential supply crunch and the ongoing supply cuts by Opec and its allies.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower as investors take to sidelines
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on April 9, 2019, as investors took to the sidelines ahead of key EU summit and European Central Bank meeting. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.08% to 21,744.72, while the Topix index declined 0.23% to 1,616.41. Investors were cautious due to uncertainty surrounding US-EU trade talks and global economic events.

site_title: US man allegedly planned to drive van into crowd
summary: A US man, Rondell Henry, 28, allegedly planned to drive a stolen cargo van into a crowd at a casino complex, inspired by the Islamic State group. He was arrested on March 28 at the National Harbor complex after stealing the van on March 26. Henry told investigators he wanted to create "panic and chaos" similar to the 2016 truck attack in Nice, France. He faces up to 10 years in prison for interstate transportation of a stolen vehicle, but it's unclear if terror-related charges will be issued.

site_title: AMC greenlights third series in 'The Walking Dead' universe
summary: AMC has greenlit a third series in "The Walking Dead" universe, set to premiere in 2020, focusing on the first generation to come of age during the zombie apocalypse. The new series will feature two young female protagonists and will begin production in Virginia this summer. This follows the success of the original show and its spinoff "Fear the Walking Dead," which drew 17 million viewers at its peak. The new series will be the third installment in the universe, with AMC committing to a tenth season of the original show.

site_title: France's Societe Generale to cut 1,600 jobs: unions
summary: French banking giant Societe Generale plans to cut 1,600 jobs, mainly in its BFI corporate and investment banking arm, with 700 cuts in France. The job cuts will be made through voluntary departures, following a plan to reduce costs by 500 million euros by 2020. The bank reported higher-than-expected profits in 2018 but anticipates financial headwinds ahead, leading to the adjustments.

site_title: UK lords approve Brexit law forcing May to consult parliament on delay
summary: The UK House of Lords approved legislation allowing parliament to scrutinise and potentially change Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit delay request to June 30. The bill, despite government opposition, will now return to the House of Commons for further consideration. This move gives parliament more control over the Brexit process, potentially delaying the UK's departure from the EU.

site_title: US 'not satisfied yet' in China trade talks: White House official
summary: US officials, citing a top White House trade official, say progress was made in talks with China on a trade deal, but issues remain, including industrial subsidies, technology transfer, and intellectual property rights. The US is pressing China to address these concerns, and the two sides have agreed on an enforcement structure to ensure Beijing keeps promises. A deal could be reached in about four weeks, according to President Trump, but no specific timeline has been set.

site_title: Hong Kong democracy leaders await Umbrella Movement verdict
summary: Three Hong Kong democracy leaders, Chan Kin-man, Benny Tai, and Chu Yiu-ming, await a verdict on Tuesday on charges of public nuisance for their involvement in the 2014 Umbrella Movement protests. The charges carry up to seven-year jail terms and have been described as politically motivated by human rights groups. The trial has sparked renewed alarm over shrinking political freedoms in Hong Kong under China's increasing assertiveness. The outcome could have a chilling effect on free speech in the city, with Amnesty International warning that it could silence debate on democracy and autonomy.

site_title: Pinterest seeks up to US$1.28 billion in IPO
summary: Pinterest Inc is seeking up to $1.28 billion in its initial public offering, offering 75 million shares for $15-$17 each. The company's valuation is below its last private valuation of $12.3 billion in 2017. Pinterest, which has 265 million monthly users, reported $756 million in ad revenue in 2018, a 60% growth rate. The IPO, led by Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan Chase, aims to capitalize on the hot US market for IPOs this year, following companies like Lyft and Snap Inc.

site_title: Stocks to watch: OUE, OUE C-Reit, UOB, Tuan Sing Holdings
summary: OUE Limited and OUE C-Reit announced a merger on Monday, creating a S$6.8 billion diversified Reit. OUE C-Reit will pay S$0.04075 cash and issue 1.3583 new units for each OUE Hospitality Trust (OUE H-Trust) stapled security. The deal valuation is S$1.49 billion, with S$74.6 million in cash and the balance paid by issuing new units at S$0.57 per unit. The merger is expected to be completed by the end of the year.

site_title: SoftBank backs startup pioneering hyper-accurate weather reports
summary: SoftBank is investing $7 million in Boston-based startup ClimaCell, which uses wireless signals, cameras, drones, and more to provide hyper-accurate weather forecasts. The investment aims to speed deployment of ClimaCell's "microweather" system, addressing the issue of inaccurate forecasts affecting power generators and grids. This move comes as electrical grids struggle with the implications of mounting wind and solar power. ClimaCell previously closed a $45 million Series B funding round and was founded in 2015, with CEO Shimon Elkabetz citing outdated technology as the reason for poor weather forecasts.

site_title: Uber scientist says some time before self-driving cars dominate the road
summary: Uber's self-driving car unit chief scientist Raquel Urtasun says it will take a long time for self-driving cars to dominate the road, but the technology will save lives. Despite facing setbacks, including a pedestrian death in Arizona, Uber is investing millions in Toronto to expand its self-driving car operations. A group of investors is in talks to invest $1 billion or more into the unit, which could lead to a valuation of up to $120 billion in Uber's IPO. The technology is expected to save lives, but the transition to autonomous vehicles will take time.

site_title: US: Stocks end mixed as market awaits earnings season
summary: US stocks ended mixed on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.3% at 26,341.02. The S&P 500 edged up 0.1% to 2,895.77, while the Nasdaq Composite Index gained 0.2% to 7,953.88. The start of first-quarter earnings season is expected to bring low expectations, which some analysts believe could boost stocks if companies outperform. Other key events this week include a Brexit summit and a policy announcement by the European Central Bank.

site_title: Australia's Crown Resorts gets US$7.1b takeover approach from Wynn Resorts
summary: Crown Resorts in Australia receives a US$7.1 billion takeover approach from Wynn Resorts, with an implied value of A$14.75 per share. The proposal includes half cash and half Wynn shares. Crown shares rose 21% following the announcement, with the potential sale fetching A$4.7 billion for former executive chairman James Packer. The discussions are at a preliminary stage, and no agreement has been reached yet.

images.alt_text: Australia's Crown Resorts said on Tuesday it was in talks with Las Vegas rival Wynn Resorts about a potential A$10 billion (S$9.65 billion) buyout, sending Crown shares up more than a fifth.

site_title: US bars entry to 16 Saudis over Khashoggi killing: Pompeo
summary: The US State Department barred entry to 16 Saudi nationals over their alleged role in the murder of journalist Jamal Khashoggi, citing Section 7031(c) of the Department of State Appropriations Act. The individuals were designated for their involvement in significant corruption or human rights violations. This move comes as the Trump administration faces pressure from Congress over its response to the killing in the Saudi consulate in Istanbul last October. The US previously revoked visas for nearly two dozen Saudi officials and froze assets for 17 others, with much of the case remaining shrouded in mystery.

images.alt_text: The announcement by Secretary of State Mike Pompeo comes as the administration of President Donald Trump has faced pressure from Congress over its response to the killing in the Saudi consulate in Istanbul last October, which sparked unprecedented international scrutiny of the kingdom's human rights record.

site_title: Korean Air chairman dies weeks after ouster from board
summary: Korean Air chairman and CEO Cho Yang-ho, 70, died of a chronic illness weeks after being ousted from the airline's board due to perceived leadership failings. His death led to a surge in airline and holding company shares, with investors seeking better governance under new management or a younger generation of the Cho family. Cho's 17.8% stake in Hanjin Kal, the holding company for parent Hanjin Group, is up for grabs, potentially sparking a bidding war. His son, Cho Won-tae, is seen as his likely successor, but a South Korean activist fund is also vying for control.

site_title: Canada hails Facebook ban on far-right figures
summary: Canada's Immigration Minister Ahmed Hussen praised Facebook's decision to ban prominent far-right activists following renewed scrutiny over the platform's handling of hate groups. Facebook banned individuals and groups deemed white supremacist and inciting violence, including Faith Goldy and Kevin Goudreau. The move comes after the Christchurch mosque attacks and Pittsburgh synagogue shooting, where hate speech was linked to the violence. Facebook stated that individuals spreading hate have no place on the platform, citing a policy against organized hate. The ban aims to prevent the spread of hate speech and violence online.

site_title: Pinterest seeks up to US$1.28b in IPO, below 2017 value
summary: Pinterest Inc is seeking up to $1.28 billion in its US initial public offering (IPO), valuing the company below its 2017 valuation of $12.3 billion. The company is offering 75 million shares for $15 to $17 each, with a potential market valuation of around $9 billion if priced at the top of the range. Pinterest reported $756 million in ad revenue in 2018, a 60% growth rate, and a net loss of $63 million in 2018. The IPO is led by Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan Chase, and Allen & Co, and is influenced by slowing US growth and the recent Lyft IPO.

site_title: Japan investors look to switch from Europe, flock to US bonds
summary: Japanese investors are shifting their focus from European bonds to US debt, driven by concerns over a potential US recession and falling yields. European bond yields have fallen to zero percent, while US bond yields remain higher, offering potential gains for investors. Japanese investors, who have historically sought refuge in foreign bonds, are now looking to US bonds, which are seen as a safer bet due to the expected rate cuts by the Federal Reserve. This shift is expected to benefit US bond prices and potentially provide capital gains for investors.

site_title: Europe: Shares dip, banks and Boeing suppliers in focus
summary: European stocks declined 0.2% on Monday, with German banks and Boeing suppliers among the top losers. Bank stocks fell 0.4%, led by Commerzbank's 2.4% drop, while European suppliers of Boeing, such as Safran and Melrose Industries, also slid. The decline was attributed to investor caution following recent multi-month highs, with investors taking a breather. Meanwhile, oil and gas stocks rose 0.9% supported by oil prices hitting a five-month peak.

site_title: Twitter limits bulk following to thwart spammers
summary: Twitter has limited the number of accounts users can follow in a single day to 400, aiming to combat spam on the platform. Previously, users could follow up to 1,000 accounts daily. The move is intended to prevent "bots" from automatically following and reciprocating with real users, which can artificially inflate the status of bot accounts and lead to spam. Twitter's policy bars the use of its service for spreading spam, which is defined as bulk or aggressive activity.

images.alt_text: Twitter on Monday trimmed the number of accounts that a user can follow in a single day in an effort to fight spam at the micro-blogging platform.

site_title: Working to elevate maritime Singapore
summary: Lawyer Gina Lee-Wan, a prominent figure in Singapore's maritime community, has made significant contributions to elevating Singapore's reputation as a leading maritime hub. She was recognized as one of the top 10 maritime lawyers globally and is a Senior Accredited Specialist in Maritime and Shipping Law. Lee-Wan has worked on various initiatives, including the Singapore Ship Sale Form 2011, to promote Singapore as a key arbitration center. She emphasizes the need for digital transformation, or "Shipping 4.0," to stay ahead of the curve in the disrupted shipping industry.

site_title: Frasers unit's sustainability loan flags growth prospect for tiny market in Asia-Pac
summary: An Australian unit of Frasers Property Ltd secured a $600 million sustainability-linked loan in Asia-Pacific, marking the first such deal in the region. The 5-year loan has a base rate margin of 135 basis points, which can drop by up to 5 basis points if the borrower meets sustainability performance targets. This deal signals growth potential for the region's sustainable finance market, which lagged globally due to coal reliance. Global sustainability-linked loans surged 7-fold in 2018, and experts expect the market to continue growing, with more borrowers entering the sustainable finance space.

site_title: Boeing shares slump as 737 earnings hit is weighed
summary: Boeing shares plummeted 4.4% on Monday after the company cut production of 737 planes to 42 per month, down from 52, amid the ongoing crisis following two deadly crashes that killed nearly 350 people. Several analysts downgraded profit estimates, predicting a six- to nine-month disruption to the 737 line and a potential reputational loss for the 737 Max. However, Morningstar maintained a "buy" rating, citing Boeing's strong order book and track record of execution. The Federal Aviation Administration has signaled a cautious approach before clearing the planes to resume operations.

site_title: Leaders in grooming talent
summary: Jurong Port and the Institute of Technical Education (ITE) in Singapore are investing in grooming talent to maintain their leadership positions in the industry. Jurong Port has developed competency frameworks and the Jurong Port Academy to upskill employees, while ITE provides career and technical education, including Work-Learn Technical Diplomas and a modularized maritime business program. These initiatives support the development of the country's maritime workforce and align with national skills certification initiatives, such as SkillsFuture.

site_title: Modi pledges US$1.44t on infrastructure in re-election bid
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi's ruling Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) has pledged to spend US$1.44 trillion on infrastructure to boost the economy and improve living standards. The manifesto also includes promises to double farmers' incomes by 2022, improve the manufacturing sector's GDP share, and double exports. Additionally, the BJP has committed to investing 25 trillion rupees in rural development and scrapping Article 370 of the Indian Constitution, which grants special concessions to the disputed state of Kashmir.

site_title: Championing maritime innovation
summary: Sembcorp Marine, a 50-year-old company, provides state-of-the-art engineering solutions to the offshore, marine, and energy industries. The company focuses on four key capabilities: rigs and floaters, repairs and upgrades, offshore platforms, and specialized shipbuilding. ST Engineering's Electronics and A*Star's software have also shown significant impact, saving lives. No specific conclusion or event is mentioned in the article.

site_title: EU-China summit timing is tricky
summary: The EU-China summit kicks off amid growing bilateral tension, with Brussels concerned over China's "dividing and ruling" tactics to undermine European interests. China's Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) has sparked tensions, with Italy becoming the first G7 state to endorse the $1 trillion plan. Despite this, EU and Chinese leaders will stress common interests, such as tackling climate change, where both share a vision of a prosperous, energy-secure future. The EU and China have a history of cooperation on climate change, and China's planned investment in the green economy is seen as a significant opportunity for growth. However, the window of opportunity for collaboration may not remain open indefinitely.

site_title: China's Belt and Road will outgrow its teething woes: Panel
summary: China's Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) is expected to overcome its initial challenges, according to a panel discussion in Singapore. Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing and shipping veteran Teo Siong Seng emphasized the initiative's ambitions and progress. Despite initial speed bumps, BRI is poised to continue its growth, with Singapore potentially benefiting from its expansion.

images.alt_text: Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing and shipping veteran Teo Siong Seng both weighed in on the rising giant at a panel after the Singapore Maritime Lecture on Monday.

site_title: Japan faces recession risks with dearth of ammunition
summary: Japan narrowly avoided a recession due to resilient business spending, but faces vulnerability if a global economic recovery fails. The country's factory and export sectors are struggling, and policymakers have few options. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe may delay a planned sales tax hike in October or increase fiscal spending to boost domestic growth, which could stabilize the economy. However, a prolonged downturn could still occur, and the Bank of Japan's ability to ease monetary policy is limited.

site_title: SGX pioneers interest rate derivatives on Japan repo
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) is launching the Asia's first total return futures (TRF) on the Nikkei 225 Index, enabling investors to replicate the full economics of Nikkei 225 Index total return swaps. The SGX Nikkei 225 Index TRF allows for trading of financing costs, including implied equity repo, and will deliver greater transparency and capital efficiency. The product complements SGX's existing Japan equity derivatives offering and supports global financial market regulations. The launch follows SGX's pioneering work in Japan derivatives, including the world's first futures contract on the Nikkei 225 Index in 1986.

site_title: Building a city within a city
summary: Hudson Yards and Battery Park City, two cities-within-a-cities in western Manhattan, differ in their development approaches. Hudson Yards, completed in 2026, took 18 years to develop and features a single lead developer, the Related Companies, which allowed for quicker completion and more control. In contrast, Battery Park City, completed in 2011, took 45 years to develop and involved multiple companies and stakeholders, leading to a more complex and slow process. The shift in approach reflects changing urban planning theories, from fitting in to standing out, and the increasing influence of the private sector in development.

site_title: Facebook wants a faux regulator for Internet speech. It won't happen . . .
summary: Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg proposed creating an independent body to appeal against the company's moderation decisions, a move that would shift the authority from Facebook to "regulators." However, US legal experts and advocacy groups rejected the idea, citing concerns over the First Amendment and freedom of expression. Zuckerberg clarified that the proposal was for private sector self-regulation in the US, not government intervention, but critics argue that this is a "faux regulation" that would not effectively address content moderation issues. The proposal is seen as a bow to public opinion, rather than a genuine attempt to address concerns over online speech.

site_title: Hermès opens a new kind of shop in New York
summary: Hermès has opened a new, casual luxury shop in the Meatpacking District of New York, a departure from its traditional high-end locations. The 5,330-square-foot store offers a wide range of luxury items, including handbags, jewelry, clothing, and home décor, at a more relaxed atmosphere. The location, near a Peruvian restaurant, marks a shift for the 182-year-old brand away from the glitzy confines of Madison and Fifth avenues.

site_title: Grab targets US$2 billion more in funding this year
summary: Grab, a ride-hailing company, aims to raise an additional US$2 billion in funding this year, bringing its total capital goals to US$6.5 billion. CEO Anthony Tan plans to expand the company's services to become an "app-for-everything" in South-east Asia, home to 650 million people. This follows a recent funding round of over US$4.5 billion, making Grab the largest private financing in the region.

site_title: Ace Achieve Infocom warns it may be unable to operate as a going concern
summary: Ace Achieve Infocom warns it may not operate as a going concern due to a terminated Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) and loan agreement. The company's shares were suspended from trading, and it now needs to find replacement funding to meet financial obligations. Ace is searching for new investors to fund its outstanding audit, compliance, and professional fees. The company's timeline to complete its annual audit and general meeting will be delayed due to the suspension.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Coffee with Claressa: Minister Ng Chee Meng on record
summary: Minister Ng Chee Meng recently appeared on the Money FM podcast "Coffee with Claressa" to discuss various economic and international issues. Key points include the ongoing impact of US tariffs on the Asian garment industry, Vietnam's surprise at the Trump tariff announcement, and China's GDP growth expected to slow. Other news includes Citigroup's target of 1,150 for the MSCI global equity index by mid-2026, and the Thai court's handling of Thaksin's daughter's suspension as PM in an ethics case. These events highlight ongoing economic and geopolitical tensions.

site_title: AI can be biased, too
summary: Artificial intelligence (AI) systems can perpetuate biases from their creators, with studies showing discriminatory patterns in job ads, risk-assessment algorithms, and digital assistants like Siri and Alexa. The lack of diversity among AI creators contributes to these biases, with research finding that only 13.5% of machine-learning professionals are female. To address this issue, experts recommend increasing diversity among AI creators, implementing independent data scientists in decision-making processes, and halting the use of biased AI tools. Recognizing and acknowledging personal biases is also crucial in minimizing their impact.

site_title: Singapore, Malaysia suspend overlapping port limits
summary: Singapore and Malaysia mutually suspended their overlapping port limits, reverting to pre-October 25, 2018 and December 6, 2018 limits, effective at 12:01am on April 8, 2019. The move follows a dispute over Singapore's territorial waters off Tuas after Malaysia extended its port limits in October. The suspension was agreed upon by foreign ministers in March to de-escalate tensions and pave the way for maritime boundary delimitation, ahead of an upcoming leaders' retreat between the two countries.

site_title: Copper up on China stimulus hopes, trade talk progress
summary: Copper prices surged 1% on Monday, ending a two-day decline, due to hopes of more stimulus measures in China and optimism over Sino-US trade talks. China announced plans to relax residency curbs and increase infrastructure spending, while US and Chinese negotiators reported "new progress" in their trade talks. This sparked buying in the metals market, with production growth in China's air conditioning sector expected to grow 7.9% this month, making it difficult to argue for weak demand.

site_title: US-China tensions - from trade war, temporary ceasefire to real wars?
summary: US-China tensions have escalated into a potential trade war, with the Trump administration imposing tariffs on $250 billion worth of Chinese goods and threatening another $267 billion. The trade war has disrupted global supply chains and has the potential to disrupt the worldwide economy. The US views China as a national security threat, citing concerns over espionage and cyberattacks, while China sees the US as trying to contain its economic and military power. The tensions could lead to military conflicts, including over the South China Sea, the Korean Peninsula, and Taiwan, potentially igniting a full-blown war.

site_title: Don't shoot the ATM, it's just a distribution tool: banks
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority (MAS) has found no impropriety by DBS in selling Hyflux securities in 2016, despite the company's bankruptcy. DBS and other banks, such as OCBC and UOB, have been offering retail securities through ATMs since 1993, with MAS stating that perpetual securities are "not complex" products. Critics argue that investors often fail to read offer documents and risk disclaimers, leading to losses. Experts say the issue lies with retail investors not keeping up with the complexity of the securities market, rather than the banks' distribution channels.

site_title: String of public agencies lease offices at Funan
summary: Government agencies in Singapore have leased office space at the revamped Funan building, with the Department of Statistics, Attorney-General's Chambers, and Smart Nation and Digital Government Office among the tenants. The Ministry of Culture, Community and Youth, Government Technology Agency, and others will occupy around 8,590 sq m of net lettable office space. The leases are part of a 20-year-old building that has seen significant redevelopment, with the goal of creating a hub for innovation and collaboration among government agencies.

site_title: CMA CGM grows global footprint from Singapore
summary: CMA CGM, a global logistics and transport player, has strengthened its presence in Singapore, a key regional base for its operations. The company employs over 1,000 people and offers more than 100 services per week. CMA CGM has partnered with PSA International to develop Singapore as an international maritime centre, including the CMA CGM-PSA Lion Terminal, which has achieved superior service levels. The company has also signed a Memorandum of Understanding with PSA International to drive digitalisation and innovation in the shipping and supply chain ecosystems, aiming to become a world leader in transport and logistics.

site_title: Harness technology, go where the trade flows are: Chan Chun Sing
summary: Singapore Trade and Industry Minister Chan Chun Sing emphasized the importance of harnessing technology and going where trade flows are, particularly in a world in flux due to demographics and climate change. He highlighted the need for a multi-faceted connectivity that includes data, talent, technology, and finance flows. Singapore plans to boost its maritime service offerings through sister sectors like finance and logistics, and has taken steps such as constructing icebreakers for new polar shipping routes and expanding its port capacity. The minister urged the need to defend an open rules-based global trading order and resist protectionism to promote a predictable pro-business environment.

site_title: Great Eastern rolls out suite of digital tools for advisers
summary: Great Eastern has launched a digital platform, "Great Digital Advantage," to enhance advisers' efficiency and productivity. The platform features five capabilities, including GreatAdvice, GreatPlanner, GreatPortfolio, Geric, and Micro Learning. The company has invested "double-digit millions" in the platform, aiming to bridge protection and financial gaps in the community. Great Eastern also offers training initiatives, including the #GreaterWay onboarding program, to support its representatives.

site_title: STI dips 0.2% on profit-taking
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) dropped 7.22 points, or 0.2%, to close at 3,315.42 on Monday, despite 17 blue-chip stocks ending in the black. Investors took profits after last week's rally, citing uncertainty over US-China trade negotiations. Genting Singapore was the most traded blue-chip, falling 0.5% to close at S$0.98. Financials were mixed among banks, with OCBC Bank gaining and DBS Group Holdings dipping. Energy stocks performed well, but analysts noted Brent oil faces technical resistance.

site_title: China to ease residency curbs in smaller cities, boost infrastructure
summary: China's National Development and Reform Commission plans to relax residency curbs in smaller cities, aiming to boost the urban population and revive economic growth. The move is part of a goal to bring 100 million people into cities by 2020. Restrictions on household registration permits will be scrapped or comprehensively relaxed in cities of one to five million, providing support for sustained economic development and social stability.

site_title: Fiat Chrysler to pay US$110m to settle investor lawsuit
summary: Fiat Chrysler has agreed to pay US$110 million to settle a shareholder lawsuit alleging the automaker misled investors about diesel admissions and US regulations. The lawsuit, filed in 2015, claimed Fiat Chrysler falsely claimed compliance with safety regulations and lost money due to failed recalls. The settlement must be approved by a federal judge.

site_title: What can Singapore do to be the global leader in autonomous vehicles?
summary: Singapore is poised to be a global leader in autonomous vehicles, ranking second in the world and first in Asia in the 2019 KPMG's Autonomous Vehicle Readiness Index. For the second year in a row, Singapore is ready to embrace autonomous vehicles, making it an imminent reality for residents. This ranking highlights the country's readiness to adopt autonomous technology, positioning it for success in the rapidly evolving industry.

site_title: India's ruling party makes US$1.4t infrastructure boost promise for election
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi has pledged to spend over $1.4 trillion on new infrastructure over five years, promising jobs and pursuing his nationalist agenda. The Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) also vowed $300 billion for farmers and rural development, with promises to scrap a law giving special privileges to residents of Jammu and Kashmir and build a grand Hindu temple in Ayodhya. The BJP's manifesto aims to boost its nationalist agenda ahead of India's general election, which starts this week.

site_title: Headway made against election abuses: Facebook
summary: Facebook has made strides in preventing online abuses in India's national election, removing over 500 fake accounts and pages linked to the opposition Congress party. The company has implemented fact-checking efforts, technology to detect doctored videos, and stricter rules for political ads. However, gaps remain, with measures such as verifying ad buyers still imperfect, and Facebook calling for more government regulation of ad-spending disclosures. The company acknowledges that some duplicates of spurious videos can still be detected.

site_title: Expression of interest launched for Big Box mall
summary: The receivers and managers of Big Box Pte Ltd are conducting an expression of interest (EOI) exercise for its Big Box mall in Jurong East, Singapore. The mall has a 30-year remaining land tenure and a total gross floor area of approximately 1.4 million sq ft. The EOI exercise aims to explore potential buyers for the mall, which has been vacant for an extended period. The outcome of the EOI process will determine the future of the mall.

site_title: Q&M Dental counting on AI to 'move the needle' for business
summary: Q&M Dental Group is investing in an AI platform to enhance dental diagnosis and treatment planning. The platform, developed in collaboration with International Medical University, will use machine-learning capabilities to analyze patient data and suggest personalized care. The move aims to "move the needle" for the business, which has seen cooling interest amid muted earnings growth. Q&M plans to trial the platform in a few clinics by the end of the year or early next year, with the goal of faster and more accurate diagnosis, and personalized care.

images.alt_text: Q&M founder and chief executive Ng Chin Siau plans to grow the business further in Singapore and continues to target opening 10 new clinics a year.

site_title: Singapore, Malaysia working on agreement to suspend RTS Link
summary: Singapore and Malaysia are working towards a supplementary agreement to suspend the cross-border rail link, the RTS Link, for six months. Malaysia requested the suspension to review key project parameters. The two countries had earlier agreed to a two-year suspension of the Kuala Lumpur-Singapore HSR Project, with Malaysia paying Singapore $15 million. The suspension will be reviewed and may incur costs, but the exact amount is yet to be determined.

site_title: Hong Lam Marine is fuelling innovation
summary: Hong Lam Marine, a Singapore-based bunker craft operator, has over 35 years of experience and operates 37 tankers with a total Deadweight tonnage of 303,886.
