site_title: 'Possible' to defer deadline for Singapore-JB RTS link
summary: Singapore's Transport Ministry says it's possible to defer the deadline for the RTS (Rapid Transit System) link between Johor Baru and Woodlands, provided it's done within the bilateral agreement's framework and both countries give their consent. Malaysia had requested a six-month delay to deliberate on the project.

images.alt_text: Responding to Malaysia's request for six more months to deliberate on the Rapid Transit System (RTS) project to link Johor Baru to Woodlands, Singapore said on Thursday that it is "possible to defer project deadlines and review project parameters".

site_title: India's central bank cuts rates a week before election
summary: India's central bank, the Reserve Bank of India (RBI), cut interest rates by 25 basis points to 6.00% on April 4, 2019, a week before the start of the general election. The move aims to boost consumer sentiment and stimulate the economy, which has been facing a slowdown. The decision comes as the global economy slows down and inflation remains below the target of 4%. The RBI cited the need to strengthen domestic growth impulses by spurring private investment. The cut is the second consecutive reduction under Governor Shaktikanta Das, a Modi ally.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Grand Venture Technology (GVT) is expanding profitably after its listing, focusing on capacity expansion and mergers and acquisitions. The company has a 10-year agreement with SICO Technology GmbH and is developing sub-micron machining capabilities. Singapore Post (SingPost) announced it will sell its US e-commerce businesses, Jagged Peak and TradeGlobal, due to underperformance and strategic review. Analysts maintain a "hold" call on SingPost, estimating a fair value of S$1.00.

site_title: ITAP 2019 to get boost from Jurong Innovation District
summary: The Industrial Transformation Asia Pacific (ITAP) 2019 event in Singapore will be strengthened by the addition of the Jurong Innovation District (JID) as part of a strategy to build on connections made at the trade show. The JID will serve as a testbed for policy and technology innovations, and its proximity to Nanyang Technological University will help attract talent. Industry players can interact with ecosystem players at JID after ITAP to consult on solutions and technology showcased at the event. The goal is to make Singapore an advanced manufacturing hub for the region.

images.alt_text: Senior Minister of Trade and Industry Koh Poh Koon (in blue suit) looking at an interactive map of the Jurong Innovation District.

site_title: Making The Call
summary: Singtel, the Singapore Telephone Board, was established in 1955, replacing the earlier Singapore Telephone Board. The company was responsible for telephone operators in the 1960s, who worked on large switchboards. The first international call was made in 1937 between London and Singapore. The telephone network was digitized in 1994, with Singapore installing its one millionth phone line by 1990. The company has undergone significant changes since its inception, reflecting advancements in technology and the evolution of the telecommunications industry in Singapore.

site_title: Women In Love
summary: The Esplanade is reviving the iconic play "Mergers And Accusations" by Eleanor Wong, which tells the story of Ellen, a closeted lesbian lawyer struggling with her attraction to a female colleague and career aspirations in 1990s Singapore. The play, part of a trilogy, explores themes relevant to the LGBTQ community. The revival, directed by Chen Yingxuan, runs at the Esplanade Theatre Studio from April 11 to 14.

site_title: Kingboard Copper Foil's controlling shareholder launches 2nd privatisation bid
summary: EXCEL First Investments, a controlling shareholder of Kingboard Copper Foil Holdings, has launched a second privatization bid for the Hong Kong-based company. The offer is at S$0.60 per share, higher than the S$0.40 per share offered two years ago. The bid aims to delist the company from the mainboard.

site_title: Are private markets redefining investment for Singapore firms?
summary: Singapore firms are shifting towards private markets as more middle-class investors enter the market, leading to increased private equity activity. Traditional IPOs may not be the best option, as they can be expensive, time-consuming, and may not attract younger investors. Private markets, such as private exchanges and venture capital, offer more flexible and accessible funding options for companies. This trend is driven by the growth of private equity, the rise of alternative investment platforms, and the increasing demand for private markets. As a result, companies are opting for private markets to raise capital, potentially paving the way for private equity to become a more viable option.

site_title: Inside the world of catering
summary: Food writers Matt Lee and Ted Lee, authors of a new book "Hotbox: Inside Catering," spent four years working undercover as catering cooks in New York City. They discovered the cutthroat world of catering, where chefs must navigate demanding clients, limited kitchen space, and high-pressure situations. The industry, worth $12 billion annually in the US, is often overlooked by food journalists and diners. The Lees worked for low wages, often $10 an hour, to gain insight into the tricks of the trade, including "sheet-pan magic" and using makeshift equipment to prepare elaborate meals.

site_title: Singtel, Bharti Airtel 'looking to acquire majority stake in India's Dish TV'
summary: Singtel and its associate Bharti Airtel are reportedly planning to acquire a 60% stake in India's Dish TV for 61.5 billion rupees (S$1.21 billion). The deal aims to give competition to Indian mobile network operator Reliance Jio Infocomm. The acquisition price is 55 rupees per share, and it is seen as a strategic move to reduce debt in the competitive Indian telecom industry. However, analysts question the strategic benefit of the deal, citing Dish TV's lack of physical last-mile access and reliance on third-party content distribution.

site_title: Mothercare UK sales slide slows in Q4
summary: Mothercare UK sales slowed down in the fourth quarter of 2019, with like-for-like store sales falling 8.8% in the 12 weeks to March 30, and 10.8% for the full year. Despite a decline in international retail sales, the company reported a 4.9% drop. Mothercare has completed its UK store closure program ahead of schedule, now operating 80 stores, and expects to deliver on previous expectations for the full year. The company aims to be debt-free by the end of this year.

site_title: In this Australian shop, all purchases are shipped to China
summary: Australia Post has opened a concept store in Sydney, catering to Chinese customers who buy and ship foreign goods to China due to the country's insatiable demand. The store, which also offers products such as infant formula and vitamin pills, has sparked a daigou trade, where products are bought overseas and resold in China. Despite China's new e-commerce rules, the store has seen success, with one customer spending an average of A$500 per week on products. The store aims to connect Australian businesses with the growing Chinese market.

site_title: Expanded IRs 'to help fill incoming MBS, RWS hotel rooms'
summary: Singapore's integrated resorts (IRs) will introduce 2,100 new hotel rooms, with Marina Bay Sands adding 1,000 suites and Resorts World Sentosa building two luxury hotels. Analysts predict this influx won't significantly impact the wider Singapore hotel market, as the IRs' captive demand will continue to drive growth. The new hotels are expected to boost overall demand and occupancy rates, particularly with the expansion of attractions and exhibition space.

site_title: Virtual Art
summary: The Artling, an online art gallery, has launched an augmented reality (AR) feature allowing clients to visualize artworks in their homes before purchasing. The feature, available on the App Store, uses a phone's camera to capture images of the space and superimpose the artwork. Founder Talenia Phua stated this feature eliminates the need to physically bring the artwork to the client's home. With over 2,500 artists' works to choose from, clients can explore and select their desired piece with enhanced details.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: New BMW 7 Series review: Still the Magnificent 7
summary: The BMW 7 Series has undergone a significant facelift, featuring a 40% larger front grille, slimmer headlamps, and redesigned tail lights. The mid-life revamp aims to make the car stand out from its smaller 5 and 3 Series models, particularly in Asian markets where it accounts for 41% of sales. The new model boasts a plug-in hybrid powertrain, offering improved efficiency and performance. New features include a digital instrument cluster, infotainment system, and voice assistant. The 7 Series also features air suspension, rear wheel steering, and improved sound insulation.

site_title: STI up marginally as rally fizzles out
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) gained 4.94 points, or 0.15%, to close at 3,316.21 on Thursday, despite a dissipating Asian market rally. This followed moderate gains in other Asian markets, with Japan, South Korea, China, and Malaysia closing higher, while Australia and Hong Kong closed lower.

site_title: Australian pension funds in talks to create A$110 billion giant
summary: Australian pension funds First State Super and VicSuper are in talks to merge, creating a retirement-savings giant with over A$110 billion in assets. The non-binding memorandum of understanding aims to deliver significant benefits to members. The merger, if successful, would make them the nation's second-largest non-profit super fund, managing over 1.1 million members. Initial discussions indicated a strong cultural alignment between the two funds, with a focus on member-first culture and quality financial advice. A recommendation to the boards is expected around the middle of the year.

site_title: US mortgage applications hit 2.5-year high
summary: US mortgage applications surged to a 2.5-year high in the week ending March 29, driven by a 18.6% increase in refinancing activity. Mortgage rates fell to their lowest levels in over a year, averaging 4.36% for 30-year "conforming" mortgages. Refinancing activity jumped 39% and accounted for 47.4% of total mortgage applications. Loan applications to buy a home climbed 3% with average loan sizes shrinking slightly, a positive sign for first-time buyers.

site_title: Burnt by Dubai, Mobius joins chorus of pessimists about its real estate glut
summary: Mark Mobius, a prominent investor, warns of a worsening real estate glut in Dubai due to the recent construction frenzy. He advises holding off on buying more property until a slump occurs, predicting a 12-18 month downturn. Dubai's property market has already dropped by 33% in the past five years, with prices and rents continuing to decline. Analysts, including Moody's Investors Service, believe the government's stimulus measures will not be enough to revive demand, and shares of developers are not cheap enough. A World Expo 2020 event may not be enough to revive the sector.

site_title: Check out the 'Louis Vuitton of cars'
summary: DS Automobiles, a French luxury car brand spun off from Citroen in 2015, aims to be the "Louis Vuitton of cars." The brand's flagship model, the DS 7 Crossback, offers fine design, attention to detail, and the latest technology, including a camera to scan the road ahead for bumps. DS Automobiles expects to boost sales with the upcoming launch of the DS 3 Crossback, but faces stiff competition from German luxury brands such as Audi, BMW, and Mercedes-Benz. The brand's confidence in its product is evident, with a focus on providing a unique customer experience through its "Only You" program.

site_title: HDB resale volume up 26.1% in March
summary: HDB resale volume surged 26.1% in March, the highest jump in 8 months, with 1,657 transactions, according to SRX Property. Resale prices rose 0.2% in March, despite a 1% decline from last March. Experts attribute the increase to seasonal trends, with more flats reaching their 5-year minimum occupation period. The government's new CPF loan rules and upcoming Home Improvement Programme II and Voluntary Early Redevelopment Scheme may also influence buyer perception of older flats in mature estates.

site_title: Making The Cut
summary: Alternative cuts of steak, such as oyster blade, intercostals, and hanger steaks, are gaining traction among local steak lovers, offering a wider range of flavors and textures. Chefs praise these cuts for their rich flavor and tenderness, which can be enhanced through proper cooking techniques. Demand for these cuts is driven by their affordability and versatility, as well as the growing trend of sustainability and reducing animal wastage. As consumers become more educated and discerning, they are willing to try alternative cuts, leading to a shift in the steak-eating experience.

site_title: Luxury Drive
summary: The new Audi A8 luxury flagship limousine boasts a range of luxurious features, including a touchscreen tablet in the armrest console that allows rear passengers to recline seats, adjust window blinds, and select massage functions. The fourth-gen A8 also introduces Level 3 autonomous driving capability, allowing drivers to take their hands off the steering wheel while the vehicle stays in lane and maintains a safe distance. This innovative package positions the A8 as a pioneer in the future of driving.

site_title: When geopolitics underlies a bankruptcy story
summary: A Korean industrial bankruptcy in the Philippines, Hanjin Heavy Industries and Construction Philippines, has sparked a geopolitical face-off between the US and China for influence over Southeast Asia and the Pacific Ocean. The bankruptcy, which left a consortium of Philippine banks on the hook for over $412 million, has led to a scramble for influence in the region. The US is seen as a key player in regaining its diminished strategic influence in the Philippines, while China seeks to exploit the situation to assert its presence in the region. Investigations and litigation are ongoing, and South Korea is expected to play a key role in resolving the bankruptcy.

site_title: Hong Kong - Asia's Cultural Capital?
summary: Hong Kong's liberal arts scene is thriving, attracting a growing audience both locally and internationally despite looming Beijing restrictions. The city is home to over 100 contemporary art galleries, including international players like David Zwirner and Pace Gallery. New public art spaces like the Centre For Heritage, Arts and Textile (CHAT) and the M+ Pavilion are presenting art that fosters discussions on society, not driven by market trends. Notable exhibitions, such as Tai Kwun's "Performing Society: The Violence of Gender" and Ho Tzu Nyen's solo show at Edouard Malingue Gallery, are drawing crowds and showcasing the city's cultural credibility. The commercial art market is also booming, with Art Basel Hong Kong reporting high-end transactions and a surge in Asian art sales.

site_title: Side Show
summary: The 2019 HSBC Singapore Rugby Sevens returns next weekend, featuring entertainment for the whole family. Smash Mouth headlines on Saturday with their 90s hits, while Rock of Ages performs 80s hair-metal classics on Sunday. Characters from DreamWorks franchises will also meet and greet. The event takes place at National Stadium on April 13 and 14.

site_title: White House says US-China talks making progress
summary: US-China trade talks made "good headway" last week in Beijing, with the two sides aiming to bridge differences. White House economic adviser Larry Kudlow said China recognized US-raised problems for the first time, and talks could extend beyond three days. US President Donald Trump is set to meet Vice-Premier Liu He in the Oval Office, with a possible meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping possible as early as Thursday. Chinese commitments to increase US agricultural and manufactured product purchases are expected, with a six-year timeline of 2025.

site_title: Hyflux says Salim-Medco rescue is off; both sides play the blame game
summary: Hyflux has cancelled a key rescue deal with Salim-Medco, citing a lack of confirmation on its commitment to invest $530 million. The deal's collapse means Hyflux will lose court protection from creditors on April 30. The two parties are now at odds over a $38.9 million deposit, with Hyflux claiming it is entitled to the funds due to Salim-Medco's repudiation of the restructuring agreement. Hyflux will engage with creditors and explore alternative investment options, while Salim-Medco claims it has adhered to the agreement and is seeking clarification on material information not disclosed by Hyflux.

site_title: Investment commitment well-timed and necessary
summary: Singapore's integrated resorts (IRs) are set to invest $9 billion to refresh their offerings and stay relevant amidst increasing competition from neighboring countries, including the Philippines and Japan. The IRs aim to open new attractions annually from 2020 to keep the resorts in the news and attract tourists. The expansion plans, including the addition of luxury hotels and gaming areas, are necessary to support gaming growth and tourism. Singapore's IR rejuvenation comes at a timely moment, with Japan poised to enter the market with its own IRs, potentially opening as early as 2024 or 2025.

site_title: Has bitcoin bottomed?
summary: Bitcoin has experienced a 70% rebound from its 2018 low, sparking debate over whether it has bottomed out. Crypto diehards believe this is the start of a new bull market, while bears argue that nothing has changed to make digital currencies more attractive to investors. The crypto market's extreme volatility and lack of reliable valuation metrics make predicting its future difficult. Historically, similar market bubbles have experienced significant gains after their lows, with examples including the Nasdaq and Dow Jones Industrial Average. If bitcoin has indeed bottomed out, it may see further upside.

site_title: Indonesia sure of meeting fiscal deficit target: minister
summary: Indonesia's Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati expressed confidence that the country will meet its fiscal deficit target of 1.84% this year despite trailing tax collections. She emphasized the government's focus on economic growth, job creation, and poverty reduction, rather than just collecting taxes. Indonesia is projecting a 5.5% growth rate for next year, despite global economic slowdowns, and is anticipating a potential boost from a US-China trade agreement. The minister acknowledged external pressures but expressed optimism about the country's economic prospects.

site_title: Thyssenkrupp to set up 3D printing innovation centre in Singapore
summary: Thyssenkrupp, a German multinational conglomerate, plans to set up a 3D printing innovation centre in Singapore, its first outside Germany. The centre, called the Singapore Additive Manufacturing TechCenter Hub, aims to unlock additive manufacturing potential for customers in Asia-Pacific and will focus on metal and plastic technologies for industries like automotive and chemicals. The hub will also host additive manufacturing engineers to co-innovate with customers and other companies. The move is expected to create jobs for Singaporeans and enrich the country's advanced manufacturing ecosystem.

site_title: Short-term pain, long-term gain for Genting Singapore: analysts
summary: Genting Singapore shares plummet 9.4% to close at S$0.97 after heavy selling following the implementation of a casino entry levy and higher casino tax rates. Analysts predict a short-term hit to earnings but believe the levies could curb problem gambling and the S$4.5 billion reinvestment plan for Resorts World Sentosa will generate long-term benefits. Despite lowered target prices, most analysts maintain "buy" recommendations.

site_title: Nomura plans US$1b of wholesale cuts
summary: Nomura Holdings Inc plans to cut $1 billion in costs at its struggling wholesale business, including 100 job losses in Europe, Hong Kong, and Singapore, as part of a sweeping overhaul of its international operations. The move aims to "right-size" its wholesale business and improve profitability. CEO Koji Nagai acknowledged that Nomura's expansion efforts have been unsuccessful and that the company needs to "build a muscular base" to restart. The cost-cutting target is expected to be completed by March 2020, with at least 30 retail brokerage branches also set to be eliminated.

site_title: Bayer pushed to put growth plans on ice
summary: Bayer faces significant legal and regulatory risks following two landmark court verdicts in the US declaring its flagship pesticide Roundup caused cancer. The company has been ordered to pay over $81 million in damages to two plaintiffs and faces an estimated 8,700-11,200 lawsuits. Regulatory authorities in European countries are phasing out or banning the pesticide, which generates significant revenue for Bayer. The company's image is being battered, and its stock price has plummeted by over 12% following the verdicts. Bayer may need to withdraw its pesticide products from household use and sell them to farmers, potentially resulting in a loss of $200 million in annual revenue.

site_title: Sale plans put bounce in SingPost's share price
summary: SingPost, a Singaporean postal carrier, plans to sell its US units, Jagged Peak and TradeGlobal, amid struggling e-commerce businesses. The move could lift earnings by 30% and boost the counter's share price. However, uncertainty over the sale process and potential buyers remains, with analysts warning of a year-long sale process and possible losses. The company must balance sale price with continued losses, and efforts to boost local service standards could also impact profits.

images.alt_text: Punters are rejoicing over news that mainboard-listed Singapore Post (SingPost) has decided to sell off its struggling US units.

site_title: South Korea launches 5G networks early to secure world first
summary: South Korea launched its nationwide 5G mobile networks two days early, beating rivals US carriers Verizon and AT&T. Three top telecom providers, SK Telecom, KT, and LG Uplus, began their 5G services at 11pm local time on April 3, 2019, ahead of the previously announced April 5 launch date. The move was reportedly made to secure the world's first 5G launch, following speculation that Verizon might start its services early. General customers will have access to the services starting April 5, when Samsung Electronics releases the Galaxy S10 5G smartphone.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims fall to lowest level since 1969
summary: US weekly jobless claims fell to a 49-year low of 202,000, indicating sustained labor market strength despite slowing economic growth. This decline is attributed to companies' reluctance to lay off workers amid a labor shortage. The four-week moving average of initial claims also fell to 213,500, the lowest level since October 2018. Economists expect the unemployment rate to remain at 3.8% despite a slowdown in job growth.

site_title: Clash over Fed policy escalates amid reversal, pressure
summary: US President Donald Trump and economic adviser Stephen Moore are pushing for a rate cut by the Federal Reserve, despite the recent reversal of monetary policy. Moore, who was nominated by Trump to join the Fed's board of governors, has called for an immediate rate cut. Investors are also demanding a rate cut, amid concerns that the Fed's super-accommodative policy has done little to quell pressure on policymakers. This escalation has raised concerns about the Fed's ability to manage the economy.

site_title: Inflight Spa
summary: Singapore Airlines introduces healthier snack options as part of its wellness and sustainability efforts. The airline partners with local farming operations and vertical farms to source fresh produce, including locally-grown vegetables and seafood. A collaboration with COMO Shambala's wellness cuisine service will be launched on selected flights from mid-year. The airline aims to reduce its environmental impact and provide healthier alternatives to traditional inflight snacks.

images.alt_text: Inflight Spa

site_title: Feast For The Senses
summary: Murray Terrace Brasserie at the Six Senses Maxwell hotel in Singapore offers an attractive and well-designed dining experience, but its menu lacks a strong identity to stand out. The restaurant's South European-inspired dishes, such as steak frites and crab cakes, show flashes of inspiration, but the menu is overly generic and fails to impress. The service is attentive, and the food is generally good, but the prices are steep, making it a promising but not outstanding dining option.

site_title: Singapore 'ideal' for EU firms to enter S-E Asia
summary: Senior Minister of State for Trade and Industry Koh Poh Koon says Singapore is an ideal location for European companies to enter South-east Asia's advanced manufacturing industry, citing its free trade agreement, central location, and strong intellectual property protection regime. Singapore is developing the 600-hectare Jurong Innovation District as a one-stop campus for advanced manufacturing, and will host the Industrial Transformation Asia-Pacific (ITAP) trade show in October to connect European industry players with Asean suppliers and partners.

images.alt_text: For European companies seeking to make inroads into South-east Asia's advanced manufacturing industry, Singapore serves as an ideal springboard to the region, Senior Minister of State for Trade and Industry Koh Poh Koon said at the Hannover Messe trade show on Wednesday.

site_title: What's next for Singapore's e-commerce landscape
summary: Singapore's e-commerce landscape is poised for significant changes as the country's services and retail industries face labor constraints due to foreign worker quotas. The transportation, storage, and logistics sector, crucial for e-commerce, will also be affected. Retailers and logistics players must balance automation with labor costs and manage the complexities of supply chain management. The rise of autonomous vehicles and last-mile logistics will impact the trucking industry, while seamless returns and fuss-free returns will be essential for customer experience. A mature ecosystem with flexible lease terms and test kitchens will support innovative businesses and startups.

site_title: Facebook's speech standard search gets flak
summary: Facebook's speech standard search gets flak as the company faces criticism for its content moderation policies from various nations. Mark Zuckerberg has called for greater regulation, but experts warn that a worldwide standard could be formed by repressive regimes. Instead, regulation is likely to occur country by country, with some nations proposing hefty fines for "harmful content". Facebook's head of public policy clarified that Zuckerberg does not want the US government to set speech rules, but rather a third-party industry group. The platform should own its own rules, rather than asking someone else to, and will require rethinking its content moderation policies.

site_title: Euro falls on report Italy will cut growth forecast
summary: The euro fell to a session low after Italy reported it will likely cut its 2019 growth forecast to 0.1-0.4% due to political wrangling over its finances. This prompted fears of a broader economic slump and weakened the euro versus the dollar. The euro has remained in a range of $1.12-$1.16 in 2019 despite the slowdown in the euro zone economy. The euro was trading at $1.122, flat on the day, amidst other economic concerns, including the European Central Bank's meeting minutes and the British parliament's approval of a Brexit delay bill.

site_title: Masayoshi Son finds easy way to make US$1b a year
summary: SoftBank Group's Vision Fund is in talks to add up to $15 billion, bringing its total to $100 billion. The fund, backed by CEO Masayoshi Son, could generate $1 billion in annual fees, beating BlackRock's returns. However, SoftBank faces challenges in delivering exits for its unicorn holdings, which rely on a vibrant US stock market. The company's size and success in raising funds could distort the new issue environment and delay the need for IPOs, posing a threat to its future prosperity.

images.alt_text: The 0.7-1.3% range that SoftBank charges its Vision Fund investors implies Mr Son could net roughly US$1 billion a year in fees - without needing any exits for his unicorns.

site_title: 16 warning signs of a company in trouble - a guide for retail investors
summary: A new report by corporate governance advocates highlights 16 warning signs of a company in trouble for retail investors. The "B-C-D-E Model" analyzes four key areas of a business: business model, corporate governance, disclosure and reporting, and events and transactions. The report identifies red flags such as unexplained financial changes, foreign incorporation, and independent directors participating in performance incentive plans. It also emphasizes the importance of exercising caution and monitoring a company's performance if multiple warning signs are present. The report aims to help retail investors minimize losses and prevent corporate scandals and failures.

site_title: Oil eases as US crude stocks build up
summary: Oil prices eased on Wednesday as US crude stocks built up, but futures remained near their highest in almost five months. Brent futures settled at $69.31 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude fell to $62.46 a barrel. A surprise build in US crude inventories, driven by increased net imports and production, offset supply cuts by Opec-led output reduction and sanctions on Iran. Market participants expect prices to rise due to tightening global supply and signs of demand picking up.

site_title: Synagie Corp, Y Ventures' price increases draw SGX queries
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has queried two Catalist-listed firms, Synagie Corporation and Y Ventures, over "unusual price movements" after their shares surged sharply in early trading. Synagie's shares rose 31.7% to 8.3 cents, while Y Ventures' shares rose 41.3% to 8.9 cents. Both companies denied any knowledge of reasons for the price increases and confirmed compliance with listing rules.

site_title: Ireland defers property tax review
summary: Ireland has deferred a revaluation of its national property tax by a year and extended controls on residential rents in areas with rapid growth until 2021 to curb rising housing costs. This decision comes as Irish house prices have nearly doubled since the tax's introduction in 2013. The government aims to maintain frozen bills, having postponed an initial revaluation by three years in 2016.

site_title: Singapore warns of jail term for marine-fuel cheats
summary: Singapore has warned shipping companies that cheating on marine-fuel rules starting next year could result in up to 2 years in prison. The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) is enforcing stricter regulations to combat pollution and save fuel costs. If enforced, this penalty would be one of the strongest deterrents yet. The rules aim to reduce emissions of sulphurous pollutants blamed for asthma and acid rain.

site_title: Why simplicity can be a winemaking virtue
summary: Simplicity can be a virtue in winemaking, as some of the most popular wines in the US have had discernible sweetness. Classics like Blue Nun, Riunite Lambrusco, and Kendall-Jackson Vintner's Reserve Chardonnay have stood the test of time, and more recent bestsellers like Apothic Red and The Prisoner also feature sweetness. This trend suggests that sweetness can be a key factor in making wines crowd-pleasing, despite the common perception that it can make people seem crazy.

site_title: Bankruptcy run in wealthy China province spooks creditors
summary: A series of major private-sector bond issuers in China's Shandong province have filed for bankruptcy since November, highlighting local governments' efforts to manage unsustainable debt loads. Four debtors have entered bankruptcy procedures in Dongying, a city once thriving with a booming tyre-making industry. This is a rare instance of court-led restructuring of publicly issued bonds in China, where thousands of bankruptcies occur each year. Local officials are moving to halt the spread of damage in selected cases, sparking concerns among creditors.

site_title: The Great HDB Lease Decay Debate, in BT Weekend
summary: The article discusses the depreciation of HDB (Housing and Development Board) properties as they age and near the end of their 99-year lease. Research on actual transactions suggests that the value of these properties can decrease over time. Factors contributing to this depreciation include the expiration of the lease, changes in local market conditions, and the need for renovation or replacement. However, the article does not provide a conclusive conclusion on the extent of depreciation or its impact on the market.

site_title: Ageing Gracefully
summary: Aesthetic medicine has become a mainstream way to age gracefully, with many people seeking non-invasive treatments to reverse signs of aging. Doctors recommend finding a balance between treatments and not over-treating, as this can lead to unnatural results. Common misconceptions include the idea that treatments affect facial expressions, that stopping maintenance leads to a worse appearance, and that low-downtime treatments are not effective. To avoid fake news, individuals should research thoroughly, visit reputable clinics, and ask questions about the treatments and equipment. Ultimately, aging gracefully means embracing one's age with confidence and finding a balance between treatments and natural aging.

site_title: Good things worth waiting for, says MBS chief
summary: Las Vegas Sands (LVS) has announced plans to invest S$4.5 billion in a new hotel tower at Marina Bay Sands in Singapore, with approximately 1,000 luxury suites and a 15,000-seat entertainment arena. The project, which will take around 8 years to complete, is expected to meet growing demand for luxury accommodations in Singapore. LVS president George Tanasijevich expressed confidence in the project's potential to increase the resort's competitive position, citing the emerging competition from other integrated resorts in the region.

site_title: Extended deadline for Lian Beng to sell assets that compete with its unit SLB
summary: Lian Beng Group, a controlling shareholder of SLB Development, has received a one-year extension from the Singapore Exchange to dispose of its competing assets in Australia and Singapore due to unfavorable property market conditions. The original deadline was April 2018, but it has been extended to April 19, 2020. Lian Beng has developed an action plan to sell the properties or its stakes in the vehicles that own the properties by the extended deadline.

site_title: Tencent raises US$6b in bond sale
summary: Tencent Holdings Ltd raised US$6 billion in a bond sale, marking Asia's largest this year, to refinance and cover general corporate purposes. The sale exceeded China Evergrande Group's US$2.8 billion issue in January. Tencent issued US$2 billion in 5-year notes, US$500 million in 7-year notes, US$3 billion in 10-year notes, and US$500 million in 30-year notes, carrying interest rates ranging from 3.280% to 4.525%. The bond sale follows the tech firm's earlier announcement to increase its Global Medium Term Note Programme limit to US$20 billion.

site_title: Gold gains on softer dollar as market focuses on US-China talks
summary: Gold prices rose 0.2% to $1,292.16 per ounce as the US dollar traded near a one-week low, amid anticipation of progress in US-China trade negotiations. This move is attributed to a softer dollar. US gold futures also increased 0.1% to $1,296.80 per ounce.

images.alt_text: Spot gold climbed by 0.2 per cent to US$1,292.16 per ounce as at 0756 GMT Thursday. US gold futures firmed 0.1 per cent at US$1,296.80 an ounce.

site_title: Souvenirs and secrets as Game of Thrones cast walk last red carpet
summary: The Game of Thrones cast walked their last red carpet together in New York ahead of the show's eighth and final season, which premieres on HBO on April 14. The cast, including Sophie Turner, Pilou Asbaek, and Isaac Hempstead-Wright, shared fond memories of their time on the show, including filming in freezing weather in Northern Ireland. Many actors kept souvenirs from their characters, such as corsets and eye patches, and the show has become known for its shocking plot twists, including the fate of beloved characters.

site_title: Brexit chaos stirs bafflement in UK's ex-colonies
summary: Brexit, the UK's departure from the European Union, has sparked confusion and amusement in Britain's former Asian colonies, including Hong Kong, India, and Australia. Many view the situation as a farce and a reversal of Britain's former status as a great power. In Hong Kong, a pro-democracy lawmaker expressed bafflement and amusement at the UK's handling of the process, while in India, a dean of a school of international affairs described Brexit as a "sharp decline in the place Britain commands as a great power." In Australia, interest in the Brexit drama has been high, but many have also expressed a sense of schadenfreude and amusement at the UK's internal division and potential isolation.

site_title: Oceanus to revise FY2017 statements, applies for extension of AGM deadline
summary: Oceanus Group is revising its FY2017 financial statements to align with accounting standards and has applied for an extension of its annual general meeting (AGM) deadline to June 28, 2019. The review, which includes engaging independent auditors and valuers, aims to complete within two months. This revision affects FY2018 statements and may also lead to Oceanus being removed from the Singapore Exchange's (SGX) watch list if it meets financial criteria, including recording a consolidated pre-tax profit and posting a market capitalization of at least S$40 million.

site_title: Mad About Belinda
summary: Belinda Carlisle is set to perform in Singapore as part of her Runaways Horses 30th Anniversary Tour, showcasing her signature bubblegum pop sound and hits like "Heaven Is A Place On Earth" and "Circle In The Sand." At 60 years old, Carlisle is still energetic and captivating, with her fanbase eagerly awaiting the 90-minute concert. The event will take place at The Star Theatre on April 6 at 8pm, with tickets available from Sistic.

site_title: Safari With A Conscience
summary: Singita, a luxury safari operator, has launched its newest camp, Singita Faru Faru Lodge, in Tanzania's Serengeti Mara ecosystem. The lodge is part of the Grumeti Fund, established in 2002 to support conservation projects, including the Anti-Poaching Canine Unit and the Serengeti Girls Run. The lodge aims to provide an immersive wildlife experience while contributing to the conservation of the region's wildlife population. Visitors can engage in activities such as elephant collaring experiences, while supporting local communities and wildlife conservation efforts.

site_title: Excel First Investments launches repeat takeover, privatisation bid for Kingboard Copper
summary: Excel First Investments, a wholly-owned subsidiary of Kingboard Laminates Holdings, has made a repeat takeover-cum-privatisation offer for Kingboard Copper Foil Holdings at S$0.60 each in cash. This follows a failed attempt two years ago. The offeror has an 87.96% stake in the company and plans to exercise its right of compulsory acquisition if successful. The goal is to facilitate management and operational control, achieve synergies, and eliminate listing-related expenses. A delisting will also enable the offeror to have a longer business planning horizon.

site_title: Nam Cheong says can still operate as going concern despite auditor report
summary: Nam Cheong Limited, an offshore vessel builder, said it can still operate as a going concern despite an independent auditor's report stating they couldn't conclude the group's ability to do so. The auditors cited uncertainty over debt obligations from 15 suspended shipbuilding contracts. Nam Cheong believes it can restructure these debts through ongoing negotiations and its experience with other subcontracted shipyards. The company's management prepared a cash flow forecast for the next 12 months, but the auditors couldn't obtain sufficient evidence for key assumptions supporting this forecast.

site_title: New incentive schemes welcome boosts for CBD; will developers bite?
summary: Singapore unveils two incentive schemes to rejuvenate the Central Business District and city centre. The Urban Redevelopment Authority's Draft Master Plan 2019 includes a CBD Incentive Scheme, which aims to increase human traffic with a mix of residential, hotels, and creative uses. The Strategic Development Incentive (SDI) Scheme encourages owners of existing commercial buildings to team up for comprehensive redevelopment, with proposals for higher plot ratios and flexibility on land use. The schemes aim to minimize negative side effects while achieving targeted outcomes, but it remains to be seen if developers will participate.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed 1.86 points higher on Thursday, reaching 1,645.07 on the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index. A total of 3.2 billion lots worth RM2.1 billion were traded, with 437 gainers outnumbering 397 losers.

site_title: Libra Group to sell M'sian investment property for S$8m
summary: Libra Group is selling a Malaysian investment property comprising 12 plots of leasehold land for S$8 million. The disposal is part of a post-acquisition covenant following Libra's acquisition of YC Travel & Tours. The property's carrying value is S$8.5 million, with a S$0.5 million deficit that will not be recognized as a loss. Net proceeds will be used to repay indebtedness and for working capital. The proposed disposal is subject to Malaysian regulatory approval and financial institution approval.

site_title: Home Is Where The Art Is
summary: A homeowner decided to renovate her decade-long apartment instead of moving due to limited space. Designer Yeo See Wee, co-founder of Wee Studio, transformed the space into an industrial-chic home with a brighter private lift lobby, larger entertaining area, and more wall space for her art collection. The result is a unique and functional home that meets her needs, showcasing the possibilities of upgrading a small space.

site_title: Lian Beng given 1-year extension to sell properties that may compete with subsidiary
summary: Lian Beng Group, a controlling shareholder of property player SLB Development, has received a one-year extension to dispose of competing properties in Australia and Singapore due to unfavorable market conditions. site_title: Singapore shares close 0.2% higher on Thursday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed 0.15% higher at 3,316.21 points on Thursday, despite a lack of catalysts. Ten of the STI's 30 constituents fell, led by Genting Singapore, which lost 9.3% due to increased casino entry levies and capital expenditure. summary: Singaporean firms experience high data-loss incidents, costing an average of US$1.4 million annually. According to a Dell EMC report, 34% of organizations in the country have suffered data loss, with 86% experiencing disruptions. The top barrier to data protection is the inability to track and protect all data due to DevOps and cloud development growth. Only 28% of local organizations feel confident in their data protection measures, ranking regulation compliance fourth. The global average for data-loss incidents is US$939,703.

site_title: Baselworld: Classics With A Bright Future
summary: At Baselworld 2019, luxury watch brands showcased new models that, while inspired by classic designs, offered significant updates and improvements. Critics argued that many new releases were rehashes of old models, but watchmakers countered that these revivals allowed them to keep iconic timepieces alive while incorporating modern technology and materials. Notable examples include Rolex's GMT-Master II and Sea-Dweller reissues, Patek Philippe's Aquanaut and Calatrava models, and Bulgari's slim Octo chronograph and Octo Roma Grande Sonnerie. site_title: Frasers Property in talks to potentially sell Frasers Tower
summary: Frasers Property is in talks to potentially sell Frasers Tower, its office property at 182 Cecil Street. The company has expressed interest from certain parties, but no certainty exists that a transaction will occur. This move is part of Frasers Property's ongoing efforts to enhance shareholder value by reviewing opportunities for collaboration or divestment.

site_title: MeGroup subsidiary renews Mazda 4S dealership in Malaysia for 3 more years
summary: MeGroup's Malaysia-based subsidiary has renewed its Mazda 4S dealership with Bermaz Motor Trading for three more years until March 31, 2022. The dealership, located in Jalan Sungai Besi, Kuala Lumpur, will continue to meet Mazda's sales and service targets. MeGroup's dealership business now comprises six automobile dealerships under the Honda, Peugeot, and Mazda brands in Malaysia.

site_title: Singapore shares inch slightly higher on Thursday; STI up 0.03% to 3,312.22
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.03% to 3,312.22 on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index gaining 0.95 points. The market saw a 75-37 gainer-to-loser ratio, with 70.2 million shares traded. site_title: Australia shares end 7-day rally as miners and healthcare slip; NZ down
summary: Australian shares ended a seven-day rally, slipping 0.8% to 6,232.8 due to losses in mining and healthcare stocks as investors booked profits. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached a near-seven-month high on Wednesday but snapped its longest uninterrupted run of gains since October 2017.

site_title: Nest Tech gets piece of Waitrr's pie with investment in F&B tech startup's pre-Series A round
summary: Nest Tech, a venture capital fund, has invested in Singapore food and beverage technology startup Waitrr in its pre-series A round, taking a minority stake. The company's earnings release on Friday will provide further clarity, with concerns about a potential defect in one of its main products adding to uncertainty.

site_title: Barclays shifting top bankers in wake of top executive's departure: sources
summary: Barclays is reshaping its investment bank following the departure of top executive Tim Throsby, who failed to boost the corporate and investment bank's performance. Fater Belbachir, a former JPMorgan executive, will join as head of the global equities desk in June. The bank is also moving several senior staff, including Art Mbanefo and Guy Saidenberg, into new roles. The changes are part of a broader management reshuffle led by CEO Jes Staley, who is restructuring the investment bank to improve performance. Barclays' investment bank had the lowest return on equity of any unit at the bank.

site_title: Singapore wooing European firms with 'Disneyland' of advanced manufacturing
summary: Singapore is positioning itself as a key hub for European companies to enter South-east Asia's advanced manufacturing industry. The country is developing a "Disneyland" for advanced manufacturing, the 600-hectare Jurong Innovation District, which will house research institutions, industry enablers, and factories. This move aims to improve access to the Asean market and tap into the region's growing middle class, expected to occupy more than two-thirds of the population in a short time. A free trade agreement between Singapore and the EU is also in the works.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Thursday afternoon at 3,312.42, up 0.03% on day
summary: Singapore stocks edged up 0.03% to 3,312.42 on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index advancing 1.15 points. Gainers outnumbered losers 167 to 125, with notable movers including Genting Singapore down 7.94% and Golden Agri-Resources up 3.39%. site_title: Seoul: Stocks hampered by slowing corporate earnings
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index rose 3.26 points or 0.15% to 2,206.53 points, but was hampered by slowing corporate earnings. Analysts attribute the decline to the relatively less attractive nature of South Korean stocks to foreigners, citing the slow earnings growth of major semiconductor companies. site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close flat
summary: Tokyo stocks closed flat on Thursday, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index edging up 0.05% to 21,724.95, while the Topix index fell 0.11%. Investors locked in profits after recent gains, with a weak yen offsetting selling pressure.

site_title: Mobile devices drive Pinoy shoppers
summary: A recent survey found that 90.8% of Filipino shoppers look up products on their phones while in store, with 84.4% influenced by social media and online ads. The Philippines lags behind Indonesia in click-and-collect shopping, but 81.4% of global consumers have ordered items online to pick up in stores. A seamless customer experience is a top priority, with 83% of global consumers preferring quick and easy checkout, and 58.7% citing customer relationship management rewards or loyalty points as a key motivator.

site_title: HDB resale volume jumps 26.1% in March, prices inch up 0.2%: SRX
summary: HDB resale volume surged 26.1% in March, with 1,657 transactions, compared to 1,314 in February and 1,897 in the same month last year. Resale prices rose 0.2% in March, but still down 13.7% from last March. Experts attribute the price dip in mature estates to older flat price weakness, while the Government's new CPF loan rules and Home Improvement Programme II may improve buyer perception. Premium buyers were willing to pay over market value, with median TOX rising in some estates.

site_title: New Zealand PM helps out a fellow mum
summary: New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern paid for a mother's groceries after the woman forgot her purse and had two young children in tow. The gesture, which Ardern described as "because she was a mum," comes after she received widespread praise for her response to the Christchurch mosque attacks. Ardern has been a vocal advocate for gun control and has taken steps to tighten gun laws in the country. The incident showcases her empathetic side and reinforces her reputation as a compassionate leader.

site_title: The Australian store where everything sold is sent to China
summary: An Australia Post store in northern Sydney sells only products shipped to China, with staff speaking Mandarin and shelves stocked with premium foreign goods. The "daigou trade" allows customers like Cathy Wang to buy products overseas and resell them in China, avoiding taxes. The store's success has led to similar ventures in Melbourne and downtown Sydney, catering to China's insatiable demand for foreign-made goods. The store's popularity may increase after China reduces postal tax on food and medicines, effective from April 9.

site_title: German industrial orders slump most in over two years in February
summary: German industrial orders plummeted 4.2% in February, the largest decline in over two years, due to a slump in foreign demand. This follows a 2.1% decline in January. The unexpected fall contradicts forecasts of a 0.3% increase. The manufacturing sector's weakness is attributed to Brexit woes, global uncertainties, and international trade disputes. Germany's economic growth forecast for 2019 has been cut to 0.8% from 1.9% due to the decline in industrial orders.

images.alt_text: German industrial orders fell at their sharpest rate in more than two years in February as they were hit by a slump in foreign demand, compounding worries that Europe's largest economy had a weak start to the year.

site_title: Distressed Hyflux says Salim-Medco rescue is off; but investor 'surprised' by news
summary: Hyflux, a Singapore water and power plant company, has cancelled a key rescue deal with Salim-Medco, an Indonesian investment group led by billionaire Anthoni Salim. The deal, valued at S$530 million, was set to provide a 60% stake in Hyflux in exchange for a portion of the company's debt. Hyflux cited Salim-Medco's concerns over working capital requirements and cash distribution plans as the reason for the deal's termination. With the deal off, Hyflux now faces a court-sanctioned reprieve from creditors set to expire on April 30, and may seek new investors or alternative opportunities to avoid liquidation.

site_title: Bank Indonesia keeps rates on hold amid global risks
summary: Bank Indonesia has kept interest rates unchanged amid global uncertainties, citing external stability and the US Federal Reserve's rate hikes on hold. Governor Perry Warjiyo plans to focus on macro-prudential policies to support economic growth, predicting a 12% loan growth this year. The rupiah is seen strengthening further, driven by the Fed's dovish rate outlook and Bank Indonesia's policy response, with the currency advancing 7% in the past six months. Economic growth is expected to pick up this year, but authorities need to work harder to boost exports.

site_title: Plastoform calls for immediate trading suspension
summary: MAINBOARD-listed Plastoform Holdings has requested an immediate trading suspension due to its inability to continue operating as a going concern. The company cited Rule 1303(3)(c) of the Singapore Exchange Securities Trading (SGX-ST) listing manual, which allows for suspension when a company's shares may be halted due to financial concerns. Plastoform shares last traded at S$0.013 on March 25. The board will assess the group's ability to continue operating and keep shareholders updated on any material updates or developments.

site_title: Thyssenkrupp to set up 3D printing innovation centre in Singapore
summary: Thyssenkrupp, a German multinational conglomerate, plans to establish an innovation center for additive manufacturing (3D printing) in Singapore, its first outside of Germany. The center, expected to launch this year, will serve as a regional hub for the company's Mülheim TechCenter, focusing on metal and plastic technologies for automotive, capital goods, and other heavy industries. The hub aims to create jobs, co-innovate with local businesses, and unlock the potential of additive manufacturing for customers in Singapore and the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: South Korea launches 5G networks early to secure world first
summary: South Korea launched the world's first nationwide 5G mobile networks two days early, ahead of its previously announced April 5 launch date. Three top telecom providers, SK Telecom, KT, and LG Uplus, began their 5G services at 11pm local time on April 3. The launch came after speculation that US carrier Verizon might start its 5G services early, prompting South Korean providers to hastily organize the launch. The services will be available to general customers on April 5, when Samsung Electronics releases the Galaxy S10 5G smartphone.

site_title: Financial stability risks remain for Thailand, says central bank governor
summary: Thailand's central bank governor Veerathai Santiprabhob expressed concerns over financial frailties in the economy, despite recent efforts to address them. Interest rates have been "low for too long," leading to an under-pricing of risk, prompting a policy rate hike in December. The central bank aims to balance competing challenges, including elevated debt levels and subdued inflation, and expects a moderate slowdown in economic growth to 3.8% this year. Political risk remains, following an inconclusive general election, but the baht has appreciated due to a current-account surplus and foreign reserves.

site_title: China's Tencent raises US$6b in bond sale; proceeds for general purposes
summary: China's Tencent Holdings Ltd raised US$6 billion in a bond sale, the largest in Asia this year, to refinance and cover general corporate purposes. The sale consisted of five-year, seven-year, 10-year, and 30-year notes with varying interest rates. The tech giant had previously announced plans to increase its Global Medium Term Note Programme limit to US$20 billion. The bond sale comes after a rough 2018 for the company, marked by a 32% decline in net profit due to regulatory issues.

site_title: US sets 2025 target for China to fulfil trade pledges: sources
summary: The US has set a 2025 deadline for China to meet its commitments under a proposed trade deal, including buying more US commodities and allowing 100% foreign ownership of US companies in China. The deal would also include benchmarks for China to fulfill its pledges, with penalties for non-compliance. US officials are pushing for China to front-load commodity purchases in the first two years of the agreement to narrow the trade deficit. However, enforcement mechanisms and the fate of imposed tariffs remain contentious issues in the negotiations.

site_title: Share prices of Synagie Corp, Y Ventures surge 40% prompting SGX queries
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has queried Synagie Corp and Y Ventures after their shares surged 40% in early morning trade. The surge comes after Synagie launched its mobile app and cloud platform offering "pay-as-you-use" lifestyle insurance policies, and Y Ventures appointed an independent reviewer to assess lapses in its internal controls.

site_title: Facebook removes exposed user records stored on Amazon's servers
summary: Facebook has removed public databases containing its user data after a cybersecurity firm, UpGuard, discovered millions of exposed records on Amazon's servers. The records included identification numbers, comments, and account names, with 540 million records found on a Mexico City-based news website and 22,000 records on another app. Facebook stated that its policies prohibit storing user data in public databases, and it worked with Amazon to take down the databases once alerted to the issue.

site_title: Virgin Australia cuts staff deal with Brunei airline over Sharia law
summary: Virgin Australia has cancelled a staff travel agreement with Royal Brunei Airlines due to the adoption of Sharia law in Brunei, which includes the death penalty for gay sex and other punishments deemed unacceptable in Australia. The agreement, which allowed staff to book discounted tickets, was terminated immediately. The decision follows international criticism of Brunei's human rights record, with the UN labelling the punishments a "clear violation" of human rights. The move comes as Brunei becomes the first country in East or Southeast Asia to implement a national sharia penal code.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Thursday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Thursday, with the Nikkei 225 index down 0.16% and the Topix index down 0.20%. Investors locked in profits from recent gains, leading to the decline.

site_title: Trump to meet China's top trade negotiator at the White House on Thursday
summary: US President Donald Trump is set to meet with Chinese Vice Premier Liu He at the White House on Thursday, signaling a potential deal to end the tariff battle between the two countries. The meeting comes as US and Chinese negotiators work to find a binding agreement addressing Trump's complaints about unfair treatment of US companies by China, which would allow a rollback of tariffs hitting businesses in both countries. site_title: Stocks to watch: SingPost, Ying Li International, Swee Hong, Eneco Energy, Metech International
summary: Singapore stocks to watch on Thursday include SingPost, which will sell off its struggling US e-commerce units, and Ying Li International Real Estate, which received a mandatory unconditional cash offer from China Everbright. site_title: Australia, New Zealand dollars dare to hope on Sino-US trade truce
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars rose as signs of progress in the Sino-US trade dispute boosted risk assets and commodity prices. The Aussie dollar reached a one-month high at 79.45 yen, while the New Zealand dollar climbed to US$0.6798, away from its recent trough. site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 0.80 points to 1,644.01. site_title: Canadian couple find lost ticket to become last-minute lottery millionaires
summary: A Quebec couple, Nicole Pedneault and Roger Larocque, won C$1 million in the lottery after discovering a forgotten winning ticket from an April 5, 2018 drawing. The ticket was found in a book while looking for materials for a school project, and they claimed their prize just in time, as the deadline to claim winnings was Friday. The couple attributes their win to chance, stating "it's all just by chance that we found it at the last minute like that."

site_title: New York debuts arts complex vowing cultural 'equity' in glitzy Manhattan
summary: The Shed, a new arts complex in Manhattan's Hudson Yards, is set to debut on Friday, offering an "everyman's art space" with a focus on cultural "equity." The eight-floor complex features galleries, a theatre, and a rehearsal space, with an initial season of nearly all newly commissioned work. The Shed aims to provide equal access to art, with exhibits and shows priced at $10 and free for children, and 10% of attendees paying $10 for shows. The complex is part of a larger effort to revitalize the area and provide a cultural hub for the community.

site_title: Accused Christchurch gunman to face 50 murder charges: New Zealand police
summary: New Zealand police announced that Brenton Tarrant, accused of carrying out the Christchurch mosque attacks, will face 50 murder charges when he appears in court this week. This is an upgrade from his previous one murder charge, reflecting the total deaths and injuries from the March 15 attacks.

site_title: Two years in a Singapore jail sound good? Just use the wrong ship fuel
summary: Singapore is cracking down on shipping companies that cheat on sulfur emissions rules, which come into effect next year. Vessels that burn overly sulfurous fuel in the country's territorial waters could face up to 2 years in prison and fines of up to S$10,000. The penalties are among the strongest deterrents yet to combat pollution, which is blamed for asthma and acid rain. Singapore will inspect ships and employ fuel-testing services to ensure compliance, and has issued technical guides to help the industry transition to cleaner fuels.

site_title: Tradeweb Markets platform raises US$1.1b in US IPO
summary: Tradeweb Markets Inc raised US$1.1 billion in its US IPO, selling 40 million shares at US$27 apiece, exceeding its marketed range. site_title: Pine Capital pumps in S$66,895 for unit's base capital to meet MAS requirement
summary: Pine Capital, a Catalist-listed firm, injected S$66,895 into its 51%-owned subsidiary, Advance Capital Partners Asset Management (ACPAM), by subscribing for 277 new shares at S$241.50 per share to meet Monetary Authority of Singapore's base capital requirement. site_title: Libra Group to sell Malaysian investment property for S$8m
summary: Libra Group is selling a Malaysian investment property comprising 12 leasehold lands in Kuala Lumpur for S$8 million. The sale is part of a post-acquisition covenant stemming from Libra's acquisition of YC Travel & Tours in 2018. The property's carrying value is about S$8.5 million, with a S$0.5 million deficit that will be assumed by executive chairman and shareholders. The disposal is expected to generate S$7.7 million in net proceeds, which will be used to repay indebtedness and working capital purposes. The sale is subject to approval from the State Authority of Malaysia within six months.

site_title: Asia: Markets rally tempered by profit-taking, eyes on trade talks
summary: Asian markets rallied, but profit-taking tempered gains, with investors awaiting trade talks between China and the US. Hopes of a trade deal and optimism about Britain's EU exit also boosted trading floors. The pound extended gains. High-level talks between China and the US resumed in Washington, with reports suggesting an agreement is near.

site_title: Hot stock: Genting Singapore down 8% at midday; analysts positive on long-term prospects
summary: Genting Singapore's shares dropped 8.5 cents, or 7.9%, to 98.5 cents at midday on April 4, 2019, amid a selloff driven by the impact of a 50% increase in casino entry levies for Singaporeans and permanent residents, and higher casino tax rates. Analysts remain positive on the company's long-term prospects, citing a S$4.5 billion reinvestment plan for Resorts World Sentosa. Brokerages have lowered their target prices, but most maintain "buy" calls, expecting the casino operator's earnings to recover in 2024-2025.

site_title: How ASEAN Can Effectively Address the Data Privacy Conundrum
summary: ASEAN, a rapidly growing tech adopter region, is developing privacy and cyber security laws in response to data breaches and fake news scandals. The region's governments must balance individual rights and national sovereignty while adopting common principles and avoiding conflating privacy and security. ASEAN can draw from models like the OECD Privacy Framework, EU's GDPR, and APEC's Cross-Border Privacy Rules, with the latter being more compatible with the "ASEAN Way." A bottom-up approach, like the CBPR, may provide a more suitable framework for developing national privacy regulations and ensuring personal data protections.

site_title: UN calls Brunei's anti-gay law a clear violation of human rights
summary: UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres criticized Brunei's new Islamic sharia laws, calling them a clear violation of human rights. The laws allow for death by stoning for adultery and gay sex, sparking global criticism. Despite this, the laws took effect on Wednesday. Guterres stated his opposition to any form of cruel punishment and emphasized the protection of all people's rights to love and choose their partners.

site_title: Tesla to show self-driving car progress to investors
summary: Tesla will showcase its self-driving car progress to investors on April 19 at its Silicon Valley headquarters, led by CEO Elon Musk. The company aims to bolster confidence in its autonomous driving software and hardware, including its FSD computer. The event will include test drives, providing an in-depth look at the technology. This move comes amid concerns about the technology's readiness for deployment, following a recent study by China-based Tencent Keen Security Lab that demonstrated a self-driving Tesla's vulnerability to interference.

site_title: Colliers hires new South Asia head for workplace solutions business
summary: Colliers International has appointed Ana Ballesteros as the new head of its workplace solutions business in South Asia, effective April 1, 2019. She will be based in Singapore and will help clients develop real estate solutions to "foster business goals and optimise employee experience." Ballesteros replaces Samarth Kasturia, who left for CBRE Group, and brings over 15 years of international experience in design, infrastructure, and strategy planning across various regions. She will report to Truddy Cheung, head of workplace solutions, Asia.

site_title: Oil eases on US crude stock build but holds near 5-month high
summary: Oil prices eased on Wednesday after US crude inventories rose 7.2 million barrels, but held near a five-month high due to Opec-led output cuts and sanctions on Iran. Brent futures settled at $69.31 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude settled at $62.46 a barrel. Despite the increase in US inventories, market participants expect prices to rise due to tightening global supply and signs of demand picking up, driven by Opec's output cuts and US sanctions on Iran.

site_title: Forever young: study uncovers protein that keeps skin youthful
summary: Scientists have discovered a protein, COL17A1, that helps maintain youthful skin by encouraging cell competition. This process drives out weaker cells and promotes the replication of stronger ones, keeping skin intact and unimpaired. The study suggests that COL17A1 may hold the key to keeping skin young, potentially providing a new approach to anti-aging treatments.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise on hopes around US-China deal and Brexit
summary: European shares rose for a fourth consecutive session on April 3, 2019, driven by hopes of a US-China trade deal and a smoother Brexit. The Stoxx 600 index rose 1% to its highest level in nearly eight months, with gains on bourses across the continent. Positive sentiment was fueled by strong economic data in China and the Eurozone, including retail sales in the Eurozone and activity in China's services sector. The market's optimism also extended to individual stocks, with some rising as much as 5.6%.

site_title: BOJ keeps eye on risks even as Japan posts positive output gap
summary: Japan's economy posted a positive output gap of 2.2% in October-December, the largest in over 26 years, exceeding its full capacity. This positive gap could lead to inflation, but the Bank of Japan (BOJ) may maintain a dovish tone due to heightening overseas risks, including China's slowdown. Business confidence hit a two-year low, but the BOJ still expects a moderate growth rebound in the latter half of the year. The central bank will review policy at its April rate review, considering the risks of prolonged easing and a lack of policy ammunition.

site_title: Brexit hardliners outplayed by May's Brexit move
summary: Theresa May has announced a plan to delay Brexit for a second time, seeking a delay to Britain's April 12 departure, after hardline Brexiters in her Conservative Party misjudged her intentions. The move risks splitting the Conservatives and may lead to a softer Brexit. Many MPs who voted against May's divorce deal want no-deal Brexit, but her plan could result in a deal, potentially splitting the party.

site_title: Democrats formally seek six years of Trump tax returns from IRS
summary: House Democrats have formally requested six years of President Donald Trump's personal and business tax returns from the IRS, citing congressional oversight responsibility. The request, led by Ways and Means chairman Richard Neal, aims to review the president's business activities before and during his first term. Trump has refused the request, stating he won't turn over returns until under audit. The decision could lead to a protracted legal battle, with the Treasury Department and Democrats prepared to sue if the request is denied.

site_title: Pence tears into Germany, Turkey on Nato anniversary
summary: US Vice-President Mike Pence criticized Germany for not spending enough on defense, saying it cannot ensure the West's defense if allies rely on Russia. Pence also targeted Turkey for buying a Russian arms system, stating "we cannot ensure the defence of the West if our allies grow dependent on Russia." The comments came on the 70th anniversary of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (Nato) as foreign ministers gathered in Washington to discuss a united front against Russia.

site_title: Top warning signs of a company in trouble: report
summary: A new report by Mak Yuen Teen and Richard Tan identifies 16 early warning signs and red flags for companies in trouble, including unexplained changes in results, foreign incorporation, and non-payment of dividends. The "B-C-D-E Model" uses publicly available information to help retail investors spot potential issues. The report cites real-life examples of Singapore Exchange-listed companies to illustrate the issues covered, aiming to help investors stay vigilant and minimize losses. The full report is available on CPA Australia and governanceforstakeholders.com.

site_title: In politics and gay? So what, say most US voters
summary: US politics have seen a significant shift in cultural attitudes, with openly gay and lesbian candidates winning mayoral races in Chicago, Madison, and Kansas City, and a third earning a spot in a runoff. This comes after a "Rainbow wave" of LGBTQ candidates across America in 2018, with the number of openly gay elected officials nationwide nearly doubling to 682. Young Americans are increasingly accepting of LGBTQ individuals, with 68% being enthusiastic or comfortable with a gay presidential candidate, according to a recent NBC News survey.

site_title: US says poised to pump dollars into Venezuela after Maduro
summary: The US is poised to pump dollars into Venezuela's economy if President Nicolas Maduro leaves, according to White House economic advisor Larry Kudlow. The plan, dubbed "Day Two," aims to fortify the country's crushed economy and would involve working with banks and the International Monetary Fund. Dollars would be used initially to reignite economic activity, with plans to introduce bolivares later. The timeline for Maduro's departure is uncertain, but Kudlow stated the US would move as fast as possible once he leaves, providing immediate economic assistance.

site_title: SingPost puts its struggling US e-commerce units on the market
summary: SingPost, a Singaporean postal company, announced the sale of its two struggling US e-commerce subsidiaries, Jagged Peak and TradeGlobal, amid a strategic review of the US businesses deemed under-performing. The sale process has not lined up potential buyers, and the divestment decision follows an impairment risk to the units' book value. The group will focus on its strengths in South-east Asia and Asia-Pacific, where it sees attractive growth opportunities, and will grow its investments in the Singapore market to leverage its competitive advantages.

site_title: US ex-VP Biden says will be 'more mindful' about personal space
summary: Former US Vice President Joe Biden has stated that he will be more mindful of personal space after facing criticism over physical contact with women. Biden, who is considering a 2020 presidential run, has faced allegations of inappropriately touching women, including former Nevada state lawmaker Lucy Flores and Connecticut's Amy Lappos. In a video message, Biden acknowledged that "social norms are changing" and that he will respect personal boundaries in the future. He has maintained that his actions were never driven by malice or misconduct, and has previously been praised by colleagues for his efforts to empower women and prevent abuse.

site_title: Hollywood actresses appear in court in US college admissions bribery case
summary: Hollywood actresses Felicity Huffman and Lori Loughlin appeared in a Boston court to face charges in a college admissions bribery case. Huffman, known for "Desperate Housewives," and Loughlin, known for "Full House," were accused of paying $15,000 and $500,000, respectively, to cheat on college entrance exams. The scandal involved 50 people, including top industry CEOs, and involved bribing coaches and university administrators. Huffman and Loughlin have remained silent since their March charges, with no parent having yet pleaded guilty. Negotiations between their attorneys and the Massachusetts federal prosecutor are ongoing, potentially leading to plea agreements.

site_title: The best places to own a vacation home in the US
summary: Mountain resorts in the US top Bloomberg's Wealthiest US Vacation Havens Index, with Aspen and Jackson Hole ranking among the top five. Summit Park, Utah, takes the top spot due to its high average sale price of single-family homes ($1.6 million) and household income ($200,000). Other top-ranked areas include Deer Valley Resort, Colorado, and popular beach locations such as Key West, Florida, and Martha's Vineyard, Hawaii. The index highlights areas with high home values, real estate industry employment, and household income, making them ideal for luxury vacation homes.

site_title: Money FM podcast: Influence: Author Rosie Milne of 'Olivia and Sophia'
summary: Rosie Milne, author of 'Olivia and Sophia', discusses her book on the Money FM podcast 'Influence'. The book is a historical account of Thomas Stamford Raffles and his two wives, Olivia and Sophia, told through fictional diaries. Milne recounts the real-life stories of Raffles and his relationships, shedding light on his life and influence. The podcast is available for download on various platforms, including Money FM's website and Spotify.

site_title: Ex-Nissan chief Ghosn rearrested in Tokyo
summary: Former Nissan chief Carlos Ghosn was rearrested in Tokyo on fresh financial misconduct allegations, just a month after his dramatic release on bail. Prosecutors claim Ghosn misused at least $32 million in Nissan funds, including a luxury boat for himself and his family. He faces three charges of financial misconduct, including under-reporting his compensation and transferring losses to Nissan's books. Ghosn denies any wrongdoing and has vowed to "not be broken" despite the latest arrest, which has sparked concerns over Nissan's corporate governance.

images.alt_text: Former Nissan chief Carlos Ghosn was rearrested early on Thursday in Tokyo on fresh financial misconduct allegations, with the auto tycoon slamming his detention as "outrageous and arbitrary".

site_title: South Korea to launch world's first national 5G networks
summary: South Korea launches the world's first nationwide 5G mobile networks, a significant leap in wireless technology. The rollout heralds the potential for transformative changes in daily life, from toasters to power grids. The US and China are among those vying for control of this innovation, while giants like Huawei are also involved. This technological advancement is expected to have far-reaching impacts, shaping the future of communication, transportation, and more.

site_title: US: Stocks push higher on trade deal optimism
summary: US stocks rose on Wednesday, pushing higher on optimism over US-China trade talks. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.2%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index climbed 0.2% and 0.6%, respectively. Analysts believe a major trade deal could be imminent, citing a report that the US and China had resolved most issues. Despite disappointing economic data, including a slower-than-expected services sector and lower-than-expected job growth, stocks remained upbeat, with chip companies leading the gains.

site_title: Casino tax rates to rise; entry levies up by 50%
summary: The Singapore government is introducing a tiered casino tax structure with higher tax rates effective March 2022 to curb problem gambling. The tax rates will increase from 5% to 8% for premium gaming and from 15% to 18% for mass gaming, with rates of 12% and 22% applying to revenues exceeding $2.4 billion and $3.1 billion respectively. Additionally, casino entry levies for Singaporeans and permanent residents will increase by 50% to $150 daily and $3,000 annual. The measures aim to promote responsible gaming and are not expected to significantly increase fiscal revenue.

site_title: Ethiopian Airlines 737 crash report expected on Thursday: sources
summary: Ethiopian officials are expected to release preliminary conclusions from the investigation into the March 10 crash of a Boeing 737, which killed 157 people. The report is expected to be published late Thursday morning in Ethiopia, marking a significant milestone in the probe.
