The conclusions are expected to shed light on the causes of the crash, which occurred just five months after a similar Lion Air 737 crash in Indonesia. The investigation has been ongoing since the crash, with the release of preliminary conclusions expected to be a key step forward.

site_title: Falling inflation, high lending rates ensnare Indian firms
summary: India's economic growth is slowing, with falling inflation rates and high lending rates affecting businesses. Profit margins are being crushed, hindering capital spending and job creation. The Reserve Bank of India's interest rate decision will be crucial, with real interest rates too high, according to economists. The government's subsidy for farmers to lower bank lending rates for them is not translating to benefits for manufacturers, who pay 12-14% annual rates. The country's general election is set to take place, with Prime Minister Narendra Modi expected to win a second term.

site_title: Citing climate differences, Shell quits US refining lobby
summary: Royal Dutch Shell Plc announced plans to leave the US refining lobby American Fuel & Petrochemical Manufacturers (AFPM) due to disagreement over climate policies. The move, part of Shell's drive to increase transparency, comes as the company supports the Paris climate agreement's goal to limit global warming by reducing carbon emissions to a net zero by the end of the century. Shell cited "material misalignment" with AFPM's stance on climate policy, including opposition to a price on carbon and action on low-carbon technologies. The decision is the latest sign of investor pressure on oil companies to address climate change.

site_title: Theresa May holding Brexit talks with Corbyn to forge a deal
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May is holding Brexit talks with opposition leader Jeremy Corbyn in an effort to forge a compromise that could finally clear parliament and deliver on Brexit. Despite initial agreement on key areas, the talks risk enflaming Conservative divisions, with two ministers quitting in protest. A "soft" Brexit that keeps Britain's economy closely aligned to the EU may become more likely, and the government has accepted this possibility. The talks come as the UK is set to leave the EU on April 12 without a deal, a scenario that could cause economic damage.

images.alt_text: Mrs May said she would seek another delay - as short as possible - to the current Brexit date of April 12.

site_title: COE prices close higher across the board
summary: COE premiums in Singapore closed higher across the board in the first round of bidding for April, with the open category increasing by 17.5% to S$48,209. The open category is used for bigger cars, while the commercial vehicle COE premium rose slightly to S$27,589. The significantly higher COE prices for larger cars may be driving consumers to choose smaller cars, leading to increased demand and higher prices for smaller cars.

site_title: Massive CIA cloud deal could be fulfilled by more than one company
summary: The CIA is set to award a massive cloud computing contract worth "tens of billions" of dollars to multiple cloud providers, including Amazon and Microsoft, by 2021. The C2E Commercial Cloud Enterprise contract, expected to be worth US$10 billion, will support the agency's national security mission and run parallel to a US$10 billion cloud effort by the Defense Department. This marks a departure from the CIA's past cloud computing efforts, which have primarily involved Amazon. The contract is expected to become a source of intense competition among cloud providers, with IBM, Oracle, and Google also vying for market share.

site_title: Singapore IRs bet on S$9b expansion; exclusive licences extended to 2030
summary: Singapore's two integrated resorts, Marina Bay Sands and Resorts World Sentosa, are investing S$9 billion in expansion, extending their exclusivity period to 2030. The IRs plan to build a 1,000-room all-suite tower at MBS and add attractions like Minion Park and Super Nintendo World at RWS. The expansion is expected to create up to 5,000 new jobs and boost the economy, with the IRs committing S$4.5 billion each. The expansion will also include additional gaming provisions and new non-gaming facilities, with the government planning to increase taxes on casino revenue to rein in problem gambling.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng

site_title: Netflix's dizzying valuation faces biggest test yet
summary: Netflix faces its biggest test yet as competitors Walt Disney Co, AT&T Inc, and Apple Inc prepare to launch their own streaming services. Disney's Disney+ will debut on April 11, while AT&T's service is expected to launch later. Apple's Apple TV+ is already available. Netflix's steep valuation will be put to the test as these companies enter the market, potentially changing the media landscape. Disney's strong content and Disney's theme parks' magic may give it an edge, while AT&T's substantial debt and Apple's ecosystem could also pose threats.

site_title: There are tentative signs that wild beasts of Chinese real estate are growing up
summary: China's real estate sector is showing signs of growth after a severe squeeze from Beijing's deleveraging campaign. Developers such as China Vanke and Yuzhou Properties are thriving, with sales increasing by 18% this year and refinancing becoming more accessible. The sector has become more prudent, with companies cutting land bank exposure and pre-selling properties to speed up cash collection. This shift in attitude may help tame the "wildest corporate beasts" and potentially lead to developers becoming investment-grade.

site_title: Helping remove the stigma surrounding mental issues
summary: New Zealand rugby legend John Kirwan is joining forces with insurer Cigna to raise awareness on mental well-being at the World Rugby Sevens tournament in Hong Kong. Kirwan, who has spoken publicly about his struggles with anxiety and depression, will share his personal experiences at a wellness summit. The "Converting Hearts & Minds" campaign aims to promote taking care of both mental and physical well-being, and Kirwan notes that more needs to be done to reduce stigma surrounding mental health issues.

site_title: Asia-Pac M&A deals dive 24% in first quarter to US$119b, lowest since 2014 Q1
summary: Asia-Pacific merger and acquisition (M&A) deals declined 24.5% to $119.9 billion in the first quarter of 2019, the lowest since 2014, due to economic headwinds and the US-China trade war. Notable exceptions were Singapore, Thailand, and Indonesia, where M&A value increased despite fewer deals. The consumer sector ranked second in value, and private equity firms saw buyouts drop to 66 deals worth $8.7 billion. Globally, M&A activity fell 15% to $801.5 billion, with only nine mega deals struck so far this year, mostly driven by US-based corporates.

images.alt_text: In Singapore, CapitaLand's bid to acquire Temasek subsidiary Ascendas-Singbridge was the largest M&A deal in Asia-Pacific ex-Japan during the period, according to latest research from deal intelligence service Mergermarket on Wednesday.

site_title: Singapore shares continue to build on gains
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,311.27, a fresh year-to-date high, up 31.49 points or 0.96% following improved Asian market sentiment due to US-China trade deal prospects and strong Australian retail and trade data.

site_title: Nestle goes meatless as trend grips the world
summary: Nestle has announced plans to introduce its plant-based burgers, the Incredible Burger, across Europe and the US this year. The meatless product will be sold under the Garden Gourmet brand in countries such as Germany, the Netherlands, and Sweden. This move is part of the growing trend towards vegetarian meals, as consumers increasingly demand more plant-based options.

site_title: BlackRock's Larry Fink starts biggest overhaul in years
summary: BlackRock CEO Larry Fink is implementing a significant overhaul, shifting leadership responsibility to region-specific leaders and installing new management in its alternatives division. The changes aim to cement client ties beyond the Americas, marking a path for growth beyond the US. Fink's memo also reorganizes staff, marking a major transformation for the financial powerhouse over its three-decade history.

site_title: How far do directors' duties extend?
summary: A Singaporean regulator has issued a stern warning to the independent directors of CAMSING Healthcare, who quit the board before resolving audit issues. The regulator's Notice of Compliance (NoC) criticized the directors for abandoning their responsibilities, saying they may not be deemed suitable for future directorships. The move sets a tone for directors' responsibilities, emphasizing their duty to steer the company to safety and not abandon their posts at the first sign of trouble. The regulator's actions aim to hold directors accountable, sparking debate on how far a director's duty extends, particularly in cases where they may be at risk.

site_title: New award to honour foreign brands in Singapore
summary: Singapore has launched a new award category, the SPBA - Global Brands award, to honour foreign brands that have grown their presence in the country over the past five years. This comes as Singapore continues to attract international businesses, establishing itself as an international business hub. The award aims to recognise the efforts of foreign brands that have established themselves in Singapore and contribute to the country's growing economy.

site_title: What is the scariest retirement healthcare number?
summary: A typical couple in retirement could face US$285,000 in out-of-pocket healthcare costs, mainly due to long-term care costs not covered by Medicare. Nursing care costs exceed US$80,000 per year, and home healthcare costs are even higher. Long-term care insurance is expensive, with major providers like Genworth exiting the market. However, limited policies and health savings accounts can help mitigate costs, and Medicare often covers dental and vision expenses. Americans aged 50-64 are most concerned about healthcare costs, with 54% worried about covering expenses before Medicare kicks in.

site_title: Silicon Valley firm eager to earn its stripes in South-east Asia
summary: Silicon Valley firm Stripe is expanding its presence in South-east Asia, valuing its operations in the region at $22.5 billion. After launching in Singapore in 2016, Stripe has expanded to Japan, Malaysia, and Hong Kong, with beta programs in India and Malaysia. Stripe's chief business officer Billy Alvarado expressed excitement for the long-term opportunity in the region, aiming to tap into the booming internet economy. The company's expansion marks a significant move in the region's growing tech landscape.

site_title: Trade talk optimism fuels gains in Aussie, yuan
summary: The Australian dollar and Chinese yuan gained value on Wednesday due to optimism over trade talks between the US and China, with reports of progress in negotiations supporting markets. The Aussie rose 0.7% to US$0.7127, while the yuan reached a high of 6.7050 yuan per dollar. The euro also rebounded, rising 0.4% to US$1.1246, as risk appetite recovered and investors pulled back from safe-haven currencies like the yen and Swiss franc.

site_title: Pernod Ricard betting on growth from green stance
summary: Pernod Ricard, the world's second-largest spirits group, has unveiled a strategic roadmap plan to 2030, pledging to preserve land, save water, and cut waste. The company aims to halve its carbon footprint, replenish 100% of water consumption, and ban single-use plastic promotional items by 2025. The plan also includes efforts to fight alcohol abuse and promote gender balance in top management teams. The move is seen as a response to consumer demands for environmentally friendly and socially responsible business practices, and is expected to boost growth and attract investments.

site_title: OCBC said to be seeking buyer for Mt Elizabeth property
summary: OCBC is seeking a buyer for its 22-storey freehold serviced-residence development at 2, Mount Elizabeth Link, worth at least S$2,500 psf on approved GFA. The 72 serviced apartments are leased to Frasers Hospitality and are located near Mount Elizabeth Hospital. OCBC appointed Cushman & Wakefield as the exclusive marketing agent. The property's estimated value could be S$261 million, based on existing gross floor area, with potential for hotel development approval.

site_title: Biggest Saudi oil field is fading faster than anyone guessed
summary: Saudi Arabia's largest oil field, Ghawar, produces a maximum of 3.8 million barrels per day, significantly lower than the estimated 5.8 million barrels per day previously believed. The field's reduced capacity was revealed in Saudi Aramco's first-ever profit figures and bond prospectus, contradicting previous claims made by the company and US oil banker Matt Simmons in the 2000s. The new details highlight the field's depletion and the shifting balance of power in the global oil market, with the Permian in the US now the largest oil production basin.

site_title: Conference on future of food, nutrition, targeted at the consumer
summary: Singapore's healthy life expectancy has not increased as much as its life expectancy, with 8 years of ill health on average. The country has the 2nd highest proportion of diabetics among developed nations, projected to affect over 1 million by 2050. The inaugural World Food Future conference, organized by Halo Health Asia, focused on food nutrition, sustainability, and safety, with the consumer as a key stakeholder. The event aimed to address the imbalance in decision-making power between consumers, businesses, and policymakers. All conference proceeds will support a school nutrition education programme.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Brokerages maintain positive views on ComfortDelGro, citing growth in public transportation, profit contributions from new acquisitions, and improved taxi earnings. RHB Research Institute sets a target price of S$2.65 and recommends buying if the share price drops below S$2.50. Sasseur Reit is also upgraded to "Add" with a target price of S$0.92, citing its first-mover advantage in the Chinese retail market and potential for inorganic growth.

site_title: Google's US workforce now more Asian, and less white and male
summary: Google's US workforce has shifted, with Asian employees now making up 39.8% of the workforce, a 1.7% increase. White employees account for 54.4%, while black workers still have the highest attrition rates. Women have gained ground in technical jobs, but still make up less than a quarter of those roles globally. The company also reported increases in women and people of color among new hires, and a decline in attrition rates for these groups. However, significant work remains to achieve diversity and inclusion goals.

site_title: UOB chief's pay rises 12% to S$10.56m in 2018
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) CEO Wee Ee Cheong's pay rose 12% to S$10.56 million in 2018, driven by a 15.5% increase in his cash bonus and share plan. The bank's net profit and revenue hit record highs, with a three-fold increase in deposit inflows and 25% of wholesale banking income coming from cross-border revenue. Despite market volatility, UOB expects mid single-digit growth for loans and fee income.

site_title: 8 in 10 Singapore CFOs struggle to hire qualified finance professionals: Robert Half
summary: In Singapore, 83% of CFOs struggle to hire qualified finance professionals, with the challenge expected to worsen in the next five years. The demand for commercially-savvy talent is high due to company expansion, with top earners commanding up to S$200,000 annually. The survey highlights the need for finance leaders to recruit technologically-adept candidates, train, and develop staff to secure and retain top talent.

site_title: How IDs can get involved without interfering
summary: Independent directors can get involved in a company's affairs without interfering by striking a balance between asking questions and respecting management's autonomy. IDs must be confident to act without fear or favor, asking the right questions to drive governance and accountability. They should challenge management on key strategic decisions, but avoid over-zealous scrutiny of day-to-day operations. IDs must also navigate their involvement sensibly, meeting the "equilibrium of welcomed interference" as the company evolves. By aligning with management and being transparent, IDs can drive integrity and sustainability without hindering the business.

site_title: Trade war, Brexit could slow developing Asia's 2019, 2020 growth: ADB
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) predicts developing Asia's growth will slow to 5.7% in 2019, down from 5.9% in 2018 and 6.2% in 2017, due to rising economic risks from the China-US trade war and a potentially disorderly Brexit. This would be the second consecutive year of slower growth, affecting 45 countries in the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: UK defence contractor names first woman to chair Rolls Royce
summary: UK defence contractor Babcock International Group has announced that Ruth Cairnie, a veteran executive with 37 years of industry experience, will become the first woman to chair Rolls-Royce, starting on July 18. Cairnie, a non-executive director at Rolls-Royce since 2014, succeeds outgoing chairman Mike Turner, who retired amid declining share prices and financial warnings. Cairnie's appointment aims to address concerns about Babcock's financial health and customer relationships, particularly in the wake of Brexit uncertainties.

site_title: Is Trump's bromance with Putin over?
summary: US President Donald Trump's relationship with Russian President Vladimir Putin appears strained, with Trump facing pressure to demonstrate his ability to stand up to Putin. Despite previously praising Putin and showing respect, Trump's stance on Russia's involvement in the 2016 US presidential election has become increasingly critical. The recent deployment of Russian forces in Venezuela poses a strategic threat to US interests in the region, potentially straining the US-Russia relationship further.

site_title: The incredible shrinking Trump boom
summary: President Donald Trump's 2017 tax cut has failed to deliver the promised economic boom, instead leading to a brief sugar high followed by slowing growth. Independent observers, including the Federal Reserve, now estimate growth at around 1.5% in the first quarter of 2019. Trump blames the Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes for the failure, but experts argue that the tax cut's impact was overstated. The tax cut mainly encouraged companies to shift their tax avoidance strategies rather than invest in the US economy, with profits largely being booked in low-tax countries.

site_title: Oil hits 2019 high as supply squeeze looms
summary: Oil prices reached a 2019 high of US$69.37 a barrel, driven by concerns over supply losses in Venezuela and Iran, with Brent crude approaching US$70 a barrel. The US is considering more sanctions against Iran, and three countries that previously received waivers have cut shipments to zero. A power outage halted operations at a Venezuelan crude terminal, further reducing global supplies. Opec supply hit a four-year low in March, and Russia's oil output remains below its pledged target.

site_title: Why May 23 could be Brexit Day as UK changes strategy
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May is set to ask Brussels for a deadline extension to May 23 for the UK's Article 50 process, potentially making May 23 a "Brexit Day." This comes as May explores a cross-UK party deal on Brexit, which could lead to a softer exit based on a customs union and/or closer relationship with the European Single Market. The move aims to avoid a disorderly exit, but some in the EU are skeptical that an additional short extension will be enough time to forge consensus.

site_title: Keppel Reit prices S$200m of 5-year convertibles at favourable end of price range
summary: Keppel Reit priced a S$200 million 5-year convertible bond offering at the most favourable end of its price range, with a coupon of 1.9% and initial conversion price of S$1.4625. The deal was oversubscribed and will be used to refinance debt and fund a potential acquisition. Notable features include a put option after three years and a call option after three years, subject to a 30% premium over the conversion price. The trust's units ended 3 cents lower at S$1.27 following the announcement.

site_title: Tutopiya takes travelling out of the home-tutoring picture
summary: Tutopiya, an online tutoring platform founded by Nuha Ghouse, is seeking S$2 million in Series A capital to fund regional growth. The platform offers one-on-one online tutoring for students aged 8-18, covering various syllabuses, and charges rates 20% lower than home tuition rates. Tutopiya employs tutors and provides training and quality control measures to ensure high-quality teaching. Since its soft launch last year, the company has acquired over 200 students and plans to expand into eight overseas markets, including the UAE, US, China, and Australia.

site_title: Japan Display to supply OLED screens for Apple Watch
summary: Japan Display Inc. will supply OLED screens for the Apple Watch starting later this year, marking the company's entry into the OLED display market. This comes after Japan Display's mainstay LCD business slumped due to Apple's shift away from LCD and disappointing iPhone XR sales. The OLED technology offers thinner screens and greater flexibility. Japan Display, which gets over half its revenue from Apple, is seeking up to $990 million in fresh financing.

site_title: Accountability: Corporate America needs a wake-up call
summary: Wells Fargo CEO Tim Sloan has retired after years of pressure, following the departure of his predecessor John Stumpf in 2016. The company has faced numerous scandals, including the fake-accounts scam that affected tens of thousands of customers. However, the lack of accountability for top executives has allowed them to avoid jail time and multimillion-dollar payouts. Critics argue that prosecutors often fail to hold executives criminally accountable, citing the difficulty in proving intent, and that this culture of complicity warps the incentives for corporate leaders, allowing them to collect fat bonuses without risk of facing criminal liability.

site_title: OCBC Bank rolls out latest FRANK store at NUS University Town
summary: OCBC Bank has opened its fourth FRANK by OCBC Store at the National University of Singapore's Stephen Riady Centre. The 947-square-foot store features an open-concept design, a large LED screen, and a cashless payment snack machine. The store is designed to be a space for students to study, interact, and relax, upending the traditional bank image. The move aims to engage with the younger demographic, with the bank's market strategy paying off as FRANK account holders aged 16-29 have increased 12-fold since 2011.

images.alt_text: The new store, spanning 947 sq ft, is Singapore's first open-concept bank branch. There are no shutters or barriers to keep people out, allowing the premises to stay open all day.

site_title: Amtrak wasted US$23m on unneeded office space: report
summary: Amtrak wasted at least $23 million on unneeded office space in Boston, New York, and Washington, according to a report by the railroad's inspector general. The report found that many desks in Amtrak's office buildings are unoccupied, despite the company having downsized its workforce. Amtrak agreed with the report's four recommendations and plans to develop a long-term facility plan to ensure consistent decisions. The company maintains 24 leased or owned buildings in 12 cities, including Chicago, Seattle, and Los Angeles.

site_title: Ghosn tweets that he'll tell all at press conference on April 11
summary: Tokyo prosecutors are considering pressing a fourth charge against former Nissan boss Carlos Ghosn, alleging an aggravated breach of trust related to at least $32 million in Nissan funds transferred to an Oman distributor. Ghosn denies all allegations and has already faced three charges of financial misconduct. He plans to give his side of the story in a press conference on April 11, where he will "tell the truth" about the case. The new charge would not necessarily require Ghosn's return to detention, as prosecutors could file charges without justifying detention.

site_title: UniCredit nearing deal with US over Iran sanctions: sources
summary: UniCredit is nearing a $900 million deal with the US to resolve allegations it provided dollar-clearing services to Iranian clients in violation of US sanctions. The agreement would spare the Italian lender from criminal prosecution. This settlement, one of the largest for sanctions violations, would eliminate a pending risk for UniCredit and potentially boost its valuation. The agreement would resolve investigations by multiple US authorities and follow similar settlements by other European banks.

site_title: Ethiopian 737 pilots 'followed Boeing guidelines before crash'
summary: The pilots of the Ethiopian Airlines Boeing 737 MAX plane initially followed manufacturer guidelines before the crash, but failed to regain control. They switched off the Maneuvering Characteristics Augmentation System (MCAS) and then switched it back as they tried to control the jet before it crashed, killing 157 people. Preliminary findings suggest the MCAS, designed to automatically lower the aircraft's nose in case of a stall, was a key factor in both the Lion Air and Ethiopian crashes. The Ethiopian government is set to release a preliminary report this week.

site_title: Ford reboots European strategy with SUVs and mild electrification
summary: Ford is revamping its European strategy with a focus on SUVs and mild electrification, introducing four plug-in hybrids and two battery-powered models to boost sales and reduce emissions. The company aims to return to profitability with a 6% margin goal for Europe and will cut costs by collaborating with rivals and considering mergers. Ford's efforts come amid slowing sales and tightening emissions rules in the region, with the company preparing to close three plants in Russia and reconsider its UK footprint in the event of a no-deal Brexit.

site_title: Canada's Brookfield eyeing US$2b property deal in Shanghai
summary: Canada's Brookfield is planning to buy a commercial property site in Shanghai for around US$2 billion, including three office towers and a retail mall at the Greenland Huangpu Centre. This would be one of the largest commercial property deals in China by a foreign firm. Brookfield is also in talks with banks for a loan of up to US$1 billion to back the purchase, which would be part of its Brookfield Strategic Real Estate Partners III fund, with total equity commitments of US$15 billion.

site_title: Getting artsy
summary: Hong Kong has seen a significant growth in art galleries, with over 100 galleries now operating, thanks in part to the success of Art HK, which has evolved into Art Basel Hong Kong. The event has helped establish Hong Kong as a cultural hub, with a more relaxed approach to art censorship and the emergence of public art spaces. Despite potential restrictions from Beijing, Hong Kong continues to build a loyal arts audience both locally and internationally.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: TECHNICS Oil and Gas has called off its agreement to transfer its listing status to Insonotech due to unfulfilled conditions. CLEARBRIDGE Health acquired a 49% stake in PT Indo Genesis Medika for S$5.1 million. SUNPOWER secured a 34.5 million yuan manufacturing and services contract from East China Engineering Science and Technology Co. Companies face market uncertainty, with oil prices rising over 2% and stocks down in Europe due to bank and healthcare issues, as well as US-EU tariff concerns.

site_title: China soya sauce maker's shareholders mull sale
summary: Honworld Group Ltd, a Chinese soya sauce maker, is exploring a sale of more than 49% of its Hong Kong-listed firm. The company, which sells products under the "Lao Heng He" brand, is working with an adviser to reach potential buyers including Foshan Haitian Flavouring & Food Co and Lee Kum Kee Co. This would be the latest in a series of US$18.3 billion acquisitions of Asia-based food companies in the past year. The sale is at an early stage, and deliberations could still result in the company remaining independent.

site_title: Metech International appoints lead independent director
summary: Metech International has appointed Chay Yiowmin as a lead independent director, effective April 3, 2019. He will also serve as chairman of the audit committee and a member of the remuneration and nominating committees. Chay previously held roles at BDO LLP and Chay Corporate Advisory.

site_title: London backs plans for 'tulip' tower to bloom over city
summary: London has approved plans to build a 320-meter glass viewing tower, nicknamed the "Tulip," perched 1,000 feet above the city. The tower, designed by Foster and Partners, will be western Europe's second-tallest when completed. Despite concerns over views of the Tower of London and radar coverage, the planning committee voted to grant permission. The project, financed by Brazilian billionaire Jacob Safra, will include a glass viewing platform, rotating pods, and an education center, with construction set to begin in 2020 and finish in 2025.

site_title: UK junior Brexit minister quits over further delay to departure
summary: UK junior Brexit minister Chris Heaton-Harris resigned after Prime Minister Theresa May announced a request to delay Brexit, citing her lack of desire for a negotiated deal. Heaton-Harris stated that he couldn't support further extension and felt his role became irrelevant. This resignation follows Nigel Adams' earlier departure, who criticized May's "grave error" in judgment. The move has enraged the pro-Brexit wing of the Conservative Party, amidst ongoing talks with Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn.

images.alt_text: Junior Brexit minister Chris Heaton-Harris(L) became the second government member to resign on Wednesday after Prime Minister Theresa May said she would ask to delay Brexit again.

site_title: Once all-male Augusta National to see first woman winner
summary: The Augusta National Golf Club, an all-male enclave since its 1933 formation, will crown a historic first woman as a tournament champion at the inaugural Augusta National Women's Amateur. The event, set to conclude on Saturday, features 30 top young women competing on the legendary 18-hole layout. This milestone marks a significant step in advancing women's golf, following a 2003 protest and the introduction of female members in 2012, including Condoleezza Rice and Darla Moore.

site_title: US services sector cools in March as labour dries up
summary: The US services sector cooled in March, with the non-manufacturing index falling 3.6 points to 56.1, a deeper slowdown than expected. Business activity declined 7.3% and new orders fell 6.2 points, while prices rose. Despite this, employment gained, and 16 industries reported growth, while two - education services and retail trade - contracted. Companies struggle to find qualified workers, citing rising costs and a shortage of labor in industries such as hotels, restaurants, and transportation. The decline is seen as a sign of a cooling economy, but no recession is expected.

site_title: Lonza in joint venture to develop biotherapeutic products
summary: Lonza, a Swiss biotech company, has entered into a joint venture with Danish bioscience company Chr Hansen Holding to develop live biotherapeutic products (LBP) for pharma and biotech customers. The $136.6 million, 3-year investment will target the emerging pre-clinical and clinical supply industry. This move aims to capitalize on the growing demand for LBP, expected to reach $1 billion by 2035. The joint venture will provide a full supply chain for manufacturing of bacteria strains for therapeutic use, addressing an unmet need in the industry and enabling customers to deliver therapies for patients.

site_title: France stalls start of EU trade talks with US
summary: France has stalled the start of EU trade talks with the US, withholding its consent despite EU ambassadors' efforts to approve the mandate for trade commissioner Cecilia Malmstrom to negotiate tariff cuts. The EU could still approve the mandate in the coming days, but France's continued hesitation has delayed the talks. This development comes as the US has announced new tariffs on Vietnam, and the Asian garment industry is bracing for potential higher US tariffs. The delay may impact global trade negotiations and economic growth.

site_title: Asean collaboration key to unlocking potential of Industry 4.0
summary: Singaporean Senior Minister of State for Trade and Industry Koh Poh Koon emphasized the importance of Asean collaboration to unlock the region's full potential through Industry 4.0 transformation. With expertise and initiatives to share, Singapore is keen to support regional partners. Asean is expected to become the fourth-largest economy by 2030, with the potential to capture up to $600 billion in global benefits from Industry 4.0 by 2025. Singapore has launched initiatives such as the Smart Industry Readiness Index and a Prioritisation Matrix to aid companies in their Industry 4.0 transformation plans.

site_title: Najib in the dock for three hours; AG leads the prosecution
summary: Najib Razak, Malaysia's former Prime Minister, stood trial for three hours on corruption charges linked to the multibillion-dollar 1MDB scandal. He faces seven charges, including three counts of criminal breach of trust and money laundering, and one count of abuse of power. The trial, led by Attorney General Tommy Thomas, marks a significant test of Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad's promises to root out corruption. Najib has pleaded not guilty and claims the charges are politically motivated, with his defense team confident of winning.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 10.38 points to 1,643.21. The market saw a volume of 2.7 billion lots worth RM1.9 billion, with 490 gainers outnumbering 329 losers.

site_title: Europe: Shares climb for fourth day on trade optimism, China data
summary: European shares rose for the fourth consecutive day, driven by optimism over a possible trade deal between China and the US. The pan-European index climbed 0.7%, with Frankfurt's DAX outperforming peers. Strong economic data from China and potential Brexit delays also boosted sentiment. The US and China are set to resume trade talks this week, with White House economic adviser Larry Kudlow expressing confidence in progress.

site_title: Thai pro-marijuana party in high demand after disputed vote
summary: A Thai pro-marijuana party, Bhumjaithai, has emerged as a key partner after winning 39 constituency seats in the lower house following a disputed election. The party's leader, Anutin Charnvirakul, is being courted by two main parties, Phalang Pracharat and Pheu Thai, to secure party seats and allegiance. Bhumjaithai wants to allow households to grow six marijuana plants each in a decriminalized approach, and Anutin has expressed a desire for unity and a "Thailand first" approach in coalition talks.

site_title: Swee Hong supplier files winding-up application against company
summary: Swee Hong Limited's supplier, Hock Hin Leong Timber Trading, filed a winding-up application in the High Court on March 29 against the company for unpaid supplies. The hearing date is set for April 26. Swee Hong's operations are not expected to be significantly impacted.

site_title: Ghosn tweets about telling the truth as report says prosecutors readying new case
summary: Carlos Ghosn, the ousted Nissan boss, has tweeted that he will "tell the truth" at a news conference on April 11, after prosecutors reportedly prepared a new case against him. Ghosn faces charges of financial misconduct and aggravated breach of trust over allegedly failing to report $82 million in salary and temporarily transferring personal losses onto Nissan's books. Released on $9 million bail last month, Ghosn denies the charges and has called them "meritless." The new case is reportedly over payments made to a business partner in Oman, with prosecutors planning to decide soon on further charges.

site_title: Faulty 737 sensor in Lion Air crash linked to Florida repair station
summary: A faulty angle-of-attack sensor on a Lion Air 737 Max, linked to the jet's deadly crash and a similar incident, was repaired in a US aircraft maintenance facility before the tragedy. The sensor, manufactured by Rosemount Aerospace Inc, was installed on the plane in Bali after pilots reported instrument issues. The sensor's faulty signals triggered repeated nose-down movements, leading to the crash. The Indonesian National Transportation Safety Committee is seeking data from the Florida repair station where the sensor was worked on, and the US National Transportation Safety Board is conducting a review of the work performed.

site_title: China Everbright unit makes offer for Ying Li
summary: A unit of China Everbright, State Alpha, made a mandatory unconditional cash offer for Chongqing-based property developer Ying Li International Real Estate at S$0.14 per share, representing a 10.9% premium to the volume-weighted average price of the shares for the three-month period prior. The offeror plans to keep Ying Li listed and does not intend to exercise compulsory acquisition rights. The acquisition aims to leverage on the expertise and execution capabilities of CEL to support Ying Li's strategy and growth plans.

site_title: Australia shares rise on mining and healthcare gains; NZ slips
summary: Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.68% to a near seven-month high, driven by gains in mining and healthcare stocks. Iron ore prices surged due to supply disruptions, boosting miners like BHP Group and Rio Tinto. The Australian government's pre-election budget promised record spending for healthcare, lifting healthcare stocks. New Zealand's benchmark index slipped 0.19% after hitting a record high in the previous session.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher on US-China trade hopes
summary: Tokyo shares rose on Wednesday, gaining 0.97% to 21,713.21, following a report that the US and China were closing in on a trade deal. The dollar strengthened to 111.43 against the yen. Key stocks, including Fast Retailing and Fanuc, also increased, with Fast Retailing jumping 5.44% and Fanuc rising 2.72%. The market is supported by hopes for a historic agreement and a slightly cheaper yen.

site_title: Eneco Energy granted extension of time from SGX to hold AGM
summary: Eneco Energy Limited has been granted an extension of time by the Singapore Exchange (SGX) to hold its annual general meeting (AGM) by May 31, 2019, due to delays in completing its financial audit. The audit, led by Ernst & Young Indonesia, requires additional time to finalize its report on Eneco's FY2018 financial results. This extension also applies to an application made to the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority.

site_title: FDA investigating possible seizure risk with e-cigarette use
summary: The FDA is investigating possible seizures associated with e-cigarette use, particularly among young vapers. Over 35 reports of seizures have been received between 2010 and early 2023, raising concerns about a potential link. However, the agency has not yet confirmed a direct relationship between e-cigarette use and seizure risk. The investigation is ongoing, and the FDA is working to determine the cause of these seizures.

site_title: Paris, Berlin draw up tough rules for e-scooters
summary: Paris has adopted measures to control the proliferation of rental electric scooters, with a steep fine for riding on pavements. The city estimates 15,000 scooters will be operating by the end of the year, up from 15,000 since their introduction last year. This comes as other cities face similar issues, with critics arguing that companies often skip permits.

images.alt_text: The city of Paris on Wednesday adopted measures to rein in the swarm of rental electric scooters that have popped up around the city, including a steep fine for riding on pavements.

site_title: Indian companies squeezed as inflation falls but interest rates remain high
summary: India's businesses are facing a squeeze as inflation falls but interest rates remain high, crushing profit margins. With real interest rates increasing to 6.2% in 2017, Indian companies are struggling to invest and create jobs. The Reserve Bank of India is expected to cut its benchmark lending rate, but some experts argue that a more substantial cut is needed to boost economic growth. The country's slowest pace of growth in five quarters, a 14-year low in new investment proposals, and a widening gap between deposits and lending are also concerns, with many economists saying real interest rates in India are too high.

site_title: IRs to invest S$9b in major ramp-up of attractions; casino exclusivity period extended to 2030
summary: Singapore's two integrated resorts (IRs), Marina Bay Sands and Resorts World Sentosa, will invest S$9 billion in new tourist attractions and MICE facilities. The expansions are expected to create 5,000 new jobs and attract over half a million more visitors annually. The IRs will also expand their gaming provisions, including the option to deploy additional gaming areas and increase the number of gaming machines. The government has extended the exclusivity period for the two casinos to end-2030 and introduced a tiered casino tax structure with higher tax rates.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks rise most since February on trade talks optimism; won gains
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index rose 1.20% to its highest since February 27, driven by optimism over US-China trade talks. The won strengthened, and bond yields rose. Foreigners bought 273.9 billion won worth of shares, while US stocks remained flat. The US and China expect to make progress in trade talks this week, according to White House economic adviser Larry Kudlow. The Kospi has risen 7.95% this year, its highest since January 2018.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rise for seventh successive day
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose for a seventh consecutive day, with the Hang Seng Index increasing 1.22% to close at 29,986.39. This follows regional advances driven by optimism over a potential China-US trade deal. The Shanghai Composite Index also rose 1.24% and the Shenzhen Composite Index gained 0.82%.

site_title: UK's May meeting opposition leader to seek a deal
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May meets opposition leader Jeremy Corbyn in a bid to reach a Brexit compromise, aiming to overcome parliamentary divisions and finally pass a European Union divorce deal. The meeting comes after three rejected votes and a national crisis over Brexit, which was initially voted for in a referendum three years ago. The outcome of the meeting is uncertain, but a deal could bring stability to the UK's Brexit process.

site_title: SingPost says will sell struggling US businesses, but no details announced
summary: SingPost, a Singaporean mail and logistics company, has announced plans to sell its struggling e-commerce units in the US, Jagged Peak and TradeGlobal, amid financial difficulties. The divestment comes after a strategic review and follows a significant impairment of S$185 million for TradeGlobal in 2017. The sale process has begun, but no potential buyers or bankers have been lined up, and the impact on SingPost's businesses outside the US is expected to be minimal. The company's focus will remain on its growth opportunities in South-east Asia and Asia-Pacific.

site_title: COE prices close higher across the board
summary: Certificate of entitlement (COE) premiums in Singapore rose across the board, with the open category increasing by 17.5% to $48,209. Larger cars saw a 9.4% increase, while smaller cars rose 9.4% to $29,159. The higher prices are driving consumers to choose smaller cars, which in turn is increasing demand for smaller cars. The COE premium for commercial vehicles and motorcycles also increased slightly. Experts believe the price trend will continue, with room for further increases.

site_title: UOB chief sees pay rise 12% to S$10.56m in 2018
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) CEO Wee Ee Cheong received a 12% pay rise to S$10.56 million in 2018, driven mainly by a bonus increase to S$9.33 million. This surpasses DBS Group Holdings CEO Piyush Gupta's 15.5% pay rise to S$11.9 million. UOB's record net profit and revenue in 2018, largely due to increased deposit inflows and cross-border revenue, may face challenges from ongoing US-China trade tensions and a slowing China.

site_title: US: Wall Street rises at open on trade optimism
summary: US stocks rose at the open on Wednesday, resuming a rally after a pause, driven by optimism over trade talks with Beijing and China's economic recovery signs. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 58.90 points, or 0.22%, to 26,238.03, while the S&P 500 opened higher by 8.85 points, or 0.31%, to 2,876.09. The Nasdaq Composite gained 42.49 points, or 0.54%, to 7,891.18. The gains followed a pause in the previous session amid concerns over US-EU trade tensions.

images.alt_text: US stocks opened higher on Wednesday, resuming a rally after a pause in the previous session, fueled by optimism over trade talks with Beijing and as China's economy showed new signs of recovery.

site_title: Bitcoin hits fresh 2019 high as sudden rally shows staying power
summary: Bitcoin reached a fresh 2019 high, surging 5.9% to $5,087.54, amid a sudden and unexplained rally. The cryptocurrency has now risen over 77% from its low in last year's crash, fueling debate over whether a new bull market has begun. While some crypto diehards see the surge as confirmation, others argue that entrenched skepticism among regulators and investors will make any rally temporary.

site_title: Cross-border mega deals 'almost disappeared' in Q1 as global activity slumps: Report
summary: Global M&A activity slowed in Q1 2019 due to market volatility, US-China tensions, and economic headwinds, with the value of deals dropping 15% to $801.5 billion. The number of deals fell 30% to 3,558, with only nine mega deals (above $10 billion) completed, down from 14 in the same period last year. Outbound activity collapsed, with China's deals contracting amid tighter regulation and US clampdowns. However, Mergermarket remains optimistic, citing pockets of consolidation in hot sectors and private equity activity.

site_title: Singapore shares gain 1% on Wednesday as rally continues
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) gained 1% on Wednesday, closing at 3,311.27, driven by a rally in Asian markets. The rally was fueled by improving prospects of a US-China trade deal. Key gains were seen in local banks, with DBS Group Holdings, OCBC Bank, and United Overseas Bank rising 2.5%, 1.8%, and 1.4% respectively. Non-STI counters also posted gains, including Clearbridge Health, which rose 13%.

site_title: Singapore manufacturing activity picks up in March, but electronics still in decline
summary: Singapore's manufacturing activity showed a 0.4 percentage point increase in March, reversing the downward trend of the past six months, with an overall manufacturing PMI of 50.8. This marks 31 consecutive months of expansion. The electronics sector, however, remained in contraction for the fifth straight month with a PMI of 49.8. The improvement was attributed to faster growth in new orders, exports, and factory output, but slower growth in supplier deliveries and order backlogs.

site_title: Brunei sultan calls for 'stronger' Islam, as sharia laws to enter force
summary: Brunei's Sultan Hassanal Bolkiah has called for stronger Islamic teachings as strict new sharia punishments, including death by stoning for gay sex and adultery, were set to come into force. The penal code, which also includes amputation of hands and feet for thieves, will make Brunei the first place in East or South-east Asia to have a sharia penal code at the national level. The laws have sparked international condemnation, with the UN labeling them "cruel and inhumane."

site_title: Trade war, Brexit could slow developing Asia's 2019, 2020 growth - ADB
summary: Developing Asia's growth is expected to slow for the second consecutive year in 2019, with a forecasted 5.7% expansion, and further lose momentum in 2020, at 5.6%, according to the Asian Development Bank (ADB). Rising economic risks from the Sino-US trade war and a potentially disorderly Brexit are cited as main concerns. China's economy is projected to grow 6.3% in 2019, but 6.1% in 2020, with restrictions on shadow banking and fiscal stimulus measures expected to influence growth.

site_title: China Everbright unit makes offer for Ying Li International
summary: China Everbright's unit, State Alpha, has made a mandatory unconditional cash offer to acquire Chongqing-based property developer Ying Li International Real Estate at S$0.14 per share. The offeror holds 58.91% stake, triggered after buying 767.1 million shares, and plans to keep Ying Li listed. The acquisition aims to realise synergies and growth potential, and may involve strategic and operational reviews. The offer represents a 10.9% premium to the volume-weighted average price of shares prior, but a 66.1% discount to the company's net asset value per share.

site_title: ING brokers S$50m green loan to fund Sunseap's rooftop solar projects
summary: ING brokers a S$50 million, five-year green loan to fund Singapore's Sunseap Group's 50 megawatt portfolio of rooftop solar projects. The loan, structured on a limited-recourse project finance basis, will benefit 20 international and domestic corporates. This is ING's first green financing transaction in the Asia-Pacific and Sunseap's first green loan, enabling the company to continue generating clean energy and offset carbon footprints for various industries.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Wednesday, STI up 0.8% to 3,304.47
summary: Singapore shares opened higher on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index gaining 24.69 points, or 0.8%, to 3,304.47. Gainers beat losers 91 to 38, with active stocks including DBS, UOB, and OCBC gaining 1.7%, 1.6%, and 1.5% respectively. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and follows a 5-day rally.

site_title: Uber's main rival in India plans to join London race
summary: Ola, Uber's main rival in India, plans to launch in London before the end of the year, starting with five smaller UK cities. The company, which has raised $300 million from Hyundai, aims to work its way up to London, citing complexity and competition. Ola's UK managing director, Ben Legg, believes this step-by-step approach will help the startup crack the London market, which is seen as the most complex in terms of regulation. No specific date for London has been set, but plans are being developed for a launch before November.

site_title: Broker's take: CGS-CIMB initiates coverage on Sasseur Reit with 'buy'
summary: Analysts at CGS-CIMB have initiated coverage on Sasseur Reit with a "buy" call and a target price of S$0.92. The analysts praise the Reit's exposure to China's retail outlet segment, rental structure providing downside protection, and potential earnings upside. They also highlight Sasseur Reit's first mover advantage in Tier-2 cities, stable rental income, and gearing of 29%. The analysts estimate Sasseur Reit has debt headroom to fund potential new acquisitions, positioning it for growth.

site_title: Asia: Markets extend winning run on fresh China-US trade hopes
summary: Asian markets continued their winning streak on Wednesday, with optimism boosted by reports of China and the US closing in on a trade deal. The pound also gained after British Prime Minister Theresa May softened her Brexit stance, and investors took heart from better-than-expected factory data and dovish central bank moves. Stocks in Hong Kong, Shanghai, Tokyo, and other Asian markets rose, with gains ranging from 0.3% to 0.8% in early trade. The rally extends the markets' winning run, driven by hopes for a historic trade agreement between the world's top two economies.

site_title: Australian shoppers splurge in boost to retailers, economy
summary: Australian retailers experienced their best sales in February since 2017, with a 0.8% increase, beating expectations. This boost to economic growth signals resilient household consumption, sending the local dollar higher. The strong sales data provides reassurance for the Reserve Bank of Australia to remain on hold, despite concerns over high debt levels and slow wage growth. The Aussie dollar rose by over a third of a US cent to $0.7100.

site_title: Google's US workforce grew more Asian, less white and male
summary: Google's US workforce has become more diverse, with an increase in the Asian workforce and a decline in the number of white and male employees. The number of Asian staff rose to 39.8% and women to 26% of US leadership, while black workers still had the highest attrition rates. The company also reported gains in the number of women, black, and Latino workers among new hires. Despite progress, white workers remain in the majority, accounting for 54.4% of employees. Google's diversity report also highlighted under-represented groups, including LGBTQ+ individuals and those with disabilities.

site_title: Ethiopian Airlines pilots followed Boeing's emergency procedures before crash: WSJ
summary: Pilots of the Ethiopian Airlines 737 MAX jet that crashed last month initially followed Boeing's emergency procedures but failed to regain control of the plane, according to the Wall Street Journal. The crash killed all 157 people on board, leading to a global grounding of 737 MAX jets. Boeing had issued guidelines to pilots about shutting off an automated anti-stall system following a deadly crash in Indonesia in 2018. The incident highlights ongoing concerns about the safety of the 737 MAX aircraft.

site_title: Broker's take: RHB says to take profit on ComfortDelGro, remains bullish on prospects
summary: RHB Research Institute advises clients to take profit on ComfortDelGro shares, citing the counter's trading near its fair value. However, analysts remain bullish on the taxi operator's prospects, citing growth in its public transportation business, profit contributions from new acquisitions, and potential improvement in taxi earnings. A target price of S$2.65 is maintained, with analysts expecting higher earnings growth over the next 2-3 years. Despite losses in its rail business, ComfortDelGro's public transport business is expected to drive growth, driven by organic growth in Singapore and acquisitions in Australia.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Wednesday, up 5.60 points to 1,638.43. The index saw a trading volume of 43.69 million lots worth RM19.05 million, with gainer-to-loser ratio at 101:48.

site_title: Tokyo prosecutors readying new case against Ghosn over Oman payments: report
summary: Tokyo prosecutors are preparing a new case against ousted Nissan chairman Carlos Ghosn over suspect payments made to a business partner in Oman. The payments, totaling $32 million, were allegedly rewards for the Oman firm being a top Nissan dealer. Ghosn, who denies charges of financial misconduct, faces further charges of aggravated breach of trust. The new case will focus on the Oman payments, which are separate from his existing charges related to failing to report salary and transferring personal financial losses onto Nissan's books. Prosecutors plan to make a decision soon on whether to prosecute Ghosn.

site_title: Jho Low's 1MDB-linked superyacht sold for US$126m to Genting
summary: Malaysia's government has sold a 300-foot luxury superyacht seized from fugitive financier Jho Low, a key figure in the 1MDB scandal, to casino company Genting Malaysia Bhd for US$126 million. The sale, approved by a Malaysian court, marks the largest amount recovered from 1MDB, with Genting required to pay by the end of April. The deal is seen as a significant judicial victory, with Attorney-General Tommy Thomas praising the sale's market value. The sale follows an earlier auction failure and brings the country closer to recouping US$4.5 billion allegedly embezzled from 1MDB.

site_title: 1MDB: Malaysia's extraordinary financial scandal
summary: Malaysia's former leader Najib Razak goes on trial over the 1MDB corruption scandal, facing seven charges of corruption and money laundering. Allegations include looting billions from a state fund to fund lavish spending, including super-yachts and art. The scandal contributed to the downfall of a coalition that had ruled the country since independence in 1957. Najib is accused of stealing RM42 million from SRC International, a former 1MDB unit.

site_title: Belt and Road without China? It's possible
summary: Italy's participation in the Belt and Road Initiative has sparked concerns among G-7 allies, but experts believe the project will become less Chinese as international banks and companies join in. Global competitors, such as Standard Chartered, may allocate billions of dollars to Belt and Road projects, reducing China's reliance on state-backed funds. This shift could benefit Chinese banks and construction firms, which currently rely on guaranteed work and preferential labor quotas. As international involvement grows, the project's funding and management may become more diverse, reducing China's control.

site_title: Singapore stocks: STI resumes Wednesday afternoon at 3,308.15, up 0.86% on day
summary: Singapore stocks resumed trading on Wednesday with the Straits Times Index advancing 0.86% to 3,308.15, driven by a 185-147 gain-to-loss ratio. Key movers included Rex International Holding, up 3.9%, and Keppel Infrastructure Trust, down 1.1%. The day's trading volume was 569.2 million securities worth S$639.3 million.

site_title: The biggest Saudi oil field is fading faster than anyone guessed
summary: Saudi Aramco has revealed that its Ghawar oil field, the world's largest conventional oil field, can produce a maximum of 3.8 million barrels per day, significantly lower than the previously estimated 5 million barrels per day. This news has been a long-held secret and was only recently disclosed in the company's bond prospectus. The revelation has significant implications for the oil market and Saudi Arabia's economy, as the country relies heavily on its oil reserves.

site_title: Trial of former Malaysia PM Najib over 1MDB graft scandal kicks off
summary: Malaysia's former Prime Minister Najib Razak has begun his trial over the alleged plundering of state fund 1MDB, facing three counts of criminal breach of trust, one charge of abuse of power, and three counts of money laundering involving RM42 million. Najib, 65, arrived at the Kuala Lumpur High Court looking relaxed, despite the high-stakes trial. The case is a result of the multi-billion-dollar 1MDB scandal that shocked the world.

site_title: 8 in 10 Singapore CFOs struggle to hire qualified finance professionals: Robert Half
summary: In a survey by Robert Half, 83% of Singapore's chief financial officers (CFOs) struggle to hire qualified finance professionals, with 85% predicting it will become even tougher in the next five years. The recruitment consultancy attributes the challenge to the high demand for financially savvy talent to drive business growth. The most in-demand financial jobs include credit risk officer, internal auditor, and finance manager, with internal auditors commanding the highest salary of S$200,000 annually.

site_title: Toyota to give royalty-free access to hybrid-vehicle patents: report
summary: Toyota Motor Corp plans to make most of its hybrid-vehicle technology patents royalty-free, covering motors, power converters, and batteries, starting this year. The move comes as the industry shifts towards pure electric vehicles. Toyota, which holds 20,000 active patents, aims to make its technology accessible to help hybrids remain relevant. The company has sold over 12 million hybrid cars since pioneering the Prius in 1997, accounting for 80% of the hybrid market. Toyota believes its hybrids offer a cost-effective alternative to all-battery EVs.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore aims to lead Industry 4.0 efforts in Asean, with manufacturing as a key pillar of its economy. Keppel Reit priced S$200m of 5-year convertibles at 100% of par with a 1.90% coupon. 8 in 10 Singapore CFOs struggle to hire qualified finance professionals. Stripe hired Rahul Shinghal, former PayPal head of small and medium-sized businesses in Asia-Pacific. ING brokered a S$50m green loan for Sunseap's rooftop solar projects. The STI gained 1% on Wednesday, closing at 3,311.27.

site_title: Malaysian SMEs to get more private support in Industry 4.0
summary: Malaysian small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are set to receive more private support for Industry 4.0 through a workshop organized by the US-Asean Business Council and the Malaysian Ministry of International Trade and Industry. The event, expected to attract over 250 SME owners and executives, will focus on digital transformation, global value chains, and digital payments. SMEs make up 96% of businesses in the region and employ half of all workers, with the US-Asean Business Council emphasizing their importance to Asean's trade policy dynamism. The workshop is part of a larger training scheme for SMEs.

images.alt_text: Darell Leiking, Malaysian Minister of International Trade and Industry, at a business and investment summit in Singapore in 2018.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rally builds on rally at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks continued their rally for a seventh consecutive day, rising 0.54% to 29,785.27, driven by a report that China and the US are closing in on a trade deal. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index slipped 0.56% and the Shenzhen Composite Index eased 0.51%. The gains come despite US President Trump's recent threats to extend tariffs, which have had a minimal impact on traders. The rally is seen as a positive sign for the market, but the impact of the US-China trade deal on global markets remains uncertain.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open mixed on Wednesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened mixed on Wednesday, with the Nikkei 225 index up 0.14% and the Topix index down 0.05%. Bargain-hunting purchases offset profit-taking sales, with no major market-moving events.

site_title: Lonza enters 90m euro JV to develop biotherapeutic products
summary: Lonza, a Swiss biotech company, has entered a 50/50 joint venture with Chr. Hansen to develop live biotherapeutic products (LBP) with an estimated 90 million euro investment over three years. The joint venture targets the emerging pre-clinical and clinical supply industry for LBP, aiming to capitalize on the growing global clinical supply industry estimated to reach 150-200 million euros by 2025. The venture will upgrade existing facilities and equip new ones to serve pre-clinical to phase II projects, and is expected to be largely self-funding after production setup.

site_title: MeGroup to buy further 25% stake in Honda dealership for up to RM3.75m
summary: MeGroup, a CATALIST-listed car dealer and component manufacturer, will buy an additional 25% stake in its subsidiary MJN Motors for up to RM3.75 million, raising its stake to 80% from 55%. The deal will be financed through internal cash resources and will result in the allotment and issue of up to 1.3 million MeGroup shares. The move aims to potentially improve future earnings, following Honda's success in Malaysia, where it was the top-selling non-national marque in 2018.

site_title: Keppel Reit prices S$200m of 5-year convertibles at cheap end of price talk
summary: Keppel Reit priced a S$200 million 5-year convertible bond at 100% of par, a 1.90% coupon, and an initial conversion price of S$1.4625, below the indicated range. The deal was oversubscribed, and Keppel Reit will use the proceeds to refinance debt and potentially fund an acquisition. The bonds have a 3-year put option and a call option after 3 years, subject to certain conditions. This suggests a tepid response to the deal, with no plan to upsize the offering.

site_title: Chinese woman arrested at Trump resort with malware on thumb drive
summary: A Chinese woman, Zhang Yujing, was arrested at US President Donald Trump's Mar-a-Lago resort in Florida on Saturday. She attempted to gain entry by claiming to be a member and attending a non-existent Chinese-American friendship event. Zhang carried multiple cellphones, a laptop, and a thumb drive with malicious software, and was charged with making false statements and knowingly entering a restricted building. She had previously worked with event promoter Cindy Yang, who has promoted herself as a path to the US president, and was found to have connections to China.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel Reit, Nam Cheong, Tritech Group, Ntegrator International
summary: Keppel Reit priced a S$200 million five-year convertible bond at 100% of par, with a 1.9% coupon. The deal is at the cheap end of price talk, suggesting a tepid response. Nam Cheong's independent auditors expressed concerns over the company's financial statements due to outstanding debts and material effects on its financial condition. The auditors were unable to issue an audit opinion.

site_title: Europe: Stocks hit six-month high as automakers, insurers gain
summary: European shares reached a six-month high on Tuesday, driven by gains in automakers, insurers, and London-listed stocks amid weakening Brexit uncertainty. The Stoxx 600 index rose 0.4% to 385.68, its highest since late September. Automakers and parts suppliers surged 1.3%, while insurers gained 0.9% and European banks rose 0.7%. The FTSE 100 also reached a six-month high, with UK firms benefiting from the pound's decline.

site_title: UK tycoon bets on iconic London site amid Brexit woe
summary: UK property tycoon John Hitchcox is planning a £700 million redevelopment of the iconic Olympia exhibition centre in west London, amidst Brexit uncertainty. The project, set to take three years, will include two hotels, theatres, performance spaces, and a tech hub, transforming the site into a performing arts and cultural district. Hitchcox's firm halted UK residential investments two years ago due to high taxes and Brexit concerns, instead focusing on the long-term project. The redevelopment aims to revitalize the area and ensure London's cultural scene remains vibrant despite Brexit's economic impact.

site_title: Faulty 737 sensor in Lion Air crash linked to US repairer
summary: A faulty angle-of-attack sensor on a Lion Air 737 Max, linked to the deadly October 2018 crash, was repaired by a US aircraft maintenance facility before the tragedy. The sensor, manufactured by Rosemount Aerospace Inc, was not functioning properly from installation, causing repeated nose-down movements that led to the crash. The sensor was repaired at XTRA Aerospace Inc in Florida, where it was later installed on the Lion Air plane. Investigators are seeking data from the Florida repair station, and the US National Transportation Safety Board is reviewing the work performed on the sensor.

site_title: Augmented reality company Kudan boss worth US$700m. And he says it's 'ridiculous'
summary: Kudan Inc, an augmented reality company founded by Tomohiro Ohno, has a market value of about US$1.3 billion, making its CEO worth around US$700 million. Ohno downplays the valuation, calling it "ridiculous," and emphasizes that Kudan is not focused on increasing market value. The company is developing computer vision algorithms to enable computers to perceive real-world objects in three dimensions, with applications in driverless cars, drones, and vacuum cleaners. Kudan has partnered with Synopsys Inc to embed its technology into Synopsys products, and Ohno aims to make the company a major player in the industry, similar to ARM Holdings.

site_title: Stripe hires PayPal veteran to steer Asia-Pacific business
summary: Stripe has hired Rahul Shinghal, a PayPal veteran, to lead its Asia-Pacific business. Shinghal, who spent four years as head of PayPal's South-east Asia business, joined Stripe this month to oversee the company's digital economy efforts in the region. He aims to increase the GDP of the Internet and help entrepreneurs and enterprises harness the power of digital economies in Asia-Pacific. Shinghal will remain based in Singapore for Stripe.

site_title: UK PM May's new plan will hand power to Brussels: Boris Johnson
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May's new Brexit plan, which includes talks with the opposition Labour Party, would hand power to the European Union, according to former Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson. He claims that this would lead to the UK having no say in trade policy and law-making. Johnson expresses concerns that the UK may be forced to contest European elections and accept exit terms that do not align with the initial Brexit vote.

site_title: Sterling rallies as PM May seeks Brexit extension
summary: The British pound rallied against the euro and US dollar after Prime Minister Theresa May announced a need for a Brexit extension to ensure a timely departure from the European Union. The pound rose 0.3% against the dollar to above US$1.31 and strengthened against the euro to 85.49 pence, easing fears of a potential no-deal Brexit. The move was seen as a relief to investors, who had been concerned about the UK's ability to leave the EU by April 12.

site_title: Malaysia ex-PM Najib to go on trial for corruption
summary: Malaysia's former Prime Minister Najib Razak will go on trial for corruption on Wednesday over his alleged involvement in the looting of sovereign wealth fund 1MDB. He faces seven charges of corruption and money laundering related to the theft of RM42 million from SRC International. Najib has denied any wrongdoing and the trial is seen as a major step towards bringing him to justice, following public anger and a long-ruling coalition's downfall. The US Department of Justice estimates $4.5 billion was looted from 1MDB.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's disgraced former leader Najib Razak will go on trial Wednesday over a multi-billion-dollar financial scandal that contributed to his long-ruling coalition's downfall last year and sent shockwaves around the world.

site_title: Brunei introduces death by stoning for adultery, gay sex
summary: Brunei introduces harsh new sharia laws, including death by stoning for adultery and gay sex, sparking global criticism from politicians and rights groups. The laws, which also include amputation of hands and feet for thieves, make Brunei the first country in East or Southeast Asia to have a sharia penal code at the national level. The Sultan of Brunei, Hassanal Bolkiah, is unlikely to change course, citing the need to burnish his Islamic credentials and shore up support among conservatives.

site_title: Actress Michelle Williams at US Capitol to push for pay equality
summary: Hollywood actress Michelle Williams appeared at the US Capitol to push for a law to close the gender pay gap, citing her own experience of being paid $1,000 for reshooting scenes in "All the Money in the World" while her male co-star Mark Wahlberg received $1.5 million for the same work. The House Democrats passed the Paycheck Fairness Act, but a vote in the Senate has not been scheduled. Williams urged the Senate to follow the House's lead, with several Democratic presidential hopefuls supporting the legislation.

site_title: Singapore aims to lead the way in Industry 4.0 efforts in Asean
summary: Singapore aims to lead the way in Industry 4.0 efforts in the Asean region by leveraging its expertise and initiatives to support the transformation of existing industries and contribute thought leadership. The country has launched the Smart Industry Readiness Index (SIRI) and a Prioritisation Matrix to help companies plan their Industry 4.0 transformation plans. With Asean expected to become the fourth-largest economy by 2030, Singapore's efforts could help the region capture up to $600 billion of global benefits from Industry 4.0 by 2025.

site_title: Facebook cannot guarantee interference-free EU elections: Zuckerberg
summary: Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg stated that the company has made progress in safeguarding elections since 2016, but cannot guarantee interference-free EU elections. Despite efforts to combat misinformation and foreign interference, Zuckerberg acknowledged that it's an ongoing "arms race" between Facebook's defenses and sophisticated governments. Facebook has ramped up its fact-checking efforts and partnered with news agencies to combat disinformation ahead of the May 26 EU vote, but Zuckerberg expressed concerns that countries trying to interfere will continue to evolve their tactics.

site_title: Malaysia fund loses US$800m in value over three days
summary: IHH Healthcare Bhd's market value has dropped by almost US$800 million over three days due to the Turkish lira's volatility, a major shareholder cutting its stake, and uncertainty over a Fortis Healthcare Ltd acquisition. The stock fell 6.6% and its 14-day relative strength index is now oversold, with Nomura Securities Co analyst Raghavendra Divekar maintaining a buy rating. IHH is looking to repay US$250 million of non-lira debt to manage foreign exchange exposure.

site_title: US warns Beijing against force after Taiwan incursion
summary: The US has warned Beijing against using "force or coercion" on Taiwan after two Chinese fighter jets crossed a maritime line dividing the two sides. The US opposes altering the status quo and has committed to defending Taiwan under the 1979 Taiwan Relations Act. National security advisor John Bolton emphasized the US's commitment to the law, saying it will strengthen democracy supporters' resolve. The US and most countries recognize Beijing as Taiwan's sovereign ruler, but Washington maintains a close relationship with the island.

site_title: Trudeau ousts 2 ex-ministers from Canada ruling party
summary: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau was ousted from his Liberal Party after expelling two former ministers, Jody Wilson-Raybould and Jane Philpott, due to their accusations of political meddling in a prosecution. The move was made in response to Wilson-Raybould's release of a secret recording that reignited the scandal. Trudeau's re-election bid was jeopardized by the controversy, leading to his removal from the party.

site_title: US hails China's expanded clampdown on fentanyl
summary: The US has welcomed China's expansion of its clampdown on fentanyl, listing all fentanyl-related substances as controlled narcotics. The move aims to curb the synthetic opioid's shipment to the US, where an opioid epidemic has claimed thousands of lives. China blamed US culture for the abuse, citing the country's long tradition of abusing prescription medicines. The US hopes to include China's commitments in a trade agreement to end the trade war, and President Trump has called for the death penalty for fentanyl distributors.

site_title: Citing climate differences, Shell walks away from US refining lobby
summary: Royal Dutch Shell Plc announced plans to leave the American Fuel & Petrochemical Manufacturers (AFPM) US refining lobby due to disagreements on climate policies, citing its support for the Paris climate agreement. Shell found "material misalignment" with AFPM and will quit the body in 2020. This move is part of Shell's drive to increase transparency and align with investor pressure to reduce carbon emissions. The decision marks the latest sign of how investor pressure on oil companies is leading to changes in their behavior around climate.

site_title: Burger King goes... vegan? The meatless Whopper is here
summary: Burger King, a fast-food giant, has introduced the Impossible Whopper, a meatless version of its signature sandwich. The new burger features Impossible Foods' plant-based patty, made from soy and potato protein, and is available at select restaurants in St. Louis. If successful, the Impossible Whopper will expand nationwide, marking Burger King's bold move into the plant-based market, following similar launches by competitors such as Nestle and Unilever. The trend of plant-based diets is expected to continue, driven by consumer demand and health benefits.

site_title: US approves anti-submarine helicopter sale to India
summary: The US has approved the sale of 24 MH-60R anti-submarine helicopters to India, valued at $2.6 billion. The helicopters, manufactured by Lockheed Martin, will significantly boost India's firepower to target submarines in the Indian Ocean as China expands its presence. The sale is part of a broader effort to enhance India's military capabilities. The State Department notified the US Congress of the approval, fulfilling a legal requirement. The deal is expected to enhance India's naval capabilities and counterbalance China's growing influence in the region.

site_title: Facebook working on tab for 'high quality news'
summary: Facebook is working on a "news tab" to support high-quality and trustworthy journalism, CEO Mark Zuckerberg announced. The tab, separate from the personalized feed, would serve users seeking news from professional media and compensate news organizations for selected content. Zuckerberg believes 10-15% of Facebook users would be interested, and the tab would require curation to ensure trustworthy information. The move aims to help journalists and news organizations monetize their content, with Facebook potentially forming direct relationships with publishers to ensure content availability.

site_title: Singapore's biggest online mall Qoo10 fights Alibaba with blockchain
summary: Qoo10, Singapore's largest online mall, is using blockchain technology to compete with Alibaba in the region. Led by entrepreneur Ku Young Bae, the company launched a separate marketplace called QuuBe in January, offering lower fees and a payment system based on blockchain. Since its launch, over 5,000 merchants have registered 2.3 million products on QuuBe. Ku aims to expand to Australia, Thailand, the Philippines, and Vietnam, using blockchain to gain an edge in a region dominated by Alibaba's Lazada and Tencent's Shopee. The technology automates transactions and enhances trust among participants.

site_title: Pentagon refuses Boeing tanker deliveries over quality issues
summary: The US Air Force has halted the acceptance of new KC-46 tankers from Boeing for the second time due to ongoing quality issues, including "foreign object debris" and other areas where Boeing did not meet quality standards. The halt is the latest setback in the already delayed air tanker program, which aims to replace the Air Force's aging KC-10 and KC-135 tankers. The Air Force plans to buy 179 KC-46s over the course of the program, with currently seven aircraft in service. This decision comes after the Air Force took its first KC-46 in January, more than a year late.
