The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.98% to 21,719.50, while the Topix index climbed 0.86% to 1,629.73. Analysts cited improved US and Chinese manufacturing data and a cheaper yen as positive factors. Steelmakers and China-linked shares also rose, with Nippon Steel and Komatsu up 1.71% and 1.79%, respectively. The Dow Jones ended up 1.3% on Wall Street.

site_title: Pound plunges as lawmakers fail to find majority on Brexit alternatives
summary: The British pound plummeted over 1% on Monday as lawmakers failed to agree on an alternative to Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit deal, leaving the UK on track to leave the EU on April 12 without a deal. Economists warn this would be the worst-case scenario, causing the pound to potentially sink to levels not seen since 2016. A no-deal Brexit is now considered a higher possibility, fueling uncertainty for the currency.

images.alt_text: The British pound plunged more than one per cent on Monday as Britain's exit from the European Union remained deadlocked after parliament failed to agree on any alternative to Prime Minister Theresa May's divorce deal.

site_title: Planning tool launched to guide firms in Industry 4.0 transformation
summary: Singapore has launched a Prioritisation Matrix planning tool to guide companies in their Industry 4.0 transformations. Developed by the Economic Development Board and its partners, the tool helps firms prioritize areas to focus on for maximum benefits. The Prioritisation Matrix builds on the Smart Industry Readiness Index (SIRI) and assesses companies' readiness levels across 16 dimensions. The tool aims to help companies overcome the challenges of designing and implementing effective Industry 4.0 roadmaps.

site_title: Trial begins for US ex-cop who fatally shot Australian woman
summary: A jury trial began in Chicago for former Minnesota police officer Mohamed Noor, who fatally shot unarmed Australian woman Justine Damond in 2017. Prosecutors claim Noor acted unreasonably, while his attorneys argue he acted in self-defense. The case has sparked outrage and calls for police reform, with many arguing that officers are rarely held accountable for their actions. The trial is the first to focus on the use of police body cameras in fatal shootings, and its outcome is seen as a test of accountability in the US justice system.

site_title: Whistleblower reveals 'grave breaches' in White House security clearances
summary: A whistleblower has revealed that 25 White House officials, including top advisors to President Donald Trump, were granted security clearances despite staff recommendations against it, posing "grave breaches of national security." House Oversight Committee Chairman Elijah Cummings is seeking information on the clearances for key officials, including John Bolton, Michael Flynn, and Ivanka Trump.

site_title: Millions without water as Venezuela crisis deepens
summary: Millions of Venezuelans face severe water shortages and power outages amid a deepening economic crisis. President Nicolas Maduro announced 30 days of electricity rationing and school closures due to blackouts, which have worsened living conditions in the country. Venezuelans have taken to the streets to protest, citing the lack of access to basic services. The crisis has been exacerbated by infrastructure issues, a brain drain of skilled personnel, and a soaring inflation rate, with the country's power grid barely generating 5,500-6,000 megawatts, down from its capacity of 34,000 megawatts.

site_title: Apple supplier Japan Display to seek funding, shares surge
summary: Japan Display Inc, a major supplier of LCD panels for Apple's iPhones, plans to raise up to $990 million in new financing as early as this week. The move comes after the company faced a slowdown in iPhone sales and the increasing use of newer OLED displays. The news sent Japan Display's shares sharply higher, indicating investor confidence in the company's ability to recover. The funding will help Japan Display navigate the challenges posed by the shift to OLED displays and maintain its position as a top vendor of LCD panels.

site_title: Facebook seeks tab to promote 'high quality news'
summary: Facebook is working on a "news tab" to support high-quality and trustworthy journalism, according to CEO Mark Zuckerberg. The tab would be separate from the personalized feed and aim to surface professional news content. Zuckerberg believes 10-15% of Facebook users would be interested in the dedicated news tab, which would compensate news organizations for selected content. The move is seen as a shift for Facebook, which has been criticized for spreading misinformation on its news feed. Zuckerberg aims to help people find trustworthy news and support journalists, potentially providing better monetization for publishers.

site_title: US: Stocks extend rally at start of second quarter
summary: US stocks rose at the start of the second quarter, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average gaining 1.3% to 26,258.42, the S&P 500 advancing 1.2% to 2,867.19, and the Nasdaq Composite Index rising 1.3% to 7,828.91. Strong economic data and optimism over trade talks drove gains, with broad-based increases across industries. The strong start follows the S&P 500's best quarterly performance since 2009. Analysts cited Chinese manufacturing data and a US manufacturing sector report as catalysts.

site_title: Will Europe continue to sleep even as China awakens?
summary: China has strengthened its ties with Italy, signing a memorandum of understanding on the Belt and Road Initiative, a move that exposes divisions within the European Union. Italy's participation marks a break with other major EU countries, including Germany and France, which have been more cautious in their dealings with China. The EU's inability to issue a unified statement on China's actions in the South China Sea and human rights record highlights the need for reform to address the issue. As China's influence grows, Europe risks becoming economically prosperous but politically impotent.

site_title: Ezion gets proposed lifeline from Malaysia's Yinson
summary: Singapore's offshore and marine firm Ezion Holdings has secured a proposed lifeline from Malaysian-listed Yinson Holdings, the world's sixth-largest FPSO operator. Yinson will help wipe off US$916m of Ezion's debt in exchange for new shares at 5.5 Singapore cents each. The deal, worth US$200m, also includes a potential cash injection of up to S$203.3m through share options, allowing Yinson to acquire up to 87.5% of Ezion's enlarged share capital. The rescue package aims to revitalize Ezion, which has been plagued by a prolonged oil slump and excess capacity in the O&M space.

site_title: ECB studies tiered rate but banks' woes go beyond that: de Guindos
summary: The European Central Bank is studying ways to cut its charge on banks' deposits, but ECB vice president Luis de Guindos suggests that the causes of low bank profits lie elsewhere, such as high costs and excessive competition. The ECB has shelved plans to raise interest rates this year due to slowing growth and inflation in the euro zone. De Guindos proposes "tiering" negative interest rates, a concept implemented in other countries, but has not made a decision yet. He blames the low profitability of banks in Europe on structural factors rather than the ECB's policies.

site_title: A second Spring?
summary: Syria may be readmitted to the Arab League within the next year, following the UAE's reopening of its embassy in Damascus and Gulf states rebuilding ties with the Assad regime. This comes after the Arab Spring of 2011, where only Tunisia established a democratic order, while others, such as Egypt, Libya, and Yemen, fell under repressive regimes. New popular movements in Jordan, Sudan, and Algeria have also emerged, with young people playing a key role in challenging long-established regimes and demanding change.

site_title: British MPs vote against all Brexit alternative plans
summary: British MPs voted against four alternative Brexit plans, rejecting all options for retaining closer economic ties, holding a second referendum, or stopping Brexit. The second referendum proposal garnered 280 votes in favour, but was defeated by 292 votes against. This marks the latest setback for the UK government's Brexit efforts, with the country's economy already experiencing a second consecutive month of contraction.

site_title: Bank of Canada chief advocates low rates but sees light on economic outlook
summary: Bank of Canada Governor Stephen Poloz expressed cautious optimism about Canada's economic outlook, despite trade uncertainties weighing on the country and the global economy. Poloz stated that the economic growth data supports the central bank's original interpretation of a temporary slowdown, but noted that the duration of the slowdown is uncertain. The Bank of Canada maintained a neutral interest rate stance, with the next rate decision set for April 24, and did not signal a rate cut. Poloz also highlighted areas of encouraging economic growth, including job creation and labor income growth.

images.alt_text: Bank of Canada Governor Stephen Poloz expressed guarded optimism on Monday that the country would emerge from a soft patch, but maintained a cautious tone overall, saying the economic outlook still warrants an interest rate below the neutral range.

site_title: India's first Reit climbs on trading debut in vote of confidence
summary: India's first real estate investment trust (REIT), Embassy Office Parks, rose 8.3% on its trading debut, reaching 324.8 rupees per unit, after raising 47.5 billion rupees in an initial public offering that was more than two-and-a-half times oversubscribed. The REIT's early success may provide a new fundraising tool for cash-strapped developers and offer investors a new exit mechanism, amid India's struggling property market.

site_title: Oil rises to 2019 highs as demand outlook improves
summary: Oil prices surged to 2019 highs on Monday, with Brent crude reaching $69.01 a barrel, driven by positive economic data and tighter supplies. The global benchmark rose 27% in the first quarter, its largest gain in nearly a decade. Analysts attribute the rally to the US and China's manufacturing data, which eased concerns about slowing global growth, and production cuts by the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries. Hedge funds and money managers have also increased bullish wagers on US crude.

site_title: Woolworths to shut 30 Big W stores over next 3 years
summary: Woolworths Group Ltd plans to shut 30 Big W stores over the next three years, costing A$270 million, as the discount department division continues to incur losses since 2016. The move aims to remove the division's drag on profitability. Woolworths also announced a previously flagged A$1.7 billion share buyback. The company expects its loss to narrow further this year but flagged a non-cash impairment of A$100 million due to the challenging retail market.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Olam International secured a $350 million, three-year digital-linked revolving credit facility from seven participating banks, described as the world's first "digital loan". The facility's interest rate will be linked to Olam's digital maturity score, determined by the Boston Consulting Group. Proceeds will be used to refinance existing loans. In other news, SIA Engineering Company signed a comprehensive services agreement with Singapore Airlines, and Keppel Corporation invested $50 million in Envision AESC, a lithium-ion battery company.

site_title: Prime areas lead slide in private home prices in Q1
summary: Singapore's private home prices declined in Q1 2019, with the Core Central Region (CCR) experiencing the largest drop of 2.9% quarter-on-quarter, according to the Urban Redevelopment Authority. The overall private home price index fell 0.6% for the first quarter, marking a second consecutive quarter of decline. The CCR's decline was attributed to the launch of new projects and increased unsold inventory, while the secondary market also softened. The URA's benchmark overall private home price index is now 0.7% below its peak in Q3 2018.

images.alt_text: Apartments and condos in the prime areas or Core Central Region (CCR) led declines in private home prices in the first quarter of this year.

site_title: Hyflux saga demands better debt disclosure rules
summary: Singapore should adopt more transparent debt disclosure rules, similar to China's new regulations on perpetual securities, to ensure investors have accurate financial information. The Hyflux saga highlights the need for clarity, as the water treatment firm hid its losses due to the classification of its perpetual securities as equity. This lack of transparency led to overstated financial leverage ratios and misled investors about the company's financial health. Standardizing disclosures, such as separating profits attributable to ordinary shareholders and perpetual securities holders, can help close the disclosure gaps and promote transparency in the market.

site_title: Improved Chinese factory data lifts Aussie dollar
summary: Improved Chinese factory activity lifted the Australian dollar by nearly half a percent, with the euro also holding above a three-week low. China's official PMI showed factory activity unexpectedly grew in March for the first time in four months, boosting risk appetite and driving gains in emerging market currencies. The euro zone inflation slowed in March, adding to the European Central Bank's headaches, while British lawmakers vote on alternatives to Prime Minister Theresa May's EU withdrawal agreement, potentially causing further volatility in sterling.

site_title: Oil extends best run in decade as China data eases slowdown worries
summary: Oil prices rose 0.9% on Monday, extending their best run in a decade, as China's manufacturing PMI data eased concerns over the global economic slowdown. The US-China trade talks are set to resume this week, boosting investor sentiment. Oil prices rose 32% in the first quarter, driven by Saudi Arabia's supply cuts, and are expected to rise further if a breakthrough in trade talks occurs. Crude futures reached a 12-year high of $60.57 a barrel, with Brent also up 0.9%.

site_title: Reasons to get health insurance
summary: Wealthy individuals with significant assets can benefit from health insurance for its flexibility in opting for luxurious healthcare and overseas care. Plans like Tokio Marine's Care & Health and AXA Insurance's GlobalCare offer global coverage with exclusions, while Lifeline by Raffles Health Insurance provides worldwide medical assistance. Premiums can be reduced with deductibles or co-payments, and guaranteed renewable plans are available. A study by Pacific Prime found the average cost of international health cover to be $8,105, with families paying the highest premium of $11,551.

site_title: EC recognises some S'pore derivatives trading venues
summary: The European Commission (EC) has recognised several Singapore derivatives trading venues as eligible for compliance with EU trading obligations for derivatives. This decision allows EU investment banks operating in Asia to meet their EU trading requirements when dealing with Singapore counterparties. The move aims to strengthen cross-border trading and facilitate trade between the EU and Singapore, enabling businesses to access deeper pools of liquidity and hedge risks more efficiently.

site_title: China manufacturing rebounds in March led by domestic demand
summary: China's manufacturing activity rebounded in March, with the Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) growing to 50.5, its first expansion in four months. Total new orders, construction activity, and output are increasing, driven by domestic demand. Analysts attribute the rebound to government efforts to boost the private sector and positive progress in trade talks with the US. However, caution is urged, as the trade war's outcome remains uncertain, and the economy is expected to slow further before picking up in the second half of the year.

site_title: Staying ahead of the future
summary: Wealth experts emphasize the importance of protection instruments for high net worth individuals. Key gaps in insurance coverage include legacy planning, liquidity needs at death, and asset protection. Experts recommend strategies such as universal life plans, trust planning, and ring-fencing personal assets from business creditors. Healthcare insurance is also crucial, particularly for those with complex medical needs or global coverage. Insurance can help facilitate legacy planning by providing liquidity and alleviating family conflicts. Experts advise considering global international medical insurance plans, setting up living trusts, and using life insurance to discharge guarantees upon demise.

site_title: NATO turns 70 with charm offensive to woo Trump
summary: NATO marked its 70th birthday with a charm offensive to win over US President Donald Trump, who had previously threatened to pull out of the military alliance. NATO Secretary-General Jens Stoltenberg is seeking to deepen US support, addressing a joint session of Congress and meeting with Trump at the White House. The move comes after Trump's 2018 summit threat, which caused tension within the West. Stoltenberg aims to consolidate ties with Trump and build bipartisan support for the alliance.

site_title: GIC names new COO in management shuffle
summary: GIC appoints Tay Lim Hock as its new Chief Operating Officer (COO), replacing Goh Kok Huat who is retiring after a decade. Tay, who is also Deputy Group Chief Investment Officer, will relocate to Singapore from London. Arjun Gupta, a managing director, will fill the Europe president role. Leslie Teo, Chief Economist, is also retiring and will continue as an adviser until June 2020. The new appointments are part of a management shuffle aimed at refreshing the bench and preparing new leaders for more responsibilities.

site_title: PMET job cuts mostly in sectors going through restructuring
summary: Singapore's Minister for Manpower Josephine Teo reported that nearly two-thirds of professionals, managers, executives and technicians (PMET) layoffs in 2018 occurred in sectors undergoing restructuring. A total of 5,400 local PMETs were let go last year, with the resident long-term unemployment rate for PMETs at 0.8%. The affected sectors included wholesale trade, financial and insurance services, information and communications, and professional services.

site_title: DSV to buy Panalpina in US$4.6b European logistics deal
summary: DSV A/S has agreed to acquire Panalpina Welttransport Holding AG in a deal worth $4.6 billion, creating one of the world's largest logistics companies. The deal, recommended by Panalpina's board, values the target at 196 Swiss francs per share, a 43% premium from DSV's initial proposal. The acquisition is expected to increase DSV's annual sales by 50% and result in a workforce of over 60,000 employees across 90 countries.

site_title: Marrying function and fashion
summary: Faire Leather Co, a Singapore-based SME, prides itself on selling quality leather goods with a personal touch. Co-founders Ryan Choy and Joseph Lor respond to customer queries personally, despite having the means to outsource chatbot management. The company's Kickstarter campaign was successful, hitting its two-year target of S$1 million in under 10 months. Faire Leather Co has partnered with Rolls-Royce and showcased its products in London. The company aims to grow its product line, distribution, and team, and introduce technological features to its bags. Its future goal is to be internationally renowned for marrying function and fashion.

site_title: These luxury Hong Kong homes are fully furnished; all you need is US$75m
summary: Hong Kong businessman Loewe Lee has developed a luxury property project with seven fully furnished homes, priced at US$75 million each, overlooking the South China Sea. The properties, designed by renowned architects, feature bespoke touches such as Persian carpets, cut crystal, and art on the walls. The project, which includes landscaped gardens, infinity pools, and a spacious car park, is the first property project overseen by Loewe Lee from start to finish. The ultra-luxury homes are aimed at well-to-do, well-traveled individuals who value attention to detail and bespoke touches.

site_title: Macau casino revenue down 0.4% in March
summary: Macau's casino revenue declined 0.4% in March to 25.8 billion patacas (S$4.32 billion), driven by slowing economic growth and the Sino-US trade war. This marks the highest revenue haul so far this year, meeting analyst expectations of flat growth. The territory's reliance on gambling revenue remains a concern, with taxes from casinos accounting for over 80% of the government's total revenue. Authorities have urged operators to diversify and broaden Macau's economic base.

site_title: Japan picks Reiwa as name for incoming emperor's new era
summary: Japan has named the new era of its emperor as Reiwa, consisting of two characters: Rei (meaning order or auspicious) and Wa (meaning peace or harmony). The name was announced on April 1, 2019, and companies have quickly capitalized on the new name, with a surge in website traffic and stock prices. The new era is set to begin when the current emperor abdicates next month.

site_title: HDB resale prices down 0.3% in Q1
summary: HDB resale flat prices in Singapore decreased by 0.3% in Q1 2019, with the resale price index at 131. This decline is slower than the 0.8% drop seen in Q4 2018. Despite this, prices have stabilized over the last two years. The government's changes to CPF loan rules and the approaching minimum occupation period (MOP) for prime flats may boost sentiment, potentially leading to increased marketing activities.

site_title: Turkish lira falls as Erdogan suffers blow in elections
summary: Turkey's President Recep Tayyip Erdogan's ruling party appears to have lost control of key cities in a recent vote, leading to a decline in the Turkish lira. The currency fell over 1% in the Asia session before trimming losses to 0.2% at 5.5839 per dollar. Erdogan conceded some municipal losses to the opposition, sparking concerns that the government may pursue populist policies, fueling further currency weakness. The central bank has signaled a hawkish stance, but investors worry about a more expansionary policy that could stoke inflation, which has already reached 20%.

site_title: Google, Huawei in AI collaboration despite trade war
summary: Google and Huawei have collaborated on AI technology despite the ongoing trade war between the two countries. Huawei's Track AI initiative uses Google's TensorFlow software tools, but no Google engineers worked on the project. The collaboration highlights the business relationships between the two companies, which have worked together in the past, including using Google's Android software and apps. This partnership may be driven by Google's advertising business in China and its desire to reach customers outside the country.

site_title: StarHub shrinks its entertainment bundles from 50 to seven
summary: StarHub has reduced its entertainment bundles from 50 to seven, offering English Entertainment Pass, Movies Pass, Asian Entertainment Pass, Malay Entertainment Pass, Indian Entertainment Pass, Filipino Entertainment Pass, and Sports Pass. The new passes can be switched at any time without a limit, and customers need a fibre broadband subscription to access the pay-TV service. The new pricing starts at S$29.90 per month with a 24-month contract, and customers can add more passes as needed.

site_title: Midas to be liquidated after failing to find a white knight
summary: Midas Holdings, a Singapore-based aluminum train components supplier, is set to be liquidated after failing to secure a rescue deal from Hong Kong-listed CRRC Corp. The company, which has 15,766 shareholders, reported an unaudited net liability position of $47.1 million as of 2018. Midas cited unsuccessful efforts to discuss a rescue with CRRC and dwindling funds as reasons for its liquidation. The company faces statutory demands from creditors, including unpaid salaries and disputed loans, and will be unable to maintain its listing status in Singapore and Hong Kong.

site_title: Life insurance - part of the wealth-planning toolkit
summary: Life insurance is a key component of wealth planning, offering benefits such as providing liquidity to beneficiaries and funding inheritance or estate tax. Term life insurance provides coverage for a fixed period, while permanent life insurance, including universal life insurance, offers flexibility in premium payments and death benefits. Insurance can be used to protect assets, provide liquidity during estate administration, and meet succession planning needs. However, taxation of insurance policies can be complicated, and policyholders should carefully consider their needs and tax implications when selecting a policy.

site_title: PSA Group, Fiat Chrysler explore European venture
summary: PSA Group and Fiat Chrysler Automobiles are exploring a potential partnership to share investments and build cars in Europe. The two carmakers are discussing a "super platform" to reduce costs and compete in the highly competitive region. The partnership could include sharing investments for new electric cars, with a focus on reducing costs and leveraging technology development. The talks, which could be announced by the end of the first half of 2019, aim to make both companies stronger and more competitive in the market. A wider combination in the future is also possible.

site_title: HSA sets up panel to review handling of sensitive data
summary: The Health Sciences Authority (HSA) in Singapore has established a board committee to review its data management policies and processes following a data breach affecting over 800,000 blood donors. The committee will also assess the lifecycle management of data handled by IT vendors. The Ministry of Health and its agencies will review the incident, with Senior Minister of State for Health Edwin Tong stating that measures will be taken to address the issue.

site_title: Energy, petrochemical sector veteran Tan Soo Koong to helm Singapore LNG
summary: Singapore LNG Corporation has appointed Tan Soo Koong as its CEO, effective April 2, 2019, replacing John Ng. Tan Soo Koong previously served as managing director of Vopak Terminals Singapore and led the manufacturing function at GE Plastics SEA. His appointment marks a significant change in leadership for the company.

site_title: Taking charge of their finances
summary: A global survey of nearly 3,700 females by UBS found that women who participate in long-term financial decisions feel more confident about their future. However, the majority of women surveyed defer to their spouses in making long-term financial decisions, with 72% of Singaporean women and 71% of Hong Kong women letting their spouses decide. This trend is attributed to the belief that their spouses know more about long-term finances. Women are urged to take a greater role in determining their long-term financial futures, particularly as they tend to live longer than men.

site_title: Economists see no further MAS tightening in April
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is expected to keep interest rates unchanged in April, with no further tightening, following the US Federal Reserve's pause in interest rate hikes and easing domestic growth and core inflation. Economists attribute this decision to the lower-than-expected February core inflation reading and the easing of domestic consumer sentiments. Most economists expect the MAS to pause at this month's review and shift away from hawkishness, with some predicting a dovish bias in the October statement and potential policy easing in April next year.

site_title: GST at 25: What do businesses need to know and do?
summary: The Goods and Services Tax (GST) system in Singapore turned 25 years old on April 1, 2019. The GST has grown to be the second largest contributor to tax collections, with the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore collecting about S$11 billion in 2018. As global indirect tax trends evolve, businesses in Singapore must understand how changes may shape the GST system and impact their operations. The PwC global tax policy group has identified three key trends: growing importance of indirect taxes, digital trade, and environmental taxes.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Tianjin Zhongxin Pharmaceutical Group Corp reported a 34.3% year-on-year increase in Q4 and full-year 2018 net profits, reaching 158.7 million yuan and 561.7 million yuan respectively. The company proposed a 10% year-on-year increase in dividend, citing growth in sales volume and a solid top-line performance. Despite volatility in the pharmaceutical sector due to China's healthcare cost reform policies, the company's TCM industry is expected to exceed three trillion yuan by 2020, providing tailwinds for the sub-sector. The analyst maintains a "buy" rating with a target price of US$1.70.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% as investors weighed market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions. In the US, stocks edged down from records amid tariff threats, while Europe's stocks declined due to bank and healthcare sector drag. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss for the second half. London's Heathrow considered increasing airport fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Meanwhile, Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case involving 285 trillion rupiah.

site_title: Saying yes to restructuring won't stop any probe into Hyflux: Sias chief
summary: Singapore's Securities Investors Association (Sias) chief David Gerald has clarified that a "yes" vote for Hyflux's restructuring scheme won't stop ongoing investigations into the company's board and management. Current investigations will continue, regardless of the restructuring outcome, and won't absolve investors of responsibility. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and the Singapore Exchange are monitoring Hyflux's developments, and will investigate any potential breaches of law or rules. The government has also stated it will not bail out Hyflux, and will instead acquire the water desalination plant at Tuaspring if restructuring is not supported by investors.

site_title: New guidelines set out what constitutes wrongful dismissal
summary: The Manpower Ministry, National Trades Union Congress, and Singapore National Employers Federation have published new guidelines outlining what constitutes wrongful dismissal in Singapore. The guidelines include examples of discriminatory dismissal, failing to pay benefits, and giving false reasons for dismissal. The Employment Act, which allows employees to file claims against employers for wrongful dismissal, has been amended to cover more managers and executives. Workers can now file claims at the Employment Claims Tribunal, but must first undergo mediation. The guidelines aim to provide clarity and help prevent frivolous claims and workplace disputes.

site_title: Australia home prices down in March; pace of decline slows
summary: Australia's home prices fell 0.6% in March, the smallest monthly decline since October, as credit conditions remained tight. The national index has fallen for 15 of the past 17 months, wiping out two years of gains. Prices in Sydney and Melbourne fell 0.9% and 0.8% respectively, with national values down 7.4% from their peak in 2017. The Reserve Bank of Australia is concerned about the impact on household wealth and spending, while the government faces an election with falling house prices posing a challenge.

site_title: Lessons in sustainability
summary: Trisara, a luxury eco-resort in Phuket, Thailand, is setting a benchmark for sustainability. The resort has implemented various eco-friendly measures, including an anti-plastic policy, upcycled furniture, and grey-water recycling systems. The resort's farm produces locally sourced ingredients for its Michelin-starred restaurant, PRU, which has earned accolades for its farm-to-table concept. Trisara has also become a nesting site for two large green-backed sea turtles, which return to the beach after a decade to lay their eggs. The resort's commitment to sustainability has earned praise from its director and general manager, Anthony Lark, who has been instrumental in the hotel's evolution.

site_title: Probe on former Midas directors, officers to continue despite winding up moves
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) will continue investigating former directors and officers of Midas Holdings, a troubled aluminium supplier, despite plans to wind up the company. The investigation focuses on possible wrongdoings at the company. The MAS stated that winding up moves do not stop the ongoing investigation.

site_title: Draft law against online falsehoods proposes jail of up to 10 years
summary: Singapore has proposed a draft law that could jail individuals spreading online falsehoods with malicious intent for up to 10 years, while internet platforms may face fines of up to $1 million for failing to correct or remove such content. The Protection from Online Falsehoods and Manipulation Bill requires two criteria to be met for action to be taken, including the statement being false and in the public interest. Opinions and criticisms are not caught by the bill, and individuals who innocently forward or share false content will be subject to correction or removal orders.

site_title: Global gold demand seen rising to 4-year high in 2019
summary: Global gold demand is projected to rise to a 4-year high in 2019, reaching 4,370 tonnes, according to Metals Focus. This marks the highest demand since 2015, driven by increased consumption by jewelers, offsetting a decline in purchases by central banks. The increase is attributed to a strong economic outlook and rising consumer demand for gold.

site_title: Malaysia asks for six more months to deliberate on JB-Singapore RTS link
summary: Malaysia is seeking a six-month extension from Singapore to deliberate on the proposed Rapid Transit System (RTS) link between Johor Baru and Singapore. The cost of the project, estimated at RM4 billion (S$1.33 billion), needs to be studied further. The Malaysian Transport Minister, Anthony Loke, cited a need to explore alternative options. The RTS project, initially expected to start operations by December 2024, now faces uncertainty, with Singapore's Acting Transport Minister, Vivian Balakrishnan, stating the project is no longer on track.

site_title: It's all about the timing
summary: The Singaporean private residential property market is cyclical, with prices and sales reflecting the economic cycle. Timing is crucial, as buyers who purchased at the peak in 1996 only breakeven in 2010, while those who bought during a crisis or lull period can benefit from significant appreciation gains. Animal spirits, or emotions, drive buyers to enter the market at the wrong time, making it essential to take a contrarian approach. Investors can mitigate risks by planning their housing consumption, avoiding speculation, and understanding the rental market. A well-thought-out exit strategy is also crucial, considering financial conditions and changes in lifestyle.

site_title: MinLaw mulling over allowing appeal to Courts post arbitration awards
summary: Singapore's Law Ministry is considering allowing parties to appeal to the courts on a question of law arising from an arbitration award, provided parties agree to the mechanism. The Ministry will conduct a public consultation on this and other enhancements to the International Arbitration Act. Currently, parties can only set aside a final award in the High Court on limited grounds, but there is no avenue for appeals on a point of law. This move aims to enhance party autonomy and flexibility while preserving certainty and finality.

site_title: China to build 6-8 reactors a year to meet 2030 development goals
summary: China plans to build 6-8 nuclear reactors per year to meet its 2030 development goals, according to the chairman of the state-owned China National Nuclear Corporation. The sector is recovering after the 2011 Fukushima disaster, but still faces challenges, including communication problems and imbalances in development. China aims to increase non-fossil fuel energy to 20% by 2030 and reduce greenhouse gas emissions to a peak by the end of the next decade. The country is promoting advanced reactor technologies and plans to begin construction of a small-scale modular reactor by the end of this year.

site_title: Two tycoons rolling out banking app for America's Generation Z
summary: German fintech N26, backed by billionaires Peter Thiel and Li Ka-shing, is expanding its international customer base before offering a wide range of banking products. The company, which currently has 2.5 million customers in 24 European countries, plans to launch in the US and Brazil this year. N26 has decided to focus on building size and market power rather than expanding product offerings, valuing at $2.7 billion after a January fundraising. The company's strategy aims to generate revenue without compromising on security and customer support.

site_title: US opens new probe into 3 million Kia, Hyundai vehicles for fire risks
summary: The US National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) has launched a new investigation into 3 million Hyundai and Kia vehicles due to fire risks, not caused by crashes. This probe comes in response to a petition from the Center for Auto Safety. The investigation follows earlier probes into the same vehicles and previous recalls by Hyundai and Kia, which have addressed engine fire risks since 2015.

site_title: KPMG questions KS Energy's ability to continue as a going concern
summary: KPMG's independent auditor has expressed doubts over KS Energy's ability to continue as a going concern due to the company's significant net loss of S$53.9 million in FY2018, and its current liabilities exceeding current assets by S$18.3 million and S$2.5 million respectively. The company also faces uncertainties in generating cash flows to meet debt obligations, including the outcome of ongoing negotiations with prospective customers and the successful implementation of financing plans. KPMG notes that if KS Energy is unable to continue as a going concern, it could impact its classification of assets and liabilities.

site_title: Achieving the goal of total wealth planning
summary: Wealthy individuals in Singapore, driven by their transnational lifestyles and complex financial needs, are seeking personalized, digitally enabled advice on wealth preservation and protection. To succeed, wealth managers must adopt a client-centric approach, leveraging digital tools and data analytics to provide tailored guidance on life goals and risk management. This shift from product-centric to relationship-driven advice will help build trust and loyalty with clients, ultimately driving long-term value and sustainability in wealth management.

site_title: Dirty-money probe into Swedbank sees fight over key documents
summary: A criminal probe into Sweden's Swedbank mortgage bank has escalated, with key documents at the center of the investigation. The bank's CEO, Birgitte Bonnesen, was fired amid allegations of money laundering, with potentially suspicious amounts exceeding $100 billion. Swedbank's board is under scrutiny, with reports suggesting they withheld documents from police. The lender is also being investigated by Swedish and Estonian authorities, as well as US authorities, amid the broader Danske Bank A/S Estonia scandal. The bank's share price has plummeted, and investors are calling for the board's handling of the case to be reviewed.

site_title: Protection is key
summary: The Koh siblings, children of UBS veteran banker Edmund Koh, aim to make healthcare accessible through their digital start-up WhiteCoat, which provides on-demand consultations and medication delivery. The service, founded by Bryan Koh and supported by his sister Natalie, a cardiologist, offers a 11.5-minute consultation and medication delivery within two hours. With seed funding from their father, WhiteCoat has attracted interest from investors and aims to bring accessible, affordable healthcare to people worldwide, mirroring the family's goal of having a doctor in every family.

site_title: Silver lining for jumbo life policies
summary: Singapore's universal life (UL) insurance policies, marketed to high net worth individuals, saw a soft patch in 2018 due to higher interest rates, competition, and economic uncertainty. Despite this, demand is expected to be driven by succession planning concerns, particularly among the next generation taking over from the first generation. Insurers such as Transamerica, Manulife, and AIA continue to see steady growth, with some offering flexible options like variable universal life (VUL) policies that can be funded by clients' own assets. However, UL policies come with substantial costs and risks, including market downturns and surrender charges.

site_title: Taxpayers cannot bail out Hyflux investors: Masagos
summary: Singapore's Minister for the Environment and Water Resources, Masagos Zulkifli, stated that the public cannot bail out Hyflux's retail investors. However, the national water agency PUB may take over the Tuaspring desalination plant to ensure Singapore's water security, despite a potential negative valuation. This move aims to safeguard the country's water supply.

site_title: Employees should come first in Singapore's new digital economy
summary: Singapore has an exceptional digital economy environment, attracting innovation centres and supporting businesses in building digital capabilities and upskilling the workforce. The country's budget includes S$19 billion for R&D and S$4.6 billion to enhance economic capabilities for businesses and workers. This focus on innovation and workforce development aims to help Singaporean businesses thrive amid industry and technological disruptions.

site_title: Investing in automation
summary: Credit Suisse sees automation, driven by AI and robotics, as a long-term investment theme. While industrial and tech giants expand their capabilities, smaller firms and start-ups are also benefiting from increased funding and interest. Key growth areas include healthcare, logistics, and service robots, with the medical imaging field expected to reach $19.3 billion by 2025. Investors can access the robotics and AI market through smaller technology companies, diversified funds, and exchange-traded funds, with the IT sector expected to be a major beneficiary.

site_title: Celebrating the ultimate feat
summary: Omega celebrates its 125th anniversary with the release of the De Ville Tresor 125th Anniversary Edition, a 40mm 18K yellow gold watch featuring a red enamel dial and burgundy leather strap. The watch is paired with the Omega Master Chronometer Calibre 8929, a highly anti-magnetic hand-winding movement. Meanwhile, A Lange & Sohne marks its 25th anniversary of the Lange 1 with a limited edition of 25 pieces, the Grand Lange 1 Moon Phase "25th Anniversary" Edition. Other brands, including Chopard, Vacheron Constantin, and Breguet, also release limited-edition watches to commemorate these milestones.

site_title: When family and business cohere
summary: The Koh family, led by siblings Natalie and Bryan, have successfully launched WhiteCoat, a digital healthcare provider aiming to bring accessible and affordable healthcare to people in Singapore and beyond. With an estimated 50,000 customers and a market value of tens of millions of dollars, the company is on the cusp of a partnership with a large insurer and is eyeing regional expansion. The family's vision is to deliver healthcare anytime, anywhere, with a focus on quality and sustainability. They have assembled a team of experienced doctors and are exploring operating on a 24-hour mode, with plans to expand into countries such as the Philippines, Indonesia, and Thailand.

site_title: The new Cold Warriors
summary: A revived Committee on the Present Danger (CPD), established in 1950 to counter the Soviet Union, has rebranded as the Committee on the Present Danger: China (CPDC) to address the perceived threat of China. The group, comprising 43 former government, military, and intelligence leaders, aims to mobilize the US against China, labeling it an "existential and ideological" threat. The CPDC's approach mirrors the neoconservative agenda of the 1970s, promoting US military intervention and regime change in the Middle East. Critics argue that the CPDC's historical analogies are faulty, exaggerating China's threat and ignoring its lack of ideological ambitions.

site_title: Keppel O&M announces novation of contract from BOTL to Borr Drilling
summary: Keppel Offshore & Marine (Keppel O&M) announced a novation agreement with Borr Drilling and BOT Lease Co, replacing the construction contract of a jackup rig being built by Keppel Fels for BOTL. Borr Drilling will take over the contract, with BOTL having paid Keppel Fels in full except for extension costs. The delivery schedule remains January 2020, despite the change. This move allows Borr Drilling to take on the rig and Keppel O&M to focus on other projects.

site_title: Opec output slides as Saudis deepen cut, Venezuela crisis grows
summary: Opec's crude production slid for a fourth month, falling to 30.385 million barrels a day, as Saudi Arabia cut output to a four-year low of 9.82 million barrels a day in March. Despite US President Trump's calls to reverse production cuts, the cartel remains committed to balancing global markets. Venezuela's economic crisis and sanctions are exacerbating the issue, with output plummeting to 890,000 barrels a day, the lowest since 2003. The extra effort in reducing production was largely driven by Saudi Arabia, which decreased output by 280,000 barrels a day.

site_title: It all boils down to water
summary: Investors are turning to water as a key concern, with asset management firms beefing up their sustainability offerings. A fund investing in water, dubbed "blue gold," has a 10-year track record and offers opportunities in new technologies and services to conserve, treat, and distribute water. Rising global demand, urbanization, and climate change are driving the need for substantial capital investments in water treatment technologies and distribution infrastructure. Key areas of investment include water infrastructure, water treatment and efficiency, and water utilities, with a focus on companies generating 20% of their revenue through water-related products and services.

site_title: Q2 trading gets off to a bright start
summary: Singapore stocks opened strong on the first day of the second quarter, with the Straits Times Index (STI) gaining 37.63 points or 1.17% to close at 3,250.51. Positive Chinese PMI figures and US-China trade talks boosted market sentiment. The Shanghai Composite Index reached a 10-month high, while the Malaysian market declined 0.9%. Trading volumes were subdued, and investors remain cautious amid geopolitical and growth uncertainty.

site_title: Kellogg sells biscuit business to Ferrero for US$1.3b
summary: Kellogg Co has agreed to sell its cookie and fruit snack brands, including Keebler and Famous Amos, to Ferrero SpA for $1.3 billion. The deal is expected to close by the end of July and will simplify Kellogg's corporate structure. Ferrero will acquire six US food manufacturing facilities and a leased facility in Baltimore. The transaction is part of Kellogg's efforts to refocus on its fast-growing business and divest underperforming brands.

site_title: Bitcoin climbs to highest level this year as volatility recedes
summary: Bitcoin reached its highest level of 2019, rising 1.6% to $4,135.60, according to weekday trading data. This milestone marks a significant recovery from a year that saw three-quarters of its market value wiped out. The surge comes after a US stocks selloff, which led to a rally in the S&P 500 Index. Bitcoin is close to breaking above an intraday level set on Christmas Eve, a day that marked the end of the US stocks selloff.

site_title: Authorities investigate possible wrongdoings of ex-Midas directors, officers
summary: Authorities in Singapore are investigating possible wrongdoing by the former directors and officers of Midas Holdings, a troubled aluminium train components supplier. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and the Commercial Affairs Department are conducting separate investigations, while the Singapore Exchange reviews potential listing rule breaches. The investigations will continue despite the company's application to wind up, with the authorities working together with liquidators if necessary. The probe began after a police report was lodged by the company's audit committee in 2018 over alleged irregularities in operations in China.

site_title: Swiss banks should face more Finma inspections, IMF says
summary: Switzerland's financial regulator Finma should increase on-site inspections of the country's largest banks to combat potential conflicts of interest, the International Monetary Fund (IMF) said. The IMF criticized Finma's current practice of allowing banks to contract auditors for regulatory reviews, citing a lack of independence and objectivity. The fund recommended that Finma directly contract and pay audit firms for supervisory audits and conduct more on-site inspections, especially of the largest banks. Finma has acknowledged the report and will analyze its findings.

site_title: Keppel, Sembcorp reinvention - from rigs to urban solutions
summary: Keppel Corp and Sembcorp Industries, two Singapore-based conglomerates, have transformed from offshore and marine engineering to sustainable urban solutions providers over the past five years. Keppel generated $943.8 million in net profit last year, while Sembcorp made $347 million. The companies have diversified into new sectors such as utilities, urban development, and renewable energy, and have developed their value chain proposition. Analysts praise their ability to leverage inter-company collaboration and share critical functions, giving them a competitive edge in securing huge projects. The companies aim to moderate their exposure to business-cycle risks by having each division contribute no more than 40% of the group's annual net profit.

site_title: Julius Baer sale of asset manager stalls over risk of losing staff
summary: Julius Baer's planned sale of its Italian asset manager Kairos Investment Management SpA is stalling due to concerns over its price and retention of top performers. The Swiss wealth manager may need to consider offers closer to 350 million euros to revive talks. Potential investors require retention agreements in place before submitting bids, and a long delay would be a blow to Julius Baer, which has been struggling to retain top talent since its CEO took over. The sale process has been ongoing since the end of last year, with Goldman Sachs advising Julius Baer on the sale.

site_title: Keppel acquires stake in electric vehicle battery businesses for US$50m
summary: Keppel Corporation has signed an agreement to invest US$50 million in Envision AESC Group, a lithium-ion battery company, for a minority stake. Envision AESC, acquired by Nissan and NEC, has a 7.5GWh production capacity and 1,400 employees. The investment is part of Keppel's strategy to expand its energy solutions with cleaner fuel sources and renewables. Keppel and Envision are exploring IoT-enabled storage devices and potential areas of collaboration for smart cities, renewable energy, and power generation.

site_title: No green light for IHH pending Fortis investigations on lapses, say external auditors
summary: IHH Healthcare's external auditors, KPMG, cannot determine if regulatory non-compliances exist due to ongoing Fortis investigations. The company acquired Fortis in November, following an investigation report on systematic lapses and internal control overrides. KPMG suggests "appropriate reassessment" of transactions with related parties, potentially requiring additional adjustments or disclosures. The findings have not granted a green light for IHH's audit report.

site_title: Facebook deletes accounts linked to India's Congress party, Pakistan military
summary: Facebook has deleted 712 accounts and 390 pages in India and Pakistan for "inauthentic behavior", including 549 linked to India's Congress party and 15 linked to an Indian company named Silver Touch, which is associated with the Indian government. The move aims to combat misinformation and political interference ahead of elections. In Pakistan, Facebook removed 57 accounts and 24 pages linked to the Pakistani military. The company's review found individuals using fake accounts and issuing posts criticizing the ruling party. Facebook's actions follow increasing pressure to ensure its platform is not used for political manipulation.

site_title: Catholic priests burn Harry Potter books in Poland
summary: Catholic priests in Poland burned books from JK Rowling's Harry Potter series, citing sacrilegious content, in a public ceremony. The book burning took place at a church in Gdansk, following a 10am mass, and was accompanied by prayers and the burning of other items deemed to have negative energy. The incident has sparked controversy, with some praising the priests' actions and others condemning them as backward. The move comes amid a broader crisis for Poland's Catholic church, which is grappling with revelations of child abuse and declining public support for the faith.

site_title: Tesla boom lifts Norway's electric car sales to 58% market share
summary: Norway's electric car sales reached a global record, accounting for 58.4% of new car sales in March. The surge is attributed to exemptions from taxes on diesel and petrol cars, favoring brands like Tesla and Nissan. This marks a significant increase from 31.2% in 2018, with Tesla's Model 3 contributing to the surge. Norway aims to end fossil-fuel vehicle sales by 2025.

site_title: Unknown footage of John Lennon, Yoko Ono resurfaces after 50 years
summary: A Dutchman has uncovered 30 minutes of previously unknown colour footage of John Lennon and Yoko Ono's 1969 "bed-in" for peace in an Amsterdam hotel, 50 years after the event. The footage, shot by an amateur, shows the couple spending a week under the sheets, promoting a pacifist message. The event, which included a press conference in Vienna, was a major media event at the time, with photographers and videographers capturing each step. The footage is expected to shed new light on this significant moment in music history.

site_title: US retail sales unexpectedly fall in February
summary: US retail sales unexpectedly fell 0.2% in February, contradicting economists' forecasts of a 0.3% increase. This decline marks a shift in economic growth as stimulus from tax cuts and increased government spending fades. Retail sales in February rose 2.2% from the previous year, down from a revised 0.7% increase in January. The decline suggests economic growth is slowing.

site_title: Virginia governor seeks additional US$4 million for housing trust fund
summary: Virginia Governor Ralph Northam is requesting an additional $4 million for the state's housing trust fund, amid rising rents and mortgages outpacing wages across the state. The fund, which received $5.5 million in the state budget this year, aims to address unaffordability concerns. This is part of Northam's 40 budget amendments submitted to the legislature during a brief veto session. The request is aimed at supporting affordable housing initiatives and addressing the growing housing affordability crisis in the state.

images.alt_text: Mr Northam's request marks a significant increase in the affordable housing fund.
Mr Northam's (above) request marks a significant increase in the affordable housing fund.

site_title: Draghi points to persisting risks in justifying massive stimulus
summary: European Central Bank President Mario Draghi stated that the euro-area economy still requires significant monetary policy support to counter external risks affecting growth and inflation. Draghi emphasized the need for substantial monetary stimulus to build domestic price pressures in the medium term. The ECB's annual report, released this year, does not include new policies such as a long-term lending program or measures to mitigate the impact of negative interest rates on banks.

site_title: Taking the leap
summary: Singaporean SMEs are expanding overseas despite regulatory and cultural challenges, with support from government agencies and free trade agreements. Companies like Porcelain the Face Spa, Team Salon, and Nail Palace are navigating these obstacles to grow sustainably. The article highlights the importance of overcoming odds and leveraging technology to stay competitive in a competitive industry. SMEs are also exploring opportunities in Asean and China, driven by growth within Singapore and support from Enterprise Singapore.

site_title: Peter Thiel and Li Ka-shing Have a Banking App for America's Generation Z
summary: Billionaires Peter Thiel and Li Ka-shing are backing a German banking app, N26, as it expands outside Europe, targeting Generation Z with free current accounts. N26 has shifted focus from product expansion to international customer base growth, citing low costs as a key to profitability. The company, which already has 2.5 million customers in 24 European countries, plans to enter the US market, where it hopes to win business from major banks like JPMorgan Chase & Co and Bank of America Corp.

site_title: Indofood Agri sinks into red with Q1 loss of 57.79b rupiah
summary: Indofood Agri Resources posted a Q1 net loss of 57.79 billion rupiah, reversing from a profit in the year-ago period, due to poorer operations and higher financial expenses. Revenue rose 5.3% to 3.36 trillion rupiah, driven by strong sales from edible oils and fats. The group's plantation division revenue was flat, affected by lower commodity prices and higher financial expenses. Shares closed flat at 28 Singapore cents.

site_title: Jet Airways misses paying US$109m loan, sources say
summary: Jet Airways India Ltd missed a $109 million loan repayment to HSBC Bank due on March 28, adding to a string of missed deadlines. The airline has also not repaid any of the loan, following previous missed payments on tranches totaling $140 million and $31 million. The company's credit rating was cut to default in January, and its collapse could put 23,000 jobs at risk. Lenders have committed to infusing $217 million in emergency debt funding, conditional on the resignation of Jet Chairman Naresh Goyal, who stepped down under pressure.

site_title: US airlines hit by system-wide outages
summary: US airlines experienced system-wide computer outages on April 1, 2019, related to issues with the Aerodata planning weight and balance programme. American Airlines reported the outage affected regional carriers nationwide, while Alaska Air Group Inc also experienced a system-wide outage. United Airlines reported problems with creating paperwork, and Southwest Airlines initially reported issues before stating the problem had been resolved. The Federal Aviation Administration confirmed the outages, but no further details were provided.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher on trade progress, China data
summary: US stocks opened higher on Monday, driven by a surprise recovery in China factory activity and progress in US-China trade talks. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.56%, the S&P 500 gained 0.50%, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 0.92%. These gains extended the upbeat mood from last quarter, despite ongoing trade tensions between the US and China.

site_title: Vietnam-based startup Jio Health raises US$5m in Series A funding round
summary: Vietnam-based healthtech startup Jio Health secured US$5 million in Series A funding from Singapore venture firm Monk's Hill Ventures. Founded in 2014, Jio operates a technology-driven healthcare ecosystem providing telemedicine, digital medical records, and home doctor visits. The funding will support expansion plans, including increasing its care provider team and clinical operations across Vietnam, aiming to deliver quality, affordable healthcare services to the region.

site_title: Xi fails to calm Europe as Juncker takes another swipe at China
summary: European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker intensified criticism of China's trade practices, stating that Chinese companies have free access to European markets but Europeans don't have the same access in China. Juncker also expressed concerns that Chinese investments could hinder EU foreign policy decisions, citing potential human rights issues. The EU has become increasingly vocal in its criticism of China, viewing it as an economic competitor and a "systemic rival" on governance. Juncker's comments come after Chinese President Xi Jinping's efforts to calm European concerns in Paris.

site_title: SIA Engineering Company signs S$1.4b services agreement with SIA
summary: SIA Engineering Company (SIAEC) signed a S$1.4 billion services agreement with Singapore Airlines, superseding the 2015 agreement. The two-year deal includes maintenance, repair, and overhaul services, with an option to renew for two more years. The agreement is expected to yield S$1.3 billion to S$1.4 billion in labour revenue over four years. SIAEC CEO Goh Choon Phong is also a director of Singapore Airlines and serves on its board.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 14.97 points to 1,628.66. A total of 2.6 billion lots worth RM2 billion were traded, with 445 gainers and 411 losers.

site_title: Singapore shares gain 1.2% on upbeat China data, progress in trade talks
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 1.17% to 3,250.51, driven by upbeat Chinese data and positive US-China trade talks sentiment. The index gained 37.63 points, with 898.08 million securities traded. The rally follows a 5-day streak ahead of GDP data, with advancers outnumbering decliners 278 to 146.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rally at open
summary: European stock markets rallied at the start of trading on April 1, 2019, with London's FTSE 100 index up 0.6% to 7,319.74 points, and the eurozone's DAX 30 and CAC 40 indices gaining 0.8% each. The gains followed strong performances in Asia.

site_title: Green Build back in black with 12.2m yuan profit for FY18
summary: Green Build reversed FY17's loss of 7.2 million yuan to report a 12.2 million yuan profit for FY18, with earnings per share increasing from a loss of 2.98 fen to 4.95 fen. Revenue dropped 70.1% to 96.5 million yuan due to the completion of a major project. The company's cash and bank balances decreased by 298 million yuan, but an increase in cash from operating activities and investing helped offset this. Green Build is optimistic about its green technology business and plans to manage and operate the completed underground utility tunnel project for 25 years.

site_title: SGX rejects Renaissance United's application for new share subscription
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has rejected Renaissance United's application for a new share subscription by two Malaysian private investors, which would have raised S$1.1 million for general working capital purposes. The new shares represent 16.6% of the enlarged share capital. Despite the rejection, Renaissance United remains committed to completing the subscription and is exploring all available options.

site_title: Ex-Barclays euribor traders jailed for as long as five years
summary: Two former Barclays Plc traders, Carlo Palombo and Colin Bermingham, were sentenced to up to five years in prison for manipulating the Euro interbank offered rate, a benchmark interest rate affecting trillions of dollars in loans and derivatives. Judge Michael Gledhill warned that those in the finance industry should expect jail time for wrongdoing. The convictions were a boost for the UK Serious Fraud Office, which has secured numerous convictions of prominent bankers.

site_title: Singapore, European regulators agree on mutual recognition of derivatives trading venues
summary: Singapore and European regulators agree on mutual recognition of derivatives trading venues, allowing EU investment banks to comply with EU trading obligations when dealing with Singapore counterparties. The decision strengthens cross-border trading, enabling businesses to access deeper pools of liquidity and hedge risks more efficiently. Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has adopted regulations to exempt EU multilateral and organised trading facilities from MAS' markets licencing requirements. The agreement aims to boost liquidity and facilitate trade between the EU and Singapore.

site_title: Japan's Emperor Naruhito pledges to work as symbol of the people
summary: Japan's Emperor Naruhito formally took office on Wednesday, succeeding his father Emperor Akihito after a three-decade reign. In a ceremony, Emperor Naruhito, 59, pledged to work as a symbol of the nation and the unity of its people, expressing a "sense of solemnity." His wife, Empress Masako, attended the ceremony, which was the first part of the formal ascension process. Emperor Akihito thanked the people of Japan and prayed for peace as he stepped down.

images.alt_text: Japanese Emperor Naruhito formally took up his post on Wednesday a day after the abdication of his father, saying he felt a "sense of solemnity" but pledging to work as a symbol of the nation and the unity of its people.

site_title: With government split, British MPs seek new Brexit plan
summary: British MPs will attempt a second round of votes on various Brexit options on Monday, amid a government split over Prime Minister Theresa May's deal. The EU warned its patience is wearing thin, with European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker saying "even patience is running out." The UK risks crashing out of the EU without a deal by April 12, with MPs considering alternatives such as a customs union or public vote. The outcome of the votes is not legally binding, but could force May's hand and potentially lead to a general election.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's government ruled that taxpayers cannot bail out Hyflux investors, citing a lack of public funds to support their losses. The private home price index dropped 0.6% in Q1 2019, a larger decline than the previous quarter. Most PMET layoffs in 2018 were due to restructuring, with 5,400 local employees let go. New tripartite guidelines set out examples of wrongful dismissal, including discrimination and punishing employees for exercising rights. The STI gained 1.2% on upbeat China data and progress in trade talks.

site_title: Taking on the world
summary: Singaporean small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are expanding globally despite trade war uncertainty and growing protectionism. Government agency Enterprise Singapore provides support through free trade agreements (FTAs) and direct assistance. To succeed, SMEs must adapt products and services, innovate, and build partnerships. Experts emphasize the importance of understanding local contexts, investing in capabilities and expertise, and finding the right talent. Companies like Lim Kee Food Manufacturing, igloohome, and Scanteak have implemented phased approaches, invested in automation and technology, and leveraged innovation to expand their global presence. The upcoming European Union-Singapore FTA is expected to further boost market access for Singaporean SMEs.

site_title: Work trends change, but a strong labour movement still crucial
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the importance of a strong labour movement in his May Day Message. Over the past 50 years, tripartism has delivered better incomes for workers and steady progress for the country. Lee urged unions to remain constructive and cooperative with employers and the government to continue on this path and strengthen trust among tripartite partners. This, he believes, will help Singapore thrive and prosper despite global economic uncertainties.

site_title: Olam secures world's first digital loan of US$350m
summary: Olam International has secured a US$350 million digital-linked revolving credit facility, the world's first "digital loan", to support its digital transformation efforts. The three-year facility is linked to Olam's digital maturity score, determined by the Boston Consulting Group, and offers annual improvement targets that could reduce the interest rate if met. Proceeds will be used to refinance existing loans, with Olam's group COO stating the financing can drive the agriculture sector's digital transformation and align with the company's purpose of reimagining global agriculture and food systems.

site_title: Netflix project to spotlight Thai cave rescue
summary: Netflix has acquired the rights to the story of the 2018 Thai cave rescue, where 12 boys and their soccer coach were trapped for over two weeks. The project will be directed by Jon M Chu and Nattawut Poonpiriya, and its format has not been decided. This marks a significant step in telling the harrowing story of the rescue, which gained international attention for its miraculous outcome. The film's production is the latest in a flurry of projects aimed at sharing the tale of the cave rescue.

site_title: UK car output to collapse on no-deal Brexit: industry
summary: The UK's car industry faces a significant threat of collapse under a no-deal Brexit, with output potentially falling to levels last seen in the 1980s. The Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders (SMMT) forecasts a 30% decline in car production to 1.07 million units by 2021, due to tariffs and increased costs. Jaguar Land Rover has already announced it will assemble the new Land Rover Defender model in Slovakia, while other manufacturers such as Honda and Nissan are also curtailing investment and production.

site_title: Sterling rises as May faces pressure to go for soft Brexit
summary: The British pound rose 0.3% to US$1.3076 on Monday as investors await a parliamentary vote on Brexit options, with some hoping for a softer Brexit than Prime Minister Theresa May's defeated withdrawal agreement. The pound has held above US$1.30 since its plunge last week, suggesting investors expect a long delay to the UK's exit or a Brexit with closer ties to the EU. Parliament will vote on different Brexit options, and May may try to bring her deal back to a vote as soon as Tuesday.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares end 1.43% higher on cheaper yen
summary: Tokyo stocks closed 1.43% higher on Monday, driven by gains on Wall Street and a weak yen. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 303.22 points to 21,509.03, while the Topix index added 1.52% or 24.17 points at 1,615.81. The Bank of Japan's quarterly "tankan" survey showed weakening business confidence, but investors were buoyed by upbeat comments from Washington and improving Chinese economic indicators.

site_title: Property data
summary: Royal Healthcare, a specialist centre, is set to open in Tokyo or Osaka, following Sojitz's takeover. Meanwhile, researchers from NUS aim to halve the price of sustainable marine fuel. Tenants at Hao Mart's Taste Orchard express concerns over poor footfall and vacant units. OCBC targets $5 billion in loans to serial entrepreneurs by 2028. Shatec shuts its Orchard campus, cutting 42 staff and putting the building up for sale. Businesses are rebranding heritage and modernizing traditional snacks to appeal to younger generations, while the Chinatown Business Association seeks compensation over the use of outdoor space.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks jump over 1% on trade talks progress, China data
summary: South Korea's Kospi stock index rose over 1% on April 1, 2019, driven by progress in Sino-US trade talks and positive Chinese factory gauges. The won and benchmark bond yield also increased. Factory activity in China unexpectedly grew in March, suggesting government stimulus measures are taking hold. US President Donald Trump said trade talks with China were going well, but he would not accept less than a "great deal." Foreigners were net buyers of shares worth 250.2 billion won.

site_title: HSBC built financial fortress around HK; it now faces its biggest threat in years
summary: HSBC, the UK-based bank, has built a significant financial presence in Hong Kong over 150 years, dominating the city's banking market with 60% pre-tax income in 2018. However, the bank now faces its biggest threat in years from upstart virtual lenders backed by Standard Chartered and Chinese insurer ZhongAn, which have secured approvals to operate in the market. These lenders are targeting 30% of Hong Kong's banking revenue, worth $15 billion, with potential gains of $3 billion from HSBC and $1.7 billion from Hang Seng Bank.

site_title: Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust's Q4 DPU up 2.7%
summary: Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust (MNACT) posted a 2.7% rise in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.956 Singapore cents for the fourth quarter ended March 31, 2019. Revenue and net property income (NPI) grew 16.2% and 15.3%, respectively, driven by contributions from new Japan properties and higher rental income. For the full year, DPU increased 2.8% and gross revenue rose 15.1%. MNACT's manager expects the Japan properties to provide a stable income stream due to long average lease expiry periods and high occupancy rates.

site_title: Shanghai Turbo shareholders reject financial statements
summary: Shanghai Turbo Enterprises shareholders rejected the company's annual audited financial statements at an annual general meeting, with 52.6% voting against adopting the statements. The shareholders also rejected the re-election of four directors and instead elected four new independent directors, including former CEO Liu Ming's nominees. This marks the latest in a long-standing dispute between Shanghai Turbo and Liu Ming, who has been accused of staging a violent stand-off at a factory and breaching his service agreement.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares start week on a high
summary: Hong Kong stocks started the week on a high note, with the Hang Seng Index rising 1.76% to 29,562.02, driven by optimism over China-US trade talks and better-than-expected Chinese factory data. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also surged, with gains of 2.58% and 3.57%, respectively. The market gains were seen as a relief for investors amid ongoing trade tensions and US-EU tariff concerns.

site_title: Kids' promotion boosts sales at Australia's Coles
summary: Coles Group Ltd, Australia's second-largest grocer, reported a 2.2% increase in quarterly sales growth despite a housing downturn, driven by a promotion offering collectable miniatures of supermarket products to children. The promotion, which was half as effective as last year, lifted comparable sales growth from 1.5% to 2.2%. Coles CEO Steven Cain attributed the success to marketing ideas, such as collectables, being more effective than traditional discounting promotions. However, analysts questioned the promotion's long-term sustainability.

site_title: Australian shares rise on China PMI surprise, mining gains; NZ up
summary: Australian shares rose 0.59% to a three-week high, driven by positive Chinese factory surveys and firm iron ore prices. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 6,217.0, with miners like BHP Group and Rio Tinto Ltd gaining 1.6% and 1.8% respectively. The rebound was also supported by Wall Street's positive performance on Friday and Beijing's decision to suspend additional US tariffs.

site_title: China Everbright Water secures waste water treatment project in Ji'nan City
summary: China Everbright Water secured a 560 million yuan (S$113.3 million) investment in Ji'nan City, China's Shandong Province, for a 30-year waste water treatment project. The project, to be built and operated on a build-operate-transfer basis, will treat 100,000 cubic meters of waste water daily. The company's shares closed 10.2% lower at S$0.44 before the announcement.

site_title: Regulators must prepare for systemic risk from startup ecosystem
summary: Regulators must prepare for systemic risk from the growing startup ecosystem in Singapore. In 2018, startups raised US$10.5 billion from 353 venture capital deals, surpassing the S$0.7 billion raised from 15 IPOs. This shift is attributed to low interest rates, technological breakthroughs, and government support for entrepreneurship. The proliferation of startups poses a risk to the broader economy, highlighting the need for regulators to adapt and mitigate potential systemic risks.

site_title: Helping rural S-E Asia to jump on digital bandwagon
summary: A growing number of Southeast Asian tech startups are working to address the region's digital divide, particularly in rural areas. These initiatives aim to provide low-cost and long-range transmissions, connecting farmers and IoT devices to improve operations and increase yields. The Alipay-NUS Enterprise Social Innovation Challenge has been launched to support the growth of startups in the region, with a focus on addressing real-world problems. The challenge will provide training and resources to selected startups, with the goal of harnessing the power of digital technology to benefit all in Southeast Asia.

site_title: SGInnovate adds 5 partners to panel of co-investors for deep tech startups
summary: SGInnovate, a government-owned deep-tech development firm, has added five new co-investors to its panel for deep tech startups under the Startup SG Equity scheme. The new partners include ST Engineering Ventures, Elev8.VC, Golden Gate Ventures, GREE Ventures, and Verge Capital Management. Together, they will co-invest in early-stage startups in areas such as AI and medtech, with a total potential investment of up to S$80 million by 2022. This brings the total number of co-investors to 22, with collective investments exceeding S$52 million.

site_title: Tesla promises return to profit after first-half losses
summary: Tesla Inc reported a net loss of $702.1 million in the first quarter, despite cutting costs and improving delivery. The company predicted a return to profit in the third quarter, citing improved production and deliveries of its Model 3 electric sedan. Despite a sales contraction, Tesla maintained its 2019 delivery forecast of 360,000-400,000 vehicles. The company ended the quarter with $2.2 billion in cash after paying off a convertible bond obligation.

site_title: Father, two brothers of Sri Lanka suicide bombings mastermind killed
summary: The father and two brothers of suspected Sri Lanka Easter Sunday bombings mastermind Zahran Hashim were killed in a security operation on the east coast. Mohamed Hashim, Zainee Hashim, and Rilwan Hashim were among 15 killed in a gun battle with the military. The group was seen in a video calling for all-out war against non-believers, sparking fears of further attacks. Authorities have detained over 100 people, including foreigners, and are investigating international links to the attacks, which killed over 250 people.
